node.title: 1101 AI-pollo
node.excerpt: We are a multicultural team including people from Brazil, Turkey and India. We focus on AI and software development knowledge.

projectDetails.name: Project 1101 AI-pollo
projectDetails.summary:
ExoDetect AI is an exoplanet discovery pipeline that turns NASA’s Kepler photometry into actionable candidate rankings.

We reimagined the classification stack around an FT-Transformer trained with self-supervised objectives on millions of stellar light-curve summaries, learning feature embeddings before any labeled supervision. This representation pretraining captures subtle photometric correlations—color indices, extinction, metallicity—that classical tabular models often miss, enabling the transformer to flag rare but promising planetary signatures with higher recall.

When the self-supervised backbone is fine-tuned on curated confirmation labels and deployed alongside our legacy tree-based ensemble, it consistently surfaces additional high-confidence candidates while maintaining a low false-positive rate.

By packaging the model inside an accessible web API and UI, we equip mission scientists and citizen researchers to score new stars instantly, prioritize follow-up observations, and accelerate the validation cycle for small, low-signal planets that traditional pipelines overlook.
projectDetails.details:
ExoDetect AI ingests features about star systems, applies a shared preprocessing pipeline, and then routes each record through a self-supervised FT-Transformer alongside four gradient-boosted baselines.

The transformer’s pretraining on unlabeled light-curve summaries yields richer embeddings, so its supervised head can spot faint transit signatures while keeping false alarms low; tree models provide interpretable cross-checks.

Deployed as a Flask REST API with a static JS frontend, the system delivers single, JSONL, and CSV scoring plus live model metrics, enabling mission teams to triage thousands of targets in seconds. Our stack relies on Python (Flask, pandas, PyTorch, scikit-learn), Torch for the transformer, Docker for reproducible deployment, and a lightweight HTML/CSS/JS interface.

We leaned into creativity by adapting vision-style pretraining to tabular astrophysics data, aligning feature engineering with astrophysical priors, and bundling the results in a scientist-friendly UI.

Key considerations included class imbalance, calibration across heterogeneous models, inference latency within CPU-only containers, and preserving interpretability so astronomers can relate predictions back to stellar physics.

challengeDetails.title: A World Away: Hunting for Exoplanets with AI
challengeDetails.excerpt: Data from several different space-based exoplanet surveying missions have enabled discovery of thousands of new planets outside our solar system, but most of these exoplanets were identified manually. With advances in artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML), it is possible to automatically analyze large sets of data collected by these missions to identify exoplanets. Your challenge is to create an AI/ML model that is trained on one or more of the open-source exoplanet datasets offered by NASA and that can analyze new data to accurately identify exoplanets. (Astrophysics Division)

challengeDetails.title: Sharks from Space
challengeDetails.excerpt: Earth’s ocean is one of the most powerful habitats in our universe, supporting a range of life that sustains ecosystems and habitability across the globe. It is common to measure photosynthetic activity in the ocean from space, but far more challenging to track top predators. Your challenge is to create a mathematical framework for identifying sharks and predicting their foraging habitats using NASA satellite data, and also to suggest a new conceptual model of a tag (a small electronic device that can be attached to an animal to track and study its movement) that could measure not only where sharks are, but also what they are eating, and in real time transmit that data back to users to enable development of predictive models. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: BloomWatch: An Earth Observation Application for Global Flowering Phenology
challengeDetails.excerpt: Witness the pulse of life across our planet! From season to season and year to year, Earth’s vegetation is constantly changing, providing critical information on plant species, crops, seasonal effects, pollen sources, and changes in plant phenology (the relationship between seasonal changes and climate and biological phenomena in plants). Your challenge is to harness the power of NASA Earth observations to create a dynamic visual tool that displays and/or detects plant blooming events around the globe—just like pollinators do–and that advances solutions for monitoring, predicting, or managing vegetation. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Cosmic Windows
projectDetails.summary: The project aims to create an accessible and user-friendly website for everyone interested in viewing space images captured and stored by NASA, with the goal of reducing complexity and making access more practical and less burdensome for the general public. The challenge essentially proposes new ways, uses, and applications for NASA’s images, from zooming in to discovering new patterns. Building on this idea, we created a simple website for the general public to view and explore the images provided by NASA’s API. Through a straightforward search, the site navigates the vast dataset, allowing users to continue their own space investigations. The main and most important point is that the website democratizes and simplifies access to complex space data and images that are otherwise difficult for the general public to obtain.
projectDetails.details:
It provides clear and accessible information, enabling searches across NASA’s vast database, and remains highly performant.
By lowering technical barriers, it democratizes access to knowledge for people who have the time, interest, or expertise — and especially for those who do not.

The intended impact of the project is to expand the dissemination of scientific knowledge and spark curiosity among the general public. By making NASA’s data and images easy to find, understand, and explore, the platform transforms passive observers into active participants in discovery.

We built the project using Python, CSS, HTML, Flask, Jupyter notebooks, Redis, PostGIS, DNS, a GoDaddy-registered domain, Hander, Figma, and Canva.
Our creative process followed three pillars: Ideation, Development, and Presentation, ensuring a strong link between user needs, technical execution, and storytelling.

The core factors guiding our approach were education and the democratization of knowledge — aligning with NASA’s mission to inspire and engage people everywhere.
By connecting cutting-edge data infrastructure with an intuitive user experience, the project reflects the spirit of citizen science and inclusion that has defined many of the most impactful Space Apps winners from Brazil in recent years.
projectDetails.aiReferences: We used Artificial Intelligence (AI) for idea generation, code optimization, data structuring, and text correction.

challengeDetails.title: Embiggen Your Eyes!
challengeDetails.excerpt: While your cell phone screen can display about three million pixels of information and your eye can receive more than ten million pixels, NASA images from space are even bigger! NASA’s space missions continue to push the boundaries of what is technologically possible, providing high-resolution images and videos of Earth, other planets, and space with billions or even trillions of pixels. Your challenge is to create a platform that allows users to zoom in and out on these massive image datasets, label known features, and discover new patterns. (Astrophysics Division)

projectDetails.name: Project AgroNautas
projectDetails.summary:
FarmGuardians: The Hope Mission is an interactive and educational game where the player takes on the role of Demétrio, a young agronomist who returns to the Hope Farm in 2047 after years of study. The farm, once prosperous, now suffers from the effects of climate change, such as droughts, storms, and wildfires. To save the farm and ensure his family's future, Demétrio must use science to restore balance.

With the help of Gaia, a NASA scientist and member of the FarmGuardians, a task force dedicated to tackling environmental issues, Demétrio learns to apply real satellite data from NASA to confront villains like Lord Drought, who represents water scarcity, and Lady Fire, who embodies wildfires. The game uses advanced technologies such as vegetation monitoring, soil moisture, climate forecasts, and wildfire alerts to combat these threats.

Throughout the journey, the player makes strategic decisions, unlocks new tools, and learns to apply scientific data to improve the health of the land and crops. FarmGuardians: The Hope Mission offers an educational experience, demonstrating how science can be a powerful tool to face environmental challenges and ensure a sustainable future for agriculture and the planet.
projectDetails.details:
FarmGuardians: The Mission of Hope is an interactive and educational game developed to address the environmental challenges faced by agriculture due to climate change. The project combines cutting-edge technologies in both front-end and back-end development to create an engaging and functional user experience while providing real-world environmental data.

Functionality and Impact:

The game places the player in the shoes of Demétrio, a young agronomist who returns to his family farm to battle the impacts of climate change, such as droughts, storms, and wildfires. Using real satellite data from NASA, players make strategic decisions to restore the farm’s balance. By interacting with advanced technologies like soil moisture monitoring, climate forecasting, and wildfire alerts, players learn how to apply real-world data to combat environmental issues. The game's educational approach highlights the importance of science in solving global challenges, ensuring a sustainable future for agriculture and the planet.

Tools and Technologies Used:

-Front-End:

Ionic: A framework for creating cross-platform applications with native-like experiences, ensuring compatibility across devices.

-Angular: Used to build dynamic applications with reusable components for a responsive UI.

-JavaScript & TypeScript: JavaScript powers dynamic features, while TypeScript ensures scalability and error prevention.

-Capacitor: Bridges web and native platforms, allowing for native device functionality.

-Back-End:

- Python: Chosen for its simplicity and efficiency in handling server-side logic.

- Flask: A lightweight framework used to build the REST API, enabling communication between the server and the game’s data.

- API (REST): Facilitates smooth interaction between the server and client, allowing for seamless game data updates.

Creativity and Team Considerations:

FarmGuardians offers a creative approach to education, blending environmental science with interactive gaming. The game not only entertains but also educates players on how technology, such as NASA satellite data, can be used to mitigate real-world environmental issues. The development team, including Jonatas Rezende Artagnan, considered the need for both a dynamic, responsive UI and a robust backend that could handle data-intensive operations in real-time, ensuring a smooth user experience.

Benefits and Intended Impact:

FarmGuardians aims to raise awareness about climate change and sustainability in agriculture. It empowers players with knowledge about climate science and provides tools to address environmental threats. The intended impact is to foster a generation of informed individuals capable of using technology to address global agricultural and environmental challenges.

For more information and access to the project’s code, visit the [GitHub repository](https://github.com/MarceloAugusto/nasa_space_apps).
projectDetails.aiReferences:
AI was used in the project primarily to generate illustrative images of the game's characters. It was also used to organize the data NASA provides and how it can be applied.

It was also used to develop part of the prototype software and to more clearly present our ideas on the slides, in addition to translating the content.

challengeDetails.title: NASA Farm Navigators: Using NASA Data Exploration in Agriculture

Simulating key farming activities like fertilizing, irrigating, and livestock management using real-world NASA satellite imagery and climate data can enable better understanding of the impacts of these variables on crop production. Your challenge is to create an engaging educational game that effectively utilizes NASA’s open data sets to simulate farming scenarios and enables players to learn how this data can inform innovative, sustainable, agricultural methods. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: From EarthData to Action: Cloud Computing with Earth Observation Data for Predicting Cleaner, Safer Skies
challengeDetails.excerpt: NASA’s Tropospheric Emissions: Monitoring of Pollution (TEMPO) mission is revolutionizing air quality monitoring across North America by enabling better forecasts and reducing pollutant exposure. Your challenge is to develop a web-based app that forecasts air quality by integrating real-time TEMPO data with ground-based air quality measurements and weather data, notifying users of poor air quality, and helping to improve public health decisions. Teams are encouraged to utilize new technologies that allow seamless scaling of computing from local devices to cloud systems, enhancing collaboration and streamlining work efficiency. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Guardions Of Jalapão
projectDetails.summary:
We are the Alpha Mackenzie team, Brazilian middle school students, and we developed the project "Guardians of Jalapão," which addresses the favorable Brazilian climate conditions for harvesting Golden Grass. Inspired by the proposed challenge and the Golden Grass Women's Project, which uses sustainable agricultural practices for the production and harvesting of golden grass, our goal was to develop an educational game to raise awareness about the importance of such initiatives that use natural resources through sustainable management based on ideal climate conditions.

Therefore, the relevance of this project lies in simulating a resource collection scenario (temperature, precipitation, and soil moisture) and providing players with information about the correct and ideal management of golden grass harvesting. This game is intended to be made available to students as a way to raise awareness about sustainability and proper golden grass management. Additionally, it could be displayed in museums and at the headquarters of the Golden Grass Women's Project to highlight the ideal conditions and the consequences of resource collection according to the seasons.
projectDetails.details:
We are the Alpha Mackenzie team, and our project, "Guardians of Jalapão," is aligned with Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 15, which focuses on life on land. That’s why we chose to work with Golden Grass — a resource widely used in the Jalapão region for the production of handicrafts that generate income for local communities — by understanding the most favorable climate conditions for its growth and harvest.

We developed a game using the tools available on Scratch, with the main purpose of raising awareness about the harvesting of Golden Grass in the Jalapão region, based on the climate characteristics we researched and how they affect the collection of this resource. The game’s primary goal is to promote awareness about the extraction of Golden Grass and how it grows throughout the seasons of the year. It serves as a tool to present the data and information collected, helping the public understand and become more conscious of this issue.

Golden Grass (Syngonanthus nitens) is a plant native to the Brazilian Cerrado, especially found in Jalapão (Tocantins state). It is used to make handicrafts that symbolize the local culture, such as bags and jewelry. Its sustainable harvesting is regulated by the Tocantins Nature Institute (Naturatins) to ensure the conservation of the species. The grass is harvested annually after the seeds mature.

We collected data using Google Earth Engine and selected the Jalapão region, where Golden Grass is most abundantly produced. Additionally, we uploaded a script with commands to retrieve climate characteristics such as temperature, precipitation, and soil moisture from last year (2024). Our main focus was on precipitation and temperature.

Based on this information, we identified the climate characteristics and associated them with their impact on the production and harvesting of Golden Grass, allowing us to understand the reactions caused by these factors. The game uses this data to show the player what happens depending on the amount of resources collected during gameplay.

"Guardians of Jalapão" runs, as mentioned earlier, on Scratch — a free, open-source visual programming language developed at MIT to teach coding in a fun and accessible way. The user will access a link that redirects them to the game on Scratch. In the game, the player controls a character and collects clouds (precipitation), a thermometer (temperature), and a soil bar (soil moisture). Depending on the number of items the user collects, the outcome will change according to the climate conditions of Jalapão for each season.

The ideal time for the player to achieve the best result is during spring, as it is the favorable season for harvesting Golden Grass in the region — a dry and arid period. If the user collects values that differ from the ideal, the game will inform them of the current season and its impact on the Golden Grass.

With this project, we aim to show how closely climate characteristics are linked to the development and harvesting of Golden Grass — a vital resource for income generation in the Jalapão region. Furthermore, one of our goals is to bring the game to museums in the Cerrado region, especially those that focus on this biome, or to communities that work with this resource, particularly the "Golden Grass Women's Project." There, tourists could learn about the differences in Brazil’s seasons and how they affect the harvesting of this plant. In this way, the game could be commercialized and made available for use in these locations (museums and community centers).

Therefore, the target audience for the game includes the communities that work with Golden Grass, organizations or institutions that deal with this resource or the Cerrado biome, and tourists visiting the aforementioned locations.

For the development of our project, we used the following technologies:

Scratch: A visual programming platform and block-based coding language that allows users to create games, animations, and interactive stories by dragging and dropping visual commands instead of writing complex code — used for creating the game developed by the team.

Google Earth Engine (a tool recommended by NASA): A geospatial data science platform that provides a massive catalog of satellite imagery and geographic data, along with cloud computing infrastructure for planetary-scale analysis — used for collecting, comparing, and analyzing climate data.

node.title: AM
node.excerpt: Our team consists of two people: Augusto Soares Porto and Matheus Fernandes Melo.

projectDetails.name: Project AM
projectDetails.summary:
Forecasting is an interactive web platform developed for the “Will It Rain on My Parade?” challenge of the NASA Space Apps 2025. It allows users to select any location on an interactive map and choose a specific date to instantly access detailed climate statistics for that day.

Beyond a single-day forecast, Forecasting offers a broader view by enabling users to visualize weather data trends from 15 days before and 15 days after the selected date through interactive charts. This helps users better understand weather patterns, identify anomalies, and make more informed decisions when planning outdoor activities or events.
projectDetails.details:
Regarding data collection, we used the NASA POWER API to obtain meteorological data and selected the parameters we considered most relevant. From this, we are able to retrieve measurements taken in the past for a single day, as well as the historical data from 15 days before and after, displayed in the form of graphs. Additionally, the web application can perform a rough forecast using the average calculated from previous years.

For the implementation of the containerized environment, we used Docker; for the backend logic, we used Python; and for the frontend, we used HTML, CSS, React, and Vite.
projectDetails.aiReferences: We used AI tools to assist in coding, primarily GitHub Copilot, which helped us write and improve our code efficiently. Especially in formatting, explanation and translation of comments

challengeDetails.title: Will It Rain On My Parade?
challengeDetails.excerpt: If you’re planning an outdoor event—like a vacation, a hike on a trail, or fishing on a lake—it would be good to know the chances of adverse weather for the time and location you are considering. There are many types of Earth observation data that can provide information on weather conditions for a particular location and day of the year. Your challenge is to construct an app with a personalized interface that enables users to conduct a customized query to tell them the likelihood of “very hot,” “very cold,” “very windy,” “very wet,” or “very uncomfortable” conditions for the location and time they specify. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Project Farm Navigators
projectDetails.summary:
For the challenge NASA Farm Navigators: Using NASA Data Exploration in Agriculture, we developed "Farm Navigators", an educational strategy card game designed to make complex Earth science data accessible and engaging. Players take the role of agricultural decision-makers, balancing four pillars — Economy, Sustainability, Technology, and People — while making choices about irrigation, fertilization, and livestock management. Each decision carries trade-offs, teaching that agriculture involves dilemmas rather than perfect solutions.

Our game integrates real NASA datasets: NDVI/EVI (MODIS & Landsat) to monitor vegetation health, SMAP for soil moisture, GPM for precipitation, and MODIS LST for land surface temperature. These datasets inform the scenarios presented in the cards, grounding decisions in real-world science.

To enrich the narrative, we created Little Eliot, an AI Agent acting as a Narrative Consequence Analyst. Eliot provides short, subtly ironic reflections on each decision and, at the end of the game, the player’s results are added to a shared database. This allows participants to compare outcomes, fostering collective learning and a sense of responsibility for the world.

Demo: https://angelus-novus.vercel.app/
projectDetails.details:
Project Details – Farm Navigators

Play it, here: https://angelus-novus.vercel.app/

What it does / how it works
Farm Navigators is an educational strategy card game that simulates real farming decisions using NASA’s open datasets. Players must balance four pillars — Economy, Sustainability, Technology, and People — while managing irrigation, fertilization, and livestock. Each choice triggers trade-offs, showing that agriculture is a world of dilemmas rather than perfect solutions.

Benefits & Intended Impact
The game makes complex NASA Earth data accessible and engaging, helping players of all ages understand how environmental variables affect food production, sustainability, and social well-being. By linking real satellite data to everyday farming scenarios, it promotes climate awareness, sustainable practices, and data-driven thinking. The collective database of player results encourages reflection on global responsibility, as participants can compare whether their choices “helped or harmed the world.”

AI Integration – Little Eliot
We created Little Eliot, an AI Agent acting as a Narrative Consequence Analyst. After each decision, Eliot generates short, subtly ironic commentaries suggesting possible futures. At the end, progress is recorded in a shared database, fostering a sense of community and collective learning.

Tools, Languages, and Frameworks
We combined modern tools to develop the project:

  • Lovable, Langflow, Cursor – for AI workflows and prototyping.
  • React & TypeScript – for the front-end interface.
  • FastAPI & MongoDB – for backend logic and database storage.
  • ChatGPT-5 nano – powering Eliot’s generative AI responses.

Creativity & Design Considerations
We designed Farm Navigators to merge serious data with playful storytelling, blending strategy, education, and irony. Our key considerations were scientific accuracy, player engagement, and scalability, ensuring the game can grow into classrooms, communities, and global platforms.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

Our project makes purposeful use of AI in both its game design and technical development:

  1. Narrative Gameplay – Little Eliot
    • We created Little Eliot, an AI Agent acting as a Narrative Consequence Analyst.
    • Eliot uses a fine-tuned prompt with ChatGPT-5 nano to generate short, subtly ironic narrative commentaries after each player decision.
    • These outputs enrich the storytelling by suggesting possible consequences without referencing scores or game mechanics.
    • We used AI-assisted tools (such as Langflow, Cursor, and Lovable) to accelerate prototyping, workflow orchestration, and prompt optimization.
    • Draft texts, gameplay scenarios, and narrative examples were initially generated with AI, then refined by our team.
    • All AI-generated texts were reviewed and edited to align with the project’s educational goals.
    • Portions of boilerplate code and database handling were generated using AI tools to speed up development.
    • Metadata and documentation acknowledge AI contributions.

Compliance Measures

  • No NASA logos, mission identifiers, or official branding were generated or modified by AI.
  • Any AI-generated visuals or audio (if used in later stages) will carry visible AI-generated watermarks and proper metadata acknowledgments.

Through this integration, AI was not used to replace originality but to accelerate creativity, enhance gameplay, and prototype faster while keeping the final vision and design firmly in the hands of our team.

projectDetails.name: Urbanistic
projectDetails.summary: Desenvolvi um simulador que auxilia planejadores urbanos a visualizar e planejar a expansão das cidades de forma mais harmoniosa com o meio ambiente. A ferramenta utiliza dados de satélite da NASA, como imagens de cobertura do solo e temperaturas de superfície, para analisar a relação entre a urbanização e seu entorno. Ele aborda o desafio de maneira prática, apresentando condições empíricas e válidas para a elaboração de arquiteturas nas regiões, comparando as antigas condições com as novas.
projectDetails.details:
O coração do simulador é a integração de diversas camadas de dados geoespaciais, muitas delas oriundas da NASA e de outras fontes de observação da Terra. Imagine um mapa digital dinâmico da cidade. Sobre este mapa, podemos sobrepor informações cruciais:

  • Diagnóstico Ambiental: Identificamos ilhas de calor urbanas através de dados de temperatura de superfície, mapeamos a localização de recursos naturais cruciais (como mananciais e áreas verdes) e avaliamos a infraestrutura existente de saneamento e energia.
  • Monitoramento em Tempo Real: Incorporamos dados de tráfego em tempo real e das estações de monitoramento da qualidade do ar, que se traduzem em um heatmap de poluição visual e intuitivo.
  • Projeção de Cenários: A ferramenta não é apenas um espelho da realidade atual. Ela permite ao usuário testar diferentes estratégias de expansão: "E se ampliarmos a zona residencial para esta área?", "E se reservarmos este corredor para um parque linear?". O sistema então projeta os impactos dessas decisões, mostrando, por exemplo, como uma nova via pode afetar o heatmap de poluição ou como a preservação de uma área verde pode mitigar uma ilha de calor.

    A criatividade do projeto não está em criar uma tecnologia completamente nova, mas em como conectamos dados existentes de forma inovadora e orientada para a solução de um problema real. Saímos do campo da pura análise acadêmica para oferecer uma ferramenta de tomada de decisão prática.

Nossa equipe considerou uma gama de fatores interconectados para garantir que a ferramenta fosse útil:

  • Fatores Ambientais: Preservação de ecossistemas, qualidade do ar e da água, e resiliência às mudanças climáticas.
  • Fatores Sociais: Bem-estar da população, acesso a áreas de lazer, saúde pública (impactada pela poluição) e equidade no acesso à infraestrutura.
  • Fatores Econômicos e de Infraestrutura: Viabilidade de expansão de redes de água, esgoto e energia, e a eficiência do transporte.
    O principal benefício é empoderar o planejador urbano com uma visão holística e baseada em evidências. Em vez de decisões tomadas com base em informações fragmentadas, ele passa a ter um painel de controle integrado da cidade.

O impacto que almejamos é profundo e duradouro:

  1. Cidades Mais Saudáveis: Ao priorizar estratégias que reduzem a poluição e as ilhas de calor, estamos contribuindo diretamente para a saúde respiratória e cardiovascular dos cidadãos.
  2. Preservação Ambiental Proativa: O crescimento urbano deixa de ser uma força destrutiva e passa a ser guiado para evitar áreas sensíveis, conservando a biodiversidade e os recursos hídricos.
  3. Resiliência Climática: Cidades planejadas com esta ferramenta estarão melhor preparadas para enfrentar eventos climáticos extremos, como enchentes e ondas de calor.
  4. Legado para o Futuro: O maior impacto é a transformação do paradigma do desenvolvimento urbano. Queremos que as cidades do futuro não sejam fruto do acaso ou da pressão imobiliária desordenada, mas sim o resultado de um planejamento inteligente que valoriza tanto o bem-estar humano quanto a integridade do planeta.

Em essência, este simulador é mais do que um software; é uma ponte entre a ciência de dados e a prática do urbanismo, visando construir um futuro onde as cidades e a natureza possam, de fato, coexistir e se fortalecer mutuamente.

O projeto foi desenvolvido utilizando as linguagens JavaScript, HTML5 e CSS3, responsáveis pela lógica da simulação, pela estruturação das páginas e pela estilização da interface, respectivamente. Além disso, foi empregado Python 3, tanto para executar o servidor local por meio do comando http.server, quanto para a execução de scripts adicionais através do arquivo app.py.

Como ferramentas de apoio ao desenvolvimento, foi utilizado o editor de código Visual Studio Code (VS Code), aliado ao sistema de versionamento Git com repositório hospedado no GitHub. Para testes de exposição do servidor local em ambientes externos, foram utilizadas ferramentas como Ngrok e Localtunnel.

Em relação ao hardware, o projeto foi desenvolvido em um computador pessoal com processador x64 e memória RAM de 16GB, além de navegador moderno compatível com HTML5, como o Google Chrome, Edge ou Firefox.

Quanto ao software, foi necessário um sistema operacional atualizado, a instalação do Python 3.x e de um navegador web. Opcionalmente, o Node.js pode ser empregado em etapas futuras, caso sejam adicionadas dependências externas em JavaScript.

projectDetails.name: Aura Air
projectDetails.summary:
Aura Air App is a full-stack air quality monitoring platform developed to address the NASA TEMPO challenge by transforming satellite data into actionable public health insights.

Our solution integrates NASA EARTHDATA, OpenAQ, and meteorological data to provide real-time Air Quality Index (AQI) monitoring and 15-day forecasts powered by XGBoost machine learning models.

The platform features:

Personalized health alerts that adapt to individual medical conditions (asthma, respiratory sensitivities)

A Google Gemini AI-powered chatbot for natural language queries

An interactive dashboard with pollutant breakdowns and weather correlations

Built with Next.js/React frontend and FastAPI/Python backend, the system processes complex environmental data and delivers it through an intuitive, mobile-responsive interface.

Aura Air empowers citizens, especially vulnerable populations, to make informed decisions about outdoor activities and health precautions. By democratizing access to NASA satellite data and combining it with predictive AI, we bridge the gap between space technology and everyday health protection, contributing to cleaner air awareness and proactive pollution response in urban communities.
projectDetails.details:
Aura Air App is a comprehensive full-stack air quality monitoring and forecasting platform designed to protect public health through data-driven intelligence. The system integrates NASA satellite data, ground-based pollution measurements, and advanced machine learning to provide real-time air quality monitoring, 15-day AQI forecasts, and personalized health alerts.

How It Works:

Our platform combines multiple data sources — NASA TEMPO/EARTHDATA, OpenAQ, OpenWeather, and IBGE geographic data — into a unified system. The backend processes environmental data through FastAPI endpoints, while machine learning models (XGBoost) analyze patterns to generate accurate 15-day Air Quality Index (AQI) forecasts. Users can track air quality in any Brazilian city with precise geolocation and receive personalized alerts based on their health profiles (asthma, respiratory conditions, sensitivities).

Key Features:

·        Real-Time Monitoring: Live AQI data with pollutant breakdowns (PM2.5, PM10, O3, NO2, SO2, CO)

·        Predictive AI: XGBoost models forecast air quality trends for the next 15 days

·        Smart Chatbot: Google Gemini AI-powered assistant provides context-aware recommendations

·        Health Personalization: Customized alerts based on user medical conditions and sensitivity levels

·        Interactive Dashboard: Real-time charts, weather conditions, and satellite visualization

·        Mobile Responsive: Optimized interface for desktop and mobile devices

Technology Stack:

·        Frontend: Next.js 15, React 19, TypeScript, Tailwind CSS, Shadcn UI, Recharts

·        Backend: Python 3.12, FastAPI, SQLAlchemy, MySQL, Uvicorn

·        Machine Learning: XGBoost, Pandas, NumPy, Scikit-learn

·        AI Integration: Google Gemini API for intelligent chatbot responses

·        Deployment: Docker, Railway (backend), Netlify (frontend)

Impact:

Our platform democratizes access to environmental data, empowering citizens to make informed decisions about outdoor activities, health precautions, and daily routines. By providing personalized alerts, we help vulnerable populations (children, elderly, people with respiratory conditions) avoid dangerous exposure to air pollution. The 15-day forecast enables proactive planning for public health agencies, schools, and event organizers.

Creativity & Innovation:

We prioritized accessibility and personalization — transforming complex satellite data into intuitive, actionable insights. Our health profile system adapts AQI calculations based on individual vulnerabilities, making air quality information truly personal. The integration of conversational AI (Gemini chatbot) makes environmental data accessible to non-technical users, answering questions in natural language.The modular architecture ensures scalability and interoperability — our API can integrate with smart city platforms, IoT sensors, emergency alert systems, and public health databases. We designed for real-world impact, combining open science principles with modern web technologies to create a tool that can genuinely improve quality of life in polluted urban areas.

Team Considerations:

We focused on data accuracy, user experience, and social responsibility. Our team ensured precise geolocation for Brazilian cities using IBGE data, implemented secure authentication (JWT), and created fallback mechanisms for API reliability. Every design decision prioritized clarity, speed, and actionable information delivery — because when air quality matters, seconds count.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Artificial Intelligence tools were used to accelerate development, documentation, and product innovation throughout the Aura Air App project. Specifically:

AI Development Assistants:

ChatGPT, Claude Sonnet, Manu, and GitHub Copilot were used for code optimization, debugging assistance, and documentation generation. These tools helped refine API endpoints, structure FastAPI routes, optimize React components, and improve TypeScript typing.

Integrated AI Features:

Google Gemini AI (gemini-2.5-flash) is directly integrated into our chatbot system to provide intelligent, context-aware responses about air quality data. The chatbot analyzes user queries and provides personalized health recommendations based on AQI levels and user health profiles.

Machine Learning:

XGBoost machine learning models were developed with assistance from AI tools for data preprocessing, feature engineering, and model optimization to predict 15-day AQI forecasts.

Design and Content:

AI tools assisted in generating initial UI component structures, documentation templates, and API response formatting.

Compliance:

All AI-generated code and content were human-reviewed, tested, and refined by our team. No NASA branding, logos, or mission identifiers were created or modified using AI tools. The final implementation, architecture decisions, and creative direction were entirely driven by our development team.

Conclusion:

AI enabled our team to focus on innovative solutions for air quality monitoring while maintaining full technical and creative control over the product.

node.title: Associação Mineira da Diversidade
node.excerpt: A Plataforma de Justiça Ambiental Comunitária é um app e web que integra monitoramento, denúncia e educação para enfrentar o racismo ambiental. Comunidades tornam-se “Sentinelas Ambientais”, registrando impactos em tempo real e gerando provas conf...

projectDetails.name: Transform(ação) de Territórios
projectDetails.summary:
A Transform(ação) de Territórios é um aplicativo que se alinha diretamente ao desafio da NASA, "Caminhos de Dados para Cidades Saudáveis e Assentamentos Humanos". Combatemos o Racismo Ambiental ao expor a concentração desproporcional de riscos ambientais (poluição, falta de saneamento) e a negação de serviços essenciais em comunidades negras e de baixa renda. Transformamos essas comunidades em agentes ativos de defesa territorial. 
O pilar de Monitoramento e Denúncia é crucial para o objetivo da NASA. Usuários, como "Sentinelas Ambientais", criam um "Mapa de Conflitos" em tempo real via geolocalização e mídias verificadas. Geramos dados de nível de rua que fornecem o contexto social e humano vital que está ausente nas observações globais por satélite. Ao cruzar estas informações, fornecemos o elo perdido entre o monitoramento da ciência da Terra e a realidade da saúde urbana. 
Com Educação continuada sobre direitos, capacitamos a autodefesa. As denúncias geram evidências jurídicas inegáveis para a Pressão Institucional, roteadas para as autoridades competentes. 
O slogan "Onde a poluição tem endereço, a justiça tem voz", resume a missão de transformar a luta social em Justiça Ambiental efetiva, entregando os caminhos de dados necessários para construir cidades verdadeiramente saudáveis e equitativas.
projectDetails.details:
O aplicativo de Combate ao Racismo Ambiental, embora focado em comunidades específicas, geram impactos significativos que alcançam o planeta e até mesmo a NASA (agência espacial dos EUA, conhecida por seu trabalho em ciência da Terra e monitoramento global). Impacto e importância para o Planeta (Meio Ambiente Global).

O aplicativo contribui diretamente para a saúde do planeta ao combater as fontes de degradação ambiental que geralmente são invisíveis nas estatísticas oficiais, como geração de dados de baixo nível para o clima: a poluição registrada pelas comunidades (lixões, esgotos não tratados, vazamentos químicos) é uma fonte significativa de gases para o efeito estufa (como o metano) e contaminantes. Ao mapear essas fontes com precisão, o aplicativo fornece dados essenciais para mitigação do clima, ajuda a identificar e remover focos de contaminação que contribuem para as mudanças climáticas. Justiça Climática sendo a luta contra o racismo ambiental é, fundamental, uma luta por justiça climática, garantindo que a adaptação e a mitigação sejam priorizadas nas comunidades mais vulneráveis.

Monitoramento da biodiversidade e da água, abrindo denúncias sobre o desmatamento, invasão de terras e contaminação de rios por comunidades ribeirinhas ou indígenas alimentam banco de dados sobre a saúde dos ecossistemas. A poluição registrada localmente tem um efeito cascata em bacias hidrográficas e ecossistemas inteiros. ODS e Agenda Global também são parte, já que os dados do aplicativo apoiam diretamente vários dos Objetivos de Desenvolvimento Sustentável (ODS) da ONU, especialmente o ODS 10 (Redução das Desigualdades), ODS 11 (Cidades e Comunidades Sustentáveis) e ODS 16 (Paz, Justiça e Instituições Eficazes). Impacto e Importância para a NASA (Ciência da Terra).

A NASA é uma líder mundial em Ciência da Terra, utilizando satélites para monitorar a saúde do planeta. O aplicativo é crucial no conceito de "Validação de Campo" e "Ciência Cidadã"; Validação de Dados de Satélite, a NASA usa satélites (como os da constelação Sentinel, ou os de medição de gases atmosféricos) para identificar grandes áreas de desmatamento, incêndios ou focos de metano. O aplicativo atua como uma "Lente de Aumento Comunitária", as denúncias georeferênciadas dos moradores verificam e confirmam o que os satélites registram. Por exemplo, um sensor de satélite pode detectar um foco de poluição no ar, mas a denúncia da comunidade (Com foto e testemunho), diz se é um lixão ilegal, uma indústria que opera sem licença ou uma queimada intencional.

Preenchendo a lacuna intangível: a importância mais crítica para a NASA é que o aplicativo fornece dados sobre o que é intangível para a tecnologia espacial. Enquanto os satélites medem a poluição, eles não conseguem medir a falta de recursos, a negação de serviços ou o acesso limitado que tornam as comunidades vulneráveis. O aplicativo documenta a injustiça social - a falta de acesso à saúde, segurança e saneamento - provando a correlação entre a degradação ambiental e a omissão do Estado.

Geração de dados de baixa altitude: Satélites são excelentes para medições amplas (alta altitude), mas tem dificuldades de medir poluentes e riscos em nível de rua ou dentro de microclimas urbanos. Os dados do aplicativo integrados com sensores comunitários de baixo custo (a funcionalidade de IoT), fornecem dados de alta resolução (onde o problema está exatamente) que são vitais para modelos mais precisos de dispersão de poluentes atmosféricos e da água.

Combate ao efeito "Nuvem" e Visibilidade do Risco: Muitas comunidades afetadas por poluição tóxica vivem sob o "efeito nuvem" - a poluição física no ar que bloqueia a visão dos satélites (nuvem de fumaça de incêndios, névoa de indústrias). O aplicativo ao documentar o problema por baixo, complementa o monitoramento da NASA, preenchendo as lacunas e garantindo que o sofrimento humano e a degradação ambiental no chão não fiquem escondidos.

Este projeto é construído com um stack moderno e robusto para desenvolvimento web.

Firebase; ChatGPT; Gemini e Figma

Framework Principal: Next.js (utilizando o App Router e React Server Components).

Linguagem: TypeScript.

Estilização: Tailwind CSS para estilização utilitária e responsiva.

Componentes de UI: ShadCN UI para um conjunto de componentes acessíveis e reutilizáveis.

Mapas:

Leaflet: Biblioteca de código aberto para mapas interativos.

React-Leaflet: Integração do Leaflet com o React.

Gráficos: Recharts para a criação de gráficos composable com React.

Ícones: Lucide React para ícones leves e consistentes.

Inteligência Artificial Generativa: Genkit (integrado, mas ainda não implementado nas funcionalidades visíveis).

Backend e Hospedagem: Firebase (configurado para App Hosting).

- Padrão (OpenStreetMap):* Um mapa de ruas detalhado.

- Satélite (Esri): Imagens de satélite de alta resolução.

- Satélite (NASA): Imagens "Blue Marble" da NASA, disponíveis através do serviço [NASA GIBS](https://earthdata.nasa.gov/gibs).

Em suma, o aplicativo faz a ponte entre a justiça social, a ciência espacial de ponta e a realidade vivida no chão, transformando a voz da comunidade em dados verificáveis e de importância global, complementando as informações da NASA ao dar contexto social e humano aos seus registros ambientais. Um plano criativo e inovador em suas vertentes e tema, considerando que o assunto (racismo ambiental) tem apenas 2 anos de validação científica, visando o desenvolvimento atual e futuro socioambiental, comunitário e global.
projectDetails.aiReferences: IAs foram utilizadas em todo o processo, desde a coleta de dados sobre o que é o Racismo Ambiental, enquanto suporte para as pesquisas. Também foram utilizadas para o Desenvolvimento de Protótipo e Codificação, Arquitetura de Dados e Plataforma, Design de Interface do Usuário e conteúdo do app (imagens), Estratégia e Comunicação.

node.title: Asteroid Watchers
node.excerpt: We are the Asteroid Watchers, united by a shared passion for space, science, and the protection of our planet. Brought together by the NASA Space Apps challenge, we thrive on creativity, collaboration, and curiosity. Together we transform data and...

projectDetails.name: Project Asteroid Watchers
projectDetails.summary:
Our project is an interactive educational platform designed to translate complex asteroid science into an understandable visual experience. Using data from NASA APIs like the JPL Small-Body Database and NeoWs, we ensure each simulation is based on real celestial objects and their observed trajectories.

From primary data such as diameter and velocity, our platform applies principles of impact physics and orbital mechanics to calculate derived parameters, including mass, kinetic energy, and seismic energy release. Users can select a real asteroid and an impact location to visualize the consequences, including the fireball radius, shockwave propagation, devastating wind speeds, and the resulting earthquake's magnitude.

Beyond simulating the problem, our project also focuses on the solution. It serves as an educational tool to showcase the mitigation and deflection strategies that modern science offers, demystifying the dangers, creating solutions and empowering people with a clear understanding of the challenges and solutions in planetary defense.
projectDetails.details:
What does it do and how does it work?

Asteroid Watchers is an educational web-based simulation platform that models near-Earth asteroid impacts and provides comprehensive analysis of potentially hazardous objects. The system works through several integrated components:

Data Collection & Processing: The platform utilizes NASA's NEO Web Service API to fetch real-time data about near-Earth objects for any selected date. The Python backend processes this data to calculate additional physical properties including mass estimation, orbital energy, and impact velocities using gravitational physics calculations.

Interactive 3D Visualization: Users can explore asteroids through a 3D preview system that allows rotation and zoom functionality to inspect object characteristics visually.

Impact Simulation Engine: The core functionality enables users to simulate asteroid impacts at any location on Earth by:

  • Selecting specific dates to view available near-Earth objects
  • Choosing from a list of asteroids with their approach distances
  • Placing impact coordinates on an interactive map
  • Running physics-based simulations that calculate crater size, casualty estimates, seismic effects, fireball radius, and shock wave impacts

Customization Tools: A creator module allows users to design custom asteroids with variable parameters (size, speed, composition) for experimental "what-if" scenarios.

Benefits and Intended Impact

Educational Value: The project transforms complex astronomical and physics concepts into accessible, interactive learning experiences. Students and educators can visualize the real consequences of asteroid impacts, making abstract scientific concepts tangible.

Public Awareness: By providing accurate data visualization of potentially hazardous asteroids, the platform increases public understanding of planetary defense challenges and the importance of asteroid monitoring programs.

Scientific Literacy: The simulator bridges the gap between raw NASA data and public comprehension, helping users understand orbital mechanics, impact physics, and risk assessment methodologies.

Research Support: The platform can assist researchers and educators in demonstrating impact scenarios and testing theoretical deflection strategies through the integrated deflection recommendation system.

Tools, Technologies, and Development Stack

Programming Languages:

  • Python for backend data processing and API integration
  • JavaScript for frontend interactivity
  • HTML/CSS for user interface design

APIs and Data Sources:

  • NASA NEO Web Service API for real-time asteroid data
  • WorldPop for displaying the real-time map to select the impact location
  • Gravitational physics calculations using standard astronomical constants

Libraries and Frameworks:

  • Python: requests for API calls and json for data parsing
  • Also we used Flask as a backend framework
  • Frontend: Modern web technologies for 3D rendering and interactive mapping
  • Also we used Nuxt and Vue as the frameworks

Deployment Platform: Vercel for web hosting and deployment. Railway for backend deployment

Physics Engine: Custom-built impact simulation using:

  • Gravitational constant calculations
  • Orbital mechanics formulas
  • Energy and momentum conservation principles
  • Seismic impact modeling

Creative and Innovative Aspects

Real-Time Data Integration: Unlike static educational tools, Asteroid Watchers provides live data from NASA's monitoring systems, ensuring users work with current astronomical information.

Multi-Layered Simulation: The platform combines orbital mechanics, atmospheric physics, and impact geology into a unified simulation experience, so it can provide user the most amount of data possible.

Deflection Strategy Integration: The system includes an innovative deflection recommendation algorithm that suggests appropriate planetary defense strategies based on asteroid proximity and characteristics.

User-Centric Design: The step-by-step guided interface makes complex astrophysics accessible to users without specialized knowledge while maintaining scientific accuracy.

Customization Capabilities: The creator module allows users to experiment beyond real asteroid data, fostering creative exploration of hypothetical scenarios.

Team Considerations and Factors

Scientific Accuracy vs. Accessibility: The team balanced computational precision with user-friendly presentation, using simplified physics models that remain educationally valuable while being computationally efficient.

Data Reliability: Careful consideration was given to handling incomplete or missing NASA data through reasonable estimation algorithms that maintain simulation functionality.

Educational Framework: The interface was designed with pedagogical principles, providing contextual help, unit clarifications, and step-by-step guidance to support learning objectives.

Performance Optimization: The team considered API rate limits and server performance, implementing efficient data caching and processing to ensure stable user experience.

Risk Communication: Ethical considerations were addressed in how impact simulation results are presented, ensuring users understand these are educational models, not predictive tools for actual events.

The project represents a comprehensive approach to space science education, combining real astronomical data with interactive simulation technology to create an engaging platform for understanding planetary defense challenges and asteroid impact physics.

Other cases include code review to troubleshoot problems we couldn't solve in time

challengeDetails.title: Meteor Madness
challengeDetails.excerpt: A newly identified near-Earth asteroid, "Impactor-2025," poses a potential threat to Earth, but do we have the tools to enable the public and decision makers to understand and mitigate its risks? NASA datasets include information about known asteroids and the United States Geological Survey provides critical information that could enable modeling the effects of asteroid impacts, but this data needs to be integrated to enable effective visualization and decision making. Your challenge is to develop an interactive visualization and simulation tool that uses real data to help users model asteroid impact scenarios, predict consequences, and evaluate potential mitigation strategies. (Planetary Science Division)

node.title: AstroBit
node.excerpt: We are Computer Science students passionate about tackling real-world challenges. This project was our first experience building a complete Artificial Intelligence system from scratch, from data processing to deploying a functional application. We...

projectDetails.name: AstroBit AI
projectDetails.summary:
AstroBit AI is an interactive web platform dedicated to exoplanet exploration. We developed a tool that integrates data from the NASA Exoplanet Archive (Kepler, K2, and TESS missions) and presents it in an accessible way, using dynamic visualizations, interactive charts, and an Artificial Intelligence-based analysis built with Python and Scikit-learn.

The project addresses the challenge of making complex astronomical data understandable. Through a responsive front-end and analysis dashboards, we enable anyone, even those without an academic background, to explore and identify patterns in exoplanet discovery, such as the distribution of planetary radii and orbital types.

AstroBit is important because it lowers the barrier between science and the public. By offering an intuitive and easily accessible tool, the platform encourages scientific engagement and astronomy education, inviting the community to actively participate in the search for new worlds and to expand our collective knowledge of the universe.
projectDetails.details:
Project Demo: https://astrobit-nasaspaceapps.onrender.com

What the project does and how it works?

AstroBit AI is an interactive web platform that uses Artificial Intelligence to analyze and classify exoplanet candidates. Its functionality is simple and direct:

  1. Data Input: Users can submit photometric transit data in two ways: by uploading a CSV file with multiple candidates or by manually entering the parameters for a single object.
  2. AI Processing: The data is sent to a Flask back-end server where a Machine Learning model (Random Forest Classifier)—trained on thousands of examples from the NASA Exoplanet Archive—analyzes the patterns.
  3. Classification and Visualization: The platform returns an instant classification, identifying the object as a Confirmed Planet, Candidate, or False Positive, and presents the results on a visual analysis page rich with charts and statistics.

What are the benefits and intended impact?

The main benefit is to democratize exoplanet science by making data analysis accessible to a wider audience.

  • For Scientists: It accelerates the initial screening of large datasets, allowing them to quickly focus on the most promising candidates.
  • For Amateur Astronomers and Students: It offers a powerful and educational tool to analyze public or personal data, promoting engagement in citizen science.

The intended impact is to inspire space exploration and provide a practical tool that bridges data science and astronomy, making the discovery process more transparent and engaging.

How is the project creative and what factors were considered?

AstroBit AI's creativity lies in its focus on Explainable AI (XAI) and user experience. Instead of being a "black box," the platform was designed to be a tool for exploration. Factors considered include:

  • Intuitive Interface: A clean and modern design that transforms complex numerical data into clear and understandable visualizations.
  • Model Transparency: The inclusion of charts like "Feature Importance" allows users to understand which variables were most decisive for the classification, building trust in the results and providing immense educational value.
  • Flexibility: The dual data input option (CSV and manual) makes the tool versatile for different use cases.

What tools and technologies were used?

  • Back-End & AI:
    • Language: Python
    • Web Framework: Flask
    • Machine Learning: Scikit-learn (for the Random Forest model), Pandas, NumPy (for data manipulation), Joblib (for saving the model).
    • Languages: HTML, CSS, JavaScript
    • CSS Framework: Tailwind CSS
    • JavaScript Libraries: Chart.js (for charts), Swiper.js (for carousels).
    • NASA Exoplanet Archive (for model training).
    • Google's Gemini AI was used as a programming assistant to accelerate front-end component development.

For testing

You can use this dataset to run tests: https://drive.google.com/file/d/123gfiwmnaZvDGhBhSIUHIkkRBYsH_PNN/view?usp=sharing
projectDetails.aiReferences: AI-Assisted Development To accelerate the front-end development process and refine the user experience, Google's Gemini AI was utilized as a coding assistant. It played a key role in generating boilerplate HTML structures, creating responsive Tailwind CSS components, and debugging complex JavaScript functions, significantly streamlining the workflow from concept to deployment.

projectDetails.name: Ziggy's Space Adventures
projectDetails.summary:
Astroismorphya team developed a short animation explaining what is Space Weather and how it affects Earth. We tried to mention all the options offered by the official website. In our animation, our intention was to keep it the most cartoon way possible, so that our project can be accessible for all ages! 
Ziggy, our protagonist, is a girl who loves space, although she ahas a problem to stay awake in classes. She ended up falling asleep in a important class about Space Weather. In spite of her bad behavior, her love for Space makes Ziggy dreams about the content that was being explained by the teacher, but with the whole visualization of the Sun and Earth! She understands and learns about Space Weather and, when the teacher asks her to explain about it, since she was the student who was ''paying the most attention in the room'', which she wasn't at all, she was able to explain everything she learned regarding it!
projectDetails.details:
What does it do or how does it work? What benefits does it have?

The project is an animation that explain to all the people, it doesn't matter their ages, about Space Weather in a simple way of understanding. The benefits that our short film has it is to explain, in an easier way, about a concept that affects Earth everyday and our whole community.

What is the intended impact of the project?

-Educational.

-Accessible.

-Cross-disciplinary.

The intended impact of this animation is to show that learning about Space in general doesn't need to be hard or full of informations and everything, there're also a lot of differents ways with images and many colors to learn!

What tools, coding languages, hardware, or software did you use to develop your project? 

For this project, we used two types of programs, Procreate for the animation and artistic part and CapCut for the editing part.

Research Sources: Nasa's website.

What factors did your team consider?

Since Space Weather is a concept that affects all of us, we decided to try to explain everything about it in a fun way that allows everyone to understand how the phenomenon works. We first thought about what we wanted to represent and demonstrate, then we created Ziggy, a character who doesn't seen that smart, but she actually is, with an easy and memorable design. Furthermore, we thought about school, a place where we can learn about everything, and started to imagine that she could fall asleep and dream about the subject that was being explained! Reading her notes in class, you can (maybe?) read some of Ziggy's scribbles and see a little art of her on a rocket! (Yes, on it and not inside of it!!). We all agreed that this idea was pretty cool, so we decided to do this one :)
projectDetails.aiReferences:
We only used AI for the audios.

Apps used:

-ElevenLabs: Bill's voice for the Narrator and also Ziggy's, and Lily's voice for the teacher.

-InShot: used to edit Bill's voice to a more alien type of voice for Ziggy's second design.

challengeDetails.title: Stellar Stories: Space Weather Through the Eyes of Earthlings
challengeDetails.excerpt: Although the Sun is 93 million miles away from our planet, solar activity can significantly impact our daily lives. “Space weather”—the variations that occur in the space environment between the Sun and Earth—can impact technologies in space and on Earth. Your challenge is to write and illustrate a digital children’s story that explains what space weather is and the varying impacts it has on different people such as farmers, pilots, astronauts, power grid operators, and the general public. You can tell the story from the perspective of a person impacted by space weather or from the point of view of a solar flare or coronal mass ejection (CME) as it approaches Earth. (Heliophysics Division)

projectDetails.name: EarthShield25 — Simulated Asteroid Mitigation
projectDetails.summary:
EarthShield25 is an interactive web platform designed to address the “Meteor Madness” challenge by simulating the potential impacts of Near-Earth Objects (NEOs) using real NASA data. The project integrates the NASA NeoWs API to retrieve updated asteroid information and combines it with geospatial layers and scientific models to calculate impact energy, crater size, seismic magnitude, and affected zones such as thermal and pressure radii.

Through an intuitive interface built with Leaflet.js and Chart.js, users can select an asteroid or input custom parameters to visualize the consequences of an impact on specific geographic regions. The tool also introduces educational features, helping the public, students, and decision-makers better understand asteroid threats and mitigation strategies.

By transforming complex astrophysical and geophysical data into accessible visualizations, EarthShield25 highlights the importance of planetary defense while promoting scientific literacy. This project demonstrates how open NASA datasets can empower communities to prepare for future scenarios and foster global collaboration in space science and disaster resilience.
projectDetails.details:
EarthShield25 is an interactive web platform designed to simulate and visualize the potential consequences of asteroid impacts on Earth. Using real data from NASA’s Near-Earth Object Web Service (NeoWs), the tool provides accurate information about asteroid trajectories, sizes, and velocities. Users can select an asteroid or input custom parameters and instantly see the simulated effects on a map, including crater formation, seismic activity, thermal radiation, shockwave radius, and potential tsunami risk.

The primary benefit of EarthShield25 is its ability to make complex scientific models accessible to a wide audience, from researchers and decision-makers to students and the general public. By transforming raw space data into interactive simulations, the project helps raise awareness of planetary defense challenges and supports education in space science and disaster preparedness.

The project was developed using JavaScript, HTML5, CSS3, Leaflet.js, and Netlify for deployment. Data visualization and physics models are integrated into the simulation engine, with a Node.js backend to handle API communication and environment variables securely.

Creativity comes from combining authentic NASA data with an engaging, gamified interface where users can not only explore impact scenarios but also test mitigation strategies (such as asteroid deflection). The project emphasizes accessibility with bilingual support (English and Portuguese) and clear explanations of technical terms to reach both experts and non-experts.

Our team considered usability, scientific reliability, and educational value as the main factors. The result is a platform that bridges the gap between scientific knowledge and public understanding, promoting global awareness and preparedness for asteroid threats.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
We used AI tools in the following ways for the EarthShield25 project:

  • Images and Icons: The main logo, favicon, and some asteroid/impact icons were generated with the assistance of AI image generation tools (ChatGPT/DALL·E). All AI-generated images include an indication in the README file and project documentation.
  • Code Assistance: AI (ChatGPT) was used to support code refactoring, debugging, and optimization of JavaScript functions for API integration and infinite scrolling. All final implementations were reviewed, tested, and validated by the development team.
  • Documentation: AI was also used to assist in drafting and translating descriptive text, including the English README and submission materials, which were later reviewed and finalized by the team.

AI was applied as a support tool to accelerate development and enhance clarity, while all creative, design, and technical decisions were made by the team.

challengeDetails.title: Meteor Madness
challengeDetails.excerpt: A newly identified near-Earth asteroid, "Impactor-2025," poses a potential threat to Earth, but do we have the tools to enable the public and decision makers to understand and mitigate its risks? NASA datasets include information about known asteroids and the United States Geological Survey provides critical information that could enable modeling the effects of asteroid impacts, but this data needs to be integrated to enable effective visualization and decision making. Your challenge is to develop an interactive visualization and simulation tool that uses real data to help users model asteroid impact scenarios, predict consequences, and evaluate potential mitigation strategies. (Planetary Science Division)

projectDetails.name: ExoData AI
projectDetails.summary:
Our project, the Exoplanet Detector AI, directly addresses the challenge of manually analyzing vast astronomical data by providing a comprehensive, AI-powered web platform. We developed a high-accuracy (98.46%) XGBoost machine learning model, trained on unified open-source data from NASA's Kepler, K2, and TESS missions, to automatically classify exoplanet candidates.

Our solution is not just a model, but an interactive tool where users can upload new data or enter parameters manually for instant classification. Furthermore, it serves as an educational hub with a data analysis dashboard for visualizing the dataset and a detailed reference guide explaining the science behind exoplanets and our AI pipeline.

This is important because it democratizes access to complex astronomical data, saves researchers valuable time by efficiently filtering out false positives, and ultimately accelerates the discovery of new worlds.
projectDetails.details:
Our project, the ExoData AI, is a comprehensive web platform designed to accelerate the discovery of exoplanets. It works in two main parts: The AI Engine (Backend): At its core is a powerful XGBoost (Extreme Gradient Boosting) machine learning model, pre-trained on a unified dataset from NASA's Kepler, K2, and TESS missions. This AI engine follows a rigorous Machine Learning Pipeline: when it receives new data about a potential exoplanet, it automatically handles missing values (imputation), normalizes the data to a consistent scale (scaling), and then feeds it to the trained model to generate a classification ('Candidate', 'Confirmed', or 'False Positive') with a high degree of accuracy (98.46%).

The benefits and intended impact of our project are multi-faceted:

Acceleration of Scientific Discovery: By automating the classification of exoplanet candidates with high accuracy, our tool drastically reduces the manual labor required by astronomers. This allows them to focus their time and resources on the most promising signals, directly speeding up the process of confirming new worlds.

Increased Efficiency: The AI is highly effective at identifying 'False Positives', preventing valuable telescope time from being wasted on signals caused by instrumental noise or other astrophysical phenomena.

Our project was developed entirely with open-source tools on standard computer hardware.

Programming Language: Python

Web Framework: Streamlit

Pandas, Scikit-learn, Imblearn, XGBoost, Matplotlib, Seaborn

Development Environment: Jupyter Notebook for model training and experimentation; Visual Studio Code for application development.

Version Control & Deployment: Git & GitHub for version control; Streamlit Community Cloud for deployment.

SITE: https://binarybitsai.streamlit.app/

GITHUB: https://github.com/gasbriel07sm/hackathon_exoplanet

PRESENTATION: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1tML0y7xdS7ZsoGhZMpWzUZGGZPHVVHVd/view?usp=sharing
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Our project utilizes Artificial Intelligence in two distinct ways:

Data and Training: The model was trained on a unified dataset from NASA's Kepler, K2, and TESS missions. We designed and executed a complete machine learning pipeline, including data cleaning, feature engineering, handling class imbalance with SMOTE, and hyperparameter tuning, all documented in our Jupyter Notebook

Function: This is the "brain" of our application. Its function is to analyze astronomical data and classify exoplanet candidates as 'Candidate', 'Confirmed', or 'False Positive' with 98.46% accuracy. This AI is the direct solution to the challenge.

AI as a Development Tool (Assistance): To accelerate development and innovation, we utilized a Large Language Model (LLM) as a programming and writing assistant throughout the project. The LLM's role was to support our team, not to create the core logic or concept. Its specific uses include.

  • Documentation: Helping to generate summaries and detailed descriptions for the project submission forms.

projectDetails.name: Cosmic Canvas
projectDetails.summary: We developed an AI-powered tool that transforms 608 space biology studies into interactive visual mind maps. Instead of scrolling through search results, researchers ask questions and get visual maps showing how studies connect, key themes, and relevant sources—all editable and exportable. This solves the critical problem of information overload: what normally takes hours of manual searching and connecting research now happens in minutes. By making research discovery visual and intuitive, we're accelerating scientific progress, and while focused on space biology now, this approach can scale to any field.
projectDetails.details:
What It Does & How It Works:

Our tool transforms static research databases into interactive knowledge maps. When a researcher asks a question, our AI agent expands the query into relevant keywords and searches through 608 space biology studies stored in a vector database. Instead of returning a simple list, it analyzes the retrieved documents to identify central themes and relationships, then generates an interactive mind map using visual canvas technology. The map shows thematic clusters, individual studies within those themes, and how everything connects to the original question—complete with citations and links. Researchers can edit the maps directly in the app and export them as images for presentations or papers.

Benefits:

- Dramatically reduces research time from hours to minutes

- Reveals hidden connections between studies that traditional search misses

- Provides visual, spatial understanding rather than linear lists

- Generates proper citations with links automatically

- Allows collaborative editing and sharing through exportable images

- Makes complex research landscapes immediately understandable

Intended Impact:

We aim to accelerate scientific discovery by making research exploration intuitive and visual. Information overload is a critical bottleneck in modern science—researchers struggle to find relevant connections across thousands of studies. By visualizing these connections automatically, we help scientists discover insights faster, identify research gaps, and build on existing work more effectively. While starting with space biology, our vision is to scale this to any research database, democratizing access to scientific knowledge across all fields.

Tools & Technologies:

- Frontend/Backend: TanStack Start (React-based framework)

- Vector Database: ChromaDB for semantic search and embeddings

- LLM Infrastructure: OpenRouter with Gemini 2.5 Flash model

- Embeddings: OpenAI embeddings for document processing

- Visualization: tldraw SDK for interactive canvas

- Framework: LangChain for AI agent orchestration

- Hosting: Railway for deployment

- Architecture: RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation)

Creative Aspects:

The creativity lies in combining multiple AI capabilities into a novel user experience. Instead of chat interfaces or search results, we chose mind maps because research thinking is inherently spatial and non-linear. We also focused on making the output actionable—maps can be edited and exported, turning AI analysis into shareable artifacts. The query expansion agent ensures users find what they need even with imprecise questions, and the automatic theme identification reveals patterns that wouldn't be obvious from individual studies.

Factors We Considered:

- User experience: Researchers need visual thinking tools, not just text

- Scalability: Built to work with any research database, not just space biology

- Accuracy: Using RAG architecture ensures responses are grounded in actual documents

- Accessibility: Making complex research discoverable for scientists at all levels

- Shareability: Export functionality allows collaboration and presentation

- Prototype nature: Acknowledging this is a proof of concept with room for improvement in speed, accuracy, and visual design

- Real-world workflow: Integration with existing research practices through exportable citations and references
projectDetails.aiReferences: We utilized AI tools throughout the development process. Claude Code (Anthropic's CLI assistant) was used extensively for writing application code, including the TanStack Start frontend/backend implementation, ChromaDB integration, and tldraw canvas generation logic. The core functionality of our project itself relies on AI models: we use OpenAI embeddings to process and embed the 608 space biology studies into vector representations, and the Gemini 2.5 Flash model (accessed via OpenRouter) powers our LangChain research agent for query expansion, document retrieval, theme identification, and mind map generation.
projectDetails.dataReferences: [Repository with links to access 608 full-text space biology publications.](https://github.com/jgalazka/SB_publications/)

projectDetails.name: Interactive Space Atlas
projectDetails.summary:
Space imagery is essential for a better understanding of both cosmic and terrestrial phenomena, as well as for comprehending the elements that make up our Solar System and the Universe. With technological advancements in the capture and processing of images and videos, the need for more efficient tools has emerged.
 Our project, developed using a combination of HTML and JavaScript, presents a web-based application designed to zoom, compare, and characterize NASA satellite images interactively, helping both researchers and enthusiasts identify patterns on Earth and in space. We addressed the challenge with the primary goal of facilitating the exploration of data provided by NASA and making it accessible to the general public and scientific communities, while also encouraging broader interest in our Universe through dynamic exploration.
projectDetails.details:
How does it works?

The Interactive Space Atlas (ISA) allows users to navigate, analyze, and compare celestial bodies using high-resolution visual data generated by NASA’s space and Earth-based missions. In addition to providing detailed visualization, the platform offers tools such as zoom, temporal comparison, and feature identification within the images. Focused on performance, we ensure a smooth browsing experience, allowing users to zoom in and out without compromising speed or image quality.

To begin the analysis, the user selects a Martian day (sun), which serves as a temporal reference for the space landscapes. Then, they choose the camera type and activate "Compare Mode," which switches the interface to "Compare (ON)." Once two images are selected, they are automatically displayed side by side and can be manipulated freely. Another option is to click the "Compare" button directly on the selected images.

Benefits:

ISA's tools help capture small details in the images, enabling careful observation of changes and patterns present across 2D images simultaneously. Additionally, the platform offers open exploration accessible to all audiences, encouraging a broader interest in astronomy.

Intended impact:

- Develop a practical platform for the general public.

- Inspire people around the world to explore and research our Universe, enabling major discoveries in astronomy.

Technologies used:

- Java Script (ES6+): used to make the website dynamic and user-friendly.

- HTML5: responsible for the overall structure of the content and the web page interface.

- CSS3: used to style HTML elements, ensuring a visually friendly and accessible interface.

- JSON: lightweight data format used for exchanging information between NASA APIs and the browser.

Creativity:

- Efficient integration of HTML, CSS and JavaScript.

- Implementation of an interactive model.

Considered factors:

- Accessibility across all devices.

- Simple and intuitive interface.
