challengeDetails.title: Embiggen Your Eyes!
challengeDetails.excerpt: While your cell phone screen can display about three million pixels of information and your eye can receive more than ten million pixels, NASA images from space are even bigger! NASA’s space missions continue to push the boundaries of what is technologically possible, providing high-resolution images and videos of Earth, other planets, and space with billions or even trillions of pixels. Your challenge is to create a platform that allows users to zoom in and out on these massive image datasets, label known features, and discover new patterns. (Astrophysics Division)

node.title: Bloom team
node.excerpt:
Equipe Bloom
Somos a Bloom Team, um grupo entusiasmado em explorar a beleza e a ciência por trás da floração das plantas através dos dados.

projectDetails.name: MODIS Bloom Tracker
projectDetails.summary:
O projeto MODIS Bloom Tracker foi feito com o objetivo de facilitar o estudo/analise sobre as plantas da Caatinga do Nordeste Brasileiro. A equipe Bloom team aproveitou dos recursos do Earthdata Search (NASA) para fazer um mapa que analisa NVDI, e para conseguir informações para o mapa interativo. 
O mapa interativo mostra as plantas que irão desabrochar separado por regiões do nordeste. Ao clicar no card da planta um pop-up ira aparecer mostrando as especificações da planta de forma simples de entender. Além disso o projeto contem uma ferramenta de comparação entre a flora de diferentes estados, uma barra de pesquisa para saber de cada planta, e a opção de importar os dados de cada planta em: .csv , .pdf , .json .
projectDetails.details: Nosso projeto e um site sobre o florescimento das plantas no nordeste. O site consiste em varias seções, como por exemplo o mapa, que e onde achamos o local que queremos ver o que florescera lá. Ele veio com a intenção de ajudar o publico a entender quais plantas crescem e quais estão a crescer no nordeste brasileiro. Utilizamos nele os computadores da escola de tecnologia TECHERS, e para programar o Visual Studio Code, com a linguagem Js script, html, typescript, react, CSS e python. Pretendemos que o projeto ajude o publico a entender melhor como o florescimento de plantas funciona no nordeste brasileiro. Nosso projeto e criativo porque ele traz uma proposta nunca antes vista, com um mapa e pop-ups que ajudam a diminuicao de poluição visual na tela. Nosso time considerou os fatores clima, temperatura, quantidade de sol que a área recebe e umidade do ar. Para as pesquisas e programação do site, usamos o Canva, site oficial do IBGE (Instituto Brasileiro de Geografia e Estatística), (continuação) pinterest para imagens, Earth Data Search, Git Hub, Gemini, ChatGPT, Claude.ai, Vscode, Netlify.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
O desenvolvimento do nosso projeto para o NASA Space Apps Challenge 2025 foi otimizado pela integração estratégica de plataformas de Inteligência Artificial generativa. Essa abordagem multimídia e interativa foi fundamental para superarmos desafios técnicos complexos e garantirmos a entrega dentro do rigoroso prazo do hackathon.

Nossa equipe utilizou o seguinte ecossistema de ferramentas de IA para acelerar e aprimorar significativamente diversas etapas do trabalho:

  • Google Gemini: Empregado majoritariamente na fase crítica de backend, atuando na resolução de erros ambientais e de compatibilidade que envolviam o ambiente Python e as bibliotecas de acesso a dados da NASA. Foi essencial na formulação da solução final robusta para a autenticação e o processamento eficiente de grandes volumes de dados geoespaciais (MODIS).
  • ChatGPT: Utilizado como recurso auxiliar no refinamento de algoritmos, na estruturação da arquitetura da aplicação React e na geração de snippets de código para otimização do frontend e da lógica de apresentação dos resultados.
  • Claude.ai: Aplicado na fase de concepção e design, tanto para gerar conceitos visuais quanto para auxiliar na criação de textos e prompts criativos, garantindo que a comunicação e a estética do projeto final fossem profissionais e envolventes.

A sinergia dessas ferramentas de IA nos permitiu focar na inovação e na lógica de negócio, demonstrando a aplicação prática da Inteligência Artificial como uma ferramenta colaborativa e catalisadora de excelência técnica no contexto de um desafio de alto nível como o NASA Space Apps.

challengeDetails.title: BloomWatch: An Earth Observation Application for Global Flowering Phenology
challengeDetails.excerpt: Witness the pulse of life across our planet! From season to season and year to year, Earth’s vegetation is constantly changing, providing critical information on plant species, crops, seasonal effects, pollen sources, and changes in plant phenology (the relationship between seasonal changes and climate and biological phenomena in plants). Your challenge is to harness the power of NASA Earth observations to create a dynamic visual tool that displays and/or detects plant blooming events around the globe—just like pollinators do–and that advances solutions for monitoring, predicting, or managing vegetation. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: A World Away: Hunting for Exoplanets with AI
challengeDetails.excerpt: Data from several different space-based exoplanet surveying missions have enabled discovery of thousands of new planets outside our solar system, but most of these exoplanets were identified manually. With advances in artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML), it is possible to automatically analyze large sets of data collected by these missions to identify exoplanets. Your challenge is to create an AI/ML model that is trained on one or more of the open-source exoplanet datasets offered by NASA and that can analyze new data to accurately identify exoplanets. (Astrophysics Division)

projectDetails.name: Project Brazuca - Plantando o Futuro
projectDetails.summary:
Education faces a major challenge: effectively integrating technology to engage students and develop citizens who are aware of the environmental and social impacts of human activities. While public policies and traditional methods are progressing slowly, new generations demand practical, up-to-date experiences connected to the real world.

Our solution addresses this challenge with an educational game that uses real-time NASA data to simulate agricultural scenarios in different regions of Brazil. The player chooses a crop and a state (for example, planting coffee in Rio Grande do Sul) and the system analyzes climate, terrain, and environmental events to demonstrate the viability and impacts of this choice. Wildfires, climate variations, and other real-world phenomena are automatically captured and directly affect crops in the game, connecting students to the living dynamics of the environment.

The result is an innovative tool that combines hands-on learning, gamification, and reliable scientific data to transform environmental education. In this initial phase, we're starting in Brazil, but our vision is global: to bring this interactive experience to schools and players worldwide, fostering collaboration, knowledge exchange, and planetary awareness.
projectDetails.details:
Project links:

  • Repository: https://github.com/3up-Dev/hackathon-nasa-2025
  • Published Project: https://nasa.3up.tech



1. WHAT DOES IT DO OR HOW DOES IT WORK

Plantando Futuro (“Planting the Future”) is an educational simulation game that teaches sustainable agriculture and climate awareness through interactive gameplay.
The application allows users to simulate the entire agricultural production cycle across Brazil’s 27 states using real NASA and INMET climate data.
Players select from 13 crops across 5 agricultural sectors (Agriculture, Livestock, Aquaculture, Forestry, and Horticulture), manage resources, respond to real-time environmental alerts, and earn sustainability-based rewards.

1.1 Core Functionality

  1. User Authentication and Profile Management:
    Secure login via Supabase Auth with persistent user profiles and multiple game slots per account.
  2. Crop and Location Selection:
    Interactive map of Brazil where players choose crops and states.
    Each state uses real geographic coordinates to fetch climate data.
    • Health (40%)
    • Sustainability (30%)
    • Water Efficiency (30%)
      Players earn medals (Gold, Silver, Bronze) and can compare results in a dashboard.
  3. Progressive Web App (PWA):
    Fully installable on mobile and desktop, with offline functionality and caching for low-connectivity environments.

2. WHAT BENEFITS DOES IT HAVE

  1. Educational Value:
    Simplifies complex climate and agricultural concepts through interactive simulation.
    Players learn how environmental decisions influence sustainability and productivity.
  2. Real Data Integration:
    Uses verified NASA and INMET data, ensuring scientific accuracy and trustworthiness.
  3. Engagement through Gamification:
    Combines education with entertainment, enhancing user retention and motivation.
  4. Accessibility and Inclusion:
    PWA support enables access on any device, even in low-bandwidth areas.
    Interface available in Portuguese and English for broader reach.
  5. Environmental Awareness:
    Encourages critical thinking about sustainability and responsible resource management.

3. WHAT IS THE INTENDED IMPACT OF THE PROJECT

  1. Educational Transformation:
    Converts environmental science into an engaging, visual, and practical learning experience.
    Players can understand the link between climate data and agricultural outcomes in real time.
  2. Critical Thinking and Responsibility:
    Demonstrates how local decisions affect global sustainability.
    Encourages reflection on water usage, emissions, and biodiversity.
  3. Regional and Social Inclusion:
    Promotes awareness of Brazil’s diverse climates and ecosystems.
    Provides accessible educational material for schools, NGOs, and rural communities.
  4. Institutional Adoption:
    Designed to serve as an educational resource for schools and environmental programs.
    Can be used in classrooms or workshops to complement sustainability education.
  5. Long-Term Awareness:
    Aims to build lasting environmental responsibility and inspire young generations to consider sustainability in real-world decision-making.

4. WHAT TOOLS, CODING LANGUAGES, HARDWARE, OR SOFTWARE WERE USED

4.1 Frontend Stack

  • React 18.3.1: Component-based UI framework.
  • TypeScript: Static typing and compile-time validation.
  • Vite: High-speed development build tool.
  • Tailwind CSS: Responsive utility-first styling.
  • shadcn/ui: Accessible UI components (based on Radix UI).
  • Zustand 5.0.8: Lightweight global state management.
  • React Router DOM 6.30.1: Protected route management.
  • React Hook Form + Zod: Validation and schema enforcement.
  • Recharts 2.15.4: Data visualization.
  • date-fns 3.6.0: Date and time handling.

4.2 Backend Infrastructure

  • Supabase: Backend-as-a-Service (PostgreSQL, Auth, and Edge Functions).
  • Supabase Auth: Secure authentication with JWT.
  • Row-Level Security: User-level data isolation.
  • Deno Edge Functions: Serverless integrations for NASA and INMET APIs.

4.3 External APIs

  1. NASA POWER API (Climate Data)
    Consumption File: supabase/functions/get-nasa-climate-data/index.ts
    NASA Endpoint: https://power.larc.nasa.gov/api/temporal/daily/point

Location in Code: Key lines 34-196

  1. NASA FIRMS API (Fire Detection)
    Consumption File: supabase/functions/get-brazil-climate-alerts/index.ts
    NASA Endpoint: https://firms.modaps.eosdis.nasa.gov/api/area/csv/{MAP_KEY}/VIIRS_NOAA20_NRT/...

Returned Data:

  • Fire hotspots (latitude, longitude, confidence)
  • Fire risk alerts by state

Location in Code: Key lines 91-159 (fire data fetching)

4.4 Deployment and Hardware

  • Hosting: Lovable Cloud (auto-deploy via Git push).
  • Database: Supabase PostgreSQL.
  • Devices: Any modern web browser (desktop or mobile).
  • Connectivity: Internet for real-time data; offline support via PWA caching.

5. HOW IS THE PROJECT CREATIVE

  1. Real Satellite Data Integration:
    First educational game to combine NASA POWER (climate) and FIRMS (fire) data for interactive sustainability simulation.
  2. Dynamic Environmental Gameplay:
    Real-time data directly influences the player’s outcomes — fires, droughts, and rainfall events generate immediate feedback and learning moments.
  3. Gamified Learning Framework:
    Transforms scientific knowledge into an engaging experience through challenges, scoring systems, and medal rewards.
  4. Cross-Disciplinary Approach:
    Combines data science, game design, and environmental education into a unified, accessible tool.
  5. Visual and UX Creativity:
    Uses pixel-art style and simple interactive dashboards to make complex climate data intuitive for all audiences.

6. WHAT FACTORS DID THE TEAM CONSIDER

  1. Pedagogical Design:
    Educational balance between scientific accuracy and accessible learning for ages 10 and up.
    Concepts simplified without losing data integrity.
  2. Accessibility and Inclusivity:
    Compliance with WCAG accessibility standards and full keyboard navigation.
    Color contrast verified for color blindness.
  3. Localization:
    Native Portuguese interface with English translation.
    Temperature and precipitation units adapted per locale.
  4. Scalability:
    Modular architecture allows adding new crops or data sources easily.
    APIs abstracted via edge functions for rapid expansion.
  5. Resilience and Offline Access:
    Built as a Progressive Web App to support unstable internet connections common in rural areas.
  6. Cultural Context:
    All examples, crops, and terminology based on Brazilian agriculture, ensuring local relevance while maintaining global applicability.

Conclusion

Plantando Futuro is an innovative educational platform that merges space technology, climate data, and game design to raise awareness about sustainable agriculture.
By transforming real NASA and INMET data into interactive learning, it enables players to understand — in an intuitive, hands-on way — how environmental conditions shape the world we live in.

  • Repository: https://github.com/3up-Dev/hackathon-nasa-2025
  • Published Project: https://nasa.3up.tech
  • YouTube Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zLOzDeXtllw

Images and Videos

node.title: break;
node.excerpt: We need a break

projectDetails.name: Project break;
projectDetails.summary:
Our group has developed an interactive website dedicated to weather forecasting and analysis. The application features an intuitive interface where users can input an address in several ways: by typing the location name, providing latitude and longitude coordinates, or by marking a point directly on the interactive map.
Upon receiving the user input, the system obtains the geographic coordinates and uses them to query a meteorological data API. The site then presents essential weather information to the user, such as temperature, air quality, atmospheric pressure, humidity, and wind speed.
This project directly addresses the proposed challenge, "Will It Rain On My Parade?", by offering a practical tool for forecasting and monitoring atmospheric conditions in real-time. This allows users to better plan their outdoor activities, minimizing setbacks caused by rain or other adverse conditions.
The importance of this solution lies in its ability to make complex meteorological information accessible in a clear and visual manner, promoting both prevention and planning. Furthermore, it integrates technology, science, and usability into a single platform, connecting data from weather APIs with a simple and useful experience for anyone.
projectDetails.details:
https://github.com/GManziFS/Project-break

Our project is a weather forecasting website that transforms meteorological data into accessible and useful information. Users can check the climate forecast using three input methods: typing the address, providing latitude and longitude coordinates, or marking a location directly on the interactive map.

The application uses a weather API to process the data and display results such as temperature, air quality, atmospheric pressure, humidity, and wind speed

Beyond real-time data, a standout feature is the 15-day historical chart from the selected date, which functions as a complete report to support the planning of events or activities. This feature was added because we recognize that events require prior organization, and understanding the recent climate behavior allows for better preparation.

The main benefit of the platform is allowing users to visualize the climate in different units of measurement, choosing the format most familiar or suitable for their reality. This ensures global accessibility, as different regions use distinct systems.

The project’s creativity is expressed both in its features and its identity:

Project Name: We created the name "Will It Rain On My Break?" as a playful twist on the challenge "Will It Rain On My Parade?", integrating our team's name, 'break;'.

Location Icon: The custom location icon is inspired by the Google Maps pin, but adapted to include a raining cloud, reinforcing the project's theme.

The system was developed using JavaScript and Node.js, integrated with HTML and CSS. We used Visual Studio Code for the development environment and conducted testing in a standard browser.

The intended impact is that anyone can better predict and organize their plans—whether for personal appointments, academic activities, or even large events. By focusing on factors like accessibility, varied location inputs, and practical utility, we deliver a robust tool that simplifies complex weather data for everyone.

challengeDetails.title: Will It Rain On My Parade?
challengeDetails.excerpt: If you’re planning an outdoor event—like a vacation, a hike on a trail, or fishing on a lake—it would be good to know the chances of adverse weather for the time and location you are considering. There are many types of Earth observation data that can provide information on weather conditions for a particular location and day of the year. Your challenge is to construct an app with a personalized interface that enables users to conduct a customized query to tell them the likelihood of “very hot,” “very cold,” “very windy,” “very wet,” or “very uncomfortable” conditions for the location and time they specify. (Earth Science Division)

Who gonna code? BUG Busters!
We are the BUG Busters! A small group of Computer Engineering students. We are passioned about technology, coding, mathematics, science at all and so on.

projectDetails.name: Project BUG Busters
projectDetails.summary:
Com certeza. Aqui está a tradução do texto para inglês, em um tom profissional e claro:

We developed a web application that uses data from NASA's Asteroids NeoWs API and cross-references it with topographic information from USGS datasets to perform realistic and educational simulations of potential asteroid collisions with Earth.

In addition to promoting educational knowledge for the general public, the application provides up-to-date data for scientists who require greater data precision. Furthermore, we created a feature to present ideas and possibilities for mitigating the risks of potential impacts.
projectDetails.details:
Our Meteor Madness project for the Nasa Space Apps 2025 is a powerful didactic and/or scientific tool designed for any type of audience. We focused on practicality and ensuring the UI was as User-Friendly as possible, without losing the most important characteristics of the project: innovation and science.

The languages used were Java and JavaScript, with the Spring Boot and Vite React frameworks. All programming was done using the JetBrains IntelliJ IDEA Ultimate IDE. To facilitate consumption by the end-user, we decided to deploy to the Render host.

To make it as didactic as possible, we implemented an on-site 3D simulation that shows Earth's orbit around the Sun and compares it with the orbit of the supposed asteroid that might collide. Furthermore, a window of possible mitigation methods was added for learning or preparation purposes, depending on the end-user.

We consider our project creative and innovative because we paid close attention to every detail of the user experience, such as: environmental risks, damage propagation, cost, devastation, mitigation possibilities, and interactive simulated visualization. Above all, we focused on the accuracy of the data sent to the user.
projectDetails.aiReferences: We used Claude Sonnet 4.5 for fast debugging and brainstorming and IntelliJ IDEA Copilot for enhance speed of typing. For complex physics calculations, we used Gemini Pro 2.5 as well.

challengeDetails.title: Meteor Madness
challengeDetails.excerpt: A newly identified near-Earth asteroid, "Impactor-2025," poses a potential threat to Earth, but do we have the tools to enable the public and decision makers to understand and mitigate its risks? NASA datasets include information about known asteroids and the United States Geological Survey provides critical information that could enable modeling the effects of asteroid impacts, but this data needs to be integrated to enable effective visualization and decision making. Your challenge is to develop an interactive visualization and simulation tool that uses real data to help users model asteroid impact scenarios, predict consequences, and evaluate potential mitigation strategies. (Planetary Science Division)

projectDetails.name: SharkFlow
projectDetails.summary: This is important because more than 120 shark species are at serious risk of extinction. These species are crucial for maintaining the balance of marine life and the order of the food chain, as sharks help control the populations of animals that feed on phytoplankton, including the whale shark and the megamouth shark, which consume phytoplankton. The project is focused on shark protection and the conservation of these species.
projectDetails.details:
1. The model uses SSH (sea surface height) data and chlorophyll concentration—an indicator of phytoplankton presence—to predict potential shark occurrence areas. Sea surface height reflects current patterns and ocean topography, while chlorophyll indicates regions with higher biological productivity, providing food for the food chain that sustains sharks.

2. Environmental preservation – Knowing where sharks are located helps protect sensitive marine ecosystems, as these animals are keystone predators.

Sustainable fisheries management – ​​Prevents shark areas from being overexploited, reducing impacts on the food chain.

Human safety – Allows for the identification of areas with higher shark presence, helping to prevent accidents with swimmers and fishermen.

Scientific monitoring – Facilitates studies on migratory patterns, behavior, and marine biodiversity.

Data-driven decision-making – Governments and environmental organizations can plan protected areas and conservation policies more accurately.

3. The project aims to impact marine conservation and human safety by identifying potential shark habitats through SSH and chlorophyll data. This allows us to protect sensitive ecosystems, guide conservation policies, support research on shark behavior and migration, reduce the risk of accidents in areas with a high presence of these animals, and combat the threat of extinction of several species by identifying their critical habitats and enabling more effective conservation actions.

4. We used Python to generate the map and process the data, collected GBIF data on shark occurrence to train the prediction model, and used data from three NASA satellites: SWOT, MODIS, and PACE.

5. The algorithm is unique.

6. The temperature, chlorophyll concentration, water surface height, longitude, latitude, and date of the data.
projectDetails.aiReferences: We use AI to study sharks and formulate codes.

challengeDetails.title: Sharks from Space
challengeDetails.excerpt: Earth’s ocean is one of the most powerful habitats in our universe, supporting a range of life that sustains ecosystems and habitability across the globe. It is common to measure photosynthetic activity in the ocean from space, but far more challenging to track top predators. Your challenge is to create a mathematical framework for identifying sharks and predicting their foraging habitats using NASA satellite data, and also to suggest a new conceptual model of a tag (a small electronic device that can be attached to an animal to track and study its movement) that could measure not only where sharks are, but also what they are eating, and in real time transmit that data back to users to enable development of predictive models. (Earth Science Division)

node.title: Candiru Space
node.excerpt: Students from Uberlândia.

projectDetails.name: Project Candiru Space
projectDetails.summary:
What we developed: A comprehensive AI-powered web application that automatically detects and classifies exoplanets using NASA's Kepler, K2, and TESS mission data. The system employs ensemble machine learning models (Random Forest, XGBoost, LightGBM) to analyze transit light curves and classify objects as confirmed exoplanets, planetary candidates, or false positives.
How it addresses the challenge: This solution directly tackles the "Planetary Tourism" challenge by providing an automated, accurate, and accessible tool for exoplanet discovery. It democratizes exoplanet research by making NASA's vast datasets accessible through an intuitive web interface, enabling both researchers and citizen scientists to contribute to exoplanet discovery efforts.
Why it's important: With over 5,000 confirmed exoplanets and thousands more candidates, automated detection systems are crucial for processing the massive amounts of data from current and future space missions. Our system accelerates the discovery process, reduces human bias, and makes exoplanet research more accessible to the global community, ultimately advancing our understanding of planetary systems and the search for habitable worlds.
Key Features: Real-time analysis, multi-language support (PT/EN/ES), interactive visualizations, data upload capabilities, and comprehensive documentation for educational purposes.
projectDetails.details:
What does it do and how does it work?

Our Exoplanet Detection AI System is a comprehensive web application that automatically identifies and classifies exoplanets from NASA's astronomical datasets. The system works through a multi-stage pipeline:

Data Preprocessing: Cleans and normalizes NASA datasets (Kepler KOI, TESS TOI, K2) using statistical methods and SMOTE for class balancing

Transit Analysis: Detects periodic brightness dips in stellar light curves using advanced signal processing

Machine Learning Classification: Employs ensemble models (Random Forest, XGBoost, LightGBM) to classify objects into three categories:

Confirmed Exoplanets: Scientifically validated planets

Planetary Candidates: Promising signals awaiting confirmation

False Positives: Stellar phenomena that mimic planetary transits

Benefits and Impact*

Scientific Impact:

Accelerated Discovery: Processes thousands of light curves in minutes vs. months of manual analysis

Reduced Human Bias: Objective classification based on statistical patterns

Democratized Research: Makes NASA's data accessible to citizen scientists worldwide

Educational Value: Interactive visualizations teach astronomy concepts

Societal Benefits:

Public Engagement: Multi-language interface (Portuguese, English, Spanish) reaches global audiences

Research Accessibility: No specialized software or expertise required

Future-Ready: Scalable architecture for upcoming missions (JWST, PLATO, ARIEL)

Technical Implementation*

Technologies Used:

Backend: Python 3.10, Streamlit framework

Machine Learning: Scikit-learn, XGBoost, LightGBM, Imbalanced-learn

Data Processing: Pandas, NumPy, SciPy

Visualization: Plotly, Matplotlib, Seaborn

Deployment: Docker, Buildpacks, VPS hosting

Infrastructure: Git version control, automated CI/CD

Architecture:

Modular Design: Separate modules for ML models, data visualization, and transit analysis

Real-time Processing: Live data updates and interactive dashboards

Responsive UI: Mobile-friendly interface with custom CSS animations

Data Security: Secure file upload and processing capabilities

Creative Elements*

Innovation Factors:

Ensemble Approach: Combines multiple ML algorithms for robust predictions

Interactive Visualizations: 3D hyperparameter landscapes and real-time charts

Multilingual Accessibility: Complete translation system for global reach

Educational Integration: Built-in documentation and tutorial system

Starfield UI: Immersive space-themed interface with CSS animations

Data Reset Functionality: Browser cache clearing for clean data uploads

Team Considerations*

Technical Factors:

Scalability: Designed to handle increasing data volumes from future missions

Accuracy: Balanced precision vs. recall to minimize false discoveries

Performance: Optimized for both speed and computational efficiency

Compatibility: Cross-platform support for various operating systems

Ethical Considerations:

Open Source: All code publicly available for scientific transparency

Data Privacy: No personal data collection or storage

Accessibility: Designed for users with varying technical backgrounds

Educational Focus: Prioritizes learning and scientific literacy

Future Considerations:

Mission Integration: Ready for JWST, PLATO, and ARIEL data

Algorithm Updates: Modular design allows easy model improvements

Community Features: Potential for collaborative research features

Mobile Optimization: Progressive web app capabilities

Intended Impact:

Short-term: Enable immediate analysis of existing NASA datasets by researchers and citizen scientists worldwide.

Long-term: Establish a foundation for automated exoplanet discovery that can scale with future space missions, contributing to humanity's understanding of planetary formation and the search for habitable worlds.

Educational: Inspire the next generation of astronomers and data scientists through accessible, interactive tools that make complex astronomical concepts understandable and engaging.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in Our Project

AI Tool Usage Disclosure

Primary AI Assistant: Claude (Anthropic) - Used exclusively for development guidance and technical assistance

How AI Was Utilized:

Code Development Assistance (90% of AI usage):

Library Guidance: AI provided recommendations for Python libraries (Streamlit, Plotly, Scikit-learn, XGBoost, LightGBM)

Syntax Help: Assistance with Python syntax, error debugging, and code optimization

Architecture Planning: Guidance on modular design patterns and best practices

Documentation: Help structuring README files and inline code comments

Technical Problem Solving:

Build Issues: Assistance resolving Buildpacks deployment errors and dependency conflicts

Translation Implementation: Guidance on creating multilingual interfaces

UI/UX Design: Suggestions for user interface improvements and accessibility features

Error Debugging: Help identifying and fixing TypeError, IndentationError, and Streamlit-specific issues

Educational Content:

Scientific Accuracy: Verification of astronomical concepts and NASA data format specifications

Project Documentation: Assistance structuring technical explanations and user guides

What AI Did NOT Do:

No Data Analysis: All machine learning models and data processing logic was developed independently

No Creative Design: All UI elements, visualizations, and user experience decisions were made by the team

No Scientific Research: All astronomical concepts and methodologies were researched independently

No NASA Branding: No AI-generated content used NASA logos, flags, or mission identifiers

Human-Driven Development:

Original Contributions:

Algorithm Selection: Team independently chose ensemble ML approach (Random Forest, XGBoost, LightGBM)

Data Processing Pipeline: Custom implementation of NASA data preprocessing and normalization

Visualization Design: Original interactive charts and real-time dashboards

Multilingual System: Custom translation framework with 3 languages (Portuguese, English, Spanish)

Deployment Strategy: Independent research and implementation of VPS deployment with Buildpacks

AI Role Summary:

AI served purely as a development assistant and learning resource, similar to how developers use Stack Overflow or technical documentation. The AI provided:

Technical guidance and suggestions

Error resolution assistance

Best practice recommendations

Educational explanations

All creative decisions, scientific methodology, code implementation, and project vision originated from the human development team. The AI was a tool to accelerate learning and problem-solving, not a substitute for original thinking or development work.

Development Breakdown:

Human Work: 80% (Original ideas, code, design, scientific methodology)

AI Assistance: 20% (Guidance, suggestions, debugging help)

AI-Generated Content: 0% (No content was directly generated by AI)

This approach exemplifies responsible AI use in scientific development, where AI enhances human capabilities without replacing human creativity, scientific rigor, or original thought.

challengeDetails.title: A World Away: Hunting for Exoplanets with AI
challengeDetails.excerpt: Data from several different space-based exoplanet surveying missions have enabled discovery of thousands of new planets outside our solar system, but most of these exoplanets were identified manually. With advances in artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML), it is possible to automatically analyze large sets of data collected by these missions to identify exoplanets. Your challenge is to create an AI/ML model that is trained on one or more of the open-source exoplanet datasets offered by NASA and that can analyze new data to accurately identify exoplanets. (Astrophysics Division)

projectDetails.name: Exoplanet Classification Tool
projectDetails.summary:
We developed the Exoplanet Classification Tool, an interactive web application that leverages a machine learning model to classify exoplanet candidates from NASA's Kepler mission data. The primary challenge in the field is efficiently vetting the vast number of potential signals (KOIs) to identify the most promising candidates.

Our tool addresses this by allowing researchers to upload their data and receive an instant classification of each object as 'CONFIRMED' or 'FALSE POSITIVE', based on a high-accuracy (99%) Random Forest model. Crucially, the tool goes beyond simple prediction. For each classification, it provides a detailed technical justification using SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations), showing exactly which astronomical parameters most influenced the decision.

This is important because by providing fast, accurate, and interpretable classifications, the tool serves as a powerful decision-support resource, helping astronomers prioritize candidates, building trust in the AI's results, and accelerating the pace of exoplanet discovery.
projectDetails.details:
The Exoplanet Classification Tool is a web application designed to automate and accelerate the vetting of potential exoplanets. The workflow is simple and direct:

  1. Data Upload: An astronomer or researcher submits a CSV file containing data for exoplanet candidates (Kepler Objects of Interest - KOIs).
    • Feature Selection: From the raw data, the system selects only the 52 features that proved most predictive in the original data analysis. Columns with a high percentage of missing values, identifiers (kepid), redundant data, and parameters not directly related to the transit's physical properties were systematically removed.
    • Missing Data Handling: If any of the 52 essential features are missing from the user's file (or contain empty cells), the system automatically fills them with pre-calculated average values from the original training dataset, ensuring consistency.
  2. AI Classification: The clean data is then fed into a high-accuracy (99%) Random Forest machine learning model, which classifies each candidate as either "CONFIRMED" or "FALSE POSITIVE".
  3. Visualization and Analysis: The results are presented in an interactive interface featuring a dashboard, tables, and most importantly, an Individual Analysis section. Here, a researcher can select any candidate and view a graph (SHAP Force Plot) and a detailed technical justification that explains exactly which factors led to that specific classification.

The primary benefit of the tool is efficiency and trust. The process of vetting exoplanet candidates is time-consuming and complex. Our tool drastically reduces the time required for an initial screening, allowing researchers to focus on the most promising candidates.

The intended impact is to accelerate the pace of exoplanet discovery. By providing not only a fast and accurate classification but also a transparent explanation of the "why" behind each AI decision, the tool serves as a powerful decision-support resource. It enables astronomers to prioritize targets for follow-up observations with more powerful telescopes, optimizing resources and speeding up the confirmation of new worlds.

The project was developed entirely with open-source software, requiring no specific hardware.

  • Programming Language: Python
  • Backend (Artificial Intelligence): Scikit-learn (for the Random Forest model), Pandas (for data manipulation), and Joblib (for model serialization).
  • Frontend (Web Interface): Streamlit.
  • Data Visualization: Plotly and Matplotlib.
  • AI Explainability: SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations), a state-of-the-art library for interpreting machine learning model predictions.

The project's creativity lies in the integration of three complex components into a single, simple, and accessible tool. We combined:

  1. A high-performance machine learning model.
  2. An AI explainability framework (SHAP) that "translates" the model's decisions.
  3. An interactive and intuitive user interface.

Instead of being a "black box," the tool makes the AI's decision-making transparent and understandable to domain experts (astrophysicists), who can validate whether the model's reasoning is scientifically sound. This bridge between advanced data science and practical application in astronomical research is the project's main creative distinction.

The key factors considered were:

  • Scientific Rigor: Ensuring the AI model was trained and validated with a robust methodology (cross-validation) to achieve high accuracy and reliability.
  • User Experience (UX): Designing a clean, minimalist, and intuitive interface that would allow a researcher to use the tool without needing expertise in programming or machine learning.
  • Interpretability: The most important factor. From the outset, the project was designed with the idea that the explanation behind a classification was as crucial as the classification itself. We wanted the tool to build trust, not just provide answers.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Audio Generation: The audio narration for the project's presentation video was created with the assistance of the AI voice synthesis tool, Luvvoice.

Code and data: Google Gemini was used as an AI assistant to support the prototyping of the project's web interface. Its role was limited to helping outline the initial Streamlit layout and generate sample CSS elements.

projectDetails.name: Code and cheese
projectDetails.summary:
Our project addresses NASA's "Will it rain at my parade?" challenge by developing an intelligent system capable of calculating the probability of adverse weather conditions months in advance, using 20 years of historical data from the NASA POWER API.

Unlike traditional weather forecasts, which have a limited range (1–2 weeks), our solution is based on long-term observational data, allowing us to identify historical patterns and climate trends for any specific location and date on Earth.

The system applies a multi-criteria statistical methodology—temperature, precipitation, wind, and humidity—to assess the weather suitability of outdoor events such as weddings, festivals, harvests, or sporting activities. From this analysis, it generates a historical probability (0–100%) of event success and suggests more favorable alternative dates within a range of ±30 days.
projectDetails.details:
This project addresses NASA's "Will it rain on my parade?" challenge by building an application that allows users to make personalized queries to determine the probability of adverse weather conditions for a specific location and time.

The Problem: Planning outdoor events - vacations, hikes, fishing trips, weddings, festivals - without knowing the chances of bad weather conditions ("too hot", "too cold", "too windy", "too wet" or "too uncomfortable").

Our Solution: A system that analyzes 20 years of NASA historical data to calculate accurate weather condition probabilities, allowing users to be better prepared and make informed decisions months in advance.

Important: This is not a weather forecast! These are probabilities based on historical data, not predictive models. This allows planning months in advance, something traditional forecasts (1-2 weeks) cannot offer.


NASA Earth Observation Data

Primary Source: NASA POWER API

We use the NASA POWER API (Prediction Of Worldwide Energy Resources), which provides global meteorological data on temperature, precipitation, wind, and humidity collected over several decades
The system analyzes 20 years of historical data (2005-2025) for each specific location and date, building a robust statistical compendium that enables pattern identification and reliable probability calculations.

Key Features

  • Location Selection: Interactive map with global coverage and precise coordinates- Personalized Query: Date and time selection with advance planning (months ahead)
  • Event Profiles: Predefined templates (picnic, wedding, sports, festival, photography) or custom criteria via LLM assistant- Probability Analysis: Visual gauge 0-100% based on NASA historical data
  • Alternative Dates: Comparative heatmap (±30 days) highlighting the best option
  • Complete Export: CSV/JSON download with metadata and sharing

How We Process the Data

Processing Pipeline

Our system follows a structured workflow to ensure accurate and reliable analyses:


Processing Steps:
  1. User Input: Location (latitude/longitude) + Specific date
  2. NASA POWER API Query: Fetch historical data (2005-2025)
  3. Data Aggregation: Organize by calendar date
  4. Criteria Application: Compare with event criteria (temperature, rain, wind, humidity)
  5. Probability Calculation: Historical analysis + recent trends
  6. Trend Analysis: Identify patterns (positive/negative/stable)
  7. Alternative Generation: Suggest nearby dates (±30 days)
  8. Results Formatting: Present probability (0-100%) + classification
  9. User Display: Clear and intuitive interface

Data Analysis in Detail

Temperature Variation Over 20 Years

This visualization shows how temperature varies on the chosen date over the last 20 years. The dashed lines indicate:

  • Green: Ideal minimum temperature for the event
  • Red: Safe maximum temperature

Usefulness: Identifies temperature patterns and extremes, helping assess if the date is consistently suitable.


Precipitation Pattern


Year-by-year analysis of precipitation on the chosen date:

  • Green Bars: Years with acceptable precipitation (≤1mm)
  • Red Bars: Years with excessive rain (>1mm)

Insights: Assesses rain risk and identifies historically problematic years.


Multi-Parameter Dashboard


Comprehensive view of all climate parameters:

  • Temperature: Minimum and maximum range
  • Precipitation: Intensity over the years
  • Wind Speed: Trends and safety limits
  • Relative Humidity: Comfort and atmospheric conditions

Advantage: Enables holistic analysis of all climate factors simultaneously.

Criteria Evaluation

Each year is evaluated based on all defined criteria:

  • Green: Year that met all criteria
  • Red: Year that failed one or more criteria

Calculation: Probability = (Ideal Years / Total Years) × 100%
Application: Provides the historical probability of success for your event.


Alternative Dates Heat Map

Compares the chosen date's probability with nearby dates (±15 days):

  • Blue Border: User-selected date
  • Golden Border: Best alternative identified

Benefit: Suggests better dates if the chosen one is not ideal.

Summary Infographic

Complete dashboard with all key metrics:

  • Main Probability: Large, color-coded percentage
  • Average Temperature: Mean of maximum temperatures
  • Rain Distribution: Proportion of dry vs. rainy days
  • Wind Analysis: Safe years vs. strong winds
  • Historical Timeline: Year-by-year visualization (2005-2025)

Usefulness: Complete executive view for quick decision-making.

How It Works in Practice

Scenario: Planning a barbecue in Uberlândia on August 15, 2026, at 2:00 PM


Select the location on the map

Click on Uberlândia or enter coordinates manually!

Choose the event date and time

Set August 15, 2026, at 2:00 PM!

Select the event profile

Choose "Barbecue" or customize weather criteria!

View analysis results

Check the probability and detailed historical data!

Analyze climate trends

Compare data from the last two decades!

Explore alternative dates

In this example, August 15 showed 100% ideal probability. To demonstrate the alternative feature, we also tested October 24, 2025 (35% probability), which shows suggested nearby dates with better conditions.

Export data for analysis

Download results in CSV or JSON

Scientific Methodology

Data Used

Primary Source: [NASA POWER API](https://power.larc.nasa.gov/)

  • System: Prediction Of Worldwide Energy Resources
  • Analysis Period: 2005-2025 (two decades)
  • Coverage: Global (any point on Earth)
  • Temporal Resolution: Daily or hourly
  • Spatial Resolution: 0.5° × 0.5° (~55km at equator)

Measured Parameters (Adverse Condition Detection):

  • T2M_MAX / T2M_MIN | T2M - Temperature at 2m (°C)
    • Detects: "too hot" or "too cold" conditions
    • Detects: "too wet" conditions (rain)
    • Detects: "too windy" conditions
    • Detects: "too uncomfortable" conditions

Benefits and Impact

For Event Organizers
  • Reduction of cancellations, postponements, and losses
  • Better contingency planning
  • Greater participant satisfaction and safety
For Participants
  • Confidence in event execution
  • Adequate preparation (clothing, equipment)
  • Greater comfort and safety in outdoor activities
For the Community
  • Democratization of access to quality scientific data
  • Evidence-based decisions
  • Awareness of local climate change

Additional Resources

  • NASA POWER API Documentation
  • Source Code on GitHub
  • Application Demo

Conclusion

Answering the Challenge: "Will It Rain on My Parade?"

Yes, now you can know!
This system addresses NASA's challenge by creating an accessible bridge between complex Earth observation scientific data and practical everyday decisions.


Our Contribution:

  • Personalized interface that anyone can use
  • Accurate probabilities** based on NASA historical data (2005-2025)
  • Clear visualizations that make complex data understandable
  • Advance planning that traditional forecasts cannot offer

NASA science serving people. Earth observation data for everyone.

NASA Space Apps Challenge 2025

Challenge: Will it rain on my parade?

Team: Code and Cheese

Technologies Used:

  • Data Source: NASA POWER API
  • Frontend: React, TypeScript, React Router v7
  • Backend: Node.js, Bun
  • Data Analysis: Python, Jupyter Notebook, Machine Learning
  • UI/UX: Tailwind CSS v4, shadcn/ui, Radix UI
  • Maps: Leaflet, React Leaflet
  • Deployment: Vercel, Coolify
  • AI Assistants: Claude Code, Gemini CLI, GitHub Copilot
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Our team utilized AI tools as productivity assistants throughout the development process:

AI Tools Used
  • Claude Code: Code generation, debugging, refactoring, and architecture planning for React components, TypeScript definitions, and NASA POWER API integration.
  • GitHub Copilot: Real-time code suggestions, autocompletion, and boilerplate generation for frontend components and utilities.
  • Gemini CLI: Command-line assistance, script generation, and data processing workflows.
Applications
  • Code Development: Component structure, TypeScript interfaces, data processing logic, and UI implementation
  • Documentation: Technical documentation, README files, and project descriptions
  • Data Analysis: Guidance on statistical methods and Python code for Jupyter Notebooks
Originality Statement

All AI-generated content was reviewed, tested, and modified by our team. AI tools served as assistive technologies only. Original team contributions include:

  • Project concept and problem-solving approach- UI/UX design and user experience flow
  • Data processing methodology and probability algorithms
  • Scientific methodology and analytical frameworks
  • Integration architecture

No AI-generated images, videos, or audio were used. All visualizations were created using legitimate data visualization libraries processing real NASA POWER API data (2005-2025).

challengeDetails.title: Will It Rain On My Parade?
challengeDetails.excerpt: If you’re planning an outdoor event—like a vacation, a hike on a trail, or fishing on a lake—it would be good to know the chances of adverse weather for the time and location you are considering. There are many types of Earth observation data that can provide information on weather conditions for a particular location and day of the year. Your challenge is to construct an app with a personalized interface that enables users to conduct a customized query to tell them the likelihood of “very hot,” “very cold,” “very windy,” “very wet,” or “very uncomfortable” conditions for the location and time they specify. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Project CODENAUTAS
projectDetails.summary:
Climetry is an intelligent, cross-platform assistant for event planning that combines real-time weather forecasts, 10-year climate normals, and NASA disaster tracking (EONET) to deliver clear, actionable guidance. Built with Flutter and Firebase, the app monitors temperature, precipitation, wind, humidity, and UV; compares forecasts to historical patterns; and flags nearby natural hazards (wildfires, severe storms, volcanoes, floods, snow/ice, tropical cyclones).

An AI engine turns this data into concise insights, risk badges (Low/Moderate/High), and specific recommendations for each event type. Users can invite friends, assign roles (Owner/Admin/Moderator/Participant), and receive smart alerts  until the event date.

Climetry addresses the challenge of fragmented, technical climate information by delivering one cohesive view that blends NASA resources with probabilistic context. It’s important because it helps communities and organizers make data-driven, safer, and more sustainable decisions when facing increasingly volatile weather.
projectDetails.details:
Climetry is an intelligent climate monitoring and forecasting platform. It transforms scientific weather data into actionable insights by combining real-time meteorological informationfrom the Meteomatics API (powered by NASA datasets) with AI models from OpenAI (GPT-4o-mini) to generate personalized recommendations, risk badges, and climate impact analyses.

The app provides forecasts up to 180 days, compares them with 10-year climate normals, and tracks temperature, precipitation, wind, UV, and humidity. It also integrates the NASA EONET API for real-time natural disaster tracking (wildfires, storms, floods, volcanoes, and more). Users receive AI-generated insights, smart alerts, and morning notifications before events to help them plan with confidence.

Key benefits include accurate predictions, personalized weather intelligence, and collaborative event managementthrough Firebase synchronization with role-based permissions (Owner, Admin, Moderator, Participant).

Technologies used: Flutter, Dart, Firebase, Meteomatics API, NASA EONET, OpenAI GPT-4o-mini, and Google Maps SDK.
Climetry is creative because it merges NASA’s scientific precision with AI-driven storytelling, turning complex data into clear, accessible guidance. The team prioritized usability, reliability, and accessibility, empowering users to make data-driven, sustainable decisions in a changing climate.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Our team used AI tools responsibly to enhance data interpretation and user experience within the Climetry project.

In-app AI (OpenAI GPT-4o-mini): Used to generate personalized climate insights, event recommendations, and contextual explanations of weather impacts based on NASA-powered data from the Meteomatics API. The AI analyzes forecast data, compares it with historical averages, and produces natural-language insights for users.

No NASA logos, flags, or mission identifiers were used or modified by AI tools.

All AI-assisted outputs are clearly acknowledged in the project documentation and metadata, ensuring full transparency regarding AI contributions.

challengeDetails.title: Will It Rain On My Parade?
challengeDetails.excerpt: If you’re planning an outdoor event—like a vacation, a hike on a trail, or fishing on a lake—it would be good to know the chances of adverse weather for the time and location you are considering. There are many types of Earth observation data that can provide information on weather conditions for a particular location and day of the year. Your challenge is to construct an app with a personalized interface that enables users to conduct a customized query to tell them the likelihood of “very hot,” “very cold,” “very windy,” “very wet,” or “very uncomfortable” conditions for the location and time they specify. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Project Cosbit
projectDetails.summary:
http://72.60.148.155:8617/: Here is the software URL, it is running locally and even though it doesn't have https, don't worry, it is safe. Sorry about that.

What I developed was software that uses a Space Biological Agent and a Data Analyst Agent to analyze and understand documents from space biology experiments and provide practical and objective insights and valuable information from the documents, thus transforming raw data into intelligent data ready for human decision-making and interpretation.This way, the productivity and gains in the work of researchers, scientists, enthusiasts, etc., increase by trying to assimilate and understand what the data is saying.
projectDetails.details:
What benefits does BioExpace offer?

It can extract any data structure you want from the document and provide you with intelligent information based on the context given to it.

This summarizes a lot of manual work and saves human time and energy from reading and understanding numerous documents.

This way, you can get straight to the point. The data is about Space Biology,

which is essential for understanding how life transforms and adapts in space.

BioExpace offers a bridge between knowledge and data generated by NASA professionals

and modern intelligence capable of transforming how you perceive data.

What is the intended impact of the project?

To gather raw data and be able to display valuable information to the end human user, it takes

all the sections (for example, Introduction, Results, Conclusion) of all documents,

analyzes everything, and generates in a practical and useful way information that may be valuable to you,

information that you might spend hours analyzing to find what you're looking for.

Which tools, programming languages, hardware, or software did you use to develop your project?

  • Languages: Python, HTML, CSS, and JavaScript
  • Frameworks:
  • Flask (good for microservices),
  • Ollama (for integrating LLMs on my local machine),
  • TikToken (for token control by chunk)
  • Database: PostgreSQL (used to store data collection, agent pipelines, and the structure of the final result)
  • Final Data Format: JSON (JSONB in PostgreSQL)
  • Hardware: Local server with only CPU, 16GB of RAM, Ubuntu operating system, no cloud dependency.

How is your project creative?

It uses text comprehension models (NLP) to analyze thousands of tokens in documents, assimilate everything, organize everything

and generate valuable information. It allows quick access to information and the possible generation

of new biological hypotheses thanks to what the Agents provide to us humans.

Furthermore, the idea of collaborative cognitive agents (one reads, another interprets) and the fusion of spatial

biology and intelligent data (thanks to AI), the notion of augmented science, and the way

data is transformed into intelligent information for this branch of science.

There are two agents working on multiple scientific documents, reviewing and generating information

What factors did your team consider?

The fact is that today, we humans are always needing more convenience, more objectivity, more speed.

Tools like this, which save 85% of your work time, make you more productive, not to mention that, of course,

the better the LLM model used, the smarter and better your final result will be. We solved that problem of scattered and possibly meaningless data,

bringing relevance in a simple and objective way, whatever your purpose may be. We solve and facilitate your exploration of the data
projectDetails.aiReferences:
In addition to using Qween and LLama for data analysis, I used ChatGPT during development for the frontend; it helped me with corrections in JavaScript, some HTML definitions, and quick styling.

I defined how I wanted the design to look, and he styled it in CSS. I started developing some frontend-backend integrations and requested corrections in the JavaScript in cases of errors.

challengeDetails.excerpt: Enable a new era of human space exploration! projectDetails.name: Comet impact simulator
projectDetails.summary:
Our team developed an interactive website where the user can simulate the impact of various asteroids on different earth locations. The user can utilize known asteroids or create their own with custom properties (velocity, angle, density and diameter). We use the NeoWs API to search and fetch information about a specific asteroid. By visualizing the size of impact effects, our tool can be used to bring awareness about asteroid collisions and their danger.
The impacts presented are: Crater, termic radiation, shockwave and sysmic zone.
projectDetails.details:
This project aims to be an interactive tool where the user can simulate the impact of asteroid on planet earth to better understand their risks and clear common misconceptions.

1 - Main ideia:

A detailed 3d globe of earth that can be spun around and zoomed in and out, the project offers various customization options and shows an estimated impact crater, expected seismic activity, shockwave radius and thermal radiation. The user can select any known asteroid by their name, and their information will be fetched and filled appropriately, after inputting asteroid density (to simulate mass) and entry degree you can choose any location on earth and verify what would happen if an asteroid fell there.

2 - Implementation:

The project works by integrating NeoWs API and NeoWs API for searching and fetching information by name. It uses Cesium API for map information. The credits for all calculations goes to Gareth S. COLLINS, H. Jay MELOSH, and Robert A. MARCUS. Their article is presented below.

3- How to use it:
First, open "impact.html" on Firefox. For a better visualization, make sure the page is full screen. Next,
either search for an asteroid (right side-window) or create a custom one (left side-window). For both
scenerios, inform the angle and the density of the asteroid. Select a place on Earth and you will be able to
see the impacts of the asteroid/meteor on the near area. You can also view informations about the existing
asteroids.
projectDetails.aiReferences: Due to the lack of members on the team (2/5 missing), there was an extensive use of AI, including Chat GPT and Google Gemini. The more complex features of the application (such as 3D map) required multiple corrections by AIs (last minute changes), with also the reduction in the scope of the initial project.

projectDetails.name: Project Cosmos Angle
projectDetails.summary: Summary: We have developed an educational website aimed at children, explaining complex situations about space weather in a relaxed, story-based format. The content is presented in a fun and engaging way for children, using kid-friendly images and explanatory texts. This is important so that children can gain a basic understanding of the space they live in and phenomena that might otherwise seem strange
projectDetails.details:
Project Details:

"Faiska's Journey" is an interactive and illustrated digital story designed to explain the complex phenomenon of space weather to children and the general public. The project functions as a web application that chronicles the journey of "Faiska," an energy spark born on the Sun, who travels to Earth during a Coronal Mass Ejection.

The user can navigate through 10 chapters using next/previous buttons, keyboard arrows, or swipe gestures on touch devices.

  • Visual Feedback: A progress bar at the top of the page indicates the reader's progress through the narrative.
  • Web Technology: The application is built with HTML for structure, CSS for visual styling and animations, and JavaScript to control all interactivity and navigation logic between chapters.
  • Animated Illustrations: Each chapter features animated SVG illustrations that visually represent scientific concepts, such as the "solar sneeze" and Earth's magnetosphere.

Key Features:

  • Educational: It makes a complex scientific topic, like heliophysics and space weather, accessible and understandable to a non-technical audience, including children.
  • Engaging: It uses the power of storytelling and interactivity to create a fun and memorable learning experience, rather than a purely technical explanation.
  • Awareness: It demonstrates the real-world impacts of space weather on our essential daily technologies, such as GPS satellites, power grids, aviation communications, and the safety of astronauts. The educational content details the concepts of Coronal Mass Ejection, Solar Wind, and the Magnetosphere.

Intended Impact:

The intended impact is to demystify space weather and increase public awareness of its importance. By showing how solar eruptions affect ordinary people—such as farmers, pilots, and power grid operators—the project aims to connect space science with people's daily lives. We hope to inspire curiosity about science and highlight the importance of solar monitoring carried out by agencies like NASA to protect our global technological infrastructure.

Technical Specifications:

  • Programming Languages: HTML5, CSS3, and JavaScript for the frontend.
  • Technologies and Tools:
    • SVG (Scalable Vector Graphics): Used for all illustrations, allowing for high-quality visuals and animations.
    • Google Fonts: The "Poppins" and "Roboto" fonts were used for the project's typography.

Design & Strategy:

  • Visual Metaphors: We simplified complex concepts through creative metaphors, such as the Coronal Mass Ejection being a "Great Solar SNEEZE!" and the magnetosphere being a "Magic Shield."
  • Humanized Impact: The project shows the effects of space weather through the stories of different professionals (an astronaut, a pilot, a farmer), making the consequences more concrete and relatable.
  • Immersive Aesthetics: The visual design, with its space theme, stylized illustrations, and smooth animations, creates an immersive experience that invites the user to explore the story.
  • Target Audience: The entire project, from the simple language to the interactivity, was designed to be accessible and interesting for children and the lay public.
  • User Experience (UX): We implemented multiple navigation methods (buttons, keyboard, swipe) to ensure the project is easy to use on both desktops and mobile devices.
  • Scientific Accuracy: Although the story is fictional, it is grounded in real scientific phenomena, ensuring that the educational content is accurate and relevant.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
AI Tools Used:

ChatGPT, Gemini, ClaudeIA

1. Content Generation and Story Scripting:

  • Brainstorming and Structure: We used AI to generate initial ideas for the "Faiska" character's narrative and to structure her journey into 10 chapters.
  • Simplifying Scientific Concepts: AI was a key tool in helping us translate complex scientific concepts from heliophysics (like Coronal Mass Ejection and the magnetosphere) into simple, playful, and accessible language for a young audience, such as the "SOLAR-SNEEZE" metaphor.
  • Text Drafting: We generated initial drafts of the descriptive texts for each chapter. All AI-generated content was subsequently reviewed, edited, and refined by our team to ensure the story's cohesion, tone, and accuracy.

2. Code and Logic Development:

  • Code Assistance (JavaScript/CSS/HTML): We utilized tools like Gemini to speed up development. AI helped us generate the basic structure of JavaScript functions, such as the logic for chapter navigation and updating the progress bar.
  • Debugging: AI was used to identify and suggest fixes for errors in the code, optimizing our development time.

Conclusion: Throughout all stages, AI was treated as a collaborator and an accelerator. The originality, final intent, content curation, and project execution were directed and carried out by our team to ensure a cohesive and creative result that met the challenge's objectives.

challengeDetails.title: Stellar Stories: Space Weather Through the Eyes of Earthlings
challengeDetails.excerpt: Although the Sun is 93 million miles away from our planet, solar activity can significantly impact our daily lives. “Space weather”—the variations that occur in the space environment between the Sun and Earth—can impact technologies in space and on Earth. Your challenge is to write and illustrate a digital children’s story that explains what space weather is and the varying impacts it has on different people such as farmers, pilots, astronauts, power grid operators, and the general public. You can tell the story from the perspective of a person impacted by space weather or from the point of view of a solar flare or coronal mass ejection (CME) as it approaches Earth. (Heliophysics Division)

projectDetails.name: CosmoEX: Simplifying access to space research with AI
projectDetails.summary: We are the team CosmoEX: Explorers of the Cosmos, and our mission is to democratize access to scientific knowledge, making NASA’s discoveries accessible to everyone. To conclude, we developed a conversational platform with artificial intelligence that answers natural-language questions based on official NASA articles, data, and publications. CosmoEX works like an assistant like ChatGPT but focused exclusively on scientific and space content. Thus, when a user types questions such as “What has NASA discovered about bone loss in low-gravity environments?”, they receive contextualized answers grounded in verified sources, plus the source URL of the file, title, authors, and the file identifier (when available) used in the answer—bringing science closer to everyday life.
projectDetails.details:
In a world driven by information, scientific knowledge is one of the most powerful tools for humanity’s advancement. However, access to that knowledge is still unequal. Every day, students, independent researchers, and small-scale scientists face major barriers when trying to find and understand relevant scientific articles processes that is time-consuming, technical, and often discouraging.

In this context, CosmoEX was created with the purpose of democratizing access to research, transforming the pursuit of knowledge into a simple, intuitive, and accessible experience.

Repository Acess - GitHub

The problem

Although scientific research is essential, it is still perceived as inaccessible to most people. In this scenario, university students and small researchers often spend hours—or even days—filtering through hundreds of articles in search of the few that truly contribute to their hypotheses.

Moreover, this difficulty in finding relevant materials is not just a technical challenge, it is also an emotional and social obstacle, since many end up giving up on their projects out of frustration or lack of resources. Consequently, the result is a significant loss of intellectual potential and innovation, especially in developing countries where access to quality scientific information remains limited.

The gap

Despite the vast availability of open data and scientific articles, the bridge between information and the people who seek it is still fragile due to current research platforms, which frequently become complex and unintuitive. In other words, there is a chasm between curiosity and knowledge—and this is precisely the gap that CosmoEX aims to bridge.

Our solution

CosmoEX is a conversational artificial intelligence designed to simplify and accelerate access to scientific research by using data and articles provided by NASA, assembling a RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) setup to constrain the model to answer only based on the provided documents. Through a chat-like interface, the user can ask questions in natural language, for example:

“What has NASA discovered about bone loss in low-gravity environments?”

The AI processes the question via a vector to search for similar information in its vector database and responds in a contextualized and reliable manner, along with a link to the full article when available. With CosmoEX, students and researchers can converse directly with knowledge, saving time and opening new doors for discoveries.

How it works

First, when the user accesses the web platform, they encounter a chat interface where they can ask questions about NASA articles previously made available for the challenge. When the user types and sends a question, the platform performs a similarity search between the question and the documents in the platform’s repository.



If it finds an answer in parts of the documents, it will respond with that answer, showing its confidence level and two charts: one showing how many parts of each document were retrieved as similar, and another showing the frequency of relevant repeated terms (excluding conjunctions). If it does not find a document that answers the question, it will reply that it does not have sufficient data to answer. In this way, the search optimizes time spent researching articles and helps democratize access to information with the aim of being less burdensome.


Implementation details

DATA PIPELINES

First, a data pipeline was used with several steps to extract all the initial scientific articles—the 608—and later part of the complementary articles, totaling more than 1,500 files that went through the pipeline. Its steps are:

  • Sources: Collection of articles in multiple formats—CSV, PDF, and various NASA datasets (with a focus on biology, human research physics)—using Python scripts with libraries such as Beautiful Soup and Selenium; converting everything to a standard JSON format organized into fields (title, authors, content, etc.), and filtering the acquired data.
  • Transformations: Python preprocessing scripts convert the data to lemmatized JSON using the NLTK library, organized into two fields—content and metadata—in addition to standard data refinement.
  • Embeddings: Creation of semantic vectors with LangChain after splitting into 1,536-token chunks with an overlap of 384, and OpenAI’s text-embedding-3-small model, stored in the Qdrant Vector Database for similarity queries based on content while taking metadata into account.

BACKEND

  • Framework: FastAPI

Python was used with the FastAPI framework to create REST endpoints, ensuring high performance and connection with the virtual interface, using a connection with QRant to search by similarity with a confidence score and using the LangChain and OpenAI libraries—using the same model (text-embedding-3-small) to embed the question—and, for the Q&A response flow, gpt-5-nano. It builds the LangChain Q&A pipeline with the retriever using the QRant documents and answers based on the returned chunks and indicates when it cannot answer due to a lack of documents. This provides a robust response flow that also generates two charts with data from the chunks and metadata.

FRONTEND

  • Stack: Application developed with Node.js + React + Vite + TailwindCSS, offering a responsive and modern interface.
    • Search for articles based on metadata or semantic similarity.
    • Dynamic dashboards with interactive visualizations generated for each question, using the chunks employed in the answer and their metadata.
    • Direct integration with the backend to display results in real time.

INFRASTRUCTURE

  • Containerization: Use of Docker and Docker Compose to orchestrate Backend, Frontend, and the QRant Vector Database services.
  • Dependencies: All libraries and versions controlled in requirements.txt (Python) and package.json (Node.js).
  • Scalability: Modular architecture allows future expansion to new data sources and integrations.

Impact

CosmoEX has the potential to revolutionize access to scientific research by drastically reducing the time spent searching for relevant information. In this context, it democratizes knowledge, enabling students, enthusiasts, and independent scientists to explore NASA data in a simple way, eliminating technical and linguistic barriers.

With this tool, more people will be able to participate actively in building scientific knowledge, stimulating critical thinking, innovation, and interest in science. In the long term, this means a more informed, collaborative society prepared to tackle global challenges—exactly as NASA has always inspired.

Conclusion

In conclusion, CosmoEX represents the meeting point of technology, curiosity, and purpose. More than a platform, it is a movement in favor of democratizing science, because by transforming complex data into accessible knowledge, our project seeks to inspire new generations of explorers, not only of space, but of understanding itself.
projectDetails.aiReferences: Open IA model (gpt-5-nano)AI and Text-Embedding-3-Small have been used in various purposes, for Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) in the Q&A flow, Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), and, with Gemini 2.5 Pro and  Student Licensed GitHub Copilot , troubleshooting, topic research, writing improvement, code generation and refinement.

projectDetails.name: Project Cronistas Estelares
projectDetails.summary: We developed an educational website that presents space weather in an interactive and engaging way. The platform includes scientific explanations of solar storms, a digital story about a young girl learning from a friendly robot, and a quiz game to reinforce learning. This combination addresses the challenge by making complex space weather concepts accessible, understandable, and engaging for people of all ages. The project is important because it raises awareness of space weather, encourages scientific curiosity, and shares NASA’s research in a creative and interactive format, inspiring users to explore and learn about the universe.
projectDetails.details:
Our project is an educational website created to present the topic of space weather in an interactive, accessible, and engaging way. It brings together scientific information about what space weather is, how it affects people and technology on Earth, and how NASA studies these phenomena.

The website also features a digital story about a young girl who, in a dream, learns about solar storms and space weather with the help of a friendly robot. Through this narrative, we aim to spark curiosity and interest in science and astronomy, especially among children, but also among people of all ages.

In addition, we developed an educational quiz game that allows users to test what they have learned in a fun and interactive way. Although the project does not include audio or video, its visual design and storytelling were carefully planned to ensure an immersive and educational experience.

The main goals of the project are to raise awareness about space weather, encourage scientific education, and share NASA’s knowledge in a simple, creative, and accessible way.

To develop the project, we used Google Docs for writing and organization, Canva for visual design, and Base44 as the development platform. The images and visual elements were created with the help of artificial intelligence tools such as ChatGPT and Perplexity, along with contributions from digital illustrators who enhanced the artistic material.

The creativity of the project lies in combining storytelling, science, and interactivity within a digital educational environment, transforming complex heliophysics and space weather concepts into something understandable, inspiring, and captivating for young learners.

Our team carefully considered the target audience and their needs, researching ways to present NASA’s missions and studies in a simplified, engaging, and meaningful format, helping inspire a new generation of curious minds about the universe.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
The AI tools that we used to develop our project were:

Base44 platform, which help us to build our website.

ChatGPT to generate images and refining ideas.

Perplexity to generate images.

Canva to edit images.

Elevenlabs to generate an audio.

challengeDetails.title: Stellar Stories: Space Weather Through the Eyes of Earthlings
challengeDetails.excerpt: Although the Sun is 93 million miles away from our planet, solar activity can significantly impact our daily lives. “Space weather”—the variations that occur in the space environment between the Sun and Earth—can impact technologies in space and on Earth. Your challenge is to write and illustrate a digital children’s story that explains what space weather is and the varying impacts it has on different people such as farmers, pilots, astronauts, power grid operators, and the general public. You can tell the story from the perspective of a person impacted by space weather or from the point of view of a solar flare or coronal mass ejection (CME) as it approaches Earth. (Heliophysics Division)

challengeDetails.title: Build a Space Biology Knowledge Engine
challengeDetails.excerpt: Enable a new era of human space exploration! NASA has been performing biology experiments in space for decades, generating a tremendous amount of information that will need to be considered as humans prepare to revisit the Moon and explore Mars. Although this knowledge is publicly available, it can be difficult for potential users to find information that pertains to their specific interests. Your challenge is to build a dynamic dashboard that leverages artificial intelligence (AI), knowledge graphs, and/or other tools to summarize a set of NASA bioscience publications and enables users to explore the impacts and results of the experiments these publications describe. (Earth Science Division)
