challengeDetails.title: Sharks from Space
challengeDetails.excerpt: Earth’s ocean is one of the most powerful habitats in our universe, supporting a range of life that sustains ecosystems and habitability across the globe. It is common to measure photosynthetic activity in the ocean from space, but far more challenging to track top predators. Your challenge is to create a mathematical framework for identifying sharks and predicting their foraging habitats using NASA satellite data, and also to suggest a new conceptual model of a tag (a small electronic device that can be attached to an animal to track and study its movement) that could measure not only where sharks are, but also what they are eating, and in real time transmit that data back to users to enable development of predictive models. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: DataLab Exoplanet Hunters: AI in the Search for Distant Worlds
projectDetails.summary:
As part of the NASA Global Challenge A World Away: Hunting for Exoplanets with AI, the DataLab team developed an artificial intelligence-based solution to accelerate the identification of potential exoplanets within large volumes of astrophysical data. We used the LightGBM model, an advanced decision tree-based machine learning technique known for its speed and high performance in classification tasks.

Our system was trained to analyze light curves — records that show variations in the brightness of stars over time — and detect subtle patterns that may indicate the transit of planets in front of those stars. To achieve this, we applied feature engineering techniques, noise reduction in the data, cross-validation, and hyperparameter optimization, building a robust, efficient, and reproducible pipeline.

This approach not only enables the automation and scaling of exoplanet candidate screening, but also frees up astronomers' time for deeper investigation. The project highlights the potential of artificial intelligence as a powerful ally in space exploration and in advancing human knowledge about worlds beyond our solar system.
projectDetails.details:
About the DataLab Exoplanet Hunters Project

DataLab Exoplanet Hunters is an interactive platform designed to assist researchers and professionals in detecting and analyzing exoplanets using real astrophysical data from missions such as NASA’s K2 mission. Through an intuitive interface, users can upload their own datasets, which then undergo an automated preprocessing phase. During this step, the platform identifies and classifies variables, whether categorical or numerical. Next, AI-powered predictive models with predefined hyperparameters analyze the data to identify potential exoplanet candidates.

The project aims to simplify the application of data science and artificial intelligence in astrophysics, offering a fast, accurate, and accessible solution for exoplanet detection.

Benefits of DataLab Exoplanet Hunters

Detecting exoplanets requires careful analysis of complex astrophysical data, a process that can be time-consuming and prone to human error. DataLab Exoplanet Hunters helps overcome these challenges by automating critical analysis steps, reducing processing time, and increasing accuracy in identifying candidates. Additionally, the platform provides clear visual outputs to assist with interpretation. This enables researchers to focus more on scientific validation and less on repetitive data tasks, streamlining the path to new discoveries.

Expected Impact of the Project

The main goal of DataLab Exoplanet Hunters is to save researchers time and effort by automating manual calculations and data preparation, thus increasing productivity and allowing scientists to dedicate more attention to activities requiring deeper analysis and interpretation. Moreover, the platform has educational potential, serving as a tool to engage students and early-career scientists with real space mission data and advanced AI techniques.

Technologies and Tools Used

The project was developed using Python, with development environments such as Visual Studio Code and Google Colab. Libraries like Pandas, NumPy, Scikit-learn, and Matplotlib were employed for data manipulation and analysis. AI assistance was provided by tools such as Gemini, ChatGPT, Perplexity, and GitHub Copilot. Cloud-based resources were used for model testing and experimentation, ensuring flexibility and scalability.

Creative Aspects of the Project

The innovation of DataLab Exoplanet Hunters lies in its ability to bridge astrophysics and artificial intelligence in a practical and accessible way. The platform allows users to perform predictive analysis with just a few clicks, regardless of their machine learning expertise. This breaks down technical barriers and encourages broader participation in space science. Furthermore, the project supports open science by making advanced tools available to a wider community of learners and researchers.

Factors Considered by the Team

Throughout development, the team prioritized usability by ensuring a simple and intuitive interface. They also focused on technical simplicity to make the platform accessible to non-experts, speed to handle large datasets efficiently, scalability to support real mission-scale data, and reliability to deliver consistent and replicable results using robust AI models.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
We used artificial intelligence tools, specifically Gemini 2.5 Pro and ChatGPT 5, to support our project in the following ways:

Analysis and Interpretation of Results: AI was used to assist in analyzing the data collected and interpreting the results, helping us draw conclusions more effectively.

Translation Support: AI tools were used to help translate and refine the language used in the project documentation and presentations, ensuring clarity and accuracy across languages.

No code or datasets were directly generated by AI. All code was written and validated by the team.

challengeDetails.title: A World Away: Hunting for Exoplanets with AI
challengeDetails.excerpt: Data from several different space-based exoplanet surveying missions have enabled discovery of thousands of new planets outside our solar system, but most of these exoplanets were identified manually. With advances in artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML), it is possible to automatically analyze large sets of data collected by these missions to identify exoplanets. Your challenge is to create an AI/ML model that is trained on one or more of the open-source exoplanet datasets offered by NASA and that can analyze new data to accurately identify exoplanets. (Astrophysics Division)

projectDetails.name: EcoAlerta Fogo Zero
projectDetails.summary: The relevance of our solution lies in the growing increase of urban and peri-urban fires in the Ribeirão Preto region, which release toxic smoke that directly impacts public health (especially respiratory and cardiovascular) and public safety. Our solution, EcoAlerta Fogo Zero, is a monitoring platform that uses NASA satellite data to map fire outbreaks in real time, forested areas, and high-risk ignition zones. As a preventive measure, the platform aggregates information on fire-resistant tree species commonly used as Green Windbreaks, providing useful data and guiding users on how to acquire seedlings of these species through the Seedling Marketplace, where we connect the platform with public programs, NGOs, and companies. This enables the empowerment of citizens, planners, and urban managers by translating complex data into concrete actions, mitigating fire spread, protecting infrastructure and air quality, and directly impacting the safety and resilience of the population. In this way, we create robust and sustainable Data Pathways for safer, healthier, and climate-resilient Cities and Human Settlements.
projectDetails.details:
What Does the Project Do and How Does It Work?

EcoAlerta Fogo Zero is a geospatial web platform focused on fire prevention and resilience in Ribeirão Preto area, using remote sensing data to guide practical fire-resistance actions.

What it Does:

1. Real-Time Risk Monitoring: Maps active fire outbreaks (immediate alert) and forested areas, correlating the data to display modeled Ignition Risk information, identifying areas with the highest probability of fire due to their proximity to active fire spots.

2. Green Prevention Solution: Provides a Species Library focused on fire-resistant plants (low combustibility, high water retention) ideal for creating “Green Windbreaks” around properties and sensitive areas.

3. Enabling Action: Connects users with suppliers through the Seedling Marketplace, turning knowledge from the map into concrete action on the ground.

How it Works (Data Flow):

The backend ingests satellite data from NASA and the World Resources Institute. These datasets are processed to plot heat spots on the interactive map. The platform cross-references fire alerts with Tree Cover Mapping to provide users with information about areas at risk of ignition.

What Are the Benefits of the Project?

The project delivers direct environmental, health, and economic benefits:

• Health Impact Mitigation: By preventing or limiting the scale of fires, it drastically reduces smoke and toxic particle emissions, protecting the respiratory and cardiovascular health of urban populations.

• Safety and Asset Protection: Strategic planting of windbreaks actively protects properties, crops, and critical city infrastructure.

• Optimization of Public Resources: Enables civil defense agencies and the Fire Department to reallocate firefighting resources to high-risk areas identified by our map, saving time and money.

• Community Empowerment: Equips citizens and rural producers to act as the first line of defense against fires through green infrastructure practices.

• Tree Planting Incentives: Facilitates increased tree planting in regions most affected by fire outbreaks, improving air quality, shade, and local microclimates, while also increasing carbon sequestration in the region.

What Is the Intended Impact of the Project?

The main intended impact is to establish a new data-driven standard for fire prevention in Brazil. We aim to achieve:

1. Measurable Reduction: A decrease in the number and total area of annual fires in Ribeirão Preto over the next five years, as a direct result of the implementation of Green Windbreaks guided by the platform.

2. Replicable Model: That EcoAlerta Fogo Zero serves as an open-source model for other medium-sized cities, especially those in fire-prone biomes such as the Cerrado.

3. Data Pathways for Health: Linking fire data urgency to the need for resilient afforestation, demonstrating that strategic planting is a direct tool for public health and smart urban planning.

Which Tools, Languages, and Software Did You Use?

• Programming Language:

◦ Python – Main language used for processing scripts, geometry manipulation, GeoJSON file handling, and generation of the interactive map.

• Libraries & Frameworks:

◦ GeoPandas: Efficient manipulation of geospatial data and creation of GeoDataFrames (vector data structure).

◦ Shapely: Execution of geometric operations such as bounding box creation, intersection tests (geom.intersects), and geometry simplification.

◦ Folium: Generation of the final interactive HTML map for result visualization.

◦ Pandas: Structuring tabular data and calculating statistics (e.g., average coverage per tile).

◦ Pathlib / OS / JSON: File path manipulation for code portability and reading/writing GeoJSON files.

• Frontend:

◦ Programming Language: TypeScript

◦ Libraries & Frameworks: React, Leaflet

• Data Sources:

◦ Tropical Tree Cover – WRI Dataset: https://datasets.wri.org/datasets/tropical-tree-cover

◦ FIRMS – Fire Information for Resource Management System – NASA Dataset: https://firms.modaps.eosdis.nasa.gov/map/#d:24hrs;@-45.8,-27.3,4.2z

What Is Creative About Your Project?

The creativity of EcoAlerta Fogo Zero lies in bridging two domains that usually do not communicate: real-time disaster monitoring and long-term silviculture.

Instead of merely alerting users about a fire outbreak (reaction), the platform provides a proactive and ecological solution (planting). It transitions from an alert system to a resilience system. We use NASA data not only to identify the problem but also to prescribe the greenest and smartest solution for the city’s future. These proactive actions not only mitigate long-term fire risks but also increase tree cover in vulnerable areas, improving the local microclimate and enhancing carbon sequestration and storage.

What Factors Did Your Team Consider?

1. Climate and Biome Factor: Full focus on the Cerrado biome and Ribeirão Preto’s drought conditions. In recent years, the region has suffered large-scale fires, spreading toxic smoke clouds over long distances, with smoke and acid rain phenomena recorded up to 400 km away. The Species Library prioritizes native or adapted plants with high water retention and low flammability.

2. Community Factor: Usability was a priority. The map must be simple enough for any citizen to understand risk, and the planting solution must be accessible (hence the Seedling Marketplace and recommendations for easy-to-grow species).

3. Scalability and Feasibility Factor: We used only open data and open-source technologies to ensure the project is economically viable and easily scalable to other Brazilian cities, fulfilling a key hackathon requirement.

Links:

https://github.com/data-roots-org/web-app

https://github.com/data-roots-org/data_extraction

projectDetails.name: NASA Weather Forecast
projectDetails.summary: An application was created that receives a user's location (city, state, etc.), a specific date, and time. The code then consumes a weather API to obtain a set of historical weather metrics from previous years. The challenge of weather forecasting was addressed with a time-series modeling strategy. We used Prophet, a robust algorithm optimized for data with strong seasonality and trends, such as weather metrics. The API provided the historical data needed to train and tune the model, allowing it to identify annual, weekly, and daily patterns to generate an accurate forecast. The ability to predict the weather early and accurately is crucial in several areas. This is essential for agricultural planning (planting and harvesting), risk management (preventing natural disasters), energy optimization, and, on a personal level, for event and travel planning. The project demonstrates the practical application of data science to make more informed and strategic decisions.
projectDetails.details:
The project informs the user of the weather forecast for a chosen date and location. This is done by consuming an API that provides weather information from recent years. With this data, it is formatted appropriately, an AI model is trained based on the Prophet algorithm. After training, the model is able to predict the weather pattern in a given period of time. From this period of time, the date selected by the user is filtered and the information is presented to him.

This project allows users to plan future activities (travel, outdoor events, agriculture, etc.) based on solid weather expectations, reducing uncertainty and maximizing the efficiency of their plans. The project provides individuals or small groups with a powerful tool to understand historical and future climate trends for a specific location. Instead of presenting complex graphs or raw data, the impact is to create an intuitive experience where the complexity of machine learning (Prophet) is left behind the scenes, focusing on delivering clear and actionable information.

The most significant impact is allowing users to make decisions based on climate information projected for weeks or months in the future. Unlike operational models that are accurate for only a few days, our solution, based on the Prophet algorithm and historical data, establishes weather patterns for distant dates. This is crucial for:

-Logistics and Supply Chain: Predicting conditions for the transportation of goods.

-Agriculture: Planning planting, harvesting, and water resource management.

-Tourism and Events: Booking and organizing events with greater confidence in the weather trend.

For the project's development, the programming languages Python, for the data science application, and JavaScript, along with HTML and CSS, were used to build a simple and interactive user page. The VSCode IDE and Colab software were also used for code development. The Giovanni API, https://disc.gsfc.nasa.gov/information/documents?title=Giovanni%20In%20The%20Cloud:%20Time%20Series%20Service, was used for collecting climate information. The Address Validation API, https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation/address-validation/overview?hl=pt_BR, was used to find the coordinates of the location the user entered. Meanwhile, the Leaflet.js library was used to create the map that shows the location the user searched for, creating the map via the open-source OpenStreetMap service. And in terms of hardware, 5 notebooks were required for development, one for each team member.

The project's creativity lies in the intelligent orchestration of advanced tools to solve a common problem in an effective and user-focused manner. The creativity is manifested in the processing pipeline: from the consumption of historical data from an API to its formatting for model training. This stage of transforming raw data into a format that the AI can learn from builds an efficient bridge between the data source and the prediction engine.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Our project's development made strategic use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools on two distinct fronts:

Development Optimization with Generative AIs (ChatGPT and Gemini): These platforms were primarily employed as coding assistants. Their use focused on script validation and optimization, allowing us to identify and correct syntax errors, as well as refine the programming logic. This resulted in a more agile development process and high-quality code.

Data Modeling and Forecasting with Machine Learning (Prophet): The Prophet algorithm was the centerpiece of the project's execution. It is a machine learning model used specifically for time series analysis and forecasting, and it was responsible for processing the data and generating the final result presented to the user.

projectDetails.name: Asan and the Space Diary
projectDetails.summary:
The project developed an interactive digital book for elementary school students, aiming to make concepts about space weather and its relationship to life on Earth accessible and engaging. Although the Sun is 93 million miles away, its activity can directly impact our daily lives, interfering with technology, communications, and even agriculture.
In the story, Asan, a curious boy with a passion for space, and Estela, his creative friend, find a lost astronaut's diary. From these mysterious pages, the two embark on an adventure of discovery about the Sun, the universe, and the importance of NASA's research for the good of humanity.
In a playful and poetic way, the book stimulates scientific curiosity, creative thinking, and care for shared knowledge, inviting children to explore, imagine, and record their own ideas—like true space explorers.
projectDetails.details: This project offers a digital and interactive educational tool designed for elementary school students. The work elucidates some concepts about space weather. Our intended benefit is to facilitate the study and understanding of solar weather, enabling diverse audiences to gain an easy understanding of the topic and, of course, sparking a desire to learn more. The tool highlights the practical relevance of the topic, demonstrating how solar activity directly impacts daily life, from satellite operation to food production. We used the Canva and we edited the video in CapCut platform to develop the digital interactive material. We used Professor Luciana Soares Muniz's "Idea Diary" methodology as a basis for our work, which we collaborate with on an extension project at the university, combining research, extension, and teaching.
projectDetails.aiReferences: We used Google's artificial intelligence (Gemini AI) to create animations of our drawings for posting on the "Diário de Ideias" project's YouTube channel. We created the animations with the intention of attaching links to the digital material to make it more interactive and fun.

node.title: Earth Trailblazers
node.excerpt: A couple vibing with coding, design, and data analysis, on a mission to explore and innovate by transforming complex data into impactful solutions :)

projectDetails.name: METEORIS by Earth Trailblazers
projectDetails.summary:
We, the Earth Trailblazers team, developed METEORIS, an innovative web application designed to be a true lifesaver for tourists planning trips anywhere in Brazil. Through an intuitive and interactive interface, users can search for a destination city or select it directly on an interactive map. By specifying the month and year of their planned trip, they receive detailed climate predictions, including average minimum and maximum temperatures, rainfall in millimeters, and the probability of rain.

Beyond forecasts, METEORIS displays insightful historical weather graphs generated from NASA Earth observation data spanning 2007–2025, enhancing the model’s reliability. The app also provides personalized travel tips based on predicted conditions, helping users plan better experiences.

This solution addresses NASA’s challenge “Will it rain on my parade?” by going beyond short-term forecasts — offering long-term, data-driven planning for travelers, months or even years in advance. METEORIS stands out for its relevance: while many apps predict short-term weather, few empower users to anticipate future climate tendencies and avoid unpleasant surprises during their dream trips.
projectDetails.details:
Overview
METEORIS is an AI-powered web application that predicts future climate conditions for any location in Brazil, based on the month and year selected by the user. The system provides mean temperature and precipitation, interactive climate plots, and travel recommendations tailored to the expected weather. It helps tourists plan their trips in advance, while also offering a data-driven dashboard for climate analysis enthusiasts.

To make the experience seamless, METEORIS integrates the Google Maps API, which enables users to search for or select cities directly on an interactive map. The API’s Autocomplete feature was essential to ensure accurate city identification, while its Geocoding service converts the city name into precise latitude and longitude coordinates — the input format required by our prediction model. This integration made it possible for the frontend, backend, and AI model to communicate efficiently, ensuring that forecasts and plots correspond exactly to the user’s chosen location.

Dataset
The dataset was built from NASA Earth observation data provided by the Global Earth Science Data and Information Service (GES DISC). Data were collected from three sources:

  • M2TMNXSLV (surface and atmospheric variables),
  • M2TMNXRAD (radiation data), and
  • M2TMNXFLX (precipitation and flux data).

We used the EarthAccess API to authenticate and download data between 2007 and 2025, filtered specifically for Brazil’s geographic boundaries (latitude −33° to 5°, longitude −74° to −35°).
The dataset includes the following variables:

  • T2M – Air temperature 2 meters above the surface
  • QV2M – Specific humidity
  • PS – Surface pressure
  • SWGDN – Solar radiation at ground level
  • PRECTOT – Total surface precipitation

All data were consolidated into monthly averages and stored in Parquet and CSV formats for high performance and compatibility.

Machine Learning Model
We trained a LightGBM MultiOutputRegressor using Python, Pandas, NumPy, and Scikit-learn to predict temperature and precipitation simultaneously for any given latitude, longitude, month, and year combination in Brazil. This approach was chosen for its high efficiency and robustness when dealing with large, multi-variable datasets.

Data Preparation and Feature Engineering
Before training, the dataset underwent several preprocessing steps to ensure data quality and model readiness:

  • Cleaning: Removed unnecessary or redundant columns (e.g., day, hour, week_day) to reduce noise.
  • Unit Conversion: Transformed temperature values from Kelvin to Celsius and humidity values from fraction to percentage, improving interpretability.
  • Geospatial Filtering: Retained only data points within Brazil’s official geographic boundaries.
  • Feature Creation: Extracted month and year from the time column and generated new columns for minimum and maximum temperature, applying a tolerance of ±3–4°C to capture variability.
  • Normalization: Scaled all features using StandardScaler to ensure uniform input distribution across the model.

Model Training and Evaluation
The final dataset contained over 1 million samples covering the period from 2007 to 2025. It was split into 80% for training and 20% for testing, maintaining consistent random states for reproducibility.
We used Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LightGBM) due to its strong performance in handling non-linear relationships, missing values, and high-dimensional data.

During training, the model optimized the L2 loss function, using 500 boosting iterations with early stopping criteria to prevent overfitting. Cross-validation was applied to tune hyperparameters such as:

  • learning_rate = 0.05
  • num_leaves = 31
  • max_depth = -1 (unrestricted)
  • n_estimators = 500

The model achieved the following performance metrics on the test dataset:

  • R² (Coefficient of Determination): 0.92
  • MAE (Mean Absolute Error): 0.17
  • MSE (Mean Squared Error): 0.10

These results indicate excellent predictive accuracy and low variance between the training and validation sets. The trained model and its corresponding scaler were exported using Joblib, enabling seamless loading through the FastAPI backend for real-time inference.

Comparing with the Meteomatics Forecast
To validate the reliability of our model, we compared its predictions against Meteomatics, a recognized global weather forecasting platform. Using Ubatuba (Brazil) as the reference city, the Meteomatics forecast reported an average temperature of 24.85°C, while our model predicted 24.92°C — a negligible difference of 0.07°C.
This near-perfect alignment demonstrates the robustness and precision of the LightGBM model, confirming that it accurately captures Brazil’s climatic patterns. A Meteomatics chart was also analyzed to visually verify the matching behavior between both datasets.

Visualization and Recommendations
All data visualizations in METEORIS were developed internally using Matplotlib and Seaborn, ensuring full control and transparency over the analysis process. These plots illustrate 18 years of historical climate trends for temperature, precipitation, humidity, and solar radiation across Brazil, helping users visualize seasonal variations and long-term patterns.

The system generates interactive time-series charts that allow users to identify ideal travel months and regions with favorable weather conditions. These insights not only support travelers but also serve as valuable references for researchers and data analysts interested in climate evolution.

While Meteomatics was referenced only for validation purposes, its data was never used within the model or visualizations. It served solely as an external benchmark to confirm the accuracy of METEORIS predictions, ensuring the credibility of the results derived from NASA’s Earth observation data.

In addition, METEORIS provides automatic travel recommendations based on the predicted climate for each city, guiding users to explore destinations that align with their preferred weather conditions.

Frontend

This project aims to help society prepare for upcoming climate changes and seasonal variations in their cities or leisure destinations.

We drew inspiration from the layouts of companies such as GitHub, my work and Google, always prioritizing simplicity and ease of use. The goal is to provide a smooth and intuitive experience, aligned with the technologies used — such as React — which focus on speed and efficiency.

Technology Stack

  • Python (Data processing, ML, and API with FastAPI)
  • LightGBM, Scikit-learn, Pandas, NumPy
  • Matplotlib, Seaborn for visualization
  • React (frontend)
  • C# (backend)

Impact and Creativity

METEORIS transforms NASA’s open climate data into actionable intelligence, bridging the gap between environmental science, technology, and tourism. By merging predictive analytics with intuitive visualization, the project enables people to understand and plan around climate conditions in a way that was previously accessible only to scientists and researchers.

Its impact extends beyond tourism: METEORIS serves as a powerful educational and analytical tool that democratizes access to decades of NASA Earth observation data. It allows users — from travelers to data scientists — to explore how temperature, precipitation, and humidity patterns evolve over time, fostering climate awareness and data literacy in a practical, engaging format.

The project’s creative strength lies in its fusion of artificial intelligence, data science, and geospatial intelligence within a single, lightweight platform. While traditional weather apps focus on short-term forecasts, METEORIS innovates by projecting long-term climate tendencies months or even years in advance, offering valuable insights for sustainability, travel planning, and environmental research.

In essence, METEORIS embodies the spirit of the NASA Space Apps Challenge: it takes complex Earth data and transforms it into something human, useful, and inspiring, empowering individuals to make informed decisions while connecting with the planet in a smarter and more meaningful way.

challengeDetails.title: Will It Rain On My Parade?
challengeDetails.excerpt: If you’re planning an outdoor event—like a vacation, a hike on a trail, or fishing on a lake—it would be good to know the chances of adverse weather for the time and location you are considering. There are many types of Earth observation data that can provide information on weather conditions for a particular location and day of the year. node.title: EcoLife

projectDetails.name: Project EcoLife
projectDetails.summary: Our project proposes improvements for cities to become sustainable. Based on data from the city of Uberlândia, we devised solutions to these problems that can also be used in other cities around the world. After discussions, we determined that the starting point for making cities sustainable required: population waste management, sustainable energy efficiency, ecological parks and green areas within the city, efficient transportation, and better nutrition/food access. By identifying these urban problems, it is possible to solve them through planning to bring benefits to the population of our city, and beyond Uberlândia, many other cities facing similar issues can apply these solutions. Large cities tend to be less sustainable. Sustainability, anchored by the environmental, social, and economic spheres, is, however, growing in importance. Uberlândia is the city with the highest growth in industrial GDP. Our project aims to create improvements for urban centers by implementing various measures to make cities sustainable. Following discussions, we decided that the focus for this is Environmental Education, which will guarantee educated and aware citizens, followed by actions for: better management of waste produced by the population, better energy efficiency through sustainable means, more ecological parks and green areas throughout the city, efficient transportation, and better nutrition/food access.
projectDetails.details:
Introduction

The NASA Space Apps Challenge hackathon, organized by NASA - the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, is an event that brings together people from all over the world. Its objective is to present problems to participants so they can submit plausible solutions for them.

We are residents of Uberlândia, a city located in Minas Gerais, Brazil. Five of us are 2nd-year high school students integrated into the Systems Development course, while our last member is a 9th-grade student at the ESEBA-UFU middle school.

To participate in the Hackathon, we chose the theme "Data Pathways to Healthy Cities and Human Settlements" because Uberlândia fits the pattern of rapidly growing cities, and we thought we could develop strategies to make our city more sustainable.

We know that the world, even with research alerting us about the state of our planet, continues to maintain unsustainable habits. Large cities are often using the word "sustainability" as a form of propaganda and ignoring its true values.

The city of Uberlândia seems to tend towards being sustainable, but even so, we can see situations where "sustainability" is used incorrectly. Thus, considering what was highlighted in the information about the theme we chose, we thought of four topics that, for us, stood out, both as areas of our interest and as obstacles that are prominent in the daily lives of us, residents of Uberlândia.

During the meetings, we realized that every time we arrived at a solution, we faced the problem of the lack of environmental education, therefore, discussing it becomes extremely important.

Environmental education is an educational practice that involves the study and learning between members of a society, applying their skills in complex and multi-tasks, and the environment. In this way, the educated individual transforms into an active and transforming agent in reactions concerning environmental conservation.

It's always interesting to emphasize during environmental education lessons that the "environment" isn't just forests and conservation areas: the environment is, especially, the places we are inserted in, whether it's our neighborhood, school, home, or city. Therefore, this education reinforces that the responsibility for conservation is also local and manifests in every action within the community.

Thus, we emphasize that for all proposed actions, the implementation of environmental education will be necessary. It is the fundamental tool that enables the individual to understand their role in the collective. It is through this awareness process that we transform knowledge into conscious action, ensuring that the solutions found are not only applied but also sustainable and long-lasting, as real change begins with the formation of the responsible citizen.

Justification

The present study is justified by the urgent need to develop and propose sustainable urban development strategies that effectively address the challenges posed by accelerated population growth. The research focuses on the city of Uberlândia to analyze critical shortcomings that require interventions based on concrete data and technological innovations. The relevance of this work is established by confronting four identified problematic axes, for which specific solutions are proposed.

The first area of intervention aims to address Food Security and Urban Health. The challenge of ensuring access to quality food and green areas is met by implementing Urban Agroforestry Systems (SAFs) and expanding Local Parks. These actions are vital for mitigating the heat island effect and promoting equity in access to organic foods.

Secondly, the problem of improper disposal and low recycling rates is tackled with a Waste Management strategy based on fiscal incentives, such as an IPTU (Urban Property Tax) abatement. This measure aims to stimulate citizen participation and factory engagement, strengthening the local production chain and boosting the circular economy.

The third axis deals with Energy Resilience and Climate Mitigation, where dependence on polluting sources is combatted by promoting photovoltaic solar energy (with tax relief for citizens) and by better utilizing the biogas generated in landfills.

A crucial technical differentiator is the utilization of geospatial data (NASA/Copernicus satellites). This innovative approach guarantees technical precision and transparency in diagnosing social and ecological vulnerabilities, allowing for more efficient and strategic urban planning.

In short, the study contributes a model of urban planning that unites technological innovation, sustainability, and social equity. All proposed solutions are, ultimately, catalyzed by Environmental Education, which acts as the fundamental vector for internalizing the sense of responsibility and ensuring the long-term sustainability of the proposed actions.

General Objective

The objective is to implement measures to improve the quality of life in urban centers based on the observations we made in the city of Uberlândia. Based on the data gathered by NASA, it's possible to observe patterns and collect useful information so that an adequate planning can be done for cities that are experiencing rapid growth, such as Uberlândia.

Specific Objectives

We divided our specific objectives into the following topics:

  • Research general information on the topics we selected from the text "Potential Considerations" made available on the NASA Space Apps Challenge page about the theme we chose.
  • Conduct research on potential solutions to the problems that can be applied in the localities that fit our theme.
  • Analyze the applicability of systems with NASA data as one of the tools for better urban planning.
  • Relate the problems and proposed solutions to the municipality of Uberlândia.
Methodology

The development of this work was conducted in three main phases, combining collaborative analysis with in-depth research, using a diverse set of digital tools.

The first step consisted of deliberation and problem definition through discussion meetings. In these sessions, the team worked on identifying and selecting challenges, proposing potential solutions, and, crucially, analyzing the viability of each proposal.

The second phase involved research and data collection on the following topics: access to local parks in specific communities; strategies for land use in agricultural activities; improving solid waste management; and analyzing the scarcity of access to electricity and other energy sources in communities.

Several digital tools were employed to execute and organize the work. Gemini and ChatGPT were used for research and insight generation. Searches for scientific articles, reports, and reliable references were conducted using Google Chrome and Google Scholar. Documentation, text preparation, and collaboration were conducted using Google Docs, while Canva was used to create visual materials and design the final work.

projectDetails.name: OrC (Orbital Clean)
projectDetails.summary: We developed OrC (Orbital Clean), a substation focused on transforming space debris in metallic wires which will be sold down on Earth for multiple purposes. This project contemplates the challenge of commercializing the Low Earth Orbit (LEO), presenting a viable destination for the metals filling the space in the first few thousand meters outside of the Earth. With OrC, we will guarantee the possibility of space navigation and exploration in the future, given the increasing number of space debris should prevent missions from being launched in the next few decades. Ultimately, OrC aims to reuse and commercialize what used to be considered space trash.
projectDetails.details:
What does it do or how does it work? 

OrC is responsible for capturing debris collected through a hatch in one of the bases of the cylindric structure, performing a wire drawing process on the inside in order to transform these metals into wires and storing them in boxes that will eventually be ejected back to Earth with the help of an attached parachute.

What benefits does it have? 

  • First, we aim to reduce the number of space debris around the Low Earth Orbit in order to avoid future trouble in regards to humanities’ space development. 
  • Second, our focus is on giving purpose and market value to the debris through their refinement and transformation into wires.

What is the intended impact of the project? 

Transform space debris into a commercialized product by turning them into raw material to be sold on Earth, benefiting both the space market as well as ensuring safety to the future missions. 

What tools, coding languages, hardware, or software did you use to develop your project? 

N/A

How is your project creative? 

The search for innovation and the need of a solution to the space debris overflow are combined though an effective solution in the execution of this project in reason of both the approach to the recycling matter but also addressing the lack of specific raw materials.

What factors did your team consider?

The need for solution to this reoccurring problem in LEO, redirecting what would potentially become an obstacle for space navigation and exploration into a product to be commercialized on Earth.

challengeDetails.title: Stellar Stories: Space Weather Through the Eyes of Earthlings
challengeDetails.excerpt: Although the Sun is 93 million miles away from our planet, solar activity can significantly impact our daily lives. “Space weather”—the variations that occur in the space environment between the Sun and Earth—can impact technologies in space and on Earth. Your challenge is to write and illustrate a digital children’s story that explains what space weather is and the varying impacts it has on different people such as farmers, pilots, astronauts, power grid operators, and the general public. You can tell the story from the perspective of a person impacted by space weather or from the point of view of a solar flare or coronal mass ejection (CME) as it approaches Earth. (Heliophysics Division)

challengeDetails.title: Sharks from Space
challengeDetails.excerpt: Earth’s ocean is one of the most powerful habitats in our universe, supporting a range of life that sustains ecosystems and habitability across the globe. It is common to measure photosynthetic activity in the ocean from space, but far more challenging to track top predators. Your challenge is to create a mathematical framework for identifying sharks and predicting their foraging habitats using NASA satellite data, and also to suggest a new conceptual model of a tag (a small electronic device that can be attached to an animal to track and study its movement) that could measure not only where sharks are, but also what they are eating, and in real time transmit that data back to users to enable development of predictive models. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Project Extraplant
projectDetails.summary: Extraplant is a crop simulator that teaches, in an interactive and gamified way, how to achieve larger and better harvests while preserving soil and biodiversity.
projectDetails.details:
Our planet's resources are limited — and unsustainable agricultural practices threaten global food production.

Extraplant presents a sustainable solution.

Using historical climate data from NASA and the UN's AquaCrop model, the app works as a real crop simulator that teaches, in an interactive and gamified way, how to achieve larger and better harvests while preserving soil and biodiversity.

Validated in numerous studies, the model achieves up to 98% accuracy when calibrated for local conditions.

By combining technology, science, and sustainability, Extraplant transforms producers into protagonists of planetary regeneration.

  •  Global Coverage: Simulate crops in 22 regions across 6 continents
  •  Scientific Accuracy: Based on FAO's AquaCrop-OS model (up to 98% precision)
  •  Real Climate Data: Powered by NASA POWER API
  •  Multiple Crops: Support for Maize, Wheat, Rice, Cotton, Potato, and more
  •  Water Efficiency: Optimize irrigation strategies and water usage
  •  Performance Metrics: Track biomass, yield, and soil water balance
projectDetails.aiReferences:
• Backend: AWS Lambda (Python 3.11)
  • Container: Docker with ECR deployment
  • Climate Data: NASA POWER API
  • Crop Model: AquaCrop-OSPy v3.0.11
  • Infrastructure: Serverless architecture (AWS Free Tier compatible)

Your challenge is to create an engaging educational game that effectively utilizes NASA’s open data sets to simulate farming scenarios and enables players to learn how this data can inform innovative, sustainable, agricultural methods. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Project FarmFlux
projectDetails.summary:
Farm Flux is an interactive educational game that simulates sustainable agriculture using real NASA satellite data from the POWER API. Players manage virtual farms by making data-driven decisions about crop planting, irrigation, fertilization, and livestock management based on actual climate conditions.

The game addresses the NASA Farm Navigators challenge by integrating real-time temperature, precipitation, humidity, and wind data to demonstrate how satellite information can inform modern agricultural practices. Players learn the environmental and economic impacts of their decisions through a sustainability scoring system (Grade A-F) and educational feedback.

This matters because it bridges the gap between space technology and practical farming education. By visualizing 30-day climate trends and showing how weather directly affects crop growth, Farm Flux teaches farmers, students, and agricultural professionals how NASA's open data can optimize resource efficiency and promote sustainable farming methods—crucial for food security in a changing climate.
projectDetails.details:
Farm Flux is an interactive web-based agricultural simulation game that integrates real-time NASA satellite data to teach sustainable farming practices. Players create virtual farms at real GPS coordinates and make data-driven decisions about crop management, irrigation, fertilization, and livestock handling.

Core Mechanics:

  • Players input farm coordinates (e.g., São Paulo: -23.5505, -46.6333)
  • NASA POWER API fetches real climate data (temperature, precipitation, humidity, wind) using MERRA-2 satellite measurements
  • Players plant crops (corn, wheat, soybean, rice, cotton) that grow automatically based on actual weather conditions
  • Every agricultural activity (9 types: organic/chemical fertilization, drip/sprinkler/flood irrigation, rotational/free-range/intensive grazing) generates educational feedback and impacts sustainability scores
  • 30-day climate trend charts visualize temperature and rainfall patterns
  • Sustainability scoring system (Grade A-F) evaluates environmental impact

🌟 Benefits & Impact

Educational Benefits:

  1. Data Literacy: Students learn to interpret NASA satellite data for practical applications
  2. Sustainability Awareness: Visual feedback shows environmental consequences of farming choices
  3. Climate Understanding: 30-day trend charts demonstrate weather patterns' impact on agriculture
  4. Decision Making: Players balance economic costs vs. environmental sustainability

Real-World Impact:

  • For Farmers: Demonstrates how free NASA data can optimize resource efficiency (water, fertilizer)
  • For Students: Gamified learning about precision agriculture and climate science
  • For Educators: Ready-to-use tool for teaching sustainable agriculture concepts
  • For Communities: Promotes food security awareness in changing climate conditions

🛠️ Technology Stack

Backend:

  • Laravel 12.0 (PHP 8.4) - Game logic, NASA API integration
  • SQLite/MySQL - Storing farms, crops, weather data, activities
  • Composer - Dependency management

Frontend:

  • Vue 3.5 (TypeScript) - Reactive UI components
  • Inertia.js 2.0 - SPA framework bridging Laravel & Vue
  • Vite 7.0 - Fast HMR (Hot Module Replacement)
  • Tailwind CSS 4.1 - Responsive styling
  • Chart.js - Data visualization (30-day climate trends)
  • Reka UI - Accessible component library
  • Lucide Icons - Modern icon system

External APIs:

  • NASA POWER API - Real satellite data from MERRA-2 (Modern-Era Retrospective Analysis)
  • Parameters fetched: T2M (temperature), PRECTOTCORR (precipitation), RH2M (humidity), WS2M (wind speed)

DevOps:

  • Git - Version control
  • NPM - Frontend package management
  • Artisan - Laravel CLI for migrations, seeding, commands

🎨 Creative Elements

1. Gamification Design:

  • Emoji-based feedback system (✅🌍💧⚠️💡) makes learning engaging
  • Grade system (A-F) inspired by academic scoring for familiarity
  • Toast notifications provide instant gratification/warning
  • Progress bars visualize abstract concepts (soil quality, water level)

2. Data Visualization Innovation:

  • Dual-axis chart: Temperature line + precipitation bars in one view
  • Trend badges (🔥 Warming / 🧊 Cooling / ⚖️ Stable) simplify complex climate data
  • Color coding: Red (hot/critical), blue (water), green (healthy), orange (warning)

3. Educational Approach:

  • Contextual tips: "Drip irrigation saves up to 50% more water than traditional methods"
  • Predictive feedback: "Optimal weather for fertilization! Plants can best absorb nutrients now"
  • Comparative costs: Shows economic vs. environmental trade-offs ($50-$200/hectare)

4. Realistic Simulation:

  • Automatic crop growth based on real weather (runs hourly via Laravel scheduler)
  • Growth stages: seedling → vegetative → flowering → ripening → mature
  • Harvest readiness: Crops mature only after sufficient days + favorable conditions

🧠 Design Considerations

1. Accessibility:

  • Keyboard navigation: Full ARIA support via Reka UI components
  • Screen reader friendly: Semantic HTML, proper labels
  • Tooltips: Hover and focus states for information
  • Color contrast: WCAG AA compliant

2. Performance:

  • API caching: Weather data cached to minimize NASA API calls
  • Lazy loading: Components load on-demand
  • Optimistic UI updates: Instant feedback while API processes
  • Debounced inputs: Form validation doesn't trigger on every keystroke

3. Scalability:

  • Modular architecture: Services pattern (NasaWeatherService, FarmSimulationService)
  • Database migrations: Version-controlled schema changes
  • Factory & Seeders: Easy demo data generation
  • Policy-based authorization: Secure multi-user support ready

4. User Experience:

  • Empty states: Motivational messages when no crops planted
  • Loading states: Skeleton loaders prevent jarring content shifts
  • Error handling: Friendly messages instead of technical errors
  • Progressive disclosure: Advanced features revealed gradually

5. Educational Integrity:

  • Real data only: No fake/simulated climate data
  • Scientific accuracy: Fertilizer/irrigation impacts based on agricultural research
  • Transparent sources: NASA API parameters clearly documented
  • Balanced messaging: Shows benefits AND drawbacks of each method

🌍 Global Applicability

Multi-Region Support:

  • Works with any GPS coordinates globally
  • NASA POWER API covers entire planet
  • Players can compare farms in different climates (e.g., Brazil vs. India)

Localization Ready:

  • Metric system (hectares, Celsius, mm, m/s)
  • Internationalization (i18n) structure prepared for multiple languages

📊 Impact Metrics

Measurable Outcomes:

  • Sustainability Score: Quantifies environmental impact (0-100)
  • Resource Efficiency: Tracks water usage, fertilizer application
  • Yield Optimization: Compares actual vs. potential harvest
  • Cost-Benefit Analysis: Shows $/hectare vs. sustainability trade-offs

Long-term Vision:

  • Export farm reports for educational portfolios
  • Leaderboard to encourage competition
  • Achievement system to reward sustainable practices
  • Multiplayer mode for collaborative learning
projectDetails.aiReferences:
During Farm Flux development, I used AI tools (GitHub Copilot, Claude) as coding assistants, not primary solution providers. AI helped with:

  • Debugging syntax errors and type mismatches
  • Suggesting code patterns and best practices
  • Generating boilerplate code and documentation
  • Identifying performance issues

All critical decisions remained human:

  • System architecture and design patterns
  • Game mechanics and sustainability algorithms
  • Educational content and feedback messages
  • NASA API integration strategy
  • User experience and interface design

AI accelerated routine tasks, allowing me to focus on creative problem-solving and educational value.

projectDetails.name: Project Finstream
projectDetails.summary: FINSTREAM is an advanced interdisciplinary system that integrates NASA satellite data with artificial intelligence to predict and analyze shark behavior in real time. It bridges oceanography, ecology, and data science through a deep neural network trained on over 345,000 biological and environmental records, achieving behavioral classification accuracies above 85%. To ground satellite insights with direct biological evidence, the project includes a custom-built underwater monitoring device attached to the shark’s dorsal fin. This modular board, based on an ESP32 microcontroller and equipped with pressure, temperature, and motion sensors, transmits real-time data via the Argos satellite network. A compact, hydrodynamic housing ensures waterproofing, durability, and minimal impact on the animal, allowing fully autonomous operation. By linking orbital observations with in situ measurements, FINSTREAM provides a new framework for validating remote sensing data through living organisms. The system advances marine conservation by identifying foraging hotspots, reducing human–shark conflicts, and guiding sustainable ocean management, demonstrating how space-based data and AI can work together to understand and protect marine ecosystems.
projectDetails.details:
FINSTREAM is an advanced, interdisciplinary system designed to integrate NASA satellite data with artificial intelligence for the real-time prediction and analysis of shark behavior. It unites oceanography, ecology, and data science to create a dynamic platform capable of transforming environmental information into biological insight.

The system operates by acquiring satellite observations from NASA’s SWOT (Surface Water and Ocean Topography) and MODIS (Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer) missions. SWOT data provide precise measurements of sea surface height anomalies, while MODIS offers chlorophyll-a concentrations, an indicator of marine productivity. All MODIS data were collected through the NASA Ocean Biology Processing Group (OBPG) API between January 1, 2024, and January 24, 2024, and used to train the artificial intelligence model. These environmental datasets were spatially and temporally aligned with high-fidelity shark telemetry, including geographic position, depth, temperature, and movement data generated or collected at high frequency.

A deep neural network trained on over 345,000 records integrates these environmental and biological variables to predict behavioral states—searching, foraging, or transit—and estimates foraging probability (p_forrageio) under varying ocean conditions. The model achieves behavioral classification accuracies exceeding 85%, allowing real-time assessment of ecological responses to ocean variability.

FINSTREAM’s architecture combines Python-based AI modules with a .NET backend, PostgreSQL database, and a React-based web interface for real-time visualization. The infrastructure supports simultaneous multi-shark tracking, sub-second latency processing, and modular scalability for expanded datasets.

Beyond its technical achievements, FINSTREAM delivers substantial scientific and conservation value. It provides a unique framework for correlating satellite-derived environmental metrics with biological behavior, offering an innovative validation mechanism for remote sensing data through living organisms. From a conservation perspective, it identifies biologically significant foraging regions, supports marine spatial planning, and contributes to reducing bycatch and human–shark interactions through predictive modeling.

Technologically, the project demonstrates a powerful application of NASA data to real-world ecological challenges, showcasing how spaceborne measurements can directly inform ocean management and species conservation. Its open-source design encourages scientific collaboration, reproducibility, and educational use, fostering interdisciplinary research across artificial intelligence, marine science, and climate studies.

In essence, FINSTREAM represents a novel synthesis of satellite observation, machine learning, and marine ecology. By bridging the gap between orbital sensors and biological systems, it provides a scalable, accurate, and ethically driven model for environmental intelligence—advancing both technological innovation and the global effort to understand and preserve marine ecosystems.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Artificial Intelligence (AI) was employed in the FINSTREAM project both as a creative and analytical tool to accelerate scientific development and technical execution. AI assisted in multiple phases of the project — from data processing and modeling to ideation and coding support.

Technically, AI was used to interpret and integrate NASA satellite datasets from the SWOT (Surface Water and Ocean Topography) and MODIS (Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer) missions. Machine learning algorithms performed spatial–temporal alignment of sea surface height anomalies and chlorophyll-a concentrations based on geographic coordinates (latitude and longitude), enabling the creation of a unified environmental dataset.

AI was also utilized to generate biologically realistic shark telemetry simulations, modeling behaviors such as migration, depth variation, and foraging activity. These synthetic datasets were combined with real NASA data to train a deep neural network capable of predicting behavioral states and foraging probability under varying oceanographic conditions.

Beyond data and modeling, AI tools were valuable for concept generation, code optimization, and workflow structuring, helping the team design more efficient algorithms and improve data analysis pipelines.

All AI-generated content, including simulated data, code segments, and analytical outputs, is properly documented and acknowledged in the project’s metadata, with no NASA branding or design elements used or modified.

challengeDetails.title: Sharks from Space
challengeDetails.excerpt: Earth’s ocean is one of the most powerful habitats in our universe, supporting a range of life that sustains ecosystems and habitability across the globe. It is common to measure photosynthetic activity in the ocean from space, but far more challenging to track top predators. Your challenge is to create a mathematical framework for identifying sharks and predicting their foraging habitats using NASA satellite data, and also to suggest a new conceptual model of a tag (a small electronic device that can be attached to an animal to track and study its movement) that could measure not only where sharks are, but also what they are eating, and in real time transmit that data back to users to enable development of predictive models. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Orbit Credits Exchange (OCE)
projectDetails.summary:
Low Earth Orbit (LEO) is on the verge of an unprecedented expansion. The European Space Agency (ESA) projects that the number of active satellites will rise from about 7,500 today to over 100,000 by 2035, a 1,200% increase that dramatically heightens the risk of collisions and chain fragmentation, the Kessler Syndrome.
NASA’s LEGEND and ESA’s MASTER models indicate that, without active mitigation, collision probabilities could rise fivefold within two decades, creating tens of thousands of new debris fragments and threatening the entire commercial use of LEO.

The Orbit Credits Exchange (OCE) transforms this challenge into opportunity by creating the world’s first financial market for orbital sustainability.
Inspired by carbon credits, OCE introduces “orbital credits”, tradable assets that reward debris removal and charge for orbital usage.
If only 1% of annual satellite launches participate, OCE could enable the removal or recycling of 2,000–5,000 debris objects per year, reducing orbital density by 15–20% within 15 years.
By aligning sustainability with profitability, OCE ensures that space remains safe, accessible, and economically vibrant for generations to come.
projectDetails.details:
Orbit Credits Exchange (OCE)

What does it do or how does it work?
The Orbit Credits Exchange (OCE) transforms orbital debris removal from a cost with no clear market into a sustainable economic ecosystem. Inspired by carbon markets, OCE introduces “orbital credits”:

  • Satellite operators pay orbital fees based on mass and time in orbit.
  • Missions (public, private, or academic) that remove or recycle debris earn credits.
  • Credits can be traded in a transparent digital marketplace, creating an economic incentive for Active Debris Removal (ADR).

A web application prototype demonstrates this mechanism: operators manage their orbital balance, ADR missions simulate debris removal, and a marketplace enables credit trading. Blockchain integration ensures trust and transparency across international stakeholders.

What benefits does it have?

  • Economic Incentive: Creates a real financial driver for debris removal, solving the current lack of motivation.
  • Sustainability: Promotes circular use of orbital resources by rewarding recycling and reuse.
  • Transparency: Blockchain-backed credits guarantee trust across agencies, companies, and citizens.
  • Scalability: As more satellites are launched, the market naturally grows.
  • Collaboration: Engages governments, startups, investors, and the public in a shared framework.

What is the intended impact of the project?
The OCE establishes the first global financial market for orbital sustainability. Its impact goes beyond technology:

  • The Orbit Credits Exchange (OCE) has the potential to reduce orbital debris density by up to 20% over 15 years by funding the removal or recycling of up to 5,000 objects per year, even with participation from just 1% of annual global satellite launches.
  • Encourages responsible orbital usage and end-of-life (EOL) planning.
  • Reduces the risk of collisions and cascade effects (Kessler Syndrome).
  • Attracts ESG investors and creates a new space economy sector.
  • Raises global awareness by allowing citizens and crowdfunding initiatives to participate in orbital clean-up.

What tools, coding languages, hardware, or software did you use to develop your project?

  • Lovable.app
  • Google docs
  • Adobe Photoshop

How is your project creative?

  • Novel Market Mechanism: First to apply the proven concept of carbon credits to space sustainability.
  • Inclusive Participation: Not limited to agencies—startups, universities, and citizens can take part.
  • Integration of Multiple Layers: Combines economics, ESG principles, blockchain trust, and orbital data in a single ecosystem.
  • Educational Impact: Serves as a tool to demonstrate orbital sustainability concepts to the general public.

What factors did your team consider?

  • Scalability: Designed to grow as satellite constellations expand.
  • Feasibility: Balance between ambitious goals (debris recycling, blockchain) and hackathon-ready prototypes (mock APIs, simulations).
  • Trust: Blockchain integration ensures international adoption potential.
  • Stakeholder Diversity: Operators, agencies, ADR missions, and investors all have defined roles.
  • Sustainability & Circularity: Ensures companies are accountable for orbital usage while encouraging innovation in debris recycling.

projectDetails.name: Eyes Beyond
projectDetails.summary:
Our project, Eyes Beyond the Sky, develops an advanced Machine Learning ensemble model to efficiently classify exoplanets using data from NASA's Kepler mission. We developed a robust classifier by combining an AutoEncoder for noise reduction and latent feature extraction with an XGBoost Classifier enhanced by a Segment Tree for improved computational speed and accuracy.

This innovative approach addresses the challenge by providing a highly robust and precise tool to swiftly and reliably identify and confirm celestial bodies, helping to process the thousands of potential exoplanet candidates where only darkness was previously seen. This work is critically important as it speeds up the discovery of new worlds, expands our understanding of planetary system formation, and helps prioritize targets for future missions searching for signs of extraterrestrial life.
projectDetails.details:
Project Details

Our project develops an advanced Machine Learning model to study and classify exoplanets, based on data provided by NASA's Kepler mission. The main architecture is an ensemble that combines a neural reconstruction model with optimized decision tree learning.

ML Process and Architecture:

  • Preprocessing: The database was treated (exclusion of irrelevant and null columns, imputation by the mean, and normalization via RobustScaler) to ensure consistency and optimize performance.
  • Feature Engineering: We integrated an AutoEncoder based on MLP (trained only with the "CONFIRMED" class) to learn the latent structure and generate a new feature: the mean reconstruction error. Next, we applied a Segment Tree structure to calculate cumulative sums, adding derived variables that capture internal relationships between the numerical attributes.
  • Training: The XGBoost model was trained with the enriched dataset for multiclass classification. We monitored performance in real-time through the learning curve to adjust hyperparameters (such as max_depth: 6 and learning_rate: 0.1) and optimize generalization capacity.
  • Evaluation: The final model is evaluated by robust metrics such as accuracy, F1-score, and Confusion Matrix—the latter being essential to analyze performance at an individual class level and identify confusion patterns.
[IMAGE ID NOT FOUND title:"" ]
[IMAGE ID NOT FOUND title:"" ]

3D Simulation (Immersive Interface)

In addition to the AI, the project includes an immersive 3D simulation of exoplanet orbits (example: TRAPPIST-1), based on real information from NASA.

  • The planet's size is calculated based on its mass (normalized by Earth's radius).
  • The orbital velocity is estimated from the orbital period.
  • The interface displays essential information (name, type, mass, star, etc.) and was developed with HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.

We seek to use simple language and an intuitive layout, making the analysis of complex data more accessible and interactive so that all people can access, share information, and experience the simulation.

Final Model Parameters (Technical Detail)

Final XGBoost Parameters:

  • objective: multi:softmax — defines the model for multiclass classification.
  • num_class: number of unique classes present in the dataset.
  • tree_method: hist — uses histograms to accelerate training.
  • grow_policy: lossguide - grows trees by prioritizing loss reduction.
  • num_round: 100 - number of epochs.
  • max_depth: 6 - controls the maximum depth of the trees, preventing overfitting.
  • learning_rate: 0.1 - learning rate used in each iteration.
  • subsample: 0.8 - fraction of samples used in each tree.
  • colsample_bytree: 0.8 - fraction of columns used in each tree.
  • eval_metric: merror - measures the classification error rate.
  • verbosity: 1 - displays informative messages during training.

Final AutoEncoder Parameters:

  • hidden_layer_sizes: (32, 16, 8, 16, 32) - defines the symmetric layer structure of the model.
  • activation: relu - activation function used to capture non-linear relationships.
  • solver: adam - adaptive optimizer for efficient weight adjustment.
  • max_iter: 500 - Number of epochs.
  • random_state: 42 - ensures reproducibility of results.

Benefits and Impact

Scientific advancement depends on ambition and perspective. Exploring exoplanets expands our understanding of the formation and evolution of solar systems.

  • Diversity of Life: The research reveals the diversity of worlds, allowing scientists to identify conditions (atmosphere, pressure, chemistry) that, although different from Earth's, could sustain forms of life.
  • Great Questions: Each exoplanet studied is a window to explore the origin, diversity, and limits of life, helping to answer: "Is there life on other planets? Could we inhabit them?"
  • Collaboration: The research encourages public and citizen science participation, in addition to promoting international cooperation and the development of new technologies.
  • AI Support: Promote the expansion of artificial intelligence as a robust and efficient support tool for exoplanet studies, for both specialists and researchers at different levels.

Tools, Languages, and Software

  • ML Model: XGBoost, AutoEncoder (MLP-based), and Segment Tree.
  • Coding Languages: HTML, CSS, and JavaScript (for the simulation). The ML pipeline was executed in Jupyter Notebook.
  • Key Libraries: RobustScaler (for normalization), in addition to the underlying libraries for XGBoost and AutoEncoder (such as Scikit-learn/TensorFlow/Keras).
  • AI Support: We used ChatGPT 5.0, ChatGPT 4.5, Claude, and Google Gemini for writing refinement, coding support, translation, and proposing technical solutions.

Considered Factors of Creativity and Robustness

The creativity of the project lies in its technical approach and user experience. In the Machine Learning aspect, the innovation is in the unique ensemble architecture, which integrates the AutoEncoder's reconstruction error as an extra feature, combined with feature optimization using the Segment Tree structure. This combination ensures significantly superior robustness and efficiency than traditional models would achieve. On the interface side, the 3D simulation of the TRAPPIST-1 system, based on real data, is a creative and immersive solution for visualizing complex orbital and planetary property data, converting raw data into a tangible educational experience. The team fundamentally considered the need for a Focus on the Public, motivating the development of this interactive 3D interface to make exoplanet science comprehensible and accessible to researchers and the general public.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Use of AI

We utilized different artificial intelligence models to support the project's development.

ChatGPT 5.0 and ChatGPT 4.5 were employed for various tasks, including writing refinement, coding support, and proposing solutions for technical problems.

Furthermore, we resorted to Claude to assist both in translating code snippets and in developing the 3D Exoplanet Simulator.

Finally, we used Google Gemini as additional support for coding and translation activities.

projectDetails.name: BioGalactic
projectDetails.summary:
BioGalactic is a web-based knowledge engine designed to address the "Build a Space Biology Knowledge Engine" challenge. We developed a data pipeline that ingests, parses, and structures over 600 NASA life science articles from PubMed Central, storing them in a PostgreSQL database enriched with vector embeddings.

Our platform offers two powerful search modes: a traditional keyword search and a semantic search that allows users to ask natural language questions and receive contextually relevant passages as answers. To make this complex research accessible, we also utilize the Llama 3 language model to generate AI-powered summaries for each study.

BioGalactic is important because it transforms a vast repository of dense scientific data into an intuitive tool, empowering scientists, students, and the public to explore the frontiers of space biology with unprecedented ease.
projectDetails.details:
So, what did we build and how does it work? Our project, BioGalactic, is a smart knowledge engine that we built from the ground up to tackle the challenge. We started with a list of over 573 NASA life science articles and created an automated pipeline to bring them to life. First, we wrote a script that visits PubMed Central for each article, parses its complex JATS XML structure, and pulls out every single passage. All this structured data gets saved into a PostgreSQL database.

But just storing the text wasn't enough. We supercharged the data in three ways:

  1. Semantic Power: We generated vector embeddings for the most important sections of each paper (like the Abstract, Introduction, and Results). This is the magic that lets users ask real questions instead of just guessing keywords.
  2. Smart Tagging: We used scispaCy to automatically read through the text and identify key biological and NASA-related terms, paving the way for even smarter filtering in the future.
  3. AI Summaries: We fed the most relevant passages of each study to the Llama 3 model. It then generated a simple, easy-to-read summary explaining what the study was about, its impact, and the tools used.

Users explore all this through a fast frontend built with React. It talks to two different backends: a robust .NET API for browsing and filtering, and a specialized Node.js API that handles the heavy lifting of our AI-powered semantic search.

What are the benefits and impact? The main goal is to break down the walls around complex space biology research. For scientists, BioGalactic is a massive time-saver, letting them ask questions like "how does microgravity affect the human immune system?" and get instant, relevant paragraphs from hundreds of papers. For students and the public, our AI summaries provide a "front door" to the science, making it approachable and exciting. We want to spark curiosity and help everyone, expert or not, make faster discoveries.

What's our creative spark? Our creativity came from not just building a search engine, but creating three different ways to see the science:

  1. The 10,000-Foot View: Quick, AI-generated summaries for a fast overview.
  2. The Magnifying Glass: Semantic search results that pinpoint the exact passages that answer your question.
  3. The Deep Dive: The full, structured text of the original article for in-depth analysis.

We also got creative with our architecture, using a hybrid "two-engine" backend. We used .NET for its strength with structured data and Node.js for its agility with AI tasks. It's like having a specialized engine for each job, making the whole system faster and more efficient.

What tech did we use?

  • Frontend: React, TypeScript, TanStack Router & Query, Tailwind CSS
  • Backend: .NET 8 (Main API), Node.js with Fastify (Semantic Search API)
  • Database: PostgreSQL with the pgvector extension
  • AI/ML: Llama 3 (via Groq API), Hugging Face Transformers.js, scispaCy
  • DevOps: Docker, Docker Compose, Portainer, and Caddy for reverse proxy and HTTPS.

What factors did we think about?

  • User-Friendliness: We wanted it to feel fast and intuitive, whether you're just browsing or asking a complex question.
  • Honesty about the Data: We knew automated tools aren't perfect, so we added a clear disclaimer and a direct link to the original source on every article page.
  • Performance: We built it to be fast and ready to grow, using pgvector for instant search results and Docker to make sure it can handle more data and users in the future.
  • Keeping Costs Low: By using the super-fast Groq API and powerful open-source models, we made sure our AI features are both top-tier and incredibly cheap to run.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Artificial Intelligence is not just a tool we used; it is the core engine of our BioGalactic project. We leveraged AI in two distinct ways: as a fundamental component of the user experience and as a tool to accelerate our development process.

1. AI as a Core Project Feature:

Our platform is fundamentally AI-driven, designed to make complex scientific data accessible and queryable. We integrated AI in the following key areas:

  • AI-Generated Summaries (Data): The centerpiece of our accessibility effort is the AI-generated summary for each of the 573 scientific articles. We developed a data pipeline that feeds key passages from each study into the Llama 3 model (served via the high-speed Groq API). The model was prompted to extract structured information: "What was studied," "Where it was studied," "Tools used," and "Study impact." In compliance with the rules, this AI-generated content is clearly presented as a summary to distinguish it from the original source material.
  • Semantic Search (Data & Code): To enable users to ask natural language questions, our backend generates vector embeddings for relevant article passages using open-source Hugging Face models. The resulting vectors allow our semantic search API to find the most contextually relevant information, going far beyond simple keyword matching.
  • Named Entity Recognition (NER) (Data): Our data ingestion process uses scispaCy, a specialized NLP library for scientific text, to identify and tag critical biological and NASA-specific entities within each article. This enriches our dataset and creates a foundation for future advanced filtering capabilities.

2. AI as a Development Tool:

In addition to being a core feature, we utilized AI language models during the development cycle to enhance our productivity and decision-making. We used these tools for:

  • Research and Comparison: We conducted research to compare the performance, cost, and implementation details of various open-source embedding models and Large Language Models to select the most effective and efficient options for our project (leading us to choose Llama 3 on Groq).
  • Brainstorming and Debugging: AI was used as a brainstorming partner for architectural decisions and as a debugging tool to help resolve complex code issues, particularly with data pipeline integration.

In summary, AI is intricately woven into the fabric of BioGalactic, powering its most innovative features and enabling our team to build a more powerful and user-friendly tool within the hackathon's timeframe.

challengeDetails.title: Build a Space Biology Knowledge Engine
challengeDetails.excerpt: Enable a new era of human space exploration! NASA has been performing biology experiments in space for decades, generating a tremendous amount of information that will need to be considered as humans prepare to revisit the Moon and explore Mars. Although this knowledge is publicly available, it can be difficult for potential users to find information that pertains to their specific interests. Your challenge is to build a dynamic dashboard that leverages artificial intelligence (AI), knowledge graphs, and/or other tools to summarize a set of NASA bioscience publications and enables users to explore the impacts and results of the experiments these publications describe. (Earth Science Division)
