projectDetails.details:
FAHRENHURBS PLATFORM: A TOOL FOR MANAGERS ABOUT EXTREME HEAT

Alice Gonçalves Coutinho de Faria (alicecdf@icloud.com)

Daniel Vito Ramos (danielvitoramos@gmail.com)

Laura Rodrigues de Souza (laura.souza2@ufu.br)

Luiz Carlos Freitas Silva (luizcw2410@gmail.com)

Maísa Gonçalves da Silva (maisasilva.eseba@gmail.com)

Saulo Coutinho de Faria (saulocoutinho@gmail.com)

Team: GEPITronautas

Challenge: Data Pathways for Healthy Cities and Human Settlements: Climate change brings new complexities to consider when maintaining the well-being of society and the environment in cities. Natural resources, ecosystems, and existing infrastructure must be monitored to ensure that the quality of human life remains high. Your challenge is to demonstrate how urban planners can use NASA Earth observation data to develop smart urban growth strategies that preserve the well-being of people and the environment (Earth Sciences Division).

Summary: Climate change requires the attention of public administrators. Temperature changes significantly affect quality of life. Managers are dealing with urban infrastructure issues and the expansion of urban spaces. According to the IBGE (Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics), 87% of the Brazilian population lives in urban areas. Various factors impact extreme heat indices; urban expansion, often uncontrolled, raises ambient temperatures. Therefore, the development of a website is proposed to organize and provide authorities with access to information on this issue, enabling the implementation of measures to create new neighborhoods. The methodology for this project was structured based on data provided by NASA on climate change, from which the "High-Resolution Annual Global Extreme Heat Estimates" was selected, containing information from 1983 to 2016. Using this material, a prototype application called FahrenHurbs was developed, integrated with the website, which uses an average of 28°C as a metric for extreme temperatures. Using this data, the interface was developed to integrate and organize all the data. This will hopefully provide urban planners with the resources to develop smart urban growth strategies that preserve the well-being of people and the environment.

Keywords: Extreme Heat, Climate Change, Cities and Solutions.

Introduction 

Climate change is a challenge that must be considered in public administrators'  discussions. Population growth and the consequent expansion of urban spaces are a  trend, especially in medium- and large-sized cities. 

According to a survey conducted by the IBGE (Brazilian Institute of Geography  and Statistics), in 2022, more than 87% of the Brazilian population lived in urban areas,  corresponding to approximately 203.1 million people (IBGE, 2025). This represents an  increase of more than 16 million people compared to the previous survey, representing  an increase of 0.82% per year. This percentage is accentuated when considering the  Brazilian regions, with the Southeast region (94.44%) having the highest urban  population (IBGE, 2025), where this project is being developed. This motivated the  researchers to develop a research proposal aimed at solving problems related to  population growth. 

Therefore, to accommodate this population growth, new neighborhoods are  likely to emerge in cities, requiring urban planning by various public sectors,  considering sanitation, urban mobility, energy, green spaces, among other aspects. 

The public administrator's concern is that growth contributes to the population's quality of life, enabling urban development. It is important to emphasize that growth must be  aligned with progress, with a view to smart cities, where modernization and technology  aim to improve the population's quality of life, always considering the criteria of  sustainable development. 

"Smart cities are related to the concept of sustainable development (FGV, 2019,  our translation)." These are cities that align technological development with  sustainability, while also considering the population's quality of life and natural  resources. 

These cities, a projection of the future urban environment, have characteristics that have evolved over time. [...] However, when a city has better data  management, it is possible to achieve holistic solutions involving different  urban systems (FGV, 2019, our translation). 

"Science has no doubt that climate change is generating significant impacts for  Brazil and the planet as a whole (ARTAXO, 2022, p. 2, our translation)." Climate  change affects different sectors, impacting the economy, ecosystems, natural  resources, infrastructure, health, among other areas, and can compromise the well being of society and the environment in cities. Among the different effects of climate  change, this work will focus on the impacts on temperature variations, considering  extreme heat. Urban development patterns produce many impacts related to urban  climate, notably the phenomenon of extreme heat, which results in impacts such as  health needs; energy supply, which is impacted by high temperatures in addition to  high consumption; water supply, which increases significantly during this period; and  transportation, which increases the number of vehicles in circulation, as there is a  preference for private transportation over public transportation on days of extreme  heat. These are some of the impacts of this phenomenon, which are exacerbated by  temperatures that exceed the global average. As well as the impacts of this factor, such as the number of days of the event and the population affected by the  phenomenon. 

As a result of urban expansion, the importance of urban climate  studies is debated and, in this context, they are fundamental to  understanding UCI across scales of analysis, integrating  everything from the environmental quality of citizens to the  impacts of UCI on regional climate (UMMUS EICHEMBERGER  et al., 2008). The negative effects of UCI include environmental degradation such as poor air quality, increased energy consumption for building cooling, respiratory diseases, and low  productivity (WERNECK, 2018, p. 18, our translation). 

In urban spaces, built-up areas and circulation routes prevent heat accumulated  at the surface from being transported to the upper atmosphere, which prevents heat  loss—that is, the circulation of cold air—which occurs more readily in rural areas.  Therefore, urban areas experience higher temperatures than rural areas, varying by  around 1°C compared to small urban areas, but this difference can exceed 4°C in large  urban centers (LOPES et al, 2022). "The intensity of urban heat depends on its spatial  location, as well as local characteristics (LOPES et al, 2022, p. 285, our translation)." 

Many Brazilian cities are "highly susceptible to the most severe impacts of  climate change, such as [...] intensification of temperature rise due to the urban heat  island (ARTAXO, 2022, p. 14, our translation)." Problems resulting from these climate  changes threaten to exceed the capacity of Brazilian cities to absorb losses and  recover from their impacts, thus justifying reflection on solutions to minimize their  impacts. 

These impacts tend to exacerbate the risks commonly encountered in  Brazilian cities, as well as the inadequacies in local governments' capacity to  address internal infrastructure and the failure to provide necessary basic  services, exacerbating the vulnerability of certain social groups and  communities. Therefore, mitigation and adaptation strategies in urban centers must consider aspects such as habitability, thermal comfort, health, mobility,  urban planning, transportation, access to water and energy, among other  aspects (ARTAXO, 2022, p. 14-15, our translation). 

Developing solutions to this problem can mean savings for the public coffers.  Planning to improve the population's quality of life while considering the city's growth,  with the emergence of new planned neighborhoods, tends to contribute to reducing the  impacts of heat zones, thus making the city more sustainable. This justifies the work,  considering the production of a website and possibly an application for public  administration to process data. This will support the allocation of funds to minimize the  impacts of extreme heat, enabling the planning of new neighborhoods. 

Extreme heat refers to temperatures exceeding 28°C, the planet's average  temperature. Urban heat islands are "one of the main causes of decreased bioclimatic  comfort in areas where surface patterns are heterogeneous, especially in summer  (LOPES et al, 2022, 281, our translation)." Several factors impact heat zones, such as  season, built-up area, location, and vegetation, which can impede evapotranspiration,  favoring increased radiative absorption and, consequently, a significant increase in  surface temperatures. 

The proposal aims to support public administrators by presenting elements that  can inform the development of smart growth strategies, creating new neighborhoods  that preserve the well-being of people and the environment, focusing on the analysis  of NASA (National Aeronautics and Space Administration) data on extreme heat. 

Methodology 

The methodology used was a review of the data provided, considering the  decision-making process of the study object. This step supported the selection of reference materials, considering the data on which the group based its solution to the  problem. 

Computer simulation can be used as a research method to understand urban  climate-related phenomena and evaluate mitigation strategies for the impacts  of urban climate control (ICU) before their implementation. This resource has  been widely applied in educational and research projects and can be an alternative to fieldwork for obtaining diagnostic information (WERNERC, 2018, p. 52, our translation). 

To organize the actions, a mental map was created to organize how the problem  of extreme heat impacts the population. 

Figure 1: Mind Map 

.

.

.

.

.

.

.

Source: Authors' own.

With this resource in mind, the researchers decided to create a website where  public managers could visualize the impact of extreme heat events, using population  as one of the baseline data. This data would be displayed on a map. Visually, the size  of the circle relates to the number of people affected by the event, while the sidebar,  with varying colors, relates to the intensity of the event, as shown in Figure 2. 

Managers can also obtain more information by clicking the icon, which opens a  tab with additional information, as shown in Figure 2, related to other factors that impact  the extreme heat index. 

Figure 2: Website Layout 

.

.

.

.

.

.

Source: Authors' own.

The project works with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), which were discussed during the United Nations (UN) General Assembly in September 2015 and  included in the 2030 Agenda. Among the objectives related to the proposal, the  following stand out: SDG 11 Sustainable cities and communities; SDG 13 Combat  climate change. 

Figure 3: Application Logo 

.

.

.

.

.

.

.

Source: Authors' own. 

An application is also expected to be developed that uses the information filtered  by the website. The application icon is shown in Figure 3 and is called  "FAHRENHURBS." The application name comes from Fahrenheit, a measure of  temperature, and Hurbs, which means "city" in Latin. The logo's colors were based on  the SDGs, a mix of 11, which is orange, and 13, which is green. 

To develop the website and, subsequently, the application, data from the study  "Annual Global High-Resolution Extreme Heat Estimates" (GEHE) were used,  covering information from 1983 to 2016. The research group opted to review the data provided and select the material, as it provides compiled data that is already organized, streamlining the process, unlike the analysis and processing of raw data using satellite  imagery. The choice of this model refers to the fact that 

[...] GEHE provides scientific researchers and decision-makers from a wide  range of fields, including climate change, public and occupational health,  urban planning and design, risk reduction, and food security, with insights into  how humid heat has impacted human and environmental systems worldwide.  The dataset can be used to identify how changes in extreme humid heat  impact human health and well-being, as well as ecological systems, at scales  ranging from local to national to global. (TUHOLSKE, 2021, our translation). 

To determine the areas potentially exposed to extreme heat and, by extension,  more susceptible to climate vulnerability, the study's data were processed and  selected, including average temperatures above the 28°C limit, excess heat, dates on  which these indices were observed, the period of occurrence, the duration interval, the  intensity of the event, the location of the collected data, vegetation, built-up area,  population, and other factors that significantly impact extreme heat in urban areas.  Other data from the study were not considered in the development of the website and  app; the research group already had a large amount of data to analyze, so it was  decided to filter this data. 

The temperature parameters are based on ISO (International Organization for  Standardization) criteria, which relate to the risk of extreme heat, based on the planet's  average temperatures. These are defined as days when WBGTmax > 28, 30, and 32  degrees Celsius, that is, when the temperature is characterized as extreme heat. 

The days with this temperature index are the markers used as coefficients,  correlating with the magnitude of the event. This dataset also includes the annual rate  of change in the number of extreme heat days that exceeded these thresholds. 

In the search for a website or application that would facilitate the creation of  Fahrenhurbs, the researchers tested three different websites: Kodular, Wix, and  Thunkable. During the tests, the only one that proved easiest to use was Thunkable, due to its practicality, so we will attempt to use it to create the application. The other two sites presented website creation errors using AI (Artificial Intelligence) or were  difficult to create due to paid plans, so the researchers chose to work with the tool that  best suited the parameters established for their work. 

The application's initial interface features the home, explore, notifications, and  profile pages. The categories include weather, strategy, emergency, risk areas, smart  cities, and safety tips, as shown in Figure 4. 

Figure 4: Application

.

.

.

.

.

.

.

.

.

.

.

.

Source: Authors' own. 

The data were organized and processed as shown in Figure 5 to enable  analysis. This process is necessary to compile the information and plot it on the website  interface and later on the application. Python was used, "Managed by the PSF (Python  Software Foundation), the Python programming language is extremely simple and robust. Its well-designed architecture provides good performance and code readability"  (SILVA; SOUSA & SILVA, 2019, p. 55, our translation). 

Figure 5: Data Analysis 

.

.

.

.

.

Source: (TUHOLSKE et al, 2021). 

The group chose to use this language because it is... 

[...] present in various everyday applications, supporting other tasks. The  language is highly versatile and can be used in commercial settings or in more  specific areas such as scientific development, geoprocessing, and mobile  applications, either alone or integrated with other tools, further expanding the Python world (SILVA; SOUSA & SILVA, 2019, p. 55-56, our translation). 

The program data is organized to present a range from 1983 to 2016,  considering the population of cities, population growth, and consequently the number  of people affected by extreme heat events, as can be seen in Figure 6.

Figure 6: Code – Analysis Range: Population Parameters 

.

.

.

.

.

Source: (TUHOLSKE et al, 2021). 

Figure 7 refers to the intensity of the extreme heat event, considering various  factors such as the number of days the event lasts, the temperature, and other factors  that will result in the extreme heat event coefficient. 

Figure 7: Code – Analysis Range: Event Intensity

.

.

.

.

.

.

Source: (TUHOLSKE et al, 2021). 

In Figure 8, the event intensity data are correlated with the population, resulting  in a parameter that allows comparison between two variables with different magnitudes  (population and event intensity). 

Figure 8: Code – Analysis Range: Event Intensity x Population

.

.

.

.

.

Source: (TUHOLSKE et al, 2021). 

Determining this variable, which combines population and event intensity,  makes it possible to compare events that occurred in different cities with different  numbers of people affected, thus enabling decision-making by public officials. This  action is necessary for the construction of the website, as well as the application  interface, based on this entire analysis performed with the database. 

Final Considerations 

This study focuses solely on the problem of extreme heat, presenting data for  public officials to use in decision-making, highlighting the negative effects of this  phenomenon, which can consequently generate greater government spending. This  would support decision-making with mitigation actions that can be propagated,  exploring opportunities for cooling cities and creating new neighborhoods, which are planned to promote the advancement of smart city development. In this sense, studies on mitigation actions, focusing on extreme heat monitoring, are becoming the target of  multidisciplinary research that discusses quality of life, materials development,  climatology, and architecture and urban planning due to the economic, social, and  environmental impacts resulting from the benefits of reduced air temperature. This is  reflected in the planned growth of cities, ensuring a balance between economics and  sustainability. 

Thus, it is hoped to provide urban planners with resources, considering NASA's  Earth observation data, to develop smart urban growth strategies that preserve the  well-being of people and the environment. 

Urban planners are responsible for shaping the best way to support  communities in their landscapes. Rapidly growing cities must implement balanced  projects to enable successful economic development and climate resilience. Earth  observation data resources can inform urban planning strategies. Data on extreme  heat can help planners assess the sustainability of urban environments over time and  support better decision-making for long-term growth.

projectDetails.name: Project NASA Helps Farming
projectDetails.summary:
We developed an interactive educational game called "NASA Space Farming", which simulates agriculture in space environments using real NASA data. The web application combines elements of gamification with scientific information on climate, soil moisture, and vegetation health obtained from NASA satellites.
The project tackles the challenge of educating about sustainable agriculture and space science in an accessible and engaging way. Players manage limited resources, make data-driven decisions, and learn about farming techniques in microgravity.
This initiative is important because it democratizes access to complex scientific data, promotes STEM education, and raises awareness of the challenges of food production in the context of climate change and space exploration, inspiring future generations of scientists and farmers.
projectDetails.details:
What is the Game?

The game is a simulation of agricultural activities where the player cultivates various crops (sunflower, tomato, lettuce, soybean, wheat, corn, and coffee).

Throughout the game, the player is guided to make decisions based on satellite data, primarily from NASA. The game provides an immersive experience in managing both crops and livestock (dogs, cattle, chickens, and sheep), all while emphasizing the use of real-time data.

Objectives/Benefits

With this project, we aim to create not just an entertainment source but also a valuable tool for information and experiences that directly connect with real-life situations. We hope to make the understanding of satellite data clearer and more practical, showing its importance in complementing ground-based data in various scenarios. External data, like aerial images, can greatly assist farmers, leading to more sustainable agricultural practices.

The game is designed to closely mirror real-world situations, and it uses accessible language and design, aiming to reach a broad audience, not just professionals in the field. It serves as a light, fun way to spark interest in agricultural technologies and data, breaking down the barriers to their implementation. It emphasizes that obtaining information isn't enough; it’s crucial to apply and make good use of it.

Using NASA Data

The  maps guide the player on the best types of crops to grow based on the available data. The data from NASA (like NDVI, temperature, and humidity) are crucial for guiding in-game decisions, helping players understand how these external data sources influence agricultural practices.                                                                                                                                                                                                          

How to Play

The game starts with the player logging in to save progress. After logging in, the player selects between two scales for their farm: Industrial or Small. The player can then track their mission, progress, score, and the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI). Below this, there is a progress bar and an area showing coordinates and the action performed. The available actions are: cultivating, fertilizing, and managing livestock.

There are two buttons: one updates the NASA data, and the other shows the points required to advance to the next mission. A world map shows the location of the player's farm, which is tied to the data from NASA. The game promotes understanding of how to use data effectively to resolve issues, highlighting their importance in making informed decisions.

The farm/soil is represented by a graph, and the player selects an action to perform by clicking on it. Lastly, the player can track soil moisture and plant health through graphs over time.

How It Works

The game is a simulation of farm management, combining agronomy (sunflower, tomato, lettuce, soybean, wheat, corn, and coffee) and livestock (dog, cattle, chicken, sheep). The gameplay is guided by real-time NASA data, which highlights the direct impact these data have on in-game actions.

Benefits/Objectives

With the project, we intend to create more than just entertainment; we aim to offer information and experiences that will help players connect directly to real-world agricultural challenges. The goal is to make satellite data easier to understand and to show its value in complementing ground-based data in various scenarios. External data, like aerial imagery, can play a crucial role in assisting farmers and promoting more sustainable farming practices. The game is designed to be accessible, encouraging a broad audience—not just professionals in the field—to engage with the concept of using data in agriculture.

It aims to spark curiosity in a light, fun way and to help break down the barriers to integrating technology and data into agricultural practices. The focus is not just on obtaining information but on applying it effectively for better outcomes.
projectDetails.aiReferences: The tools we used were artificial intelligence and websites provided by the NASA SPACE APPS team. The artificial intelligence we used was Blackbox, Kimi, Chat GPT, and Gemini, which we used for help developing ideas and codebase ideas. We also used them for logo ideas and cropping the logo's edges. We added the information from the provided website to the game.

challengeDetails.title: NASA Farm Navigators: Using NASA Data Exploration in Agriculture
challengeDetails.excerpt: The agriculture community faces the challenge of integrating technology and data to enhance sustainable farming practices. Simulating key farming activities like fertilizing, irrigating, and livestock management using real-world NASA satellite imagery and climate data can enable better understanding of the impacts of these variables on crop production. Your challenge is to create an engaging educational game that effectively utilizes NASA’s open data sets to simulate farming scenarios and enables players to learn how this data can inform innovative, sustainable, agricultural methods. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Eco City
projectDetails.summary:
Eco City : We build the conection, we live the change
Eco City is a data-driven sustainability platform that transforms citizens into active agents of environmental change. By converting eco-friendly actions, such as cycling, walking, or using public transport, into Green Tokens, the system monetizes avoided CO₂ emissions and makes sustainable habits financially rewarding. Unlike traditional carbon credit systems restricted to corporations, Eco City democratizes the market, integrating individuals, companies, and governments in a shared ecosystem of incentives and transparency. Each token represents a tangible and auditable environmental contribution, backed by a sustainable rewards fund that combines carbon credit sales, ESG sponsorships, and circular-economy vouchers. Beyond personal engagement, Eco City also empowers urban planners by providing real-time mobility data and seasonal reports that bridge the gap in outdated urban databases. This dynamic flow of environmental and mobility information enables more accurate planning, forecasting, and policy design.
projectDetails.details:
ECO CITY – PROJECT FOR THE NASA SPACE APPS CHALLENGE

Challenge: Data Pathways and Healthier Cities

Team: Guardians of the city


In the current world, it is evident that pollutant emissions and sustainability have become critical issues in the social fabric. According to data released by NASA's observatory in 2023, the combined effects of polluted air contribute to 6.7 million premature deaths per year. Thus, atmospheric contamination is a determining factor in the degradation of quality of life.
The causes that aggravate this issue are diverse, with the main ones being: constant use of individual motor vehicles, excessive consumption of electricity and cooling, as well as the inadequate disposal of waste.Furthermore, the time gap for updating urban data is detrimental to urban development, as planners are limited to outdated data, which leads to delays and poor city planning. In this way, Eco City emerges as a solution that connects the environment to the urban planner.
Eco City is the MVP of a fintech company aimed at Generation Z, which seeks health, quality of life, and has become engaged in sustainability issues, as shown by Forbes in the article: Gen Z cares about Sustainability: make your brand actions tangible. For the prototype, we used React Native and Git. At the same time, it is noted that the carbon credit trade remains restricted to the business sphere, disregarding the potential of society’s participation and cooperation as an active agent of environmental impact. In this scenario, Eco City aims to promote integration and collective engagement, aligning the interests of individuals, industry, and the State for sustainable and shared development.
To achieve this, radical innovation is required by creating a sustainable incentive ecosystem that transforms individual environmental actions into real economic value. This proposal fundamentally democratizes the carbon credit market. The technical basis of the GreenToken – Eco City's economic system – is anchored in the metric of avoided CO₂, measured through a transparent and auditable methodology. We used as reference the average emission of a gasoline-powered car, estimated at 0.2 kg CO₂/km, a value that represents the average fleet in circulation. Whenever a user replaces the car with an ecological alternative, the system quantifies the direct reduction in emissions using the formula: Tokens per km = (CO₂ avoided by the activity / CO₂ avoided by the bicycle) × Effort Multiplier. The practical application of this results in specific values for each type of transport: cycling generates 1.0 token/km as the reference standard, walking produces 1.25 tokens/km given its urban mobility, and public transportation generates approximately 0.5 token/km, reflecting its proportionally lower impact – it should be 0.75, but to compensate for walking, the token value for public transport was reduced.
The value of each Green Token was stabilized at $0.87 through a calculation that considers economic viability and aims to engage the user. This value is not arbitrary but derived from a fundamental comparative analysis: considering only the pure value of the carbon credit at $79/tCO₂ – according to the Chicago Stock Exchange on 10/05/2024 – the value per kilometer cycled would be only $0.0158, resulting in just $4.74 per month if the user cycled 300 km/month – an amount clearly insignificant and insufficient to motivate a change in habits. Thus, through a model in which the token value is given by token = monthly target payout / average tokens generated per month. For an average user performing 20 kilometers of cycling (20 Green Tokens), 10 kilometers of walking (15 Green Tokens), and 50 km of public transport (25 Green Tokens), totaling 60 Green Tokens per month, the calculation 52.20/60 = 0.87 USD/token ensures a payout of $52.20, a value sufficiently effective to generate engagement in the population.
The superiority of this model becomes evident in direct comparison with the traditional carbon credit system. In the same usage scenario, the conventional model would generate only $0.95 per month ($0.316 from cycling + $0.237 from walking + $0.395 from public transport), making the incentive of Green Tokens 55 times more powerful and transforming carbon credits from a technical instrument into a viable mechanism of social and economic engagement.
Economic sustainability is guaranteed by the tripartite structure of the Rewards Fund. First, through the sale of aggregated carbon credits, where the actions of all users are consolidated using the formula: Total credits (tCO₂) = Σ (equivalent km × 0.0002) for sale on the voluntary market. Second, through corporate sponsorships for ESG and sustainable marketing, where companies finance part of the fund to achieve proven environmental goals. Third, through the circular economy with partner vouchers, allowing tokens to be exchanged for products and services, reducing the need for direct liquidity in dollars. This structure ensures that the token at $0.87 functions as a stable internal conversion value, backed by real assets and recurring revenues, not by market speculation.
Users have multiple ways of realizing value: direct cash withdrawal, exchange for premium vouchers at partner establishments, donations to environmental projects, or participation in gamification systems with rankings and missions that offer multipliers and additional bonuses. This diversified ecosystem creates virtuous cycles of sustainable engagement, where each use or redemption feeds back into the system while generating valuable impact data for companies and governments.
In conclusion, Green Tokens profoundly redefine the role of the citizen in the contemporary carbon economy. By systematically converting sustainable activities into measurable and financially relevant value, we create a paradigm where individuals are fairly and motivationally rewarded; companies meet ESG goals with precise traceability and authentic social engagement; governments and cities acquire new metrics for participatory decarbonization; and the planet benefits from real, measurable, and auditable emission reductions. The $0.87 token thus symbolizes much more than a monetary value – it represents the concrete instrument that materializes environmental impact into tangible economic and social return, transforming sustainability from an abstract concept into a lived purpose and shared benefit.
In addition, the Eco City project also includes an interface for the urban planner. As mentioned earlier, whether governmental or not, the time gap for updating this data hinders professionals from predicting and designing scenarios, which delays urban development. Thus, with data collected from users on urban mobility, planners would rely on seasonal reports to complement the previous database, thereby reducing the time gap.
For future implementations, the proposal is to integrate municipal data on infrastructure, mobility, sanitation, energy, and housing with NASA's spatial information, capable of representing the environmental and climatic behavior of the territory. From this combination, we could build a simulator that projects possible changes in the city and assists in visualizing the consequent urban alterations in the region, such as increased traffic or microeconomic changes, with precision.

challengeDetails.title: Data Pathways to Healthy Cities and Human Settlements
challengeDetails.excerpt: Climate change brings about new complexities to consider for maintaining the wellbeing of society and the environment in cities. Natural resources, ecosystems, and existing infrastructure all must be monitored to ensure human quality of life remains high. Your challenge is to demonstrate how an urban planner can use NASA Earth observation data to develop smart strategies for city growth that maintain both the wellbeing of people and the environment. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Project Guinea Pigs
projectDetails.summary:
Urbanization, which intensified after the Industrial Revolutions, brought significant technological and economic progress, but also considerable environmental impacts, most notably, increased deforestation and wildfires. Many of these fires are intentionally set to convert forested areas into urban or industrial zones, serving economic interests. Additionally, fires are used as a low-cost method of waste disposal. Although natural fires, such as those caused by lightning, do occur, they represent a small minority. Given the environmental and public health damage caused by wildfires, this project proposes the creation of a website that uses NASA FIRMS' satellites data to detect fire outbreaks in real time or near real time and alert the nearest fire station to facilitate a quick report, leading toa  quick response and containment.

https://nasaspaceapps-guineaspigs-production.up.railway.app/
projectDetails.details:
In this project, our goal is to develop a program capable of analyzing data from the NASA FIRMS's datasets and show the information given about fire spots in an iteractive map, facilitating people to report them to the capable authorities, as well as incentivize people to search about the tragedy those wildfires can lead to.

You can explore more of our project on the link below:

https://nasaspaceapps-guineaspigs-production.up.railway.app/

APIs used:

> NASA’s FIRMS (Fire Information for Resource Management System) API

> Overpass API (OpenStreetMap Overpass API)

> API Ipinfo (to get an approximated position of the user from his IP address)

Receiving the fire spots data:

The following images demonstrate the uses of NASA FIRMS's API to identify the location of fire spots from their latitude and longitude classifying them by its bright(bright_ti4) and also classifying them by color, with  yellow indicating the ones with less heat, and carmine red indicating the fires with most heat.

[IMAGE ID NOT FOUND title:"" ]

The more we zoom out the map, the more the spots get grouped together, showing the number of fire spots present in that region, as seen in the image below:

[IMAGE ID NOT FOUND title:"" ]

Tracking the user’s location

With the help of the Ipinfo API, the program is able to get an approximated location of the user based on its IP address, using that information as a reference when centering the map's field of view.

The user’s location is shown by the blue marker below:

[IMAGE ID NOT FOUND title:"" ]

Tracking the nearest fire brigades

With the use of the Overpass API(OpenStreetMap), the code automatically searches for fire brigades within a radius of 50km.

The fire brigade's location will be shown by a red marker with a picture of a fire extinguisher.

[IMAGE ID NOT FOUND title:"" ]

Automatic updates

The system has a default update time of 10 minutes.

In case there's not a CSV file already loaded, the program will create a new one, consuming the most recent data from the FIRMS API 

In case there is a CSV file already loaded, and it is time to update, the program will save the new CSV file and delete the old one, avoiding duplicates.

This way, the user always has access to the most relevant and recent information regarding the fire spots.

projectDetails.name: Project Guris de Marte
projectDetails.summary: This study presents a sustainable in situ recycling and manufacturing system designed for crewed missions to Mars, inspired by the NASA Space Apps Challenge 2025 — SpaceTrash Hack: Revolutionizing Recycling on Mars. The objective was to propose innovative solutions for reusing polymeric materials and foams, such as Zotek F30, Plastazote, EVA, and nitrile gloves, based on technologies previously tested by NASA under microgravity conditions. A qualitative and exploratory methodology was employed, grounded in scientific literature, technical NASA reports, and open-source sustainability projects. The developed model introduces a modular, lightweight, and energy-efficient system capable of shredding, melting, and extruding waste into reusable filaments for 3D printers such as the ReFabricator and the Additive Manufacturing Facility (AMF). Beyond technical aspects, the project incorporates environmental and psychological dimensions through the concepts of “Residential Renewal” and “Cosmic Celebration,” which emphasize the creative reuse of waste to enhance habitat comfort and crew well-being. Results suggest that integrating thermal recycling, additive manufacturing, and modular equipment design enables a closed-loop reuse system for Martian colonies, reducing Earth dependency while promoting self-sufficiency and sustainability in long-duration missions.
projectDetails.details:
Our project implements a compact and modular recycling line for three classes of inorganic waste: plastics, metals, and textiles. It focuses on benchtop operations, closed-loop cleaning, and controlled preparation of inputs for manufacturing. The architecture prioritizes mechanical and thermomechanical processes, avoiding combustion and minimizing byproducts. The final valorization stage uses additive manufacturing: 3D printing for polymers and WAAM (Wire Arc Additive Manufacturing) for metals, both technologies already used and investigated by NASA in different programs and testbeds, reinforcing their maturity and applicability for space missions.

Plastics

Shredding

Plastic waste is first segregated by polymer family (PE, PP, PET, PA, EVA, and foams) with removal of surface contaminants. It then goes through a low-speed shredder to reduce it to uniform flakes or chips, which facilitates rheology in extrusion and thermal compaction. Washing occurs in a closed water loop with controlled drying to remove moisture and residues that could cause extrusion failures and defects in additive manufacturing.

Extrusion

Hygroscopic polymers are pre-dried. The material is melted in an extruder with heating zones and a conveying screw, then forced through a die with controlled temperature, pressure, and cooling, ensuring dimensional stability of the input (filaments or pellets). This control guarantees diameter and viscosity consistency, essential for stable deposition in 3D printing.

Compression

Dried flakes or pellets are loaded into molds and subjected to hot pressing under defined temperature and pressure parameters. Cooling under pressure stabilizes dimensions and reduces internal stresses. This step produces flat or shallow shapes as semifinished stock that can be machined or drilled and used as bases for habitat components.

3D Printer

The extruded material is used as input for fused filament 3D printing. Layer-by-layer deposition is adjusted by nozzle and bed temperatures, speed, and interlayer cooling, ensuring geometric integrity and cohesion. This stage converts recycled mass into functional parts with sufficient precision for daily habitat use.

Metals

Shredding

Metal items are disassembled with separation of nonmetallic parts. Mechanical fragmentation adjusts size for subsequent steps, followed by cleaning and drying to remove oils, moisture, and residues that would degrade solid-state bonding and wire quality.

Pressing

Fragments are compacted into briquettes to increase apparent density and enable subsequent consolidation. Applied pressure promotes initial cohesion without melting, and mild thermal conditioning helps remove trapped gases that could cause porosity during extrusion.

Metal extrusion

Briquettes are heated below the melting point in a controlled environment and subjected to plastic deformation by solid-state extrusion to form rods that are then drawn down to wire. Atmosphere control minimizes oxidation, a critical factor to avoid inclusions and bonding defects. The result is wire with suitable diameter and surface for the additive stage.

Metal 3D printer

Metal additive manufacturing is performed by the WAAM method with wire feed. The process uses a controlled arc (MIG or CMT) for layer-by-layer bonding, with thermal management between passes to limit residual stresses and discontinuities. WAAM is a proven route for large metal parts and has been explored and used by NASA in studies, experiments, and pilot applications, such as the printing of large structural components and tooling, confirming its suitability for mission environments.

Textiles

Non-synthetics

Cotton or cellulose textiles are cleaned and dried for hygiene and dimensional stabilization, then cut and organized by basis weight and weave. This preparation ensures predictable behavior in forming steps.

Shredding

Textiles are fragmented into strips or flakes by manual or mechanical cutting, with size homogenization for consistent performance. Storage is in dry conditions to prevent degradation.

Compaction and needling

Overlapped layers form a web that is consolidated by needling or compression, promoting fiber interlocking. Density is adjusted by varying the number of layers and the intensity of needling, producing webs with different stiffnesses and thicknesses.

Light thermal pressing

The formed web is stabilized by moderate heat and pressure. Flat surfaces or molds impart the desired geometry, and cooling under pressure locks in the structure, resulting in panels and mats with stable form.

Synthetics

Polyester or nylon fabrics are cleaned and dried, cut, and organized by basis weight and texture. Where applicable, edges are thermally sealed to reduce fraying and loose particles.

Shredding

The material is reduced to flakes or strips, classified by size for processing consistency, and stored in closed containers to avoid contamination.

Light thermal pressing

Layers are thermally laminated under pressure for cohesion. Forming in shallow or flat molds is controlled in time and temperature, and controlled cooling maintains the final shape. This approach also produces stable mats and panels for internal habitat uses.

challengeDetails.title: SpaceTrash Hack: Revolutionizing Recycling on Mars
challengeDetails.excerpt: During a hypothetical three-year mission to Mars and back, an eight-person crew would accumulate 12,600 kg of inorganic waste, or trash, including various packaging materials, textiles, and structural materials. This scenario creates a pressing need to recycle available materials, rather than execute the expensive and inefficient processes of transporting additional resources from Earth and/or sending trash back to Earth. As humans prepare to explore unknown worlds in the future, your challenge is to design sustainable systems that could manage, reuse, or recycle inorganic waste (“trash”) that is brought to and/or accumulated on the surface of Mars. (Space Technology Mission Directorate)

challengeDetails.title: Your Home in Space: The Habitat Layout Creator
challengeDetails.excerpt: Space habitats are “homes in space” that keep crew members healthy and able to execute their mission. Whether located on a planetary surface or in space, habitats must support critical functions such as waste management, thermal control, life support, communications, power, stowage, food storage and preparation, medical care, sleep, and exercise. Space habitat concepts can involve a diverse array of materials, geometries, and layouts. Your challenge is to create a visual tool that enables users to define a space habitat’s shape/volume and explore possible layout options. (Exploration Systems Development Mission Directorate)

challengeDetails.title: From EarthData to Action: Cloud Computing with Earth Observation Data for Predicting Cleaner, Safer Skies
challengeDetails.excerpt: NASA’s Tropospheric Emissions: Monitoring of Pollution (TEMPO) mission is revolutionizing air quality monitoring across North America by enabling better forecasts and reducing pollutant exposure. Your challenge is to develop a web-based app that forecasts air quality by integrating real-time TEMPO data with ground-based air quality measurements and weather data, notifying users of poor air quality, and helping to improve public health decisions. Teams are encouraged to utilize new technologies that allow seamless scaling of computing from local devices to cloud systems, enhancing collaboration and streamlining work efficiency. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: GoldLens
projectDetails.summary:
GoldLens is an AI-powered platform designed to assist in the detection of exoplanets using NASA’s open-source datasets. Developed for the NASA Space Apps Challenge 2025, it addresses the challenge of automating exoplanet identification — a task that has historically relied on manual analysis.

The system integrates a Python-based backend and a React web frontend, providing an accessible interface for training, evaluating, and applying machine learning models. The core AI model is trained by combining two distinct datasets — KOI and K2 — to enhance generalization and improve classification accuracy across different missions.

GoldLens not only supports researchers in detecting potential exoplanets but also promotes open science, transparency, and collaboration by offering an end-to-end, user-friendly environment for exploring astronomical data.
projectDetails.details:
GoldLens is an artificial intelligence platform designed to automate exoplanet detection using open NASA datasets. It combines KOI and K2 data to train a robust machine learning model capable of classifying celestial objects as potential exoplanets. The model leverages scikit-learn with techniques such as SMOTE for class balancing and Random Forest for feature analysis and prediction accuracy.

The backend, developed in Python, handles data preprocessing, model training, evaluation, and inference, while the frontend, built with React + Vite, offers a modern and interactive interface. Users can visualize performance metrics such as precision, recall, AUC-ROC, and the confusion matrix, enabling transparent analysis and reproducibility.

GoldLens provides both scientific and educational benefits: it simplifies complex data science workflows, encourages collaboration, and makes advanced AI tools accessible to students, researchers, and enthusiasts. The project promotes open science and democratization of space research, aligning with NASA’s mission of fostering global participation in space exploration.

Our team’s creativity lies in uniting data science, astronomy, and usability within a single, open-source platform — making the search for worlds beyond not only possible but interactive and inspiring.
projectDetails.aiReferences: AI/LLM Tools were used to assist mainly on parts of the code made for data preprocessing and web development. Also, the video description of the project made by the team, available on Youtube, used AI Tools for editing.

challengeDetails.title: A World Away: Hunting for Exoplanets with AI
challengeDetails.excerpt: Data from several different space-based exoplanet surveying missions have enabled discovery of thousands of new planets outside our solar system, but most of these exoplanets were identified manually. With advances in artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML), it is possible to automatically analyze large sets of data collected by these missions to identify exoplanets. Your challenge is to create an AI/ML model that is trained on one or more of the open-source exoplanet datasets offered by NASA and that can analyze new data to accurately identify exoplanets. (Astrophysics Division)

challengeDetails.title: Deep Dive: Immersive Data Stories from Ocean to Sky
challengeDetails.excerpt: Satellite observations reveal insights about our dynamic home planet to scientists, but people without a remote sensing background often find the stories within these datasets difficult to access. NASA’s open data policy makes these observations available to everyone—scientists and non-scientists alike. Your challenge is to build a short, immersive, virtual reality (VR) experience that leverages NASA’s Earth observation datasets and visualizations to bring stories about our planet’s oceans to life, connecting a broad audience to this data, its beauty, and its impact. Using visuals, spatial audio, and even interactive elements, your VR experience can enable users to dive deeper into Earth’s unfolding ocean story. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: IFTeaM
projectDetails.summary: The IFTeam, composed of six first-year high school students, developed an interactive website to catalog and summarize NASA research data. We created a responsive dashboard that allows users to explore and visualize research findings easily. Using CSV files as our initial data source, we worked to integrate the information into an online API for easier management and display. Built with VS Code, HTML, Tailwind CSS, and JavaScript, the project demonstrates how young students can combine programming, data visualization, and teamwork to make scientific data more accessible and engaging.
projectDetails.details:
Project Details

The IFTeam, composed of six first-year high school students, developed an interactive website designed to catalog, summarize, and visualize NASA research data. Our main goal was to make scientific information accessible, engaging, and easy to understand, while demonstrating how student-led projects can leverage technology to explore real-world data.

How It Works

The project starts with NASA research data stored in CSV files, which include titles, summaries, publication details, and other relevant information. These files are processed and displayed through a responsive, interactive dashboard. Users can:

Browse research projects by category or topic;


View summarized descriptions to quickly understand the content;



Filter or search for specific studies, making the data easier to navigate;



Visualize data dynamically with panels that adapt to different screen sizes.

To improve data management, we also attempted to convert the CSV files into an online API, enabling more efficient updates, filtering, and dynamic display. This approach allows the dashboard to handle larger datasets and provide real-time access without manually editing the files.

Benefits and Intended Impact

The website makes NASA research more accessible to students, educators, and space enthusiasts, offering a platform where complex information can be explored intuitively. By presenting scientific data visually, the project encourages learning, curiosity, and critical thinking. It also demonstrates how young students can combine programming, data visualization, and teamwork skills to create practical and educational technology tools.

Tools, Languages, and Technologies

Visual Studio Code (VS Code) – development environment

HTML, CSS (Tailwind), JavaScript – frontend design and structure

Node.js + Express – backend prototype for API integration

CSV files – original structured dataset

NASA Open Data – primary source of information

Creativity and Design Considerations

Our project is creative because it transforms raw CSV data into an interactive, user-friendly dashboard, inspired by professional NASA-style visualizations. Key design considerations included:

User experience, with clear navigation and visual hierarchy;

Data clarity, presenting summaries in an easily digestible format;

Interactivity, allowing users to explore research projects dynamically.

Future Potential

The project can be further expanded to include additional NASA datasets, visualizations, or interactive charts, making it an even more comprehensive tool for learning and research. By creating this dashboard, we aim to bridge the gap between complex space research and public understanding, inspiring students and the general public to engage with scientific data in a meaningful way.
projectDetails.aiReferences: We used AI tools to synthesize some code snippets through ChatGPT and Gemini, to improve translation and proofreading of texts, to help summarize and explain parts of the project creation process, and we also attempted to implement the Gemini AI API to assist with a function on the website.

Your challenge is to build a dynamic dashboard that leverages artificial intelligence (AI), knowledge graphs, and/or other tools to summarize a set of NASA bioscience publications and enables users to explore the impacts and results of the experiments these publications describe. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Quality Air
projectDetails.summary:
The "Quality Ar" project forecasts Nitrogen Dioxide (NO2) levels and the corresponding air quality index in São Paulo. Using historical data from the CETESB Pinheiros monitoring station, it allows users to check air quality predictions for specific future dates.

This tool addresses the challenge of urban pollution by enabling citizens, especially vulnerable groups, to take preventive health measures against high pollution days. Its importance lies in democratizing access to environmental data, raising awareness, and helping people make informed decisions to protect their health.
projectDetails.details:
The benefits:

  • Accurate forecast of NO2
  • A study to define public policies to support people with or at risk of respiratory diseases.
  • A study to improve air quality and understand the main emitters of hazardous gases.

Tools:

  • Python for data analysis, neural network training, forecast NO2 at N dates.
  • Java for scrape data from CETESB Qualar
  • React Native for frontend.

Hardware:

  • PCs with GPU dedicated to train and test the models
  • Dedicated Server to Host the backend and frontend

projectDetails.name: Project KOIKWA
projectDetails.summary:
Koikwa 1 – Buraco no Céu is an educational Internet of Things (IoT) project designed to simulate satellite data acquisition and analysis. The system measures local environmental conditions—specifically temperature—using a BMP180 sensor connected to a Heltec V3 microcontroller, and compares these ground-based readings with satellite-derived temperature estimates from NASA’s POWER (Prediction of Worldwide Energy Resources) dataset.

Additionally, the project integrates a u-blox M10 GPS module to record geographic coordinates (latitude and longitude), ensuring accurate spatial correlation between local and satellite data. Data is transmitted via Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) in real time to a connected application, where it is stored, visualized through dynamic graphs, and analyzed statistically to highlight variations and trends.

The overarching mission of Koikwa 1 – Buraco no Céu is to inspire scientific curiosity and technological learning among children by providing a hands-on demonstration of how IoT technologies and open-access satellite data can be combined to explore environmental science in an accessible and engaging way.
projectDetails.details: The project aims to simulate the reading of satellite data by comparing temperature measurements obtained from the BMP180 sensor with information from NASA POWER, while also displaying latitude and longitude data using the u-blox M10 GPS module, with both the module and sensor controlled by the ESP32-S3 microcontroller.

projectDetails.name: Project Koikwa 2
projectDetails.summary:
Our project, Koikwa 2 - Cotton Rope, is a space lander prototype designed as an educational tool for instrumentation, embedded electronics, sensing, and programming. We developed a system using a BBC micro:bit board and an HC-SR04 ultrasonic sensor to map surfaces by acquiring real-time distance and magnetic field data. The micro:bit's internal magnetometer measures the magnetic field, providing orientation and composition data, while the ultrasonic sensor determines the lander's altitude and maps the surface topography.
This prototype directly addresses the challenge by providing a hands-on, low-cost platform for learning essential space exploration technologies. Our project is deeply inspired by the origin story of the Kayapó people of Brazil, whose ancestors descended from the sky on a long cotton rope. In their story, the stars represent their celestial ancestors. Our lander's descent to map a new world mirrors this mythological journey. This connection is important as it bridges modern space science with the rich, ancient cosmology of indigenous cultures, reminding us that the quest to understand our origins and explore new frontiers is a timeless, universal human endeavor.
projectDetails.details:
Inspiration: A Bridge Between Worlds

Our project is deeply rooted in the powerful origin story of the Mebêngôkre (Kayapó) people, an indigenous ethnicity from our home region in Uberlândia, Brazil. Their cosmology tells of ancestors who lived in the sky until a warrior discovered a passage to Earth. Enchanted by the world below, they decided to descend using a long rope made of cotton. For them, the stars are their celestial ancestors, a nightly reminder of their origins.

Our lander's mission—to descend from above and map an unknown world—is a direct technological parallel to this ancient journey. Our "Cotton Rope" is the stream of data connecting our probe to our control station. The goal of Koikwa 2 is to create a project that is not only scientifically functional but also rich in meaning, connecting the drive for space exploration with humanity's oldest stories about the cosmos.

How It Works: The Technical Mission

Koikwa 2 is a functional prototype built to demonstrate the core principles of a planetary lander's survey mission.

  • Hardware Core: The brain of our lander is a BBC micro:bit, a versatile and accessible microcontroller. It's connected to an HC-SR04 ultrasonic sensor, which acts as a simple altimeter and surface scanner. The entire system is powered by a 3.7V LiPo battery, making it a self-contained unit.
    1. Topographical Mapping: The HC-SR04 sensor emits ultrasonic pulses and measures the time it takes for the echo to return. Our code converts this time into a precise distance measurement, allowing the lander to map the height and contours of the surface below it.
    2. Magnetic Field Analysis: Simultaneously, the micro:bit’s onboard magnetometer gathers magnetic field data (X, Y, Z axes). This data can be used to determine the lander's orientation and could potentially detect magnetic anomalies on a planetary surface.
  • Software & Data Stream: The firmware was developed in MicroPython, valued for its simplicity and power. The lander outputs a continuous stream of comma-separated values (CSV) in the format distance_cm, magnetic_field_x, magnetic_field_y, magnetic_field_z via a serial connection. This raw data can be easily logged, parsed, and visualized using simple scripts or even spreadsheet software.


How Our Project Addresses the Challenge

Koikwa 2 directly addresses the challenge of creating educational tools for space science in several ways:

  • Accessibility & Low Cost: It uses off-the-shelf, affordable components, making space science accessible to students, hobbyists, and educators without large budgets.
  • Hands-On Learning: It provides a tangible platform for learning fundamental skills in electronics, programming (MicroPython), sensor integration, and data analysis—the very skills needed for a career in aerospace.
  • Inspiration & STEAM: By connecting STEM with the Arts and Humanities (the "A" in STEAM), our project provides a powerful narrative hook to engage a wider and more diverse audience in the wonders of space exploration.

projectDetails.details:
Temporean

This is a web application that provides AI-powered weather forecasts to help users plan their outdoor events.

The application offers real-time forecasts for upcoming dates and utilizes historical data for long-term forecasts, ensuring you're always prepared.

The main backend logic runs on the server.

The application is a Single-Page Application (SPA), with all user interaction occurring on a single main screen.

Benefities:

Location- and Date-Based Forecast: Enter any location, date, and time to get a detailed weather forecast.

AI Analysis: Uses generative AI (Genkit with Gemini) to analyze weather data and provide:

Probability Scores: Percentage ratings for conditions such as "Too Hot," "Too Cold," "Too Windy," "Too Wet," and "Uncomfortable."

Detailed Report: A natural language summary of what to expect, with personalized advice based on the details of your event.

Real-Time and Historical Forecasts: Uses the Open-Meteo API for real-time forecasts for the next 14 days.

Uses NASA's POWER API for historical data averages for future dates beyond 14 days.

Customizable Comfort Thresholds: Set your own thresholds for temperature, humidity, and wind speed to get a personalized "uncomfort" score.

Interactive Map: Visualize your event's location on an interactive map (Leaflet) with satellite and cloud layers.

Data Export: Download complete forecast data in CSV format with a single click.

Responsive Design: User interface built with Tailwind CSS and ShadCN UI that works seamlessly on mobile and desktop devices.

Event Details Form

A form where users enter the information needed to generate the forecast.

Location: Event location (text).

Date: Event date (date picker).

Time: Event time (time picker).

Event Details: Optional event description (text area).

Customize Thresholds (Optional, expandable):

Temp (°C): Temperature threshold for discomfort.

Humidity (%): Humidity threshold for discomfort.

Wind (km/h): Wind speed threshold for discomfort.

Main Function:

Receives form data.

Calls the geocodeLocation function to obtain coordinates from the location name using the OpenStreetMap API.

Checks whether the event date is within 14 days or in the distant future.

Calls a function (using the Open-Meteo API) for near-term dates or getHistoricalForecast (using the NASA POWER API) for distant dates.

Prepares the AI ​​input with the weather data.

Calls Genkit's conditionLikelihoodForecast function to obtain the AI ​​analysis.

Returns the full result (or an error) to the frontend.

Forecast Display:

This section appears after submitting the form and displays the results of the AI ​​analysis.

Forecast Summary:

Displays probability scores (0-100%) for conditions such as:

"Very Hot," "Very Cold," "Very Windy," etc.

Exports data in CSV format.

Location Map:

An interactive map showing the location of the event with map layers (Street, Satellite, Clouds).

Integrates NASA GIBS satellite layers, allowing you to view clouds (GOES) and precipitation (GPM) in real time.

Detailed Report:

Displays the text generated by AI.

Technologies

The application uses the Next.js App Router. Nodejs. https://nodejs.org/

Frontend:

Next.js (App Router)

React

TypeScript

Styling:

Tailwind CSS

ShadCN UI

Maps:

Leaflet

React Leaflet

External APIs

Geocoding: OpenStreetMap Nominatim API.

Real-Time Forecast: Open-Meteo API (Real-Time Geocoding and Forecast)

Historical Data: NASA POWER API
projectDetails.aiReferences:
We use AI to generate textual weather analysis using Genkit and Google Gemini.

The AI ​​queries the Open-Meteo API and the NASA POWER API to obtain real-time weather data (temperature, humidity, wind), making the analysis more accurate.

projectDetails.name: The Secrets of Space Weather
projectDetails.summary:
Our project, “The Secrets of Space Weather”, focuses on teaching kids about space weather through a fun and educational game. The main goal is to make complex scientific concepts, such as solar flares, CMEs, radiation storms, and their effects on Earth, accessible and engaging for young learners. We developed an interactive digital game that combines storytelling, colorful visuals, and simple challenges to encourage curiosity and understanding of how the Sun influences our planet.

To address the challenge of limited awareness and education about space weather among children, "The Secrets of Space Weather" uses gamified learning techniques and playful interaction. The game provides short missions where players learn about solar activity and understand the importance of space weather in our lives. This approach transforms abstract scientific data into relatable, hands-on experiences.

"The Secrets of Space Weather" is important because it bridges the gap between science and education, inspiring the next generation to explore astronomy and space science. By presenting real scientific ideas in a creative and age-appropriate way, the project promotes STEM education (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) and helps build a foundation for future scientific curiosity and understanding.
projectDetails.details:
The mysteries of space weather and its influence on Earth are often seen as complex and distant subjects, but they can directly affect our daily lives. Solar flares, coronal mass ejections, and geomagnetic storms can interfere with communication systems, navigation, and even power grids. Despite their importance, these phenomena are rarely explored in an accessible way for young audiences.

To change this, we created “The Secrets of Space Weather”, a digital educational game  that combines science, art, and narrative to introduce children and teenagers aged 10 to 15 years to the fascinating world of space weather — in a fun and interactive way.

The story follows Luma, a curious girl passionate about science who embarks on a journey guided by her scientist friend, Dr.Brall, to discover what space weather is and how it affects people around the world. Across three exciting phases, Luma meets different characters such as a pilot struggling with signal loss, a photographer chasing auroras, and astronauts facing dangerous solar radiation. Throughout these, Luma meets not only people impacted by the space weather but also the personified phenomena themselves.

Each event, like a Solar Flare, an Aurora Borealis or a Radiation Storm, becomes a living character who explains its origins and behavior. These unique interactions allow children to learn from both sides of the story: the people who experience the effects and the solar phenomena that cause them. Each encounter includes playful dialogues that translate scientific concepts into easy understanding comparisons and mini-games that reinforce learning in a fun way.

What makes our solution unique is its creative and emotional approach. The personification of solar events gives them memorable and relatable personalities that help children connect emotionally with scientific ideas. Through visual metaphors and everyday analogies, the game connects abstract physics to the child’s own world, making learning intuitive and inspiring.

Unlike traditional educational materials, our game does not just explain — it invites the player to live science, allowing children to actively participate in the narrative, helping characters and solving thematic mini-games. This promotes active learning, critical thinking, and curiosity through play. 

Another key differentiator is the balanced portrayal of space weather’s dual nature — its challenges, like radiation and interference, and its beauty, like the auroras that paint the sky. Few educational materials highlight this duality, and our game does so in a way that sparks wonder, empathy, and environmental awareness.

Beyond entertainment, the game has strong educational potential. It can be integrated into classrooms or informal learning environments as a support tool for science education and space literacy, encouraging new generations to become interested in astronomy, physics, and environmental awareness.

In addition, the project aligns with several United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). By promoting accessible STEM education and scientific literacy, it supports SDG 4 (Quality Education). Finally, by encouraging environmental awareness and responsibility through its storytelling, it contributes to SDG 13 (Climate Action). Together, these goals reflect the project’s broader mission — to inspire informed, responsible, and curious citizens capable of understanding and protecting both our planet and the space environment that surrounds it.

Our current version functions as a pilot project with three stages, designed to demonstrate the game’s educational potential and scalability. Future levels can be created to expand this universe, introducing new challenges such as helping a power grid operator redirect Geomagnetically Induced Currents (GICs) to protect transformers from failures caused by Geomagnetic Disturbances (GMDs); assisting a space traffic engineer in maneuvering satellites to compensate for increased atmospheric drag driven by Coronal Mass Ejections (CMEs) and neutral density (ND) expansion; or even supporting a farmer in stabilizing GNSS signals to ensure precise planting despite signal scintillation during a geomagnetic storm. This progressive expansion highlights the real-world diversity of space weather impacts, demonstrating the game’s potential to grow further while educating players about some of the most fascinating space phenomena.

The project was developed using Kripta for character and environment design and Godot 4.5 as the main game engine, with GDScript as the primary programming language. The Dialogic plugin was implemented to manage the interactive storytelling system. Team collaboration was supported through Discord for communication and Git/GitHub for version control and code synchronization.

The educational content is based on NASA data, which provided the scientific foundation to explain key space weather concepts such as solar flares, aurora borealis, radiation storms, coronal mass ejections (CMEs), and the solar activity cycle. The design of the game’s levels and missions — such as helping a transatlantic pilot after a solar flare or saving astronauts facing dangerous solar radiation — was created by insights from a NASA survey on user needs for space weather, ensuring the gameplay aligns with realistic scenarios and practical understanding.

The game's design is directly inspired by the Results of the First National Survey of User Needs for Space Weather (NASA resource) report, which outlines user needs and critical impacts across seven sectors important to national security, the economy, and society. The idea was to transform documented space weather threats into a dynamic challenges. For instance, the Aviation Sector phase mirrors the real-world operational need to mitigate risks from Solar Flares that cause HF communication outages (Radio Blackouts), forcing the player to execute the maneuver of diverting the aircraft to safer routes, replicating actions taken by some air carriers during events like the Gannon Storm. By translating these specific, identified sector vulnerabilities and the documented need for improved education and awareness into dynamic mechanics the game directly contributes to the overarching goal of enhancing national resilience to space weather.

Ultimately, “The Secrets of Space Weather” seeks to make space science accessible, emotional, and inspiring. By transforming NASA’s research into a living adventure, combining visual design, gameplay mechanics, and verified space weather data, our project not only educates but also cultivates the next generation’s curiosity about the Sun–Earth connection, motivating young minds to explore, discover, and protect the world around them — from the ground to the stars — with wonder and understanding.
projectDetails.aiReferences: We used AI (ChatGPT version 5.0) primarily to assist with translation, text refinement, and generating ideas for the project script. Additionally, AI was employed to troubleshoot technical issues and suggest improvements in code.

challengeDetails.title: Stellar Stories: Space Weather Through the Eyes of Earthlings
challengeDetails.excerpt: Although the Sun is 93 million miles away from our planet, solar activity can significantly impact our daily lives. “Space weather”—the variations that occur in the space environment between the Sun and Earth—can impact technologies in space and on Earth. Your challenge is to write and illustrate a digital children’s story that explains what space weather is and the varying impacts it has on different people such as farmers, pilots, astronauts, power grid operators, and the general public. You can tell the story from the perspective of a person impacted by space weather or from the point of view of a solar flare or coronal mass ejection (CME) as it approaches Earth. (Heliophysics Division)
