projectDetails.name: Project Lobotomia Soluções
projectDetails.summary:
Our project, Astral Leucotome, is an interactive, web-based simulation tool that models the regional consequences of an asteroid impact on Earth. We developed a Python Flask backend that serves as the scientific engine, coupled with a dynamic JavaScript frontend that provides intuitive controls and a map-based interface for visualizing the outcomes.
This tool directly addresses the challenge by allowing users to select real asteroids from NASA's API or customize their own theoretical impactor. The backend calculates a suite of environmental effects using physics-based models, including crater dimensions, kinetic energy, seismic magnitude, and air blast radius. These calculations are based on established scientific principles, such as the Gutenberg-Richter relation for seismic shaking and yield scaling for the air blast. Users can also simulate a kinetic impactor mitigation mission, demonstrating how a spacecraft can alter an asteroid's velocity.
The importance of this project lies in its ability to make the abstract threat of an asteroid impact tangible and accessible. By translating complex scientific data into clear, visual consequences, it serves as a powerful educational tool for the public, students, and policymakers, effectively underscoring the critical importance of planetary defense initiatives.
projectDetails.details:
What It Does & How It Works

Astral Leucotome is a web-based simulation tool that calculates and visualizes the regional environmental consequences of an asteroid impact on Earth. It operates on a client-server architecture:

  • Backend: A robust API built with Python and the Flask framework serves as the scientific engine. It receives simulation parameters, fetches real-time data on near-Earth objects from NASA's NeoWs API, and processes it through a pipeline of physics modules. These modules calculate the asteroid's kinetic energy, the resulting crater dimensions, the equivalent seismic magnitude (using the Gutenberg-Richter relation), and the radius of the air-blast shockwave based on scientific models from papers like Collins et al. (2005). The backend also includes an endpoint to simulate a kinetic impactor mitigation mission.
  • Frontend: A dynamic, interactive interface built with HTML, CSS, and JavaScript (using jQuery, Leaflet, Bootstrap, D3 and TreeJS) provides the user experience. Users can either select a real asteroid from a searchable list or customize a theoretical impactor using sliders for mass, diameter, and velocity. They can then choose an impact point by dragging and dropping an icon onto an interactive world map, triggering the simulation and visualizing the results.

The primary benefit of our project is its educational power. It demystifies the complex science of asteroid impacts, making the abstract threat tangible and accessible to a broad audience, from students to policymakers. By transforming raw scientific data into clear visual outputs—such as concentric circles for the crater and shockwave on a map—the tool effectively communicates the scale of a potential disaster.

The intended impact is threefold:

  1. Raise Public Awareness: To foster a greater public understanding of the real, albeit low-probability, risk of an asteroid impact.
  2. Support Decision-Making: To provide a "what-if" sandbox where users can explore the consequences of an impact in a specific location, highlighting the need for and effectiveness of planetary defense.
  3. Inspire Interest in Science: To create an engaging, hands-on experience that encourages exploration and learning in the fields of physics, geology, and planetary science.

Tools, Languages, and Software

  • Backend:
    • Languages: Python
    • Frameworks/Libraries: Flask (for the web server), Flasgger (for OpenAPI/Swagger documentation), SQLAlchemy (for caching), python-dotenv (for environment management).
    • Languages: HTML, CSS, JavaScript
    • Frameworks/Libraries: Bootstrap (for styling and layout), jQuery (for DOM manipulation), Leaflet (for the interactive 2D map), D3.js and Three.js (for dynamic data visualizations and 3D rendering).
    • Version Control: Git, GitHub
    • IDE: Visual Studio Code
    • Deployment/Tunneling: ngrok (for development and sharing).

The project's creativity lies in its transformation of static scientific research into a dynamic, hands-on learning experience. Instead of reading a complex paper, a user can directly engage with the physics. The combination of a searchable database of real asteroids with fully customizable "what-if" scenarios provides both realism and creative freedom. The drag-and-drop interface for selecting an impact location is an intuitive and engaging method that immediately connects the simulation to a familiar geographical context, making the results far more personal and impactful.

Factors Considered

Our team prioritized several key factors during development:

  • Scientific Accuracy: We based our core calculations on peer-reviewed scientific literature, specifically the models presented by Collins, Melosh, & Marcus (2005) for impact effects and the Gutenberg-Richter relation for seismic magnitude. We made simplifications where necessary for the hackathon but always started from an established scientific basis.
  • User Experience (UX): We focused on creating an intuitive interface. The use of sliders for input, real-time calculation feedback, and clear visual outputs on a map were all deliberate choices to make the tool easy and engaging to use without prior scientific knowledge.
  • Modularity and Scalability: The backend was designed with a clear separation of concerns (data fetching, energetics, cratering, effects), making the code easier to manage, test, and extend in the future.
  • Team Collaboration: We utilized a feature-branching workflow in Git to allow for parallel development on the frontend and various backend modules, which was critical for making significant progress in a short amount of time.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
We utilized Google's Gemini, ass an AI-powered tutor, and technical consultant throughout the hackathon. The AI's role was to accelerate development and assist in overcoming technical challenges, allowing our team to focus on the project's vision, design, and scientific integration.

Specifically, AI was used in the following areas:

  • Conceptualization and Scientific Modeling: Assisting in the interpretation of the project's scientific documents, explaining complex physics concepts (such as kinetic energy, overpressure, and NAT loopback), and helping select and implement appropriate simplified formulas (like the Gutenberg-Richter relation and cube root scaling for air blasts) for the hackathon's scope.
  • Debugging: Providing real-time assistance in diagnosing and solving a wide range of issues
  • Best Practices and Documentation: Aiding in the formulation of conventional Git commit messages, explaining team collaboration workflows (feature branching), translating code comments, and assisting in the drafting of the final project summaries and descriptions.

All AI-generated code and concepts were reviewed, understood, and integrated by the team members.

challengeDetails.title: Meteor Madness
challengeDetails.excerpt: A newly identified near-Earth asteroid, "Impactor-2025," poses a potential threat to Earth, but do we have the tools to enable the public and decision makers to understand and mitigate its risks? NASA datasets include information about known asteroids and the United States Geological Survey provides critical information that could enable modeling the effects of asteroid impacts, but this data needs to be integrated to enable effective visualization and decision making. Your challenge is to develop an interactive visualization and simulation tool that uses real data to help users model asteroid impact scenarios, predict consequences, and evaluate potential mitigation strategies. (Planetary Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: A World Away: Hunting for Exoplanets with AI
challengeDetails.excerpt: Data from several different space-based exoplanet surveying missions have enabled discovery of thousands of new planets outside our solar system, but most of these exoplanets were identified manually. With advances in artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML), it is possible to automatically analyze large sets of data collected by these missions to identify exoplanets. Your challenge is to create an AI/ML model that is trained on one or more of the open-source exoplanet datasets offered by NASA and that can analyze new data to accurately identify exoplanets. (Astrophysics Division)

challengeDetails.title: Stellar Stories: Space Weather Through the Eyes of Earthlings
challengeDetails.excerpt: Although the Sun is 93 million miles away from our planet, solar activity can significantly impact our daily lives. “Space weather”—the variations that occur in the space environment between the Sun and Earth—can impact technologies in space and on Earth. Your challenge is to write and illustrate a digital children’s story that explains what space weather is and the varying impacts it has on different people such as farmers, pilots, astronauts, power grid operators, and the general public. You can tell the story from the perspective of a person impacted by space weather or from the point of view of a solar flare or coronal mass ejection (CME) as it approaches Earth. (Heliophysics Division)

challengeDetails.title: Sharks from Space
challengeDetails.excerpt: Earth’s ocean is one of the most powerful habitats in our universe, supporting a range of life that sustains ecosystems and habitability across the globe. It is common to measure photosynthetic activity in the ocean from space, but far more challenging to track top predators. Your challenge is to create a mathematical framework for identifying sharks and predicting their foraging habitats using NASA satellite data, and also to suggest a new conceptual model of a tag (a small electronic device that can be attached to an animal to track and study its movement) that could measure not only where sharks are, but also what they are eating, and in real time transmit that data back to users to enable development of predictive models. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: A.I.M. - Aegis Impact Model
projectDetails.summary: A.I.M. (Aegis Impact Model) is a visualization and predictive system designed to simulate and analyze scenarios in which celestial bodies collide with Earth. The platform leverages Large Language Models (LLMs) to generate analytical reports based on the selected impact location, detailing instantaneous, economic, and environmental consequences, as well as physical parameters such as released energy and impact radius. Users can fully customize meteor parameters, including composition, diameter (0–100 km), velocity, and impact angle, enabling the exploration of a wide range of collision scenarios across different regions of the planet. The project aims to serve as both a scientific and exploratory tool, providing a dynamic environment for impact assessment and educational visualization. Future expanded versions of A.I.M. are envisioned to incorporate pre-impact prediction and post-impact analysis, creating a comprehensive framework for understanding and modeling the complete lifecycle of meteor events.
projectDetails.details:
INTRODUCTION

According to the Statistical Discovery Report from the Center for Near-Earth Object Studies (CNEOS), nearly 40,000 Near-Earth Objects (NEOs) have been discovered to date. With a significant number of these bodies passing close to Earth, and with recorded impact events such as the Chelyabinsk Event (2013), the study and prediction of potential impact scenarios are of critical importance. Accurate forecasting of such events has the potential to mitigate risks and ultimately save lives.

[Image 1 - CNEOS Close Approach Visualization 2025 SY10]

THE NECESSITY

Given the vast number of objects passing near Earth, the probability of collisions with our planet remains a significant parameter to consider. Through the use of advanced computational and analytical technologies, predicting all possible impact scenarios based on an asteroid’s physical composition and trajectory becomes an invaluable approach to mitigating potential threats.

From an educational perspective, such a tool could serve as an exceptional resource for academic research, classroom studies, and scientific outreach, enhancing understanding of celestial dynamics and planetary defense.

THE SOLUTION

Powered by artificial intelligence, A.I.M. can generate a comprehensive range of statistical and analytical data that may assist governmental and environmental agencies in mitigating the environmental, economic, and social impacts of potential meteor events within a given region.

[Image 2 - A.I.M.'s Main Screen]

Beyond its scientific applications, the system also serves as a valuable educational platform for universities, schools, and research institutions, expanding knowledge about asteroids while enabling users to simulate and analyze real-world problem-solving scenarios.

[Image 3 - A.I.M.'s Config Screen]

The DEMO version of A.I.M. allows for full customization of meteor parameters, supporting diameters of up to 100 kilometers, thereby encompassing not only minor but also catastrophic impact scenarios. It features an interactive 3D visualization of the Earth, providing a highly immersive simulation experience.

For the development of this DEMO, Gemini 2.5 Flash was employed to process and interpret data based on the user-selected impact location, ensuring accuracy and dynamic adaptation of simulated conditions.

[Image 4 - A.I.M.'s DEMO A.I. Report]

TECHNOLOGIES UTILIZED

The A.I.M. system integrates AI-powered and map visualization APIs, while maintaining a lightweight core architecture built primarily with HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. These core technologies handle the rendering, styling, and mathematical computations required to visualize impact radius and released energy based on the meteor’s defined parameters.

The web application is deployed on Vercel and fully integrated with GitHub for continuous development and version control. Its core logic is implemented in HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, while external APIs including Gemini 2.5 Flash for AI-driven data interpretation and Mapbox for geospatial visualization extend its analytical and interactive capabilities.

[Image 5 - Application Architeture Diagram]

Future Improvements

  • Advanced AI Integration: Implement more sophisticated AI models to generate highly detailed and statistically accurate reports, including graphical visualizations, data tables, and potentially proposed mitigation strategies for different impact scenarios.
  • Integration of a Meteor Database: Incorporate a database of scientifically catalogued meteors to enhance simulation realism and expand configuration parameters, allowing users to analyze real-world impact cases with precise physical data.
  • Enhanced Map Data Visualization: Enrich the map interface with additional environmental and physical data, such as detailed information about the impact radius, shockwave propagation, tsunami generation, and seismic activity associated with the simulated event.

Conclusion

The A.I.M. (Aegis Impact Model) serves as a foundational step toward the development of a modular and comprehensive system for the prediction and simulation of meteor impacts. Designed as both a scientific and educational tool, it aims to democratize access to impact analyses and case studies, allowing users from various fields to explore the potential consequences of celestial collisions in an interactive and data-driven environment.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
During the development of this project, artificial intelligence played a key role in several areas:

  • Report Generation: The Gemini 2.5 Flash API served as an essential tool for producing predictive reports based on the user-selected impact location, providing detailed analyses of potential consequences.
  • Content Review and Ideation: ChatGPT 5.0 contributed to textual review, refinement, and idea generation, supporting the project’s conceptual development and enhancing the clarity and quality of documentation.

projectDetails.name: Project EcoPulse
projectDetails.summary:
Our project aims to improve access to healthcare and promote sustainability in Uberlândia, focusing on vulnerable areas with limited infrastructure that are sensitive to extreme climate variations. The lack of accessible healthcare facilities and the worsening of health conditions due to climate change are critical challenges. To mitigate these problems, we propose an integrated system that involves the distribution of smart watches to monitor the health of vulnerable populations. These devices, which measure blood pressure, heart rate, blood oxygenation, and detect falls, help prevent serious complications and enable rapid intervention. In case of anomalies, the watch sends an alert via radio waves to the healthcare system, triggering mobile health stations.
These mobile stations will be deployed seasonally to the regions most in need, based on detailed data on climate and extreme environmental conditions, such as air quality, extreme temperatures, and other climatic factors. This ensures that medical care is optimized for areas at greatest risk of health problems due to climatic conditions. In addition, the clocks will be made from recyclable materials, promoting the city's sustainability. The system aims not only to improve the efficiency of medical care, but also to offer a response tailored to the needs of each community, preventing health complications and ensuring rapid action when most needed.
projectDetails.details:
EcoPulse – Project Documentation

1.0 About our Project

1.1 What It Does

The project aims to improve access to healthcare and promote sustainability in Uberlândia, focusing on vulnerable areas with limited infrastructure and sensitivity to extreme climate variations.

1.2 How It Works

The system is integrated and involves the distribution of smartwatches to monitor the health of vulnerable populations. These devices measure blood pressure, heart rate, blood oxygen levels, and detect falls. In case of anomalies, the watches send alerts via radio waves to the healthcare system, activating mobile units.

1.3 Benefits

  • Prevention of serious complications through continuous monitoring.

  • Rapid and efficient response with deployment of mobile units.

  • Improved healthcare management and reduced hospital overload.

1.4 Intention

  • Promote sustainability by using recyclable materials in the manufacture of the watches.

  • Ensure efficiency and inclusion in medical care, prioritizing vulnerable populations.

1.5 Impacts

  • Facilitated access to healthcare in regions with limited infrastructure.

  • Encouragement of sustainability through eco-friendly materials.

  • Reduction of severe medical emergencies and social inequality.

1.6 Considered Factors

  • Social vulnerability and extreme climatic conditions (air quality, temperature, rainfall).

  • Seasonal allocation of mobile units based on climate and environmental data.

2.0 Mobile Units – Improvement

Mobile health units, implemented through adapted vans, already exist in Uberlândia, but the proposal is to enhance this infrastructure, making it more efficient in serving vulnerable communities.

2.1 Functioning and Integration

When the watch detects an anomaly, it automatically sends an alert to the healthcare system. The nearest van is dispatched, receiving the data and navigating to the location with real-time information.

2.2 Seasonality and Planning

The distribution of vans will be optimized according to climate risks, such as heat waves and increased pollution, ensuring strategic deployment.

2.3 Equipment and Training

Vans will be equipped with full medical kits, direct communication with hospitals, and trained personnel, ensuring integrated healthcare delivery.

2.4 Benefits for the Community

This enhancement transforms mobile units into continuous connection points between citizens and the healthcare system, preventing severe emergencies and improving service efficiency.

3.0 Links Used and Applications

3.1 Copernicus – UCDB 2024 Visual

European Union (EU) Copernicus Global Human Settlement Layer (GHSL)

  • Socioeconomic: Life expectancy increased from 2000-2015 but decreased from 2015-2020, highlighting the challenge of maintaining a healthy and sustainable city.
  • Danger and Risk: Increased risks from 2014-2016, mainly linked to heat waves affecting cardiovascular and respiratory health, potentially causing fainting.
  • Climate: Average annual temperature increased 2.5°C (1970-2010) with projections until 2030, showing the direct impact of climate change on health.
  • Emissions: Increase in pollutant and CO₂ emissions (1975-2020), intensifying the greenhouse effect and respiratory diseases.
  • Healthcare: Average of 6 hospitals per 100,000 inhabitants in Uberlândia (approx. 42 for 760,000 inhabitants), low considering demand.



  • Access: Between 300,000–400,000 people live more than 1 km from a hospital, evidencing difficulty of access in vulnerable areas.

3.2 GHSL – Global Human Settlement Layer

European Union (EU) Copernicus Global Human Settlement Layer (GHSL)

 Used to identify vulnerable suburban zones (in yellow), essential for planning mobile unit distribution.

3.3 INPE – Map Catalog

Brazilian Space Research Institute (INPE) Catalogue

Geographic database for evaluating regions of Uberlândia, supporting mapping of social and environmental vulnerabilities.

4.0 WebSite Link

https://missaohorizonte.github.io/EcoPulse/MissaoHorizonte/index.html

projectDetails.name: Project Mugiwaras
projectDetails.summary:
SpaceAPSS Agents is an intelligent system that helps make NASA’s bioscience research easier to explore and understand. We built a backend platform that processes hundreds of space biology publications, extracts their content, generates AI embeddings with Google Gemini, and stores everything in Azure Cosmos DB for semantic search.

With this system, users can ask questions like “How does microgravity affect human cells?” and instantly get short, science-based answers supported by real NASA studies. The project makes it faster and simpler to find relevant information, discover research gaps, and connect past experiments to future Moon and Mars missions. It’s a step toward turning decades of scientific data into accessible knowledge for everyone.
projectDetails.details:
Our project, SpaceAPSS Agents, is an intelligent knowledge engine designed to make NASA’s bioscience research more accessible and meaningful. It automatically processes hundreds of space biology publications, extracting text, generating embeddings, and storing them in a vector database, so users can ask complex scientific questions and receive clear, AI-generated answers grounded in real studies.

By using Google Gemini for natural language understanding and Azure Cosmos DB for vector search, the system enables semantic exploration across NASA’s research on microgravity, radiation, and life sciences. Scientists, mission planners, and data analysts can easily identify patterns, compare results, and discover knowledge gaps relevant to future Moon and Mars missions.

The project is built entirely in Python, using FastAPI for the backend, Google Generative AI APIs for embeddings and reasoning, and Cosmos DB (SQL API with vector search) for intelligent data retrieval. We automated the data ingestion pipeline with asynchronous processing and Azure CLI scripts for infrastructure setup.

What makes our project creative is how it merges modern AI techniques with open NASA data, turning static research papers into an interactive, queryable knowledge space. Our team focused on designing something both technically scalable and scientifically valuable, ensuring it supports open science principles, future expansion with knowledge graphs, and multilingual accessibility.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
We used Artificial Intelligence primarily in our project’s backend to process and interpret scientific content. Specifically, we integrated Google Gemini models for:

  • Text embeddings – converting scientific article text into numerical vector representations for semantic search.
  • Natural language generation – producing concise, evidence-based answers to user questions based on retrieved articles (Retrieval-Augmented Generation).

Additionally, we used AI-assisted coding tools such as GitHub Copilot and ChatGPT to accelerate development by generating boilerplate code, improving documentation, and refining function structures. All core logic, data handling, and system architecture were designed and implemented by our team.

No AI-generated images, audio, or videos were used. All AI use is acknowledged within our code comments and documentation.

Project Details

AstroUQuest is an educational game designed to make learning about space fun, interactive, and engaging for children. The game works through quizzes, challenges, and rewards, allowing players to explore the universe while earning official NASA Space Uberlândia 2025 certificates.

Creativity and Considerations:

node.title: Nexonull
node.excerpt: Building Stories

projectDetails.name: The Day the Sun Messed with Everything.
projectDetails.summary:
Our project, “The Day the Sun Messed with Everything,” is an educational illustrated story designed to explain the effects of solar activity on everyday life in a simple and engaging way. We developed a narrative that follows different characters — a farmer, a pilot, an astronaut, an engineer, and a child — all experiencing the impacts of a solar storm from their unique perspectives.

The project addresses the challenge of making complex scientific phenomena, like solar flares and geomagnetic storms, accessible to children and the general public. By connecting these events to relatable daily situations, readers can better understand how solar energy influences technology, communication, and life on Earth.

This is important because increasing awareness of space weather helps people appreciate the Sun’s power and the importance of science in predicting and protecting our planet from its effects.
projectDetails.details:
Our project, “The Day the Sun Messed with Everything,” is an interactive educational story that demonstrates how solar activity can affect life on Earth. It works by combining storytelling, visual illustrations, and science communication to explain complex phenomena — such as solar flares, magnetic storms, and their effects on satellites, communication systems, and power grids — in a way that is accessible to all ages, especially children.

The main benefit of this project is its ability to transform scientific knowledge into an engaging learning experience. Readers gain awareness of the importance of solar observation and space weather research, while also developing curiosity about science, technology, and environmental awareness.

The intended impact is to promote scientific literacy and help communities understand how solar energy influences everyday technologies — from airplanes and electricity to GPS and internet systems.

We developed the project using Canva for graphic design. The creativity lies in the fusion of storytelling and real-world science — turning a potential global issue into an inspiring, easy-to-understand narrative.

Our team considered clarity, age-appropriate language, cultural inclusivity, and scientific accuracy to ensure the story educates, entertains, and empowers readers to appreciate the Sun’s vital role in our lives.

(Earth Science Division)

node.title: Nimbus UNIUBE
node.excerpt: A team from the University of Uberaba (UNIUBE) seeking to leverage cloud computing to transform Earth observation data into actionable predictions for cleaner and safer skies.

projectDetails.name: Project Nimbus UNIUBE
projectDetails.summary: Nimbus is an AI-powered air quality forecast platform that integrates NASA's TEMPO satellite data with ground measurements and weather information to provide timely, localized, 24-hour pollution predictions. Our solution transforms complex Earth Observation data into actionable health alerts for citizens and decision-makers, promoting cleaner skies and public safety.
projectDetails.details:
The core of Nimbus is a robust, full-stack application designed for scalability and reliability. The solution is composed of:

Data Pipeline & Model Training: We use historical data from NASA TEMPO (Tropospheric Emissions) and MERRA-2 (Meteorological) resources, fused with ground-truth measurements from OpenAQ/Pandora Networks, to train our Machine Learning model. The ML model is designed to forecast PM2.5 concentrations up to 24 hours in advance.

Backend API: A high-speed, scalable FastAPI application serves as the prediction engine. It is fully containerized using Docker to ensure zero-configuration deployment, adhering to MLOps standards.

Frontend/UX: A modern web interface with Leaflet maps allows users to click any location. It visualizes the forecast as an interactive, multi-axis chart, displaying PM2.5 concentrations alongside predicted temperature and wind speed (from MERRA-2 data).

Action Layer: The system generates instant, color-coded alerts and specific health recommendations (e.g., 'Avoid outdoor activity') based on the predicted AQI level.

Nimbus innovates by focusing on the actionable gap: we don't just display current data; we provide predictive confidence and guidance. The architecture ensures data integrity through Pydantic validation at the API level, making it a reliable tool for public health organizations.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
The project leverages Machine Learning (ML) to move beyond simple meteorological models and achieve higher predictive accuracy.

ML Model: We utilized a simulated LightGBM (Gradient Boosting Machine) model, a highly effective algorithm for structured time-series forecasting.

Feature Engineering: The model uses several features critical for accurate forecasting: Lags (historical PM2.5 values), Seasonal Trends (diurnal/daily cycles), and TEMPO Bias Features to calibrate the satellite's readings against local ground stations.

Prediction Output: The ML model returns not just a single value, but an hourly forecast over 24 hours, which is visualized in the frontend for robust trend analysis.
projectDetails.dataReferences:
[OpenAQ / Pandora Network](https://openaq.org/)
[MERRA-2](https://gmao.gsfc.nasa.gov/gmao-products/merra-2/)

challengeDetails.title: From EarthData to Action: Cloud Computing with Earth Observation Data for Predicting Cleaner, Safer Skies
challengeDetails.excerpt: NASA’s Tropospheric Emissions: Monitoring of Pollution (TEMPO) mission is revolutionizing air quality monitoring across North America by enabling better forecasts and reducing pollutant exposure. Your challenge is to develop a web-based app that forecasts air quality by integrating real-time TEMPO data with ground-based air quality measurements and weather data, notifying users of poor air quality, and helping to improve public health decisions. Teams are encouraged to utilize new technologies that allow seamless scaling of computing from local devices to cloud systems, enhancing collaboration and streamlining work efficiency. (Earth Science Division)

node.title: Orbital Token Market
node.excerpt: Hello! My name is Marcelo, and I am interst about blockchain, innovation, and the future of the space economy. I am developing Orbital Token Market, a platform that tokenizes satellite service hours into Real World Asset (RWA) tokens, enabling com...

projectDetails.name: Project Orbital Token Market
projectDetails.summary:
We developed Orbital Token Market, a groundbreaking platform that bridges the real economy of space with blockchain technology, enabling a new era of accessibility and transparency in orbital infrastructure. Our mission is to transform orbital capacity into liquid, tradeable, and accessible assets through tokenization. By registering satellites and converting their available service hours into Real World Asset (RWA) tokens, we create a secure marketplace where companies can monetize unused orbital time, and investors can directly participate in the space economy with clarity and confidence.

The platform provides tools for satellite scheduling, token management, and the creation of investment pools that finance new space projects. Each available satellite hour is tokenized into a digital asset, which can be purchased, traded, or allocated. When the service is consumed, the token is burned, ensuring efficiency, scarcity, and a continuous operational flow. This system establishes a dynamic and sustainable cycle, connecting enterprises, investors, and researchers.

Our platform democratizes space because it makes the next frontier accessible, transparent, and collaborative. Any researcher, company, or individual anywhere in the world can rent satellite time using cryptocurrency tokens, making access to orbital infrastructure no longer restricted to governments or large corporations. Addressing the critical challenge of opening the space economy to global participation.
projectDetails.details:
What does it do and how does it work?


Orbital Token Market is a blockchain-based platform that transforms orbital capacity into liquid and accessible assets. By registering satellites, we convert available service hours into Real World Asset (RWA) tokens. These tokens can be purchased, traded, or allocated by companies, researchers, or individuals anywhere in the world. When satellite time is used, the token is burned, ensuring transparency, efficiency, and a continuous cycle.

Benefits and intended impact
The Orbital Token Market delivers tangible value across multiple sectors of society by transforming orbital capacity into an accessible, tradeable asset.

For space companies, the platform offers a new revenue stream by enabling them to monetize unused orbital time. Instead of idle satellite capacity going to waste, companies can convert it into tokenized service hours, improving operational efficiency, generating recurring income, and attracting new customers from around the world. This creates financial sustainability for satellite operators and incentivizes the development of additional infrastructure.

For investors, the model provides direct exposure to the real space economy, which has traditionally been closed to individuals or limited to large institutional players. Through tokenization, investors can diversify their portfolios with Real World Asset (RWA) tokens backed by orbital services, receiving transparent and verifiable returns. This democratizes access to one of the fastest-growing industries of the 21st century.

For researchers and academic institutions, the platform removes cost and logistical barriers. By renting satellite hours directly with cryptocurrency tokens, they can conduct experiments, gather Earth observation data, or test communications systems without requiring massive budgets or government-level partnerships. This accelerates scientific discovery and innovation.

For entrepreneurs and startups, the system creates opportunities to build new businesses on top of orbital services—whether in communications, climate solutions, agriculture analytics, or IoT networks. Accessing satellite capacity through tokenized assets reduces entry costs and fosters innovation.

For ordinary individuals, the project represents the first time that people from anywhere in the world can meaningfully participate in the space economy. Anyone can acquire a fraction of orbital capacity, rent it for personal or community projects, or hold tokens as part of a transparent, blockchain-based ecosystem.

The intended impact of the Orbital Token Market is to reduce barriers to entry, create sustainable funding for new satellites, and foster a collaborative global ecosystem. By aligning the incentives of companies, investors, researchers, and individuals, the platform not only expands access to space but also strengthens its role as a shared resource for humanity.

Tools and creativity
We use Hedera blockchain, smart contracts (Solidity), token management systems, scheduling interfaces, and cloud infrastructure to ensure scalability and reliability of services. We already have a functional prototype available at orbitaltokenmarket.com, and our smart contract is deployed on the Hedera Testnet (hashscan.io/testnet/contract/0.0.6854902/source), fully prepared to move into production. We also integrate Laravel technology for robust backend management and user-friendly web applications.

A core innovation of our project is the introduction of Real World Assets (RWA) tokenization into the space economy. In our model, each satellite service hour becomes a digital tokenized asset that represents a tangible share of orbital capacity. These RWA tokens can be traded, purchased, or allocated in a transparent and efficient way, providing liquidity to previously inaccessible infrastructure. Once the service is consumed, the token is burned, ensuring a continuous and verifiable economic cycle.

This approach enables satellite-owning companies to monetize unused orbital time, while researchers, individuals, and organizations can rent satellite hours directly using cryptocurrency tokens. Investors, in turn, gain direct access to recurring revenue streams tied to real space operations, something that was once limited to governments or large corporations.

The project’s creativity lies in combining DeFi principles with RWA tokenization of orbital infrastructure, creating a unique marketplace where finance, technology, and space converge. By bridging blockchain with space assets, Orbital Token Market introduces a sustainable and scalable economic model that democratizes access to low Earth orbit and fosters collaboration among companies, investors, and innovators.

Scalability
The model scales naturally as more satellites are registered on the platform, creating a growing ecosystem of orbital services. Each new satellite adds capacity and diversity, enabling the marketplace to expand into a wide range of applications such as advanced Earth observation for climate monitoring and disaster response, global communications networks that bridge underserved regions, high-precision navigation systems for transportation and logistics, and even in-space manufacturing of advanced materials, pharmaceuticals, and components that cannot be produced under Earth’s gravity. Looking further ahead, the same model could support sustainable space tourism platforms, where access to orbital infrastructure is allocated transparently through tokenized assets.

By tokenizing satellite hours into Real World Asset (RWA) tokens, the model creates true liquidity for orbital capacity, transforming what was once an illiquid and inaccessible resource into a globally tradeable asset class. Tokenization not only ensures flexibility to meet dynamic global demand, but also enables fractional ownership and usage, allowing individuals, startups, and research institutions to access orbital resources previously available only to governments or large corporations. This scalability drives both the growth of the space economy and the democratization of access to space, establishing Orbital Token Market as a foundation for the next generation of space-enabled services.

Sustainability
We emphasize responsible orbital operations by collaborating with agencies and companies on debris mitigation strategies and long-term end-of-life satellite management. Our roadmap includes incentives for operators who follow sustainable practices and recycling strategies for decommissioned assets.

Resilient infrastructure
We plan to integrate resilient satellite architectures capable of handling LEO challenges such as radiation, thermal cycles, and debris impact. This includes adopting modular components and adaptive scheduling for redundancy.

Cost-effectiveness
Beyond launch, the model addresses ongoing operational costs by distributing them across token holders, creating investment pools that fund maintenance, upgrades, and new deployments.

Regulatory landscape and international cooperation
We acknowledge the complexity of national and international space laws. Our model evolves in compliance with licensing frameworks, while partnerships with international agencies and organizations strengthen global trust.

Profitability and responsibility
We aim to balance financial returns with ethics and environmental sustainability by aligning investor rewards with responsible orbital practices. Transparency and accountability are at the core of our model.

Innovation
Orbital Token Market introduces an entirely new asset class: tokenized satellite service time. By converting orbital capacity into Real World Asset (RWA) tokens, the platform transforms something once accessible only to governments and large corporations into a liquid, tradeable resource for the global community.

This innovative approach lowers financial and technical barriers, enabling participation from startups, researchers, investors, and even individuals. It opens the door to entirely new markets—ranging from precision agriculture and climate monitoring to secure communications, advanced Earth observation, and in-space manufacturing. Each of these sectors can now access orbital infrastructure in a fractional, transparent, and flexible way.

Beyond market creation, the platform also promotes collaboration across industries by aligning the incentives of space companies, investors, researchers, and innovators. It establishes a bridge between blockchain and the space economy, where decentralized finance (DeFi) mechanisms fuel real-world orbital infrastructure.

In essence, the Orbital Token Market is not just innovating in finance or space, it is pioneering a new economic model where blockchain technology, orbital assets, and global accessibility converge, laying the foundation for a sustainable and inclusive space economy.

Prototyping
We already have a functional prototype: the website orbitaltokenmarket.com enables token management, purchases, and satellite hour scheduling. In addition, our smart contract is already deployed on the Hedera Testnet, available for audit here: hashscan.io/testnet/contract/0.0.6854902/source. This prototype effectively demonstrates the feasibility and innovation of our model.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
AI assisted in drafting and debugging our Solidity smart contract, generating generic illustrative images for our presentation (chatgpt), and creating the voiceover narration through text-to-speech (ttsmp3). No NASA branding or mission identifiers were used in any AI-generated content, and all design, architecture, and innovation decisions remain entirely original and team driven.

Both did not generate a watermark.

Audio: https://ttsmp3.com/ai

As a measure of transparency, this information has been included in the video description.

challengeDetails.title: Commercializing Low Earth Orbit (LEO)
challengeDetails.excerpt: As the commercialization of space rapidly accelerates, the future of business in low Earth orbit (LEO) holds incredible potential, but also presents significant operational, regulatory, and environmental challenges. This new economic frontier invites innovative and sustainable approaches to foster long-term viability and responsible execution. Your challenge is to conceptualize and design a scalable, sustainable, business model, accompanied by a prototype, that explores the unique opportunities LEO offers while addressing the complexities of operating in space. (Joint Agency Satellite Division)

challengeDetails.title: Deep Dive: Immersive Data Stories from Ocean to Sky
challengeDetails.excerpt: Satellite observations reveal insights about our dynamic home planet to scientists, but people without a remote sensing background often find the stories within these datasets difficult to access. NASA’s open data policy makes these observations available to everyone—scientists and non-scientists alike. Your challenge is to build a short, immersive, virtual reality (VR) experience that leverages NASA’s Earth observation datasets and visualizations to bring stories about our planet’s oceans to life, connecting a broad audience to this data, its beauty, and its impact. Using visuals, spatial audio, and even interactive elements, your VR experience can enable users to dive deeper into Earth’s unfolding ocean story. (Earth Science Division)

node.title: Os guris da catequese
node.excerpt: É os guris

projectDetails.name: Project Os guris da catequese
projectDetails.summary:
O trabalho aborda a importância dos oceanos e da atmosfera para a regulação climática e a manutenção da vida na Terra, utilizando dados de satélites da NASA como PACE, SWOT, GRACE-FO e OCO-2. O estudo explora fenômenos como o aumento do nível do mar, circulação oceânica, ecossistemas marinhos, além da dinâmica da troposfera e da estratosfera. Também discute o papel humano no agravamento das mudanças climáticas desde a Revolução Industrial, destacando impactos como poluição, aquecimento global e branqueamento de corais.

O grupo propõe como solução a criação de um jogo educativo em realidade virtual dentro do Roblox, permitindo que os jogadores explorem diferentes eras da Terra, desde a formação primitiva até o futuro dos oceanos. Essa abordagem busca unir ciência e tecnologia para tornar o aprendizado mais acessível, interativo e atrativo. Conclui-se que a educação ambiental interdisciplinar, apoiada em ferramentas imersivas, é fundamental para conscientizar sobre os desafios climáticos e promover ações em defesa do planeta.
projectDetails.details:
O projeto "Mergulho Profundo: Histórias Imersivas de Dados do Oceano ao Céu" é uma experiência educacional imersiva no Roblox e VR, que funciona como um documentário jogável. Através de mapas interativos que representam diferentes eras geológicas, o projeto traduz dados científicos complexos em uma jornada visual e emocional. O objetivo principal é gerar uma profunda conscientização ambiental, indo além dos fatos para criar uma conexão real do jogador com a história do planeta. A nossa abordagem criativa focou em usar a construção de mundos como uma ferramenta de visualização de dados, buscando inspirar uma reflexão sobre nosso impacto e a urgência de ações sustentáveis.

Para a execução técnica deste projeto, utilizamos o Roblox Studio como ambiente de desenvolvimento principal. Toda a programação das interações e dos eventos dinâmicos, como chuvas de meteoros foi realizada na linguagem Luau. Para a criação de modelos 3D e assets personalizados que exigiam maior detalhe ultilizamos modelos prontos. A compatibilidade da experiência de Realidade Virtual foi garantida para os principais headsets do mercado, como Meta Quest e Valve Index, utilizando o cliente VR nativo do Roblox para proporcionar o mais alto nível de imersão possível.

Documento completo

node.title: Oumuamua
node.excerpt: Somos um grupo de pessoas.

projectDetails.name: Project Oumuamua
projectDetails.summary:
BreezyAI — Intelligent Respiratory Health

BreezyAI is a web platform that helps people with chronic respiratory conditions plan their day based on environmental and meteorological data. It integrates NASA’s TEMPO satellite data (NO₂ and O₃ tropospheric columns), POWER climate data, FIRMS fire detections, and OpenAQ ground measurements to generate a real-time Respiratory Risk Index.

The system forecasts air quality and health risk windows up to 72 hours ahead, providing personalized alerts such as “Avoid outdoor activity between 2–6 p.m. — high ozone and heat.” Using scientific conversions (DU → ppb → μg/m³) and epidemiological weighting, BreezyAI translates complex atmospheric variables into clear, actionable insights.

Built on a serverless AWS Lambda architecture, it scales seamlessly while keeping costs low. By combining space-based and ground-based data into a user-friendly interface, BreezyAI transforms NASA science into a practical, evidence-based tool for improving public health and empowering vulnerable populations to reduce exposure to harmful air pollutants.
projectDetails.details:
What BreezyAI Does:

  • Displays current and forecasted data for temperature, humidity, fire, precipitation, pressure, wind, and pollutants (NO2​ and O3​).
  • Calculates a respiratory risk index weighted by the intensity and duration of triggers.
  • Shows contextual alerts such as: “Avoid outdoor activities from 2 PM to 6 PM — high ozone and heat levels.”
  • Presents a visual and educational weather dashboard focused on respiratory health.

How It Works (Simplified Logic):

  • Meteorological and Pollutant Features: Temperature, humidity, fire, precipitation, pressure, wind speed, wind direction, and pollutants (NO2​ and O3​).
  • Scoring: Weights are applied based on the strength/speed of effect (e.g., NO2​ and severe cold receive a higher acute weight), interaction terms (O3​× heat; pollution × allergens), and vulnerability factors (children, elderly, asthma/COPD diagnosis).
  • UX: Cards display risks and brief recommendations; navigation is focused on “what to do now,” considering the barriers and hypervigilance described in Doc 3.
  • Data Integration: Combines data from sensors and APIs (OPENAQ, FIRMS, POWER, and TEMPO NRT) and applies epidemiological weights (according to Doc 2).
  • Synergies and Vulnerabilities: Incorporates synergistic interactions (e.g., heat potentiates the effect of ozone) and vulnerability factors (children, the elderly, asthmatics).
  • Communication: Translates complex results into simple, visually light language, considering the psychosocial and cognitive barriers described in Doc 3.

Benefits:

  • Provides clear and actionable information to reduce exposure and the anxiety of the "invisible."
  • Equity: Prioritizes variables that most impact vulnerable groups.
  • Increases autonomy and well-being for people with respiratory conditions.
  • Facilitates daily decisions (“should I go to the park?”, “should I open the window?”) based on real risk.
  • Can be adapted for public policies, local alerts, and environmental health education.

Objectives:

  • Validate a predictive index and daily micro-recommendations.
  • Measure adherence (clicks/dismissals), perceived utility, and reduction in symptoms/rescue inhaler use in pilot studies.

Stack (MVP):

  • Frontend: React + Vite/Next, UI components.
  • Initial Modeling: Rules and weights derived from literature (Doc 2), with room for ML (XGBoost/LightGBM) in the next phase.
  • Data Infrastructure: Consumption of open APIs (NASA/Partners), with aggregation and normalization on the client/edge.

NASA Data

1) Overview and Scope

For this challenge, we used only NASA sources. Below we describe all data sources used, how we extracted, processed, correlated, and which variables are forecasted—with justifications.

Sources referenced in the project:

  • POWER LARC (NASA) – Climate/meteorological data: https://power.larc.nasa.gov
    • We extracted 2-meter air temperature (T2M) and additional meteorological variables (RH2M, WS10M, WD10M, PRECTOTCORR, PS).
    • We generated a map with lat/lon for all US stations and an inventory of variables per station.
  • FIRMS (NASA) – Fire hotspots (location, FRP, confidence, sensor), used to correlate smoke with wind.
  • TEMPO (NASA, Near Real-Time) – NO2​ and O3​ in DU (Dobson Units), tropospheric column; also PBL Height and Surface Pressure as support.

NO2​ redundancy: We use tropospheric NO2​ from TEMPO (converted to ppb and μg/m3) and surface NO2​ (OpenAQ), ensuring multiple sources for the same variable.

2) Data Extraction and Ingestion

2.1 TEMPO (Near Real-Time – Cloud API)

  • Products/topics extracted:
    • Tropospheric NO2​ Column (vertical_column_troposphere) – molecules/cm² and DU; used for scientific conversion to surface concentration.
    • Total O3​ Column (vertical_column_total) – DU (total tropospheric ozone).
    • PBL Height (support_data/pbl_height) – meters (planetary boundary layer thickness).
    • Surface Pressure (support_data/surface_pressure) – hPa.
    • Quality Flags (main_data_quality_flag) – 0=excellent, 1=good, 2+=poor.
  • Usage: NRT collection feeds conversions and tropospheric analyses, plus regional hotspot detection (O3​/NO2​) and alerts.

2.2 OpenAQ (Ground Level – USA)

  • Variables and series:
    • Surface NO2​ – μg/m3 (time series hourly: 1000 points; daily: 40 days).
    • Surface O3​ – μg/m3 (time series hourly: 1000 points; daily: 44 days).
    • Station metadata: lat/lon, distance to the point of interest, active sensors, measurement counts.
    • Given a user lat/lon, we query our location index for the closest station that has the required variable (O3​ or NO2​).
    • If no recent data is available, we move to the second-closest station, and so on, until we retrieve data.
    • Search radius: up to 100 km (see also “Nearby Station Search”).
  • Unit note: We also work with ppb when needed; we perform μg/m3↔ ppb conversions (see formulas in Section 5).

2.3 NASA POWER (Meteorological API)

  • Variables: Temperature (T2M) [°C, K], Relative Humidity (RH2M) [%], Wind Speed (WS10M) [m/s], Wind Direction (WD10M) [degrees], Precipitation (PRECTOTCORR) [mm/h], Pressure (PS) [hPa].
  • Primary usage: Pollutant dispersion, comfort/health, rain scavenging, unit conversions, and physical calculations (air density) together with TEMPO when needed.

2.4 NASA FIRMS (Active Fires)

  • Attributes extracted: Hotspot locations (lat/lon, search within 100 km), FRP (MW) with classes Low <50, Moderate 50–150, High 150–300, Very High >300, Confidence (0–100%), Sensor (VIIRS_SNPP_NRT or MODIS_NRT).
  • Primary usage: Correlate smoke with wind fields and classify regional risk.

3) Processing, Standardization, and QA

3.1 Conversions and Physics (DU → ppb → μg/m3)

  • Goal: Obtain surface concentration from tropospheric columns (TEMPO) and stay compatible with ground data (OpenAQ).
  • General formulas used:
[IMAGE ID NOT FOUND title:"" ]
[IMAGE ID NOT FOUND title:"" ]
  • Equations implemented in the system:
    • N_air = (P × h) / (k_B × T) / 10000
    • ppb = (DU × 2.69e16 / N_air) × 10⁹
    • μg/m³ = (ppb × M_NO2 × P) / (R × T) × 10⁶
  • Error: < 3% compared to theoretical values.

3.2 Standardization and Flags

  • Quality Flags (TEMPO): We enforce 0 (excellent), 1 (good) and filter out ≥2 (poor).
  • Units (OpenAQ/TEMPO/POWER): We harmonize μg/m3, ppb, DU per analysis need (AQI, hotspots, windows).

3.3 Catalog and Maps

  • We built a map with all US OpenAQ stations and the variables each one has; this powers nearby station search (fallback by availability/recency).

4) Correlations, Compositions, and Products

4.1 Regional Hotspot Detection/Alert (Hotspot Alert)

  • Inputs: Tropospheric O3​ (TEMPO), Tropospheric NO2​ (TEMPO), Fires (FIRMS), Wind/Wind Direction (POWER).
    • O3​: >100 μg/m3 (moderate alert), >150 μg/m3 (high alert).
    • NO2​: >50 μg/m3 (moderate), >100 μg/m3 (high).
  • Trajectory/ETAs: Time = distance / wind speed; wind direction defines the projected path to the user.
  • Outputs: Alert status, dominant pollutant, concentration, level, distance (km), ETA (h), wind vectors, and path layer for map visualization.

4.2 Smoke–Wind Correlation (FIRMS + POWER)

  • FIRMS hotspots (distance, FRP, confidence) are combined with wind fields (WS/WD) to explain dispersion and prioritize risk based on intensity (FRP) and proximity.

4.3 Scientific NO2​ Conversion (Ground ↔ Troposphere Redundancy)

  • Goal: Derive surface NO2​ from tropospheric DU (TEMPO) and compare it with ground NO2​ (OpenAQ in ppb/μg/m3), ensuring redundancy and robustness in dashboards and alerts.

5) Forecasting (What We Predict and Why)

5.1 Clean Air Window

  • We forecast hourly risk for the next 24 hours to identify safe windows, based on:
    • Hourly AQI (O3​/NO2​ surface via OpenAQ);
    • Meteorological adjustments (T, RH, Wind, Pressure) with health/dispersion impact;
  • Output: Best times for outdoor activities (recommendation).

5.2 Meteorological Panel (24h Trends)

  • Temperature, Humidity, Wind (speed/direction) – current values and 24h trend, with impact descriptions (comfort/risk).

5.3 Personal Respiratory Risk Index

  • Composition:
    • O3​ and NO2​: 50% (AQI core);
    • Temperature: 20% (extremes raise risk);
    • Humidity: 20% (very dry <40% or humid >60%);
    • Wind: 10% (stagnant <2 m/s or >8 m/s).
    • Pressure: used for conversions/AQI.
  • Output: 0–10 index with classes from Very Low to Very High and personalized recommendations.

5.4 Time Series and Trends

  • NO2​/O3​ (OpenAQ) – hourly (1000 pts) and daily (40–44 days);
  • 24h meteorology (POWER) – for correlation and projections;
  • Usage: Patterns, peaks, moving averages, weekly/monthly analysis — the foundation for forecasts and explanatory messaging.

5.5 Allergen Conditions (Meteorological Heuristic)

  • Rules applied:
    • Temperature: >20 °C (+2 pollen pts), >25 °C (+3 pts).
    • Humidity: >70% (+3 mold pts), <30% (+2 pollen pts).
    • Wind: >5 m/s (+2 pollen dispersion pts).
    • Precipitation: >0 mm/h (−2 pts, pollen washout).
  • Output: 0–10 levels for pollen and mold, with environmental tags (“Strong wind,” “Heat,” “Rain”).

6) AQI (Air Quality Index) Calculations

  • Inputs: Surface O3​ and NO2​ (OpenAQ), Temperature (POWER), Pressure (POWER).
    • O3​: 0–54 (Good), 55–70 (Moderate), 71–85 (USG)…
    • NO2​: 0–53 (Good), 54–100 (Moderate)…
  • Outputs: AQI 0–500+, category (Good → Hazardous), dominant pollutant, and health guidance.
  • Note: Temperature may adjust O3​ limits (higher toxicity under heat).

7) Spatial Algorithms and Station Selection (OpenAQ)

  • Inputs: User lat/lon, database of 1599 stations (USA), radius up to 100 km.
    • distance = sqrt((lat1-lat2)² + (lon1-lon2)²) × 111 # km
  • Outputs: Distance-ranked list of stations, automatic selection of the nearest with data, and fallback to alternatives.

8) Generated Dashboards and Layers

  • Complete Meteorological Panel: Current values, 24h trends, health/comfort impacts.
  • Regional Hotspot Alert: Status, pollutant, concentration/level, distance, estimated time of impact, trajectory, and wind vectors.
  • Series and Trends: Full history (NO2​/O3​), trend charts, pattern detection, and basis for forecasts.

9) Statistical Summary of Data Usage

  • Sources: 4 main APIs (TEMPO, OpenAQ, NASA POWER, NASA FIRMS).
  • Variables: 20+ environmental and air-quality variables.
  • Analyses: 10 implemented analyses/derivations.
  • Volume: 1000 hourly points (NO2​/O3​), 40–44 daily days, 24h of meteorological forecast, 100 km fire radius.
  • Accuracy: NO2​ conversion with error < 3%; AQI per EPA standard; Temperature via callback for higher precision.

Final Notes (Justifications)

  • Why TEMPO NRT (troposphere): Broad spatial coverage and tropospheric column (DU) enable surface derivation, enriching areas with sparse ground observations.
  • Why OpenAQ (ground): Validates/anchors surface-level concentrations and powers AQI and hourly products.
  • Why POWER/FIRMS: Meteorology explains formation/dispersion and rain removes particulates; FIRMS contextualizes smoke and regional risk (FRP, confidence, sensor).

SYSTEM CLOUD ARCHITECTURE

Air Quality & Weather API: AWS Serverless Architecture

Overview The Air Quality & Weather API is a production-grade serverless application deployed on AWS Lambda, designed to deliver real-time air quality metrics and meteorological data. It integrates multiple scientific data sources from NASA and OpenAQ, leveraging containerized Lambda functions to handle complex scientific computations while maintaining automatic scalability and cost-efficiency.

Architecture Components The system follows a four-layer serverless architecture:

[IMAGE ID NOT FOUND title:"" ]

1. Public Endpoint Layer

  • AWS Lambda Function URLs provide a managed HTTPS endpoint (e.g., https://jujg5bnt5a7...lambda-url.us-west-2.on.aws/) that serves as the single entry point for all client requests.
  • This approach eliminates the need for API Gateway while retaining built-in CORS and authentication support.

2. Compute Layer

  • A Lambda function runs a Docker container (~1.2 GB) built on Python 3.11.
  • Configuration: 1024 MB memory, 300-second timeout.
    • FastAPI for HTTP routing
    • Mangum as the ASGI-to-Lambda adapter
  • This containerized approach overcomes the 250 MB Lambda package size limit, allowing the inclusion of heavy scientific libraries such as pandas, numpy, and earthaccess.

3. Configuration Layer

  • Environment variables store API credentials for NASA Earthdata, OpenAQ, and NASA FIRMS.
  • Supports migration to AWS Secrets Manager for improved production security.

4. Storage & Monitoring

  • Amazon ECR hosts the container image with automated vulnerability scanning and versioning.
  • CloudWatch Logs capture execution logs, errors, and performance metrics (invocations, duration, errors, throttles) under /aws/lambda/airquality-api.

Data Flow Client requests follow a seven-stage processing pipeline:

  1. HTTPS request hits the Lambda Function URL.
  2. AWS validates origin, headers, and CORS.
  3. Lambda invokes the container instance.
  4. Mangum transforms the Lambda event into an ASGI request.
  5. FastAPI routes the request to the appropriate endpoint handler.
  6. Data services fetch information from external APIs (NASA POWER, TEMPO, OpenAQ, FIRMS) and perform scientific transformations (e.g., NO2​ DU→μg/m3 conversion, EPA AQI calculation).
  7. The JSON response is returned to the client.
  • Typical latency: 200–500 ms (warm start) or 8–10 s (cold start).

Scientific Data Integration The architecture integrates four authoritative data sources:

<colgroup><col><col><col></colgroup>

Source

Description

Resolution / Update Frequency

NASA POWER

Global meteorological data

0.5° spatial resolution

NASA TEMPO

Satellite-based tropospheric

NO2​

/

O3​

Hourly updates, ~10 km resolution

OpenAQ

1,599 ground-based air quality stations

Near real-time data

NASA FIRMS

Active fire detection

3–5 hour latency

Exportar para as Planilhas

The system applies a hybrid integration model, prioritizing ground-based measurements when available and using satellite-derived estimates as a fallback.

Scalability & Performance

  • Automatic horizontal scaling from 0 to thousands of concurrent executions (default concurrency limit: 1,000; expandable upon request).
  • Each container instance handles one request at a time.
  • Memory usage: approximately 180–200 MB.
  • Cold start: 8–10 seconds (due to container size and dependency loading).
  • Warm start: 200–500 milliseconds.
  • Provisioned Concurrency can eliminate cold starts by maintaining pre-warmed instances (with additional cost).

Operational Excellence

  • Deployment is fully automated through the deploy-docker.sh script:
    • build container → push to ECR → update Lambda function → configure Function URL → set permissions.
    • Automatic monitoring
    • Metrics dashboards
    • Log analysis
    • Alarm configuration for proactive incident detection

Cost Model

<colgroup><col><col></colgroup>

Component

Pricing / Estimate

Lambda

$0.20 per 1M requests + $0.0000166667 per GB-second

1M req/month≈ $20–25
ECR storage

≈ $0.10/month

CloudWatch Logs

≈ $0.50–5/month

Exportar para as Planilhas

The pay-per-use model ensures that costs scale proportionally with usage—making the solution economical for both low-traffic and high-scale workloads.

  • Compared to traditional compute options:
    • EC2: ~$30/month minimum
    • ECS Fargate: ~$50/month minimum

Architectural Strengths The serverless design delivers:

  • Simplicity: Single-service deployment
  • Elasticity: Automatic scaling with no configuration
  • Reliability: Multi-AZ availability by default
  • Maintainability: No OS patching or infrastructure management
  • Developer Experience: Identical local and production environments
  • Cost Efficiency: No idle capacity charges

Planned Enhancements:

  • ElastiCache for external API caching
  • DynamoDB for historical data persistence
  • Multi-region deployment for latency reduction
  • API Gateway integration for advanced features (throttling, usage plans)

Use of Artificial Intelligence

BreezyAI leverages Predictive Artificial Intelligence to transform raw environmental data into personalized health insights. Through supervised learning and time-series modeling, the system anticipates atmospheric changes and estimates individual respiratory risk, providing both short-term (0–24h) and medium-term (24–72h) forecasts.

Dataset Insights

Temporal Characteristics The time-series variables used (O3​, NO2​, T2M, RH2M, WS) exhibit strong daily seasonality, with regular 24-hour cycles and distinct weekly and seasonal patterns. Exploratory analysis revealed:

  • Strong Daily Seasonality: All variables follow clear diurnal patterns.
  • Weekly Seasonality: Particularly evident in temperature, with weekday vs. weekend differences.
  • Non-stationarity: Presence of trend and seasonal components, requiring differentiation or explicit modeling.
  • High Data Quality: Continuous hourly records with minimal missing values after preprocessing (thanks to NASA POWER and OpenAQ sensor stability).

Variable Behavior

  • Ozone (O3​): Consistent daytime peaks; strong correlation with solar radiation.
  • Humidity (RH2M): Inversely related to temperature, with nighttime maxima.
  • Temperature (T2M): Highly regular and predictable diurnal cycle.
  • Wind (WS): Most variable and stochastic among all variables.

Modeling Strategy

BreezyAI combines traditional time-series models with modern machine learning methods, selecting the optimal algorithm for each variable based on its statistical and physical behavior.

<colgroup><col><col><col></colgroup>

Variable

Main Model

Technical Rationale

Humidity (RH2M)

Random Forest

Captures multiple overlapping seasonalities and nonlinear relationships with temperature and pressure. Robust to noise and outliers.

Temperature (T2M)

Ridge Regression (hourly) + Hybrid Naive/Prophet (daily)

The hourly component is quasi-linear and predictable; the hybrid combines strong autocorrelation (Naive) with long-term trends (Prophet).

Wind (WS)

Statistical Simulation

Highly stochastic variable influenced by local topography and pressure fields. Empirical simulation based on typical diurnal patterns provides more realistic estimates.

Ozone (O3​)

Random Forest

Complex photochemical formation process dependent on multiple nonlinear factors (

NOx​

, temperature, radiation). Random Forest captures these interactions effectively.

Exportar para as Planilhas

AI Architecture

The AI pipeline in BreezyAI operates through three main layers:

  1. Preprocessing and Feature Engineering
    • Creation of short-term (1–24h) and long-term (168h) lags.
    • Moving averages to smooth noise and capture local trends.
    • Time encoding (sin/cos) to represent daily and weekly cycles.
    • Cross-correlation between meteorological and pollutant variables.
    • Rolling window temporal split (train/test/validation).
    • Hyperparameter tuning via cross-validation.
    • Evaluation metrics: MAE and RMSE.
    • Benchmarking across linear, seasonal, and ensemble models.
    • Generates hourly forecasts for 24h and daily forecasts up to 72h.
    • A blending mechanism automatically selects the most reliable forecast.
    • Final adjustment using real-time meteorological variables.

Model Justifications

  • Random Forest: Chosen for O3​ and RH2M due to its ability to capture complex nonlinear relationships and multivariable interactions. Achieved the lowest overall error metrics.
  • Ridge Regression + Prophet: The Ridge model’s L2 regularization prevents overfitting in linear and highly autocorrelated series (like temperature). Prophet complements it by capturing long-term seasonal and trend components with interpretability.
  • Statistical Simulation for Wind: Given the high stochastic nature of wind and its dependence on unobserved local factors, an empirical simulation based on typical hourly and directional patterns provides more realistic behavior than deterministic models.

node.title: Plastic Busters
node.excerpt: Sou Gustavo Kim, apaixonado por ciência e tecnologia. E quero explorar o poder dos fungos contra o plástico.Busco pessoas criativas

projectDetails.name: Project Plastic Busters
projectDetails.summary:
Plastics exhibit high resistance to natural degradation, with a half-life that can exceed 600 years depending on their polymeric composition. This persistence poses a significant environmental challenge, as plastics gradually fragment into smaller particles known as microplastics, which display high stability and potential toxicity to living organisms. Recent studies have reported the presence of microplastics in fish and even in human tissues, underscoring the extent of environmental and biological contamination.
Given this global issue of plastic pollution, the development of sustainable and science-based solutions is imperative. Several fungal species have demonstrated notable efficiency in degrading synthetic polymers under optimal conditions, particularly those belonging to the genera Aspergillus, Pestalotiopsis microspora, Zalerion maritimum, Penicillium spp., and Fusarium spp.
This project aims to advance this field of study by employing artificial intelligence tools to identify and assess, on a global scale, environments with favorable conditions for fungal-mediated plastic biodegradation, thereby enhancing bioremediation strategies and promoting environmental sustainability.
projectDetails.details:
This environmental pollution icontinues to increase every day, and while the only current remediation is the use of alternative products, there is still no solution for all the existing pollution. Once developed, this project can greatly assist in combating plastic pollution. The greatest challenge is creating a sustainable world, and using fungi to degrade plastic, even in inhospitable environments, could be the path to the future.
The front-end development was structured based on modular architecture best practices in Python, prioritizing scalability and code clarity. The Streamlit library served as the core of the interface, chosen for its ability to integrate interactive components, dynamic visualizations, and scientific APIs with minimal development overhead.
Communication between the interfaces and backend modules (such as ml_model.py, correlation.py, and data_loader.py) occurs through direct function calls, ensuring an optimized data flow. The interactive map was implemented using Folium and streamlit-folium, incorporating layers from NASA GIBS (Global Imagery Browse Services) to render satellite imagery, allowing users to explore environmental variables such as air quality and altitude.
The Analytical Dashboard was developed with Plotly Express and Matplotlib, displaying performance indicators of fungal activity in the decomposition of different types of polymers. The Predictor module integrates with a machine learning model, providing forecasts of fungal colony behavior when exposed to specific plastic types, based on data stored in an SQLite (.db) database.
The input layer (modules “Insert Plastic” and “Insert Fungus”) was designed to automatically feed data into the database, including field validation and direct integration with analytical routines. The entire application was developed with a focus on usability, efficiency, and digital sustainability, applying the principles of Green Computing within the environmental and scientific scope of the Plastic Busters project.
This pollution continues to increase every day, and while the only current remediation is the use of alternative products, there is still no solution for all the existing pollution. Once developed, this AI can greatly assist in combating plastic pollution. The greatest challenge is creating a sustainable world, and using fungi to degrade plastic, even in inhospitable environments, could be the path to the future.

projectDetails.name: Project PowerGeeks
projectDetails.summary:
A página “ISS Experience | NASA Challenge 2025” convida você a viver uma experiência interativa inspirada na Estação Espacial Internacional (ISS). Nela, você pode explorar a Terra como se estivesse na cúpula da ISS, passeando por diferentes lugares e vendo fotos reais tiradas pelos astronautas.

Além disso, é possível personalizar seu próprio astronauta, aprender curiosidades sobre fenômenos naturais e descobertas científicas feitas a partir do espaço, e se divertir em simuladores de treinamento — como o Laboratório de Flutuação Neutra, onde treinam para caminhadas espaciais ou até mesmo missões na Lua.

A página mostra como a ISS é importante para pesquisas que ajudam a humanidade, desde entender melhor o clima até preparar astronautas para as próximas aventuras espaciais. Também oferece links para saber mais nos sites oficiais da NASA e da ISS.
