projectDetails.name: Fire Alert: World Edition
projectDetails.summary: We developed a wildfire monitoring system using real-time data from NASA satellites through the FIRMS platform. The system collects and analyzes data such as geographical coordinates, fire intensity, and detection reliability, calculating the distance to points of interest and classifying fire hotspots by intensity and risk. Additionally, the system displays real-time alerts on a web interface and allows user interaction. Based on the same concept, we created a game, Fire Alert: World Edition, to encourage wildfire fighting in a simple and interactive way. Both projects aim to improve early detection and rapid response to wildfires, contributing to the protection of ecosystems, communities, and facilitating the planning of preventive actions. The importance of these systems lies in creating effective tools for continuous monitoring and raising public awareness about the severity of wildfires.
projectDetails.details:
System Description

The system uses real-time data from NASA satellites through FIRMS. Each satellite provides information on fire hotspots, including geographical coordinates, fire power (FRP), acquisition time and date, and detection confidence level. To access the database, the system uses the Map Key provided by NASA, ensuring authentication and authorized access.

Programming and Processes

The program is written in Python, utilizing libraries such as pandas and numpy for data manipulation and analysis, and requests for HTTP requests.
It performs the following processes:

  • Generation of an area of interest (bounding box) based on the latitude, longitude, and radius provided by the user;
  • Collection of satellite data for the past N days;
  • Conversion and standardization of essential columns: latitude, longitude, FRP, intensity, reliability, risk, and distance;
  • Calculation of the distance between each hotspot and the point of interest using the Haversine formula;
  • Classification of intensity (Low, Moderate, High), reliability (>40%), and risk (Medium, High);
  • Sorting and filtering of data to display only reliable hotspots near the monitored point.

Artificial Intelligence Collaboration

Initially, the AI helped create a basic version capable of querying fire hotspots near a coordinate by making requests to the NASA FIRMS API, filtering the data by reliability, and calculating the distance to the central point.
Based on user feedback, the AI then suggested parameter adjustments, increasing the alert radius, and adding different confidence levels, making the code more flexible.

In later stages, the AI guided the introduction of multiple satellites, vectorization with NumPy to improve performance, handling missing data, and the creation of additional metrics such as fire intensity and risk based on reliability.
Enhancements were also made to the presentation of results, such as sorting by proximity, formatting timestamps, and centering tables, always following the user's instructions to make the output clearer and more understandable.

Finally, the AI assisted in implementing user interactivity and the bilingual translation of the script, maintaining all previous functionalities.
Each design decision, each function addition, or logic adjustment was made based on conversations, demonstrating how artificial intelligence can be used to guide and structure the development of a complete project in a collaborative manner.

Data Presentation and Interface

The processed data is transformed into centered tables with clear headers and professional alignment, making quick interpretation easier.
The web interface provides real-time alert visualization, including geographic location, fire intensity, data reliability, risk, and distance from the monitored point.

System Benefits

The system's benefits come from early detection of fire hotspots, enabling rapid responses, continuous and reliable monitoring based on official NASA data, risk assessment based on quantitative and qualitative variables, public availability for managers, companies, and communities, expanding prevention efforts, and potential future integration with emergency response systems.

Project Objectives and Impact

The project aims to significantly reduce damage caused by fires, protect ecosystems and human communities, increase decision-making efficiency for environmental agencies and private companies, and create business opportunities through the public monitoring platform.
Additionally, it contributes to environmental research and provides reliable data for prevention policies and territorial planning.

Educational Expansion

Moreover, based on the same programming concept, we developed a game called Fire Alert: World Edition.
The goal of the game is to encourage global firefighting efforts in an interactive and simple way.

Game Description

The game presents a world map in which the players assume the role of firefighters responsible for extinguishing fires in different regions.
Two types of events are displayed on the map:

  • Real fires, represented by a flame icon;
  • False alerts, represented by a red triangle containing an exclamation mark and the letter “F.”

The map is covered with these symbols. False alerts must not be clicked, as doing so results in a deduction of 5 points. Conversely, real fires must be clicked, representing the act of extinguishing the fire; each correct action adds 10 points to the player’s score.

At the beginning of the game, the initial score is set at 25 points.
Each successfully extinguished fire awards 10 points, while each mistakenly selected false alert deducts 5 points.
The game concludes when the score reaches zero or more than 100.

Programming and Mechanics

The game was developed using the Scratch platform, employing programming blocks that perform the following functions:

  • Define and update the score according to the player’s actions;
  • Control time through a timer that counts up to four seconds before restarting;
  • Utilize a custom block named “coordinates”, responsible for moving the sprites to random positions on the map;
  • Switch the backdrop between the World Map and a black screen (Game Over or Good Game) according to the game’s progression.

The system includes five false alerts and five fires, distributed across the continents and relocated every five seconds.
In addition, the "Start" button was programmed to initialize the game before clicking the green flag.

Mathematical Logic

The game’s functionality is grounded in computational logic and mathematical calculations, which define the coordinates and timing of each event.
These operations ensure that all movements and interactions occur with accuracy, consistency, and precision.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
The development of the code was entirely based on conversations with an artificial intelligence, using ChatGPT as a programming assistant. With each version, the code evolved from suggestions, adjustments, and explanations provided by the model, which interpreted the user's commands and objectives and transformed these instructions into practical implementations.

We also used ChatGPT to translate the texts from Portuguese to English.

projectDetails.name: External Support Structure (ESTU)
projectDetails.summary: Our project aims to tackle one of humanity's greatest challenges: the waste of essential resources. The proposal is to optimize the use of materials during a space mission to Mars, utilizing waste generated throughout the process. The mission, lasting about three years, inevitably generates waste. Our solution consists of repurposing materials that would be discarded by constructing external structures to the habitat. The ESTU (External Support Structure), as it is called, Our project aims to reduce waste, ensuring greater efficiency in resource use. In a world where space exploration is growing exponentially, it is necessary to establish ways to prevent the increase of waste in space, thus solidifying humanity's commitment to sustainability in the cosmos.
projectDetails.details:
External Support Structure (ESTU)

ESTRUTURA EXTERNA DE APOIO

our website: https://ingryd-julia.github.io/reorbit6/NASA.html

PROPOSAL: An External Support Structure (ESTU) is a structure built outside the astronauts' habitat that can be used for various purposes, including workshop and storage (the use will depend on the astronauts' needs and available resources). The ESTU was developed for the useful utilization of the three-dimensional cubic structure, material recycled after the inflatable habitat is inflated and secured, to create a new space that serves as support for astronauts to perform tasks, missions, and life in space more efficiently and sustainably.

Workshop - A suitable place for the development of tools and materials using or not using recyclable resources. The workshop will be built in a way that promotes the creation and artisanal development with workbenches, support tables, and spaces for organizing tools.

Warehouse - A suitable place for the storage of any materials developed or brought from Earth that are not essential in the astronauts' habitat for the economy and optimization of astronauts' spaces. The location should be constructed in such a way that the mentioned storage structures are prioritized.

WASTE: Temporary aluminum structure of the inflatable habitat, clothing waste, floor cloths/plates, food packaging (containing aluminum and polyethylene), bubble wrap, packing foam, air cushions for packing, empty CTBs, used PMC plates in packaging, Martian regolith (not waste, but used).

  • Structure - rearranged aluminum from the temporary three-dimensional cubic structure of the inflatable habitat:

(We estimated around 2.6m (3,3 feet) in height at the highest point of the cabin, since it is made with the support poles from the habitat.{ Maybe it will be taller.})

  • Cloth (see below)

PROPOSAL: Multi-purpose protective cloth developed from recyclable material that will be used for external protection of ESTU and other activities, for example:

a) to be used as a floor for the ESTU as well;

b) protect materials added outside the astronauts' habitat and the ESTU as equipment if necessary;

c) can be used as extra protection for astronauts due to its thermal properties and protection against dust and other environmental elements;

Important: the uses of the tarpaulin are unlimited and can vary according to the team's needs.

The original tarp has three layers, designed to form an effective protection.

1. The outermost layer, which will be the most resistant layer, will protect the ESTU from the hostile environment of Mars, keeping stored materials and astronauts safe. The outermost layer, which will be the most resistant layer, will protect the ESTU from the hostile Martian environment, keeping stored materials and astronauts safe. Furthermore, it is the layer that will serve as a barrier against sandstorms, and in the case of using tarps for equipment protection, it is also very important. The materials must be the most resistant ones available.

Materials: aluminum, polyethylene, nylon, polyester. Present in: Food packaging, external packaging, beverage bags, thermal bags, rehydration bags.

How can the joining of the packaging/materials for the creation of the first layer be done: By heating the edges of the plastics to bond them together.

Note: this can be done with a tool similar to an iron or a hair straightener.

Important: This heating must be done at a low temperature to avoid releasing any toxic gases.

2. The middle layer for thermal insulation and extra protection. For human uses or depending on the intended use of the ESTU, temperature is crucial, which is why this layer is important.

Materials: bubble wrap or air bags. Present in: Various packaging. (in some situations, these materials are the packaging themselves.

How the joining of the packaging/materials for the creation of the second layer can be done: By heating the edges of the plastics to bond them together. Note: this can be done with a tool similar to an iron or a hair straightener.

Important: This heating must be done at a low temperature to avoid releasing any toxic gas.

3. The innermost layer that will serve to structure the tarp, in addition to being the least rigid of the layers. In the case of human use or equipment protection, a material like aluminum (present in the first layer) could cause a lot of discomfort or damage to the integrity of the equipment, which is why the fabric layer is quite useful.

Materials: Fabrics such as cotton, cellulose, nylon, polyester. Present in: clothes, dishcloths, disinfectant wipes.

How can the joining of the fabrics for the creation of the third layer be done: By sewing the fabrics together. This can be done with a kit brought by the astronauts themselves or by using small strips of fabric to tie everything together with knots.

After developing the three layers separately, it is necessary to join them.

Ways to join the three layers of the Cloth:

a) Join layers 1 and 3 in such a way that layer 2 remains firmly in the middle without the need to be fixed. How: Heat the entire edges of the first layer and stick it to the third layer so that the second layer stays in the middle.

b) Join all the layers using tape that ensures secure adhesion (to avoid potential problems with the structure of the tarp)

Important: The structure of the three-layer tarp can be rearranged as needed. For example, it may be necessary to have a tarp made only of fabric, so the astronauts could use three layers made only of fabric.

Proposal for the floor of ESTU: A cloth made only with first-layer materials.

PROPOSAL: Modular containers and tables for storage and project fabrication

Cargo transfer bags (CTB's) - Self-storage bags for space missions and come in various size configurations. After emptying a CTB, its shape is suitable for making simple structures.

Blocks - When filled and compacted with Martian regolith, they can become convenient structural blocks for cladding and structuring. They can also be used as seats and other furniture if their interior is filled with foam and other materials.

PROPOSAL: Modular Tables/Shelves for Storage and Project Development

Polymer Matrix Composites (PMC's) - These are materials composed of a thermoplastic or thermosetting resin matrix coated with a fiber that is substantially more resistant than the matrix. In the case of the PMC provided in the mission, which is made of plastic resin and carbon fiber, we can reuse its hardness and strength to produce workbenches and modular furniture for the developing structure.

(In the example, a PMC top is placed on an aluminum structure, serving both as a table and a shelf.) If all the aluminum has been used in the workshop structure, CTB blocks can also be used as a foundation for such tables.

challengeDetails.title: SpaceTrash Hack: Revolutionizing Recycling on Mars
challengeDetails.excerpt: During a hypothetical three-year mission to Mars and back, an eight-person crew would accumulate 12,600 kg of inorganic waste, or trash, including various packaging materials, textiles, and structural materials. This scenario creates a pressing need to recycle available materials, rather than execute the expensive and inefficient processes of transporting additional resources from Earth and/or sending trash back to Earth. As humans prepare to explore unknown worlds in the future, your challenge is to design sustainable systems that could manage, reuse, or recycle inorganic waste (“trash”) that is brought to and/or accumulated on the surface of Mars. (Space Technology Mission Directorate)

(Astrophysics Division)

node.title: Savoir-faire
node.excerpt: We are a group of 6 friends from the same Computer Science class at UFU (Federal University of Uberlândia).

projectDetails.name: Statistical Weather Analysis and Meteorology Prediction Tool (SWAMP Tool)
projectDetails.summary:
We've developed Savoir-Faire SWAMP (Statistical Weather Analysis and Meteorology Prediction), a web application that provides historical meteorological data and statistical analysis to help users estimate the likelihood of specific weather phenomena for a given day and location.

SWAMP it addresses to the challenge because the tool enables users to create a personalized dashboard to view the probability of certain weather conditions (e.g., temperature, precipitation, humidity, wind speed) for a selected time and place.

SWAMP is particularly useful for anyone planning an outdoor event, such as a vacation, a hike, or a fishing trip, as knowing the chances of adverse weather helps in making more informed decisions.
projectDetails.details:
What does it do or how does it work?

Our project is a web application that provides a probabilistic weather forecast based on historical data. Using NASA's POWER API, it gathers 20 years of climate data for a specific location and date. Instead of predicting the weather in real-time, it applies a statistical model based on the Bell Curve (Normal Distribution) to analyze weather patterns within a seven-day window around the chosen date. The result is a forecast that informs the likely intensity of a weather event (like rain), allowing the user to know if the historical pattern points to a drizzle, a heavy storm, or a day with no precipitation.

What benefits does it have?

The main benefit is providing a much more detailed and useful forecast for event planning. While traditional forecasts offer a percentage chance of rain, our tool contextualizes that chance with its probable intensity. This allows users to make more informed decisions: a high probability of a "drizzle" has a very different impact than a high probability of a "storm." Consequently, the project helps manage expectations and prepare more suitable contingency plans for any outdoor activity.

What is the intended impact of the project?

The intended impact is to empower people to plan events with greater confidence by reducing the uncertainty associated with the weather. By providing a historical perspective on what is "normal" for a given week of the year in a specific location, our tool aims to become a reliable resource for event organizers, travelers, and anyone who needs to plan ahead. The ultimate goal is to lessen the stress of planning and increase the success rate of activities that depend on good weather.

What tools, coding languages, hardware, or software did you use to develop your project?

For development, we used a modern, performance-focused stack. The frontend was built with React, Tailwind CSS, Shadcn/ui, and Recharts for data visualization. The backend is an API built in Python with the FastAPI framework, served by Uvicorn and Gunicorn. For data processing, we used the Pandas and NumPy libraries. For optimizations, we employed aiohttp for asynchronous requests to the NASA API, orjson for rapid JSON serialization, and an in-memory cache to speed up responses.

How is your project creative?

Our project's creativity lies in its approach to the problem. Instead of competing with real-time weather forecasts, we shifted the question from "Will it rain?" to "Based on the last 20 years, how does the weather typically behave this week?". The application of a well-established statistical model (the Bell Curve) to generate a forecast of likely intensity, based on a vast set of historical NASA data, is an innovative way to extract practical value and insights for event planning—something that conventional forecasting tools do not offer.

What factors did your team consider?

Our team considered several factors. First, technical feasibility aligned with our skills: we chose a web application challenge because the team has strong full-stack development experience. Second, the quality and availability of data, which led us to select a challenge with rich NASA data sources. Finally, performance and user experience were crucial, guiding our technological choices to ensure the application was fast, responsive, and presented the data clearly and intuitively to the end-user.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
No images, videos, audio, or data were generated with AI.

We used Lovable AI as a kickstart for our frontend development. We provided the tool with our original references, screen mockups, and logo to guide the design process. We also detailed the planned functionality, expected UI behavior, and responsiveness requirements. Based on this input, the AI generated a React prototype that served as the foundation for building our application, kickstarting the initial development. Additionally, we used Gemini Pro as a copilot to refine the code, streamline the process, and ensure the proper use of React features with which we were unfamiliar.

challengeDetails.title: Will It Rain On My Parade?
challengeDetails.excerpt: If you’re planning an outdoor event—like a vacation, a hike on a trail, or fishing on a lake—it would be good to know the chances of adverse weather for the time and location you are considering. There are many types of Earth observation data that can provide information on weather conditions for a particular location and day of the year. Your challenge is to construct an app with a personalized interface that enables users to conduct a customized query to tell them the likelihood of “very hot,” “very cold,” “very windy,” “very wet,” or “very uncomfortable” conditions for the location and time they specify. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Meteor Madness

Your challenge is to develop an interactive visualization and simulation tool that uses real data to help users model asteroid impact scenarios, predict consequences, and evaluate potential mitigation strategies. (Planetary Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Project SpaceGuard
projectDetails.summary:
SpaceGuard is a web platform that transforms complex asteroid impact data into clear, visual knowledge for decision-makers and the public. When astronomers detect a new near-Earth object, the information is often technical and hard to interpret outside the scientific community. SpaceGuard bridges this gap by combining NASA’s Near-Earth Object parameters (size, speed, orbit) with USGS environmental layers (elevation, seismic catalogs, coastline risk) to simulate possible impacts and their consequences.

Users can enter object properties — such as diameter, density, velocity, and impact location — and instantly visualize impact energy, crater size, seismic effects, and hazard zones on an interactive map. A mitigation module shows how small deflections could change the impact site, helping people understand deflection strategies.

This project makes complex planetary defense science accessible, interactive, and actionable, supporting public communication during asteroid alerts, enriching STEM education, and helping emergency planners and policy makers prepare before a real threat emerges.
projectDetails.details:
SpaceGuard is an interactive web platform that turns complex asteroid impact data into clear, accessible visual information for decision-makers, educators, and the general public. It combines NASA’s Near-Earth Object (NEO) parameters — such as size, velocity, and orbit — with USGS environmental data — including elevation, seismic catalogs, and coastline risk — to simulate asteroid impacts, visualize potential consequences, and explore mitigation strategies.

Users can input asteroid characteristics (diameter, density, velocity, angle, and impact location) and instantly receive simulations that show impact energy, crater size, seismic magnitude, and risk zones displayed on an interactive map. A dedicated mitigation module demonstrates how small trajectory changes (∆v) could alter an impact point, helping people understand planetary defense strategies in an intuitive way.

The project was built with React + TypeScript + Vite on the frontend, using Three.js / @react-three/fiber for realistic 3D visualization of Earth and asteroids, Leaflet for mapping and hazard zones, Framer Motion for smooth animations, and D3.js for dynamic data visualization. The backend uses Node.js + Express to run simulations and process data, with integration capabilities for external APIs such as NASA NeoWs and USGS.

Our creative focus was to translate complex planetary defense science into something engaging and understandable, combining scientific accuracy with a user-friendly experience. SpaceGuard aims to support STEM education, improve public communication during asteroid-related news events, and assist emergency planners and policy makers in preparing for potential space threats.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
We used Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools to accelerate the development and prototyping of the project.

ChatGPT was used to support the developers by assisting with ideation, code review, technical documentation, and the creation of explanatory texts and project pitches.
Lovable was used to assist in user interface prototyping, allowing the team to quickly test design ideas and navigation flows before implementation.

All AI-generated content was manually reviewed and refined by the team to ensure technical accuracy and originality. No NASA branding or design elements were used, modified, or incorporated.

projectDetails.name: Project Space Life Team
projectDetails.summary:
We developed a web platform that allows users to efficiently search and explore NASA’s bioscience publications through an intelligent keyword-based search system. Our tool organizes and filters hundreds of scientific papers, helping researchers quickly locate information relevant to their interests.
At this stage, the project focuses on building a robust and accurate search engine — the foundation for future enhancements. Upcoming features will include an AI assistant capable of answering questions based on NASA publications, as well as bibliometric visualizations that reveal relationships, trends, and research gaps.
By creating a structured and scalable platform, our goal is to make NASA’s bioscience data more accessible, interactive, and insightful, empowering scientists and mission planners to accelerate discoveries that support the next era of human space exploration.
projectDetails.details:
Project Details

Our project is an intelligent search platform designed to help users explore NASA’s bioscience publications more efficiently. It focuses on creating a powerful keyword and semantic-based search system that makes navigating hundreds of scientific articles faster and easier.

What it does / How it works

The system processes NASA’s bioscience publication data, cleans and structures the text, and generates vector embeddings using natural language models. These embeddings are stored in a FAISS index to enable fast and semantically meaningful searches.
Through an interactive Streamlit interface, users can type keywords and instantly retrieve the most relevant publications, along with short text excerpts that summarize each result. This allows users to identify useful information without opening every document.

Benefits and Intended Impact

The project significantly reduces the time required to find relevant scientific studies, improves accessibility to NASA’s bioscience data, and supports evidence-based decision-making. By providing a strong foundation for future features—such as AI-powered question answering, bibliometric visualizations, and similarity notifications—it aims to accelerate discoveries that support future lunar and Martian exploration.

Tools and Technologies

We used Python, HuggingFace for text embeddings, FAISS for efficient vector search, and Streamlit for building the interactive web interface. The system architecture was designed for scalability and modularity, ensuring easy integration of future functionalities.

Creativity and Design Considerations

Instead of relying on simple keyword matching, our system uses semantic understanding to connect related ideas across documents. It also includes automatic deduplication and contextual excerpts for a smoother user experience.
Our team focused on performance, scalability, and user accessibility—creating a clean, intuitive, and expandable foundation for a knowledge exploration tool that bridges science, data, and discovery.
projectDetails.aiReferences: Using embedding and vectorization techniques and stacks to build a vector database, we used HuggingFaceEmbeddings for embedding processing, such as retrieval, document loaders, and FAISS to construct the pipeline.

challengeDetails.excerpt: Witness the pulse of life across our planet! challengeDetails.title: Through the Radar Looking Glass: Revealing Earth Processes with SAR
challengeDetails.excerpt: Like Alice in Wonderland, let’s travel down the rabbit hole to reveal a world that looks like our planet Earth… but not quite! Using synthetic aperture radar (SAR), we can image the world by emitting radar pulses toward Earth and recording the energy that is reflected back after the signals interact with Earth's surface. Your challenge is to download multi-frequency or multi-polarization SAR data for an interesting study area of your choice –e.g., your hometown, a tropical wetland, ice sheet, forest wildfire, flooded neighborhood, volcano eruption, etc.—and use that data to develop hypotheses about the physical drivers operating there. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: ET and Lily - Starborn Girls
projectDetails.summary: We present the story “ET and Lily”, a digital children's book that takes kids and teens on a fun journey to discover what space weather is and how it affects different people on Earth. Using NASA data and accessible explanations, the project offers a solution to the challenge of writing and illustrating a story that explains space weather and its diverse impacts on the people around us and various situations. We believe it is essential for the new generations to learn about scientific topics in a lighthearted way, awakening their curiosity and promoting knowledge. That is why “ET and Lily” was created in order to make this knowledge accessible and easily understandable for everyone, encouraging the little curious to be the great scientists of the future.
projectDetails.details:
What does it do and how does it work?

"ET and Lily" is a children's story that begins when an extraterrestrial researcher falls into Lily's backyard, a curious and dreamy girl who has the desire to become a scientist. Together, they embark on a journey to explore Earth and understand how space weather impacts people's lives and even their own.

The story uses data from NASA, as well as additional information from other agencies and images to explain the events that occur in the story in a light and understandable manner for a young and lay audience. 

The characters travel to various locations around the world to meet new people who can help them understand more about space weather. In this narrative, they learn about what space weather is and how it impacts farmers, photographers, radio stations, and astronauts by interfering with GPS and radio signals and creating auroras borealis and emitting harmful radiation in space. At the end of the story, there is a direct interaction with the reader, encouraging them to take an interest in scientific events that directly affect the planet, such as space weather, as well as in scientific research and the pursuit of knowledge.

What are the benefits?

The project offers a series of benefits by bringing a story that makes complex concepts and real NASA data be understood in a playful and engaging way, in addition to providing authentic learning without losing the fun tone. The story also captivates and offers reflections on how events that seem so distant actually affect all our lives and the importance of studying them.

What do we hope to achieve?

The story was designed to encourage children to see the world more broadly and understand the relationships between natural phenomena and the daily lives of humanity. We hope that readers develop an interest in science and scientific research and, consequently, let them know more about NASA.

What tools were used?

The development of "ET and Lily" involved various tools and resources to ensure the quality of the content and the effectiveness of the project. Among the tools used are:

  • Canva: For the creation of illustrations and visual designs of the story, in addition to being the platform on which the project was made;
  • Ibis Paint: Creation of the characters and flying saucer;
  • Google: Used to access the scientific information utilized and ensure that the scientific concepts addressed in the story are accurate and truthful;
  • Quillbot: Grammar review and translation.

Factors considered in the project development and why is it creative?

  • Natural curiosity of children: We know that children are naturally curious, and we want to take advantage of this characteristic to engage them with scientific topics.
  • Childlike visual aspects: The characters were hand-drawn to bring a more playful and accessible feel, with the intention of creating an emotional connection with the child audience.
  • Educational approach: The story was constructed to be informative without losing its fun character, with the idea that learning about science should be an enjoyable experience.

projectDetails.name: Starkaxe - BloomWatch
projectDetails.summary:
BloomWatch: Web Platform for Plant Bloom Monitoring
Abstract: BloomWatch is a web tool integrating satellite, climate, and observational data via APIs to monitor and predict plant blooming in user-chosen regions. Built with HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and hosted on GitHub, it offers map-based region selection, species data (names, images), and bloom forecasts. It’s a scalable tool for citizen science and phenology research.
Introduction: Phenology tracks cyclic biological events like flowering, sensitive to climate shifts. BloomWatch visualizes and predicts blooms using open data, aiding scientists, educators, and enthusiasts.
Design and Implementation:

Tech: HTML for structure, CSS for responsive design, JavaScript for interactivity and APIs.
Data: Uses NASA POWER/NOAA for climate, Sentinel-2 for imagery, and iNaturalist for observations.
Interface: Interactive map enables region selection, species retrieval, bloom predictions, and NDVI monitoring.

Modeling: A degree-day model with precipitation thresholds predicts blooming, calibrated with historical data.
Case Study: Coffea arabica bloom predictions were accurate within 5-7 days in coffee regions.
Results: BloomWatch enables real-time monitoring but faces issues like sparse data in some areas.
Future: Expand species, add AI models, and implement bloom alerts.
Conclusion: BloomWatch merges tech and open data to track blooms, supporting ecological research.
projectDetails.details:
Starkaxe - BloomWatch: A Web-Based Platform for Monitoring and Predicting Plant Blooming Events
Abstract
Phenological changes, particularly in blooming timing, serve as critical indicators of ecosystem responses to climatic variability. We present BloomWatch, an interactive web platform that integrates satellite, climate, and observational data via APIs to monitor and forecast blooming phenophases within user-selected geographic regions. The system—implemented in HTML, CSS, and JavaScript and hosted on GitHub—allows users to select regions on a map and retrieve species data (common name, scientific name, imagery) alongside modeled bloom forecasts and real-time phenological monitoring. A slide presentation was also produced to clearly communicate methodology, results, and implications. BloomWatch constitutes a scalable, open-access tool for citizen science, ecological education, and phenological research.

1. Introduction
Phenology—the study of periodic biological events such as flowering, leaf-out, and fruiting—is fundamental to understanding how organisms respond to climatic and environmental change. Among phenophases, the onset of flowering is one of the most sensitive to shifts in temperature, precipitation, and photoperiod, and its alteration can propagate through ecosystems by affecting pollinators, reproductive success, and trophic interactions. The advancement of flowering by several days per degree Celsius of warming has been documented, with cascading implications for agriculture, biodiversity, and ecosystem services. To foster wider access to phenological insights, we developed BloomWatch, a web tool designed to facilitate visualization, monitoring, and forecasting of flowering events in any region of interest.

2. System Design and Implementation
2.1 Architectural Overview and Technologies
BloomWatch is structured using conventional web technologies:
HTML provides the structural markup for pages,

CSS ensures responsive styling, layout consistency, and aesthetic cohesion,

JavaScript drives the interactive elements, mapping, API integration, and real-time data processing.

The full source code is versioned and publicly accessible in a GitHub repository, ensuring transparency, collaborative development, and reproducibility.
2.2 Data Sources and API Integration
To realize phenological monitoring and predictive functionality, BloomWatch ingests data from multiple open APIs and remote sensing platforms:
Meteorological datasets (e.g. NASA POWER, NOAA, or regional climate services) supply daily temperature, precipitation, radiation, and related parameters;

Satellite imagery (e.g. Sentinel-2 from Copernicus) supports derivation of vegetation indices (such as NDVI) that reflect plant health and phenophase transitions;

Biodiversity and phenological observations (e.g. via iNaturalist API) provide empirical records of species occurrence and flowering events, enabling local calibration and validation.

By fusing remote sensing, climatic data, and citizen-science observations, BloomWatch aims to deliver spatially and temporally robust phenological inference.
2.3 User Interface and Workflow
Upon accessing the platform, the user is presented with an interactive global map interface. The user may:
Zoom, pan, or define a geographical boundary of interest;

Submit a selection (polygon or point) corresponding to a region;

Retrieve a list of species known or likely present in that region, including:
 • Common (vernacular) names
 • Scientific names
 • Representative photographs

Access model-based forecasts of flowering onset dates for those species, predicated on climatic and phenological parameters;

Monitor vegetation dynamics via index time series (e.g. NDVI trends) to detect phenophase transitions.

This workflow supports both exploratory inquiry and hypothesis-driven phenological investigation.

3. Phenological Modeling and Forecasting
3.1 Model Formulation
BloomWatch implements a degree-day accumulation model augmented by precipitation thresholds, whereby flowering is predicted once a critical thermal sum is reached following adequate moisture conditions. Species-specific parameters may be configured when historical phenological records exist for calibration.
3.2 Calibration and Validation Procedures
Model validation is achieved by comparing predicted flowering dates against observed records from phenological databases, citizen science inputs, or herbarium metadata. Discrepancies are used to quantify model error and refine parameter tuning on a region-by-region basis.

4. Case Study: Coffea arabica
As a demonstration, Coffea arabica (coffee) was selected due to its economic significance and sensitivity to climate cues. We analyzed temperature regimes (e.g. 15–24 °C) and precipitation patterns typical of coffee zones, applied our phenological model to forecast flowering windows, and cross-examined satellite-derived vegetation indices during pre-flowering periods. This case affirms BloomWatch’s potential utility in agronomic, ecological, and phenological contexts.

5. Results and Discussion
The prototype system facilitates user-driven selection of regions and retrieval of species information and bloom forecasts.

Integration of satellite indices (e.g. NDVI) enables real-time monitoring of vegetation status and phenophase transitions.

Hosting via GitHub ensures reproducibility, version tracking, and open collaboration.

Limitations and challenges remain, including:
 • Sparse phenological observations in underrepresented territories, limiting model calibration accuracy;
 • Simplified phenological models may not capture local microclimate, soil moisture heterogeneity, or biotic interactions;
 • Latency in API responses or satellite revisit cycles may constrain temporal resolution.

Despite these constraints, BloomWatch demonstrates the viability of a public, web-accessible phenology platform based on open data and accessible technologies.

6. Future Directions
Expand the species catalog across diverse biomes and taxonomic groups;

Integrate machine learning and statistical modeling (e.g. random forests, time-series forecasting) to enhance bloom prediction accuracy;

Implement alert or notification systems (via email, SMS, or webhooks) for imminent phenophase events;

Incorporate real-time sensor networks (IoT) and crowd-sourced phenophase submissions;

Develop researcher dashboards for comparative analysis across years, species, and regions.

7. Conclusion
BloomWatch synergizes modern web technologies, open APIs, satellite sensing, and citizen science to create an interactive platform for monitoring and forecasting flowering phenology. As climate change continues to shift phenological patterns, tools such as BloomWatch can empower scientists, educators, and the general public to observe, analyze, and anticipate ecosystem responses. Its GitHub-based, open architecture encourages further refinement, adoption, and extension in diverse ecological and climatic contexts.

challengeDetails.title: BloomWatch: An Earth Observation Application for Global Flowering Phenology
challengeDetails.excerpt: Witness the pulse of life across our planet! From season to season and year to year, Earth’s vegetation is constantly changing, providing critical information on plant species, crops, seasonal effects, pollen sources, and changes in plant phenology (the relationship between seasonal changes and climate and biological phenomena in plants). Your challenge is to harness the power of NASA Earth observations to create a dynamic visual tool that displays and/or detects plant blooming events around the globe—just like pollinators do–and that advances solutions for monitoring, predicting, or managing vegetation. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Through the Stellar Gaze
projectDetails.summary:
For the "Stellar Stories" challenge, I developed "Through the Stellar Gaze," a children's storybook that translates complex NASA science into an educational narrative for early readers. The core of my project is a custom AI agent, configured in Gemini with a curated dataset of NASA's resources on space weather. This agent's ability to be continuously updated with new information makes the storytelling dynamic and endlessly customizable.

This project directly addresses the challenge by creating an accessible story about space weather. Its importance lies in making science relatable. Growing up with a passion for stars, I often felt that scientific knowledge and representation were out of reach. "Through the Stellar Gaze" uses AI to bridge this gap, creating relatable narratives that can inspire the next generation, especially young girls, to see themselves in STEM careers and feel empowered to explore their own scientific curiosity.
projectDetails.details:
At its core, this project is about forging a personal connection between children and science.

"Through the Stellar Gaze" is a children's storybook that brings the science of space weather to life for early readers. It works through a unique, AI-assisted workflow. The project's creative core is a custom AI agent I developed in Gemini Pro, which was trained on a curated dataset of NASA resources (articles, transcripts). This agent was configured with a specific persona: an expert astrophysicist skilled in simplifying complex information.

The true innovation lies in this customizable agent. It serves as a dynamic engine capable of generating new, scientifically-grounded stories and characters on demand. This makes the project a replicable framework for science communication, not just a single story.

The primary benefit is making science accessible and engaging. A key asset of the custom agent is its ability to generate diverse characters, allowing children from all backgrounds, cultures, and identities to see themselves front and center in scientific narratives. Furthermore, the story can be easily adapted into other languages, amplifying its impact to a global audience.

The project addresses a gap I experienced firsthand: a world where scientific wonder wasn't always reflected in the stories available to young people. The AI-powered system behind "Through the Stellar Gaze" was designed specifically to bridge this divide. Its purpose is to craft narratives that are not only educational but also deeply empowering. The ultimate goal is to foster a lasting sense of curiosity and show young minds, particularly girls, that they have a central place in the world of science and exploration.

As a solo participant, every decision during development was guided by the goal of maximizing the project's impact and accessibility. This involved a careful balance of three key factors. The story was designed to be visually engaging and simple enough for early readers to ensure it could reach the widest possible audience. However, this simplicity did not come at the cost of accuracy; a primary goal was to maintain scientific fidelity to the sourced NASA data. Finally, inclusivity and representation were a core consideration, leading to a framework that supports diverse characters to make the world of science feel welcoming to every child.

Tools used:

  • Gemini 2.5 Pro: Used to create the custom AI agent, generate the foundational manuscript, produce all core illustrations, and summarize research data.
  • Canva: Used for the final layout and design of the storybook, cover art, text effects, and presentation materials.
  • Google Drive: Used for sharing the final storybook and presentation.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
My intent for this project was to translate complex NASA data into a scientifically-grounded yet accessible children's book. As a solo participant working within a tight deadline, the originality of my approach was to develop a custom AI collaborator to efficiently manage the project's scope.

The process began by me curating a dedicated knowledge base from NASA's available resources for this challenge. I selected key materials, including scientific articles and video transcripts. Using this information, leveraged Gemini 2.5 Pro to build a custom AI agent with a unique persona: an expert astrophysicist who also shared my skills in communication, art, and storytelling, specifically tasked with transforming complex data into a simple, user-friendly narrative.

The custom "gem" was essential for:

Synthesizing the vast amount of technical information into a foundational manuscript, which then served as the basis for my work. My efforts focused on editing and adapting this AI-generated draft to ensure the final narrative quality and alignment with the project's original intent;

Instructed the AI agent to produce a foundational manuscript for a children's book aimed at an audience of early readers, based on NASA's data that I selected;

Authored the detailed prompts that guided the AI in generating the illustrations, defining specific characteristics for each character and the cover art;

All core illustrations and character designs were generated in Gemini 2.5 Pro based on the detailed prompts. I then used a separate graphic design tool to edit the final book cover and page layouts using these AI-generated assets. To ensure transparency, the original illustrations feature a Gemini watermark in the bottom-right corner;

Additionally, I utilized the AI for a final grammatical and stylistic review of the project's texts, using it strictly as a revision tool not for creation to ensure professional clarity.

projectDetails.name: TARS: Threat Assessment & Response Simulator
projectDetails.summary: Our project, TARS, directly addresses the "Meteor Madness" challenge by creating a robust orbital physics engine to simulate potential asteroid impact scenarios. Using real-time data on Near-Earth Objects (NEOs) from NASA's JPL Small-Body Database API, our system reverse-engineers a potential threat. Instead of merely tracking an existing orbit, TARS calculates the precise starting position and velocity an asteroid, originating from beyond Neptune, would need to guarantee a future collision with Earth. This entire catastrophic trajectory is then visualized in a user-friendly web interface, allowing users to select a real NEO and watch its simulated journey. TARS is a powerful educational and predictive tool that highlights the critical importance of planetary defense by modeling physically plausible worst-case scenarios.
projectDetails.details:
The project is a comprehensive simulation platform designed to model and visualize potential asteroid impact threats to Earth.

  • How it Works: The system is built on a two-part architecture. The backend is a powerful simulation engine written in Python. It pulls data for a selected Near-Earth Object (NEO) from NASA's API, including its estimated size. It then performs a complex calculation, treating the solar system as an n-body problem, to determine a hypothetical starting point in the outer solar system. This starting point is specifically calculated to ensure the NEO's trajectory will eventually intersect with Earth's orbit for a direct impact. The frontend is a web-based interface built with HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. It runs on a localhost server, which communicates with the backend engine. Users can select a real NEO from a list, and the frontend then dynamically visualizes the NEO’s entire calculated trajectory from the outer solar system to its final impact with Earth.
  • Benefits and Impact: The primary benefit of TARS is its unique "inverse" approach. It serves as an advanced educational tool for demonstrating the complex orbital mechanics that could lead to an impact. For planetary defense researchers, it provides a method to simulate and analyze worst-case scenarios, which is crucial for developing and testing interception strategies. The intended impact is to raise public and scientific awareness of NEO threats by providing a clear, data-driven visualization of what a potential catastrophe could look like.
  • Tools and Creativity: We used Python with the NumPy library for the backend physics calculations and HTML/CSS/JavaScript for the frontend visualization. The project's creativity lies in its reverse-engineering of an impact event. While most tools track existing paths, we calculate a hypothetical but physically accurate path that guarantees an impact, offering a novel perspective on threat assessment.
  • Live Server: This Visual Code Extension was used to run the localhost server.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Declaration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) Use

In the development of our project, Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools were utilized to accelerate innovation and assist in specific technical areas. The core concepts, scientific logic, and overall project direction were driven entirely by human ideation and collaboration among team members. The AI's role was that of a supportive tool, not a primary creator.

Our use of AI can be broken down as follows:

  1. Backend Simulation Engine: The physics engine and core simulation logic were predominantly designed, architected, and coded by our team. AI assistance was employed for targeted tasks, such as debugging minor logical errors, optimizing code snippets for performance, and suggesting alternative algorithmic approaches. The fundamental structure and its scientific integrity are products of human effort.
  2. Front-End Development: Our team did not possess prior expertise in front-end programming. To bridge this skill gap, we utilized AI to help generate the foundational code for the user interface. While the AI assisted in translating our design concepts into functional code, the user experience (UX) flow, visual layout, and all creative decisions were conceived and directed by the team. Human ideas and solutions were paramount, with the AI serving as an implementation tool.
  3. General Debugging and Problem-Solving: Throughout the project, AI was used as a debugging partner to help identify syntax errors and troubleshoot complex issues. This allowed our team to focus more on the high-level logic and creative aspects of the project, rather than getting stalled by minor implementation hurdles.

In all instances, the AI was a tool that followed human guidance. The solutions, creative direction, and the very intent behind our project were the result of our team's original thoughts and collaborative work.

challengeDetails.title: Meteor Madness

Your challenge is to develop an interactive visualization and simulation tool that uses real data to help users model asteroid impact scenarios, predict consequences, and evaluate potential mitigation strategies. (Planetary Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Shark Predictor
projectDetails.summary: We developed Shark Predictor, a data-driven application that directly addresses the "Sharks from Space" challenge. Our solution integrates diverse satellite data from NASA and Copernicus Marine Service, including sea surface temperature, chlorophyll concentration, and ocean currents. Using a machine learning model, the application analyzes these factors to predict the probability and type of shark presence in any given marine location, complete with a risk assessment for human populations. This project is vital as it translates complex Earth observation data into actionable insights for marine conservation, scientific research, and public safety.
projectDetails.details:
Our project provides a comprehensive, two-part solution to the "Sharks from Space" challenge: a fully developed predictive web application for immediate use, and the conceptual design for a next-generation hardware tag to revolutionize future research.

Component 1: The "Shark Predictor" Web Application

Our application provides real-time predictive analysis of shark habitats based on publicly available oceanographic data.

How it Works: The system workflow is as follows:

  1. Input Validation: The application first validates that input coordinates fall within a marine environment, ensuring the model operates in its intended domain.
  2. Data Integration: It retrieves multi-source data via APIs, including Sea Surface Temperature (SST), ocean currents, and chlorophyll from NASA, alongside ocean depth from Copernicus Marine Service.
  3. ML Prediction: This integrated data is fed into our trained machine learning model to calculate the probability of shark presence, predict potential species, and assess the corresponding risk level to humans.
  4. Visualization: The results are presented through an intuitive user interface, featuring an interactive map that clearly visualizes high-probability zones and risk levels.

Component 2: Conceptual Hardware - The High-Fidelity Trophic Tag (HFTT)

To address the challenge's call for a new tag design, we conceptualized the HFTT, a realistic, next-generation device designed to collect the "ground truth" data that is currently missing in marine science.

Key Features:

  • Physiological Monitoring: It combines motion sensors with a non-invasive ECG sensor to track a shark's heart rate, providing direct insight into its physical effort and metabolic cost.
  • Event-Triggered eDNA Sampling: Using an onboard AI, the tag detects a predation event and automatically collects a water sample. This allows for later lab analysis of environmental DNA (eDNA) to genetically confirm what the shark preyed upon.
  • Onboard AI Management: A low-power AI classifies behavior (hunting, traveling, etc.) in real-time to intelligently manage the tag's systems, dramatically extending its battery life and providing scientists with pre-analyzed data summaries.

Overall Impact, Synergy, and Innovation

Our core innovation is this dual approach, creating a powerful feedback loop between software and future hardware:

  • Immediate Impact (Software): The "Shark Predictor" application is a cost-effective, globally scalable, and instantly deployable tool. It uses existing satellite data to provide valuable, actionable insights for conservation, scientific research, and public safety today.
  • Future of Research (Hardware): The HFTT is designed to be the ultimate data source for tomorrow. The data collected by the HFTT—linking physiology, environment, and confirmed prey—would be used to train and validate vastly more accurate future versions of our machine learning model.
  • Synergy: Our application can identify ideal locations to deploy the HFTT, and the HFTT, in turn, provides the high-fidelity data needed to refine the application's predictions from correlation to causation.

Together, these two components represent a complete strategy: a powerful tool for now and a clear, viable roadmap for the future of marine ecology and conservation.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Our team utilized a suite of Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools to support and accelerate various phases of the project.

RESEARCH AND CONCEPTUALIZATION
For in-depth research and refining concepts, we leveraged large language models including Google Gemini and GPT to search for technical information and validate ideas.

CODE DEVELOPMENT AND REFINEMENT
AI-powered coding assistants were essential. We employed Manus A.I for initial code generation and refinement. Claude A.I was used for advanced code refinement and correcting complex errors. Additionally, our commented code was reviewed and enhanced by these AIs to improve clarity and maintainability.
PRESENTATION AND DESIGN

We used Prezi AI to assist in the design, layout, and visual structuring of our final presentation slides, helping to communicate our project's story effectively.

PROJECT UTILITIES
We also used Manus A.I for utility tasks, such as organizing and packaging our final project files for submission.

This multi-AI approach allowed our team to work more efficiently, enabling us to focus on the core architectural logic and data integration.

challengeDetails.title: Sharks from Space
challengeDetails.excerpt: Earth’s ocean is one of the most powerful habitats in our universe, supporting a range of life that sustains ecosystems and habitability across the globe. It is common to measure photosynthetic activity in the ocean from space, but far more challenging to track top predators. Your challenge is to create a mathematical framework for identifying sharks and predicting their foraging habitats using NASA satellite data, and also to suggest a new conceptual model of a tag (a small electronic device that can be attached to an animal to track and study its movement) that could measure not only where sharks are, but also what they are eating, and in real time transmit that data back to users to enable development of predictive models. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Project Tech for good
projectDetails.summary:
Let’s conquer Mars without forgetting those who remain on Earth.
Our project uses NASA’s Earth observation data (MODIS, SMAP, GPM, GLDAS, and VIIRS) to identify municipalities with the highest levels of food vulnerability on our planet.
The Tech4Good Platform enables local governments to register beneficiaries, accredit restaurants, and manage the distribution of food aid through digital vouchers, replacing centralized cafeterias and food baskets.
This model distributes income within local businesses, reduces urban inequality, and creates a virtuous cycle of economic growth in vulnerable communities.
By turning NASA data into actionable intelligence, we help public managers direct resources precisely where they are most needed — promoting social dignity, sustainability, and healthier cities for all.
projectDetails.details:
What it does / How it works:
The Tech4Good Platform transforms NASA’s Earth observation data (MODIS, SMAP, GPM, GLDAS, and VIIRS) into actionable intelligence to identify municipalities with the highest levels of food vulnerability. Local governments register beneficiaries, accredit restaurants, and manage aid distribution through digital vouchers — replacing traditional food baskets and centralized cafeterias.

Benefits and Intended Impact:
This approach decentralizes food access, strengthens local economies, reduces inequalities, and ensures that assistance reaches those most in need. The platform increases transparency, reduces waste, and fosters social dignity by creating a sustainable, data-driven food assistance ecosystem.

Tools, Languages, and Software:
The project integrates NASA APIs, Python, GitHub Copilot, and AI tools such as ChatGPT for data processing, indicator modeling, and dashboard visualization. The system uses QR code technology to validate meals and automate payments to local establishments.

Creativity and Design Considerations:
Tech4Good stands out for connecting space data to urban food policy, transforming global insights into local action. The team prioritized sustainability, scalability, and social impact, ensuring that the model can be replicated by municipalities worldwide.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Our team leveraged AI technologies such as ChatGPT and GitHub Copilot to enhance both creativity and technical execution.

  • ChatGPT was used to design the project’s visual identity (logo and graphics), refine written content, and translate materials from Portuguese to English.
  • GitHub Copilot assisted in building the tool for consuming NASA APIs, calculating vulnerability indicators, and developing the interactive monitoring dashboard.

By combining human insight with AI-powered tools, our team accelerated development, ensured clarity in communication, and delivered a data-driven solution aligned with NASA’s mission to apply space data for social impact.

projectDetails.name: The Chess Forecasters
projectDetails.summary:
The project is a smart, personalized weather forecasting platform designed to support decisions about outdoor events and everyday activities. It collects weather data from trusted sources like NASA, processes it, and transforms it into detailed forecasts for any location worldwide, using machine learning models to generate actionable recommendations and relevant insights.
The solution automates data collection and processing, enabling on-demand forecasts even for locations poorly covered by traditional services. This helps individuals and organizers make safer and more efficient decisions, reducing risks and optimizing resources. The project is important because it democratizes access to high-quality forecasts, improves the user experience, and makes weather technology accessible and practical for everyone.
projectDetails.details: Our project is a web application developed with Next.js, TypeScript, and Node.js, using Python only to build a supporting API. The API connects to the Distance Matrix to calculate distances and routes and integrates the LLaMA model from Meta, which generates natural language explanations to enhance the user experience. Development was carried out in VSCode, prioritizing a modern and scalable architecture, without the use of visual maps in the interface, instead presenting results in reports and interpretive texts. The goal is to provide a creative solution that combines precise route calculations with intelligent AI-driven analyses, positively impacting academic, logistics, and decision-support applications.
projectDetails.aiReferences: We used Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools in several parts of our project. AI assisted us in documentation writing and code correction, helping accelerate the development process. Additionally, we integrated Meta’s LLaMA model into our web application to provide climate explanations, and we used Prophet (Python library) for time series forecasting.

projectDetails.name: Exoplanet Classifier ML
projectDetails.summary:
We developed an intelligent exoplanet classification system using XGBoost machine learning to automatically distinguish between real exoplanets and false positives from space mission data. Our solution addresses the critical challenge of validating exoplanet candidates by analyzing 24+ astronomical parameters including transit characteristics, stellar properties, and quality flags.

The system features a modern web interface built with Streamlit, offering both individual object analysis and batch processing capabilities. It supports data from multiple NASA missions (Kepler, TESS/TOI, and K2) and provides real-time classification with probability scores.

This tool is crucial for the astronomical community as it accelerates the exoplanet discovery process, reduces manual validation time, and improves accuracy in candidate screening. By automating the classification workflow, researchers can focus on the most promising candidates for follow-up observations.

The application is deployed online and ready for immediate use by astronomers worldwide, democratizing access to advanced exoplanet classification technology.
projectDetails.details:
**What does it do and how does it work?**

Our Exoplanet Classifier AI is a machine learning system that automatically analyzes astronomical data to distinguish between real exoplanets and false positives. The system processes 24+ observational parameters including orbital periods, transit depths, stellar characteristics, and quality flags from NASA missions. Using XGBoost gradient boosting, it generates probability scores for each candidate, enabling rapid and accurate classification.

**What benefits does it have?**

The system dramatically reduces manual screening time from hours to seconds, improves classification accuracy through consistent machine learning algorithms, and provides standardized validation across different space missions. It democratizes access to advanced classification technology, making it available to researchers worldwide without requiring specialized computational resources.

**What is the intended impact?**

This tool accelerates exoplanet discovery by enabling researchers to focus on the most promising candidates for follow-up observations. It supports the search for potentially habitable worlds and contributes to our understanding of planetary formation and evolution. The system can process thousands of candidates efficiently, potentially leading to new exoplanet discoveries.

**Technical Implementation:**

Built with Python and Streamlit for the web interface, XGBoost for machine learning, and pandas for data processing. The system supports Excel/CSV import, real-time validation, and batch processing. Deployed on Streamlit Cloud for global accessibility with automatic updates via GitHub integration.

**Creative and Innovative Aspects:**

The project combines cutting-edge machine learning with user-friendly design, featuring a space-themed interface with interactive visualizations. We implemented intelligent data validation, dynamic warnings for extreme values, and comprehensive error handling. The system bridges the gap between complex ML algorithms and practical astronomical research.

**Team Considerations:**

We prioritized user experience, data security, and scientific accuracy. The system includes safety warnings about model limitations, protects sensitive training data, and provides comprehensive documentation. We focused on making advanced technology accessible to the broader astronomical community while maintaining professional standards.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
**AI Usage Declaration:**

This project utilized AI tools for documentation and code enhancement purposes only. The core machine learning model, algorithm selection (XGBoost), training process, and scientific methodology were developed independently without AI assistance.

**Specific AI Applications:**

1. **Documentation Generation**: AI was used to translate project documentation from Portuguese to English, including README.md, deployment guides, and user manuals.

2. **Code Comments and Integration**: AI assisted in adding explanatory comments to existing code and making minor integration adjustments for better code readability and maintainability.

3. **Text Enhancement**: AI was used to improve technical writing clarity and structure in documentation files.

**AI Tools Used:**

- ChatGPT/Claude for documentation translation and enhancement

- AI-assisted code commenting for better readability

**Original Work:**

- Complete XGBoost model development and training

- Astronomical data preprocessing and feature engineering

- Streamlit web application development

- Scientific methodology and validation approach

- All core algorithms and machine learning logic

**Compliance:**

All AI-generated content has been reviewed and validated. No NASA branding, logos, or mission identifiers were used in AI-generated content. The scientific integrity and originality of the core project remain intact.

challengeDetails.title: A World Away: Hunting for Exoplanets with AI
challengeDetails.excerpt: Data from several different space-based exoplanet surveying missions have enabled discovery of thousands of new planets outside our solar system, but most of these exoplanets were identified manually. With advances in artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML), it is possible to automatically analyze large sets of data collected by these missions to identify exoplanets. Your challenge is to create an AI/ML model that is trained on one or more of the open-source exoplanet datasets offered by NASA and that can analyze new data to accurately identify exoplanets. (Astrophysics Division)
