projectDetails.name: OX2YOU
projectDetails.summary: Ox2you is an interactive web-based platform designed to deliver accurate and accessible real-time air quality forecasts. By enabling users to better understand local pollution dynamics, the system supports the reduction of exposure to unhealthy air conditions. Additionally, it provides evidence-based health and environmental guidance aimed at promoting sustainable air quality preservation.
projectDetails.details:
Ox2you is an interactive web-based platform designed to deliver accurate and accessible real-time air quality forecasts. By enabling users to better understand local pollution dynamics, the system supports the reduction of exposure to unhealthy air conditions. Additionally, it provides evidence-based health and environmental guidance aimed at promoting sustainable air quality preservation.

This project provides a complete data ingestion, processing, and visualization pipeline for monitoring air quality using NASA’s OMI satellite data. Currently, the system focuses on sulfur dioxide (SO₂) concentrations, but the platform is designed to be extensible in the future to handle additional pollutants such as CO₂, NO₂, and others. The system automatically downloads, processes, and stores air quality data every hour, exposes it through a RESTful API, and displays the results on an interactive React-based heatmap interface.

The goal of Ox2You is to forecast local air quality by integrating real-time data from the TEMPO and OMI satellites. The platform aims to protect public health and raise environmental awareness by making NASA’s Earth data understandable and accessible to everyone.

Expected Impacts:

  • Reduce exposure to harmful air pollution levels.

  • Increase public access to environmental data.

  • Support environmental decision-making and local sustainability policies.

  • Promote education and awareness through NASA’s open Earth science data.
[IMAGE ID NOT FOUND title:"" ]

Components

  1. Python Ingestion Service (Scheduler)
    • Runs hourly using an internal scheduler.
    • Downloads OMI Level 2 granules from NASA’s Earthdata API.
    • Parses .he5 files to extract geospatial data fields (currently SO₂).
    • Classifies air quality levels (good, moderate, unhealthy_sensitive, unhealthy, very_unhealthy).
    • Inserts processed data into a PostgreSQL database.
    • Serves as the backend interface for querying air quality data.
    • Provides endpoints for fetching aggregated or filtered data (e.g., by date range, region, or pollution level).
    • Handles connection pooling and query optimization for large datasets.
    • Central data repository for all measurements.
    • Stores geospatial coordinates, pollutant levels, timestamps, and quality classifications.
    • Indexed for efficient geospatial queries (PostGIS optional).
    • Displays real-time and historical data on an interactive heatmap.
    • Uses color coding to represent pollution levels (e.g., green for good, red for very unhealthy).
    • Allows users to filter by date/time and pollution intensity.

All source code is publicly available on GitHub: https://github.com/Ox2you

Live demo: https://ox2you-web.onrender.com/

 Frontend Technologies

  • Vite → Fast and modern development build tool.

  • HeroUI → Accessible and flexible UI component library.

  • Tailwind CSS → Utility-first styling for consistent, responsive design.

  • Tailwind Variants → Enables reusable, theme-based styling.

  • TypeScript → Adds static typing and improves code reliability.

  • Framer Motion → Provides smooth and intuitive animations for the interface.

Main Frontend Features

Interactive Map: Displays global levels of pollutants (PM₂.₅, PM₁₀, NO₂, O₃) in real time.

Search and Filters: Users can find data by city, region, or coordinates.

Air Quality Alerts: Provides alerts when air pollution reaches harmful levels and offers people guidance on how to respond to specific air quality situations.

Dynamic Themes: Light and dark modes adapt to user system preferences.

Responsive Interface: Optimized for both mobile and desktop viewing.

Live API Integration: Connects directly to backend endpoints to fetch real-time forecast and pollutant data.

Backend Technologies

Node.js → Provides a fast and scalable runtime for the server and API logic.

Express → Lightweight web framework used to build RESTful endpoints.

TypeScript → Adds static typing and enhances code readability, safety, and scalability.

PostgreSQL (Supabase) → Cloud-hosted relational database with spatial support and secure SSL connections.

Swagger (OpenAPI) → Generates automatic API documentation and enables easy testing and integration.

Pino → High-performance structured logger for monitoring queries, performance, and debugging.

Render.com → Cloud hosting and CI/CD deployment platform ensuring continuous integration and delivery.

Project Structure (Simplified)

ox-api/

├── src/

│   ├── index.ts             # Main server entry point

│   ├── routes/

│   │   ├── health.ts        # Health-check endpoints

│   │   └── airQuality.ts    # Endpoints for forecasts and pollutant data

│   ├── services/

│   │   ├── db.ts            # Database connection and SSL management

│   │   ├── logger.ts        # Centralized logging configuration

│   │   └── dal.ts           # Data Access Layer and business logic

│   └── swagger/             # Swagger configuration for API documentation

├── scripts/

│   └── seed_db.ts           # Database seeding and mock data generation

├── package.json

└── tsconfig.json

Express handles API routing and middleware, PostgreSQL (via Supabase) manages structured and geospatial data, and Swagger provides an interactive documentation interface for developers and frontend integration.

Main Backend Features

Real-Time Data Ingestion: Retrieves and normalizes pollution metrics (PM₂.₅, PM₁₀, NO₂, O₃) from NASA’s open APIs.

Geospatial Querying: Processes and returns data in GeoJSON format for dynamic map rendering and heatmap visualization.

Forecast and Guidance Engine: Generates real-time air quality forecasts and health-based recommendations for different regions.

Database Management: Uses Supabase to securely store, query, and update air quality data while maintaining SSL-protected connections.

Health Monitoring: /health and /health/db endpoints ensure server and database connectivity validation.

Automatic API Documentation: Swagger provides interactive endpoints and cURL/Postman-ready examples for testing and development.

Logging and Observability: Pino captures runtime performance and error logs for analysis during deployment and operation.



Technical Summary

The Ox2You backend transforms raw NASA satellite and environmental data into structured, actionable information.

By leveraging Node.js, TypeScript, and PostgreSQL with Supabase, it ensures high-performance data processing, reliable API delivery, and secure communication with the frontend.

Swagger enables clear documentation for developers, while Render’s automated deployments guarantee stability and scalability.

Ultimately, the backend provides the foundation that allows Ox2You to translate complex Earth observation data into real-time, location-based insights — empowering communities to make informed decisions about air quality and environmental health.

OMI SO2 Ingestion Service

This project automates the ingestion of sulfur dioxide (SO2) satellite data from NASA's OMI (Ozone Monitoring Instrument) API into a PostgreSQL database. It downloads, processes, and stores air quality data every hour using an automated scheduler.

Overview

Purpose

This service retrieves SO2 concentration data (in mol/m²) from NASA's EarthData system, extracts relevant information from .he5 files, classifies air quality levels, and stores them in a PostgreSQL table (air_quality_observations).

Main Features

  • Automated hourly data ingestion using a Python scheduler.
  • Secure download via NASA EarthData authentication.
  • Data validation and quality filtering.
  • Scalable PostgreSQL batch insertion.
  • Logging system for monitoring and debugging.

Architecture

High-Level Components

+-----------------------+

|  Scheduler (hourly)   |

|  (schedule library)   |

+----------+------------+

           |

           v

+-----------------------+

|    Data Fetcher       |

| (NASA CMR API client) |

+----------+------------+

           |

           v

+-----------------------+

|   File Downloader     |

| (Authenticated HTTPS) |

+----------+------------+

           |

           v

+-----------------------+

|     HE5 Processor     |

| (h5py + numpy)        |

+----------+------------+

           |

           v

+-----------------------+

|  PostgreSQL Inserter  |

| (psycopg2 batch ops)  |

+-----------------------+

Data Flow

  1. Scheduler triggers the process every hour.
  2. Data Fetcher queries NASA's CMR API for OMI SO2 granules from the past 24 hours.
  3. File Downloader retrieves .he5 granule files (skips existing ones).
  4. HE5 Processor extracts latitude, longitude, time, and SO2 concentration.
  5. Air Quality Classifier assigns a qualitative label (good → very_unhealthy).
  6. PostgreSQL Inserter batches and commits all valid rows to the database.

Technologies Used

<colgroup><col><col></colgroup>

Component

Description

Python 3.10+

Main programming language

requests

For NASA API communication and file downloads

h5py / numpy

For reading and manipulating .he5 files

psycopg2

PostgreSQL database connection and batch insertion

python-dotenv

Loads environment variables from .env file

schedule

Lightweight scheduler for periodic task execution

logging

Centralized log management

Project Structure

project_root/

│

├── omi_so2_ingestion.py     # Main script with scheduler and ingestion logic

├── .env                     # Environment configuration file (not committed)

├── omi_so2_ingestion.log    # Log output (auto-generated)

├── README.md                # Documentation (this file)

└── requirements.txt         # Python dependencies

Environment Variables

Define the following variables in a .env file:

EARTHDATA_USERNAME=your_earthdata_username

EARTHDATA_PASSWORD=your_earthdata_password

PG_CONN=postgresql://user:password@host:port/database

DOWNLOAD_FOLDER=/path/to/download/folder

Database Schema

The table air_quality_observations must exist with at least the following columns:

CREATE TABLE air_quality_observations (

    id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,

    source_id TEXT,

    granule_id TEXT,

    location_id TEXT,

    lat DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL,

    lon DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL,

    observed_at TIMESTAMP NOT NULL,

    pollutant TEXT NOT NULL,

    value DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL,

    unit TEXT,

    aqi INTEGER,

    quality_level TEXT,

    attrs JSONB

);

Future Improvements

  • Extend the platform to handle additional pollutants such as CO₂, NO₂, and PM2.5.

projectDetails.name: The of blacks Forun. From the space for your PC
projectDetails.summary: Our project, the of blacks Hub, is a collaborative web forum for space exploration enthusiasts, students, and engineering professionals to share and discuss their space habitat designs.It addresses the challenge by creating a centralized community platform where users can post their own habitat concepts, complete with summaries, key features, and design constraints. The forum allows for peer review and feedback, enabling an iterative and collaborative design process. Members can browse diverse projects, draw inspiration from different approaches to mission scenarios (like Lunar bases or Mars colonies), and engage in discussions that refine their own ideas.This is important because it shifts space habitat design from an isolated exercise to a community-driven effort. The Hub fosters a creative and educational environment, helping to crowdsource innovative solutions and inspire the next generation of space architects by making their work visible and interactive.
projectDetails.details:
Project Details: Habitat Design Hub

What does it do or how does it work?

The Habitat Design Hub is a web-based community forum designed for sharing, discussing, and iterating on space habitat layouts. It functions as a centralized gallery and collaborative workspace for enthusiasts, students, and professionals in the space exploration field.

How it Works:

  1. Discover: Upon visiting the site, users are greeted with a main feed showcasing a variety of habitat design projects. These are presented in a visually engaging card format, each displaying the project's title, creator, and key tags (e.g., "Mars," "Lunar," "Student Project," "Deep Space").
    • Project Title: A catchy name for their habitat.
    • Summary: A 50-200 word overview explaining the concept.
    • Detailed Description: An in-depth look at features, mission parameters (crew size, duration, destination), and design choices.
    • Images/Renders: An option to upload visual aids for their design.
    • Tags: Keywords to categorize their project for easy filtering and searching.
  2. Engage and Collaborate: Users can click on any project to view its dedicated page. Here, they can read the full details and participate in a discussion through a comment section. They can ask questions, offer constructive criticism, suggest improvements, or simply show appreciation with an upvote/like system. This feedback loop is central to the platform's collaborative nature.

What benefits does it have?

  • Centralized Knowledge Base: It consolidates scattered ideas from various platforms into a single, focused hub, creating a rich, searchable database of habitat concepts.
  • Community Feedback and Iteration: Designers receive valuable feedback from a diverse audience, helping them refine and improve their concepts in ways they might not have considered alone.
  • Educational Tool: It serves as a practical, engaging resource for students learning about engineering, design, and space exploration. They can see theoretical concepts applied in creative ways by a global community.
  • Inspiration and Networking: The platform connects like-minded individuals, fostering a community that can inspire new ideas and potential collaborations.

What is the intended impact of the project?

The intended impact is to democratize space architecture. We want to lower the barrier to entry for contributing ideas to our future in space. By creating an accessible and collaborative environment, the project aims to:

  • Inspire the Next Generation: Motivate students and hobbyists to pursue STEM fields by giving them a platform to showcase their creativity and engage with professionals.
  • Accelerate Innovation: Crowdsource a wide range of solutions to complex challenges in habitat design, potentially sparking novel ideas that influence real-world missions.
  • Build a Global Community: Foster a vibrant, supportive community passionate about humanity's multi-planetary future, united by the shared goal of designing our home in space.

What tools, coding languages, hardware, or software did you use?

The project is a web application developed with the following technologies:

  • Frontend:
    • Languages: HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript
    • The platform is hardware-agnostic. As a web application, it is accessible on any device with a modern web browser, including desktops, laptops, tablets, and smartphones. No specialized hardware is required.

How is your project creative?

The project's creativity lies in its social and thematic approach to a technical challenge.

  1. Niche Community Focus: Instead of a generic design tool, we created a specialized social platform. This transforms the solitary act of design into a collaborative, community-driven experience.
  2. Immersive User Interface: The UI/UX is intentionally designed to be futuristic and space-themed. Elements like the "glassmorphism" card style, dark-mode aesthetic, and specialized fonts create an immersive experience that makes users feel like they are part of a forward-thinking, space-age community.
  3. Bridging Disciplines: The Hub creatively merges the technical field of aerospace engineering with creative design, community management, and education, making a complex subject engaging and accessible to a much broader audience.

What factors did your team consider?

  • User Experience (UX): Our primary consideration was making the platform intuitive and easy to use. The process of posting a project and giving feedback needed to be seamless to encourage participation.
  • Accessibility: We aimed for a clean design with readable fonts and a responsive layout that works flawlessly across all devices, ensuring anyone can access the hub from anywhere.
  • Scalability: The technological foundation (Firebase) was chosen to ensure the platform could grow from a small community to a large, active one without performance issues.
  • Positive Community Culture: We considered the need for moderation tools and clear community guidelines from the outset to ensure discussions remain constructive, respectful, and focused on creative problem-solving.
  • Engagement: We included features like upvotes, comments, and tags specifically to drive user engagement and make the platform a dynamic and exciting place to visit regularly.

Space habitat concepts can involve a diverse array of materials, geometries, and layouts. Your challenge is to create a visual tool that enables users to define a space habitat’s shape/volume and explore possible layout options. (Exploration Systems Development Mission Directorate)

projectDetails.name: Project The solar sisters
projectDetails.summary:
A equipe “solar sisters” foi formada com o intúito de explorar o programa da Nasa space apps.
Descobrimos sobre o projeto por meio de nossa escola e decidimos formar uma pequena equipe familiar, incluíndo as duas irmâs da família e o pai como responsável.
projectDetails.details:
Escolhemos o desafio chamado “Stellar Stories: Space Weather Through the Eyes of Earthlings” que pede para fazer uma história para crianças explicando o clima espacial.

É uma história curta, sobre uma criança chamada Sarah, que, durante um dia quente, pergunta para sua mãe sobre o sol. A mãe de Sarah trabalha no Nasa, e tenta explicar para a filha suas perguntas.

challengeDetails.title: Stellar Stories: Space Weather Through the Eyes of Earthlings
challengeDetails.excerpt: Although the Sun is 93 million miles away from our planet, solar activity can significantly impact our daily lives. “Space weather”—the variations that occur in the space environment between the Sun and Earth—can impact technologies in space and on Earth. Your challenge is to write and illustrate a digital children’s story that explains what space weather is and the varying impacts it has on different people such as farmers, pilots, astronauts, power grid operators, and the general public. You can tell the story from the perspective of a person impacted by space weather or from the point of view of a solar flare or coronal mass ejection (CME) as it approaches Earth. (Heliophysics Division)

projectDetails.name: Pale Blue Dot: The Legacy of the Ocean
projectDetails.summary:
Team Titan presents “Blue Point: The Legacy of the Ocean”, an immersive Virtual Reality (VR) experience that transforms raw NASA ocean data into a captivating visual and sound narrative.

Our project addresses the challenge “Deep Dive: Immersive Data Stories from Ocean to Sky” by placing the user in the role of a space explorer whose spacecraft encounters Earth as a potential new home. Through an interactive analysis system, the VR experience takes the user on a journey from space to the ocean depths, highlighting the complex relationship between oceans.
projectDetails.details:
The Pale Blue Dot Project is an immersive Virtual Reality (VR) experience that transforms official NASA scientific data on Earth's oceans into an interactive narrative. The user takes on the role of a space traveler from a distant galaxy on a mission to find habitable planets, eventually discovering Earth. This allows for a deep and immersive exploration of ecological processes, oceanography, and environmental changes over time.

Benefits and Impact:

  • It allows for the visual and sensory understanding of the human impact on oceans and the biosphere.
  • It raises awareness about environmental degradation and ecological imbalances, bridging science and environmental education.
  • It provides a unique VR learning and engagement experience, exploring complex data in an intuitive and interactive way.

Tools, Languages, and Hardware/Software Used:

  • Unity and C# for VR environment development and interactions.
  • Deep Voice (Unity plug-in) for the narration by the AI copilot AURA.
  • Blender 3D, 3Ds Max, and Autodesk Inventor for object and hologram modeling and animation.
  • Meta Quest 2 as the immersion hardware.
  • Audacity for audio editing and cleaning.
  • Python Web Scraping to collect public NASA data.
  • AI tools such as ChatGPT and Gemini for narrative support, analysis, and dynamic storytelling.
  • Panoply for geospatial data time series and visualization.

Creativity and Key Considerations:

  • It combines real science, narrative, and interactivity in VR, allowing the user to experience a space exploration journey.
  • It's designed to be intuitive, educational, and aesthetically immersive, ensuring the data is understandable and impactful.
  • The team considered narrative design, scientific accuracy, visual and auditory immersion, data interactivity, and the user's emotional engagement.
projectDetails.aiReferences: Artificial Intelligence (AI) was utilized as an integral tool and development accelerator across multiple phases of our project. The GPT-5 model was employed to assist in the optimization and structuring of the C# code for logic and objects within Unity. It also proved essential in the creative phase, being used to structure the narrative, integrate scientific data cohesively into the storyline, and refine the dialogues of the robot Aura. Concurrently, the Gemini 2.5 Pro model provided crucial assistance in data analysis and web scraping, helping to debug the Python script and diagnose time range issues for datasets such as ICEC, CDHW, CO2F, SURF, and WOAQ, thereby ensuring accuracy in the historical data collection. Finally, for the generation of all audio containing Aura’s speech, we exclusively used the Deep Voice (Text-to-Speech) Unity plugin, as required by the guidelines. In summary, the strategic use of AI allowed the team to maximize the originality and execution of the core concept, dramatically optimizing the time spent on technical development and content production.

challengeDetails.title: Deep Dive: Immersive Data Stories from Ocean to Sky
challengeDetails.excerpt: Satellite observations reveal insights about our dynamic home planet to scientists, but people without a remote sensing background often find the stories within these datasets difficult to access. NASA’s open data policy makes these observations available to everyone—scientists and non-scientists alike. Your challenge is to build a short, immersive, virtual reality (VR) experience that leverages NASA’s Earth observation datasets and visualizations to bring stories about our planet’s oceans to life, connecting a broad audience to this data, its beauty, and its impact. Using visuals, spatial audio, and even interactive elements, your VR experience can enable users to dive deeper into Earth’s unfolding ocean story. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: SabIA
projectDetails.summary:
SabIA is a web and mobile application that transforms meteorological information into a visual, educational, and entertaining experience.

The idea is simple: an intelligent thrush bird reacts to real-time weather conditions, changing its appearance and behavior according to the detected climate.

More than just displaying numerical data, SabIA helps the user understand what the weather really means whether the day is too hot, too cold, too humid, or simply uncomfortable.

SabIA aims to bring convenience to the hectic urban life as well as to the cyclical life in the countryside. In large cities, even a small change in the weather can delay traffic, cause flooding, and disrupt outdoor events. In rural areas, however, the weather governs the entire production cycle it is crucial to know in advance when the rainy season will begin in order to plan the best time to plant and harvest, as well as to organize the logistics of purchasing seeds and transporting the crops.
projectDetails.details:
SabIA is an intelligent system powered by a machine learning model capable of predicting the weather for a future date based on the temporal data used during training.

Our system can be divided into three layers:

  • The first layer is the user layer, a front end developed as a one-page application/PWA entirely built with JavaScript, HTML, and CSS. This layer presents a dashboard displaying meteorological data for the selected date, along with our mascot offering tips on what to do under those weather conditions. Additionally, an AI-powered chatbot is available to provide more detailed information about the weather.
  • The second layer is the API layer, written in Python using the FastAPI framework. It exposes endpoints that are consumed by the front end to build its dashboards.
  • The third and final layer is an AI model trained on meteorological data provided by NASA. We adopted a pre-trained XGBoost model specialized in sequential data through the refinement of decision trees. This layer includes specific models for short-term and long-term forecasts.

The project introduces a new approach to handling meteorological data by using AI specialized in sequential data, such as time series of temperature (maximum and minimum) and wind speed. The main goal is to improve long-term prediction accuracy, which can consequently enhance urban life by making it easier to anticipate floods and heavy rain, as well as rural life by helping plan planting and harvesting schedules.

In addition, a mascot was created to act as a virtual assistant, providing advice on how to respond to different weather conditions offering a more empathetic and engaging way to present weather forecasts.

A preview can be found here.
projectDetails.aiReferences: Google Gemini was used to generate the mascot’s images and GIFs, ChatGPT was used to assist with content translation, and CursorAI was used for building the front end and making adjustments to the back end. Heygen was used to create a presentation video.

challengeDetails.title: Will It Rain On My Parade?
challengeDetails.excerpt: If you’re planning an outdoor event—like a vacation, a hike on a trail, or fishing on a lake—it would be good to know the chances of adverse weather for the time and location you are considering. There are many types of Earth observation data that can provide information on weather conditions for a particular location and day of the year. Your challenge is to construct an app with a personalized interface that enables users to conduct a customized query to tell them the likelihood of “very hot,” “very cold,” “very windy,” “very wet,” or “very uncomfortable” conditions for the location and time they specify. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Evaporative Cooling Efficiency Index
projectDetails.summary: We developed the Evaporative Cooling Efficiency Index (EECI), an innovative metric that uses Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) data to assess the actual capacity of urban green infrastructure to combat Urban Heat Islands (UHI). The EECI combines vegetation structure and soil moisture, overcoming the limitations of optical satellites by providing a deeper analysis of the functionality of green areas. It addresses the UHI challenge by precisely identifying where new investments in green infrastructure are needed and how to optimize existing areas. Its importance lies in empowering urban planners with actionable data to create more resilient cities, efficiently allocate resources, and promote sustainable, cooler urban development.
projectDetails.details:
Project Details: EECI - Turatteam | NASA Space Apps Challenge 2025

The EECI (Evaporative Cooling Efficiency Index) project, developed by Turatteam for the NASA Space Apps Challenge 2025, aims to evaluate the efficiency of urban green infrastructure in combating Urban Heat Islands (UHI) using Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) data.

What does it do or how does it work?

The EECI is an innovative index that combines vegetation structure and soil moisture to measure the evaporative cooling efficiency of green areas. It works through a process of SAR data analysis (Sentinel-1 VV and VH polarizations) collected via Google Earth Engine and Copernicus. The methodology involves:

  1. Data Acquisition: Collection of Sentinel-1 GRD (Ground Range Detected) SAR data with VV and VH polarizations for the São Paulo, Brazil area, from January to June 2024.
  2. SAR Processing: Calculation of the Radar Vegetation Index (RVI), which indicates the 3D structural complexity of vegetation (RVI = q[(q+3) / (q+1)²] where q = VH/VV), and a Moisture Index based on VV polarization, sensitive to the surface dielectric constant (Moisture = VV × -1 - 5 / 15).
  3. EECI Calculation: The EECI is obtained by multiplying the Moisture Index by the Structure Index (EECI = Moisture × Structure). Only areas scoring high in both factors receive a high EECI, indicating high evaporative cooling efficiency. Smooth asphalt surfaces, which strongly reflect SAR signals, are excluded from the analysis through land cover masks to ensure accuracy.

What are the benefits?

The main benefits of the project include:

  • Identification of Critical Areas: Allows for the identification of urban areas with low or no cooling efficiency, indicating where the city needs to invest in new green infrastructure.
  • Optimization of Existing Areas: Reveals forested regions with low cooling efficiency, suggesting interventions such as soil irrigation to maximize their potential.
  • Combating Urban Heat Islands: Provides concrete data for urban planning, assisting in the creation of more resilient and comfortable cities, especially in the face of climate change.
  • Detailed Information: Unlike traditional optical satellites, the EECI evaluates the health and functionality of vegetation, not just its presence.

What is the intended impact of the project?

The intended impact of the project is to provide a robust and data-driven tool to inform and optimize urban planning, specifically regarding green infrastructure. By quantifying cooling efficiency, the project aims to empower decision-makers to:

  • Allocate resources more effectively for the creation and maintenance of green areas.
  • Mitigate the effects of Urban Heat Islands, improving citizens' quality of life.
  • Promote sustainable urban development, ensuring that green infrastructure solutions are truly effective.

What tools, programming languages, hardware, or software did you use to develop your project?

Based on the website's information, the main tools and technologies used were:

  • Processing Platform: Google Earth Engine.
  • SAR Data: Copernicus Sentinel-1.
  • Land Cover Data: ESA WorldCover 2020.
  • Programming Language: JavaScript (for the Google Earth Engine code).
  • Frontend: React, Vite (for the build), Tailwind CSS (for styling), Radix UI (components), among other JavaScript libraries for the user interface.

How creative is your project?

The project's creativity lies in its innovative approach to quantifying evaporative cooling efficiency. Instead of simply mapping the presence of vegetation, the EECI integrates multiple factors (vegetation structure and soil moisture) from SAR data, which are less susceptible to atmospheric conditions than optical data. The combination of these indices to create a cooling efficiency metric is a key differentiator, allowing for more precise and actionable analysis for urban planning. The use of Google Earth Engine for lar
projectDetails.aiReferences:
In the development of the EECI project, Artificial Intelligence (AI) was used as a support tool to accelerate innovation and creativity, in accordance with the guidelines of the NASA Space Apps Challenge. Specifically, AI was employed for:

  • Slide Production: AI tools were used to assist in the generation and organization of visual and textual content for presentation slides, optimizing the design process and communication of project ideas.
  • Project Architecture: AI was also consulted to assist in the conception and refinement of the overall project architecture, helping to efficiently structure the different components and workflows.

It is important to note that AI was not used in the main analysis code of the project, which involves the calculation of the EECI and the processing of SAR data. This critical part of the project was developed manually by the team, ensuring the originality and deep understanding of the applied scientific methodology.

challengeDetails.title: Through the Radar Looking Glass: Revealing Earth Processes with SAR
challengeDetails.excerpt: Like Alice in Wonderland, let’s travel down the rabbit hole to reveal a world that looks like our planet Earth… but not quite! Using synthetic aperture radar (SAR), we can image the world by emitting radar pulses toward Earth and recording the energy that is reflected back after the signals interact with Earth's surface. Your challenge is to download multi-frequency or multi-polarization SAR data for an interesting study area of your choice –e.g., your hometown, a tropical wetland, ice sheet, forest wildfire, flooded neighborhood, volcano eruption, etc.—and use that data to develop hypotheses about the physical drivers operating there. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: UrbanMinds - Sustainable Urban Planning
projectDetails.summary: We created a website that recommends the best sustainable urban development methods for the user’s selected location. The platform focuses on enhancing residents’ quality of life while supporting a fast and sustainable city growth. It is important because sustainable urban development is one of the most pressing issues today, since most urban areas worldwide lack an ecologically sound growth, which is vital for improving people's quality of life and other essential aspects.
projectDetails.details:
We created a website that features a map integrating NASA Earth Science data to recommend the best sustainable urban development methods for the user’s selected location (currently limited to a few cities). The platform focuses on enhancing residents’ quality of life while supporting fast and sustainable city growth. We intend to bring benefits in people's quality of life and urbanization, since it can help with useful information about pollution, helping the development of cities without destroying nature. Used softwares and tools: NASA Worldview, NASA GIBS (Global Imagery Browse Services), OpenStreetMap, Web Map Service (WMS), Canva, Visual Studio Code, Google Docs, Vercel. Used coding languages:JavaScript, HTML, CSS and Python, and Artificial Intelligences were used to assist the coding. Our project is innovative as it provides practical and dynamic solutions, addressing complex issues related to urban infrastructure. This approach enables citizens to actively participate in identifying problems and to request that the appropriate authorities implement effective solutions.

The interactive map, in conjunction with our artificial intelligence, Aurora, facilitates interaction between citizens and the city. This is an interactive website focused on solving social issues, where users can influence local challenges, while solutions are generated by a proprietary artificial intelligence system.

Our team primarily focused on practicality in problem-solving, as well as on the ease of use and integration of user-provided information into the interactive map. Our starting point was the need to establish a connection between governmental action and individual engagement, with the goal of building more structured and sustainable urban spaces.

How it works (detailed):

Our web application loads an index.html code containing our front-end with a brief summary of our project and our two main tools of the project.

The first tool is an interactive map built using NDVI (Normalized Difference Vegetation Index) data obtained from NASA's MODIS_Terra_NDVI_8Day layer, which is accessed through GIBS. This data is integrated into our interactive map using Leaflet, a JavaScript library, allowing us to visually represent vegetation index across major urban centers around the globe. The map includes markers that provide detailed and interesting information a few locations, presenting informative insights about vegetation levels, temperature variations, and air pollution metrics.

Our second tool is an artificial intelligence, that we called Aurora, implemented with the Grok API, using the Llama3.3 model with a defined personality. This AI receives a location and a local urban-nature problem from the user, processes them, and generates a possible solution that is then displayed to the user, aiming to offer practical recommendations to resolve it.
projectDetails.aiReferences: We used AIs for various purposes, including research, writing improvement, creation of our AI logo, generating our images used in our project, and to assist our AI coding and website coding (Gemini, Grok, and ChatGPT).

challengeDetails.title: Data Pathways to Healthy Cities and Human Settlements
challengeDetails.excerpt: Climate change brings about new complexities to consider for maintaining the wellbeing of society and the environment in cities. Natural resources, ecosystems, and existing infrastructure all must be monitored to ensure human quality of life remains high. Your challenge is to demonstrate how an urban planner can use NASA Earth observation data to develop smart strategies for city growth that maintain both the wellbeing of people and the environment. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Urbmind - Intelligence for resilient cities
projectDetails.summary:
Climate change poses growing challenges for cities.
It affects urban infrastructure... and people's very quality of life.
To address this scenario, we developed a solution focused on Uberlândia, Minas Gerais, that combines data provided by NASA to predict natural disasters in real time.
Our system not only identifies flood and climate catastrophe risks, but also generates safe escape routes and sends automatic notifications to authorities—Fire Departments, Civil Defense, City Hall, and Military Police.
This project takes an innovative approach, combining climate change analyses provided by NASA itself, soil permeability and relief maps, and predictive analytics to suggest escape routes to avoid potential natural damage.
Although initially implemented in Uberlândia, the solution is scalable, allowing its expansion to other cities and regions facing similar climate challenges.
The result is clear: we reduce human and material losses, preserve the environment, and promote sustainable urban growth.
It's technology that saves lives today... and builds safe cities for the future.
projectDetails.details:
Aqui está uma versão estruturada, pronta para você adicionar fotos no final de cada tópico. Mantive a relevância científica, o peso dos impactos e deixei os locais para inserir imagens bem definidos.

Urbmind

Natural events are inevitable and can cause tragedies and enormous losses. With technology, we can predict risks, reduce damage, and transform response into prevention.


Data Acquisition

  • Sentinel-2 Images: RGB, NIR, and SWIR bands with high spatial resolution.
  • SRTM Data: elevation, slope, roughness, and aspect for topographic analysis.
    All data are aligned in the same CRS and grid for pixel-by-pixel analysis

Colored terrain visualization derived from the SRTMGL1 Digital Elevation Model. Each color represents different altitudes, facilitating the interpretation of terrain morphology, valleys, plateaus, and higher elevation areas. This representation provides a detailed view of the landscape, allowing for precise identification of natural drainage patterns, depressions, and areas prone to water accumulation. By highlighting subtle changes in elevation, it supports hydrological analysis, urban planning, and environmental monitoring. Urban planners and engineers can use these visualizations to assess flood risk, optimize infrastructure placement, and design effective stormwater management systems. Additionally, combining this elevation data with other geospatial layers, such as land cover and satellite imagery, enables comprehensive spatial analysis and decision-making for sustainable development and disaster mitigation.

Multispectral Compositions

  • Atmospheric Penetration: highlights urban areas and water bodies.
  • False Color: precise identification of vegetation and plant cover.
  • NDWI: detection of wet areas and water bodies.

Multispectral composition processed from Sentinel-2 L2A imagery with Atmospheric Penetration enhancement, highlighting urban areas, water bodies, and vegetation zones. This technique improves the visibility of elements hidden by dense vegetation, shadows, or atmospheric particles, allowing for a clearer and more accurate interpretation of land cover. By enhancing the contrast between natural and built-up surfaces, it enables detailed land use analysis, identification of impervious surfaces, and detection of potential flood-prone areas. The imagery supports urban planning, environmental monitoring, and infrastructure development by providing actionable insights into how terrain, vegetation, and urbanization interact. Furthermore, when combined with topographic and hydrological data, this multispectral analysis becomes a critical tool for predictive flood modeling, risk assessment, and sustainable city management, ensuring that decision-makers have precise spatial information for proactive interventions.

Elevation Models and Morphometric Analysis

  • Hillshade, Slope, and Aspect: enable visual analysis of topography.
  • Flatness and Smoothness: identify flat or rough terrain.
  • Flow Accumulation Proxy: simulates natural drainage and water accumulation.

Flood History

Geolocated CSV containing latitude, longitude, rainfall intensity, and dates of past events.
Used for risk adjustment in areas near historical events.

Calculation of Hydrological and Urban Indices

  • TWI (Topographic Wetness Index): identifies areas that accumulate water.
  • Imperviousness: combines band brightness and NDWI to map impervious areas.
    Each index is assigned a calibrated weight: TWI and Imperviousness have higher relevance for flood risk.

Dynamic Integration with Rainfall Data

Final flood probability calculated based on:

  • Rainfall intensity (mm/h)
  • Rainfall accumulation (mm)
  • Event duration
  • Proximity to historical events
    Result is a flood risk score calibrated between 0 and 1.

Examples of Calculations and Analyses


Sentinel-2 RGB bands are carefully aligned to the DEM grid, ensuring precise pixel-by-pixel correspondence between optical and topographic data. From these bands, essential indices are calculated: NDWI, highlighting wet areas and water bodies; NDBI, identifying urban and built-up regions; and Impervious, estimating impervious surface presence. These indicators are normalized to standardize their scales and combined with topographic metrics such as TWI (Topographic Wetness Index) and Flow Accumulation, which assess the terrain’s natural tendency to accumulate water and potential drainage flow. Each indicator is weighted based on its physical relevance and impact on flood risk, resulting in a flood susceptibility score that provides a quantitative and spatially detailed view of the most vulnerable areas, supporting urban planning, disaster prevention, and water resource management.

Automation of Data Collection and Storage

Data are constantly updated and stored in real-time on Supabase. N8N automates the collection of weather information from the weather forecast API, recording rainfall, intensity, and duration in the database. This data is available for the back-end to process and calculate the flood probability at each city point, ensuring the front-end displays accurate, up-to-date alerts for users.

Strategic and Societal Impact

The application interface where the user can directly access flood alerts generated by the model. The interactive dashboard displays the city map with highlighted risk zones, colors indicating flood probability, and detailed information on rainfall intensity and duration. Users can explore different areas, view risk statistics, and receive real-time alerts, enabling rapid decision-making and preventive planning.

Benefits

  • Safe Urban Planning: identifies risk areas and guides urban expansion away from vulnerable regions, ensuring that new developments are situated in safer locations and reducing long-term exposure to floods.

Natural Disaster Reduction: helps prevent human and material losses by anticipating flood-prone areas, enabling timely interventions and community preparedness.

Environmental Protection: supports the preservation of riverbanks, green spaces, and fragile ecosystems, maintaining biodiversity and mitigating erosion.

Water Resource Management: facilitates efficient control of floods, dams, canals, and drainage systems, optimizing infrastructure and resource allocation.

Early Warnings: provides real-time information for alerts and evacuations before critical events, enhancing public safety and response effectiveness.

Resilient Infrastructure: allows for the design of buildings, roads, and urban utilities considering actual flood risk, increasing durability and reducing maintenance costs.

Interactive Visualization: users can explore dynamic maps with detailed flood risk information, overlaying multiple datasets for informed decision-making and spatial planning.

Reduced Public Costs: aids in prevention strategies, lowering expenses associated with repairs, emergency responses, and recovery in flood-affected areas.


Urbmind Platform Features

URBMind is an advanced urban analysis platform that predicts flood risks and climate-related hazards in real time, providing strategic support for critical decision-making in safe and sustainable city management.

Key Features

  • Location Search and Personalized Alerts: users can search any address or coordinate and receive instant alerts if there is a flood risk, ensuring rapid response and damage prevention.
  • City-wide Alert Dashboard: clearly displays all active alerts, highlighting risk zones and providing detailed information on intensity, duration, and probability of critical events.
  • Lab Section: allows users to simulate climate and rainfall scenarios by adjusting intensity and duration, evaluating vulnerability in different areas and anticipating potential disasters.
  • Urban Planning Support: provides precise data and analyses to guide urban expansion, infrastructure projects, and construction planning, contributing to resilient and sustainable cities.
  • Interactive Visualization and Real-Time Data: dynamic maps integrating elevation, soil permeability, and flood history data, allowing detailed exploration of high-risk areas.
  • Integration with Meteorological and Historical Data: combines rainfall forecasts, topography, and historical events to generate flood probabilities, enabling effective preventive planning and action.
  • Future Safe Route Support: planned evolution of the platform will provide safe evacuation routes during critical events, integrating risk analysis and topography to guide movement during emergencies.

URBMind is more than an alert tool — it’s a strategic platform that transforms complex data into actionable decisions, reducing human and material losses, protecting the environment, and promoting safe urban development.

Project Documentation and Repositories


All the code developed for this project, including the frontend and backend implementations, is available in the repositories below.
The API documentation is also accessible through Swagger for testing and reference purposes.


Frontend Repository

GitHub: UrbmindNasa Frontend

Backend Repository

GitHub: API-Nasa Backend

API Documentation (Swagger)

Swagger Docs: http://148.230.78.172:8000/docs
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Use of AI for Code Development and Acceleration

During project development, generative Artificial Intelligence tools were integrated into the Visual Studio Code (VS Code) environment, mainly GitHub Copilot and OpenAI Codex.
These AI solutions were used to speed up coding, suggest code in real time, and optimize complex implementations, resulting in a more efficient and accurate workflow.

Tools and Integration

  • GitHub Copilot: Assisted in writing code inside VS Code by suggesting code blocks, completing functions, and improving inline documentation.
    • VS Code Documentation

Main Applications

  • Automation of repetitive coding tasks.
  • Faster prototyping of new solutions.
  • Optimization and refactoring of existing code.
  • Support for technical documentation and code comments.

Results

projectDetails.name: Project VoyIAger
projectDetails.summary:
O Exoplanet Hunter 2025 é um projeto desenvolvido para o NASA Space Apps Challenge, cujo objetivo é detectar e estimar a habitabilidade de exoplanetas usando técnicas de inteligência artificial. A solução utiliza um classificador Random Forest treinado com dados do NASA Exoplanet Archive, com balanceamento de classes via SMOTE, e permite previsões individuais ou em lote. Uma interface interativa em Streamlit exibe métricas como matriz de confusão e importância de features, além de visualizações auxiliares.

Essa abordagem é relevante porque automatiza e escala a análise de grandes volumes de dados astronômicos, ajudando a priorizar candidatos promissores para investigações futuras. Ademais, integra ciência de dados e astrofísica para promover descobertas em exoplanetologia.
projectDetails.details:
O Exoplanet Hunter 2025 é uma aplicação que utiliza aprendizado de máquina para identificar e avaliar a habitabilidade potencial de exoplanetas com base em dados reais do NASA Exoplanet Archive. O sistema emprega um modelo de classificação Random Forest treinado e balanceado com SMOTE, capaz de prever se um planeta pode sustentar condições habitáveis.

O projeto oferece uma interface interativa em Streamlit, onde o usuário pode enviar dados de planetas, visualizar resultados, interpretar métricas de desempenho (como matriz de confusão e importância das features) e compreender o processo preditivo.

Os principais benefícios incluem a automação da triagem de exoplanetas, redução do tempo de análise e apoio a decisões de priorização para estudos futuros. O impacto pretendido é ampliar o alcance da pesquisa astronômica e estimular o uso de IA acessível para exploração científica.

Ferramentas e tecnologias: Python, scikit-learn, pandas, matplotlib, Streamlit, GitHub, Google Colab e Gamma App (para o slide).

A criatividade do projeto está na integração prática de ciência de dados e astrofísica, tornando a detecção de exoplanetas mais intuitiva e educativa. A equipe considerou interpretabilidade, usabilidade, transparência e o uso ético de IA.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Nosso projeto faz uso de ferramentas de IA como ChatGPT (OpenAI GPT-5), Grok e GitHub Copilot para auxiliar na refatoração de código, otimização de lógica e geração de documentação e textos explicativos.
Essas ferramentas não geraram os dados científicos nem o modelo preditivo principal, mas foram usadas para acelerar o desenvolvimento, melhorar a clareza do código e preparar a apresentação.
A Gamma App (também com recursos de IA) foi usada para criar o slide de forma visual e organizada.
Todo conteúdo gerado por IA foi revisado, ajustado e validado pela equipe humana.

node.excerpt: We are Wavehub, a team of friends passionate about technology, innovation, and space exploration. With skills in software development, creativity, and teamwork, we aim to learn, grow, and create impactful solutions at the NASA hackathon.

projectDetails.name: Wave Nimbus
projectDetails.summary:
Problem. Air pollution changes rapidly, and data is fragmented between satellites, ground stations, and meteorology. This delays local forecasts, hinders timely alerts, and reduces the ability of policymakers and citizens to make evidence-based health decisions.

Solution: A professional REST API in Golang for ingesting, processing, and analyzing tropospheric NO₂ from TEMPO (NASA), also integrating global data and meteorology. The Go core (Gin Framework) offers low latency, robust routing, and documentation via Swagger UI; a scientific module in Python performs advanced analysis (NetCDF, statistics, and unit conversions). The pipeline: (1) discovery/ingestion of TEMPO granules; (2) reading of NetCDF files; (3) spatial/temporal slicing; (4) aggregations (mean/percentiles) and normalization; (5) exposing endpoints such as /no2/now, /no2/timeseries, and /no2/forecast. Docker standardizes local and cloud deployment. The hybrid architecture combines the performance of Go with the scientific flexibility of Python, maintaining stable REST contracts.

Impact. The API transforms complex data into actionable information, enabling early warnings and short-term forecasts, reducing the exposure of sensitive populations, and supporting public policies. By offering a scalable and documented backend, it accelerates multidisciplinary teams, increases transparency, and facilitates the creation of dashboards, mobile apps, and integrations with other air quality sources.
projectDetails.details:
What the project does / how it works

A Golang (Gin) REST API that processes tropospheric NO₂ (NASA TEMPO) and integrates ground stations (OpenAQ/AirNow) and meteorology (GFS/HRRR/POWER).

Pipeline: granule discovery → NetCDF reading (Python/xarray module) → QA/masking → spatial/temporal subsetting → statistics (mean/percentiles) → satellite+ground+weather fusion → nowcast/forecast (0–24h) → AQI + alerts.

Endpoints (e.g.): /no2/now, /no2/timeseries, /no2/forecast, all in JSON with metadata (units, source, period).

Benefits

Actionable information in plain language (AQI) for citizens, schools, and policymakers.

Early alerts that reduce exposure during critical episodes.

Single backbone for future dashboards, mobile apps, and research, with low latency and clear documentation.

Intended impact

Public health: safer daily decisions (outdoor activities, commuting, sports).

Environmental management: supports policy, enforcement, and risk communication.

Open science: reproducibility (Parquet/Swagger) and transparent data sourcing.

Tools, languages, and software

Golang (Gin, Swagger/OpenAPI), Python (xarray, netCDF4), Docker, Redis (cache/queues), Postgres/Timescale or DuckDB (time series), PMTiles (map tiles), Prometheus/Grafana (observability).

Creativity (what sets us apart)

Hybrid architecture (Go + Python) combining API performance with scientific flexibility.

Spatiotemporal fusion with transport variables (wind/PBL) to improve “now” and short-term forecasts.

Pluggable design: switch TEMPO (North America) or Sentinel-5P/OMI (global) without changing the API.

Factors considered

Geographic coverage (NA vs global), data latency, quality/QA, scalability (local → cloud), accessibility (AQI, clear health messaging), AI governance, and compliance (no NASA branding usage).

projectDetails.name: Project Solar Bloom
projectDetails.summary: Our project addresses the challenge of making scientific data accessible and understandable in order to transform agriculture into a more sustainable practice. Although advanced technologies such as satellite imagery and climate modeling provided by NASA already exist, there is still a significant barrier of access and comprehension that prevents many farmers and communities from benefiting from this information. This results in negative impacts on productivity, resource conservation, and adaptation to climate change. To tackle this issue, we developed an educational game that uses these open datasets as a foundation to teach agricultural challenges and solutions in an intuitive, visual, and accessible way, even for those without technical knowledge. The gameplay is simple and card-based, where players must make decisions in real-life inspired scenarios such as irrigation, fertilization, or climate variations. This allows players to practically understand how these choices affect production and the environment. The game not only entertains but also democratizes access to scientific knowledge, turning complex data into an interactive experience that connects science and society.
projectDetails.details:
Introduction

Solar Bloom is an educational card game designed to make NASA’s agricultural data accessible, engaging, and easy to understand. In the game, players encounter characters facing real farming challenges, such as irrigation, soil health, or climate impacts, and must select strategy cards, each one representing insights drawn from NASA’s open data, to find the best solution. This gamified approach transforms complex scientific information into interactive play, helping farmers, students, and agricultural enthusiasts learn practical applications for space-based technology. By combining fun gameplay with real-world impact, Solar Bloom promotes sustainable decision-making and raises awareness about how space science supports agriculture on Earth. Our goal is to empower diverse communities to use knowledge from space to cultivate smarter, more sustainable futures.

It's our pleasure to welcome you to Solar Bloom!

Presenting Solar Bloom

The experience starts on this page, where you can select to start the game. The entire interface is designed with pixel art, giving it a nostalgic and charming visual style that makes the experience feel both retro and unique. This artistic choice helps create an inviting atmosphere.

When the game begins, you find yourself in a small wooden room. At that moment, an assistant named Leo shows up, he’s there to guide you, explain what needs to be done, and help you complete the missions step by step. Having an assistant like Leo makes the game easier to understand and more accessible for everyone. It helps new players quickly learn the mechanics, reduces confusion, and allows people of different ages and backgrounds to enjoy the game without feeling lost.

Soon after, people from different countries start appearing, each asking for your help with various tasks, each one related to agricultural problems from their own country.

The player's mission is to select and deliver the card that corresponds to the person's problem in order to solve it. However, the player must be careful, as each letter has its own advantages and disadvantages. Every correct card match propels the story forward, deepening the narrative. Your accuracy unlocks new cards to solve more complex problems and attract new clients from different regions.

Technical Details

In this section, the technical aspects of the project will be presented.

The game was developed in C# using the Godot engine. Godot is a free and open-source game engine known for its flexibility and active community, ideal for creating 2D and 3D games.

All the pixel art for the game was created using Pixilart, a free online platform dedicated to pixel art creation.

Throughout development, a key focus was maintaining simplicity and clarity. To ensure the game is easy to understand, we avoided overly long or confusing dialogues, complex mechanics, and excessive technical or detailed information in the game itself.

Future Improvements

  • Expanded Narrative: Introduce more characters and problems to solve, increasing the game's depth and replayability.
  • Card System : Add new cards with innovative solutions and distinct advantages. This lets you address and solve a wider range of complex problems.
  • Multi-Language Support: Translate the game into several languages, to make it accessible to a global audience.

Conclusion

Solar Bloom delivers an engaging and educational experience by making NASA data accessible through interactive gameplay. It allows players to learn through the intuitive mechanic of matching seeds and techniques to the correct crops and seasons. While there is room for future improvements, the core gameplay successfully creates a rewarding and informative journey into the world of farming.
projectDetails.aiReferences: Throughout the project, we utilized ChatGPT (GPT-5) to enhance the writing quality, assist in logo creation, and support code generation and refinement.

projectDetails.name: Project Solarius
projectDetails.summary:
The objective of this project is to develop an interactive website that encourages children to investigate the intriguing realm of space weather, through a character, called "Solaris", the solar flare. The website helps kids understand how changes in the Sun and Earth can impact our technology and the environment by transforming complicated scientific concepts into something entertaining and simple to understand through interactive simulations and enjoyable activities.


This project makes science interesting and immersive. It illustrates how space weather affects daily life and contemporary technology by combining important concepts from space physics, such as the heliosphere, magnetosphere, and ionosphere. The project is important to prevent communication, navigation, and power system disruptions, educating people about and monitoring these phenomena. It also serves as a reminder of how interconnected we are with events occurring beyond our planet. It's more than just a website, it's a educational resource that stimulates interest, promotes exploration, and teaches youth the importance of space science both here on Earth and elsewhere.
projectDetails.details:
What exactly does it do?

  • Delivers a 25-page interactive story following Solaris, a solar flare character, as it travels from the Sun to Earth, affecting various technologies along the way
  • Features 7 unique characters representing different professions impacted by space weather: ISS astronaut Sofia, tech farmer Pedro, aviation pilot Captain Ana, NOAA scientist Dr. John, power grid operator Maria, and satellite controller Bruno
  • Provides realistic audio experiences based on scientific data, including solar wind frequencies (40-350Hz), authentic ISS alarms, tractor engine sounds, jet turbines, and electrical transformer harmonics
  • Implements an achievement system that rewards exploration and learning progress with badges like "Space Explorer" and "Cosmic Scholar"
  • Teaches real space weather impacts on GPS agriculture, aviation routes, power grids, satellite communications, and International Space Station operations using authentic NASA data
  • Includes interactive navigation with keyboard controls, sound toggles, volume controls, and random page access for personalized exploration

How does it work?

  • Frontend Architecture: Built with HTML (11.2%), CSS (50.1%), and JavaScript (38.7%) using modern web technologies
  • Audio System: Utilizes Web Audio API and ElevenLabs to create scientifically-based sounds including pattern sequences, frequency sweeps, and harmonic generators that simulate real space weather phenomena
  • State Management: JavaScript class-based architecture maintains user progress, visited pages, achievements, and audio preferences across the session
  • Content Delivery: Modular page system with dynamic content loading, scientific data integration, and responsive design for multiple devices
  • Educational Integration: Each page incorporates real NASA data including solar core temperatures (15 million°C), Earth-Sun distance (150 million km), ISS altitude (408 km), and solar wind speeds (300-800 km/s)

What benefits does it have?

  • Makes complex science accessible by transforming technical space weather concepts into relatable character-driven narratives
  • Addresses real-world relevance as solar storms recently caused over $500 million in agricultural damages and disrupted GPS systems used by farmers
  • Aligns with NASA educational priorities supporting Space Weather Centers of Excellence and SWREDI initiatives
  • Promotes STEM education through authentic scientific data while maintaining engaging storytelling elements
  • Builds space weather awareness crucial for our technology-dependent society, especially as solar activity increases during the current solar maximum
  • Supports multilingual learning by presenting NASA content in Portuguese, making it accessible for Brazilian students
  • Demonstrates practical impacts showing how space weather affects GPS farming equipment, aviation safety, power grids, and satellite operations that students encounter daily

What do we hope to achieve?

  • Increase space weather literacy among young learners, preparing them for a future where understanding solar-terrestrial interactions becomes increasingly important
  • Inspire future scientists by showing real-world applications of space science through relatable characters and scenarios
  • Bridge the gap between complex NASA research and public understanding, making space weather as recognizable as terrestrial weather
  • Create lasting educational impact through memorable characters and interactive experiences that make learning space science engaging rather than intimidating
  • Contribute to global space weather awareness supporting NASA's mission to protect technological infrastructure from space weather events
  • Demonstrate effective science communication by combining rigorous scientific accuracy with creative storytelling and modern web technologies

Tools, Languages & Technologies Used:

  • Frontend: HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript (ES6+)
  • Audio Technology: Web Audio API, synthetic sound generation, frequency modulation
  • Scientific Data: NASA Solar Dynamics Observatory data, NOAA Space Weather Prediction Center information
  • Development Tools: Git/GitHub for version control, responsive web design principles
  • Content Management: Modular JavaScript architecture, JSON data structures for story content
  • Accessibility: Keyboard navigation, volume controls, audio toggle functionality
  • Educational Framework: Based on NASA Space Weather Research, Education, Development Initiative (SWREDI) standards

Google Gemini Pro was adopted in the final opinion of the project and in possible improvements to be made.

By administering these AI tools with responsibly and with care, we were able to focus more on creativity and innovation, not to mention accessibility, while ensuring transparency in what purposed AI was applied.

You can tell the story from the perspective of a person impacted by space weather or from the point of view of a solar flare or coronal mass ejection (CME) as it approaches Earth. node.title: Zyra - Inovação Urbana
node.excerpt: Zyra - Inovação Urbana

projectDetails.name: Zyra - Hydrological Risk Index
projectDetails.summary:
Our project, Zyra, is an innovative platform that calculates a Hydrological Risk Index for urban areas. We developed a solution that transforms complex NASA data into visual and actionable insights for urban planning.

It addresses the challenge of decoding spatial data that, while readily available, is often too complex for practical use by urban planners. With a single click, our tool integrates NASA elevation data, local rainfall patterns, and land use data to generate an intuitive heat map that identifies critical flood zones.

This is crucial because millions of families, like the 2.3 million cited in our case study, live in flood risk zones without knowing it. Zyra offers a scalable prevention tool, developed for Belford Roxo, but applicable to any city worldwide, with the ultimate goal of transforming data into saved lives.
projectDetails.details:
What does it do or how does it work?

Our project develops an Urban Hydrological Risk Management Framework that integrates NASA Earth observation data to create a risk index that assists urban planners in developing more effective urban settlements. The system operates through two main layers: (1) Data Collection - using NASA GPM/IMERG precipitation data, SRTM Digital Elevation Models, and Landsat land use data; (2) Risk Classification System - creating a hydrological risk management index based on critical precipitation events, land use mapping, topography, and population vulnerability.

What are its benefits?

The framework offers technical benefits such as improved accuracy through the integration of NASA data, scalability for different urban regions, and standardization of risk assessment. The socio-environmental benefits include reducing the loss of human life through safer urban planning, protection of critical infrastructure, promotion of urban sustainability, and climate resilience adaptation.

What is the intended impact of your project?

The framework aims to provide urban planners with a standardized risk index to guide decisions on locating new urban settlements. The direct impact includes more efficient urban planning that is integrated with municipal master plans. The long-term impact encompasses the development of more sustainable cities, improvement of population well-being, reduction of environmental impacts, and greater climate resilience.

What tools, coding languages, hardware, or software did you use to develop your project?

NASA Data: NASA Earthdata platform, GPM/IMERG API for precipitation data, SRTM Digital Elevation Models, and Landsat Science for land use data. Technologies: Machine learning algorithms for data processing and classification, multi-criteria analysis to create the risk index, and validation with local Brazilian data.

How is your project creative?

The project presents methodological innovation by combining global NASA data with local Brazilian realities, adapting international methodologies for specific Brazilian biomes. The technical creativity lies in the hybridization of NASA satellite data with local terrestrial information and in the application of machine learning adapted to Brazilian tropical precipitation patterns.

What factors did your team consider?

Alignment with the NASA Challenge: Exclusive use of NASA data as a primary source, with a focus on human well-being and environmental sustainability for urban planners. Global Scientific Context: The project is based on international best practices, such as programs from the Netherlands, Japan, Singapore, and the United Kingdom. Local Validation: We considered testing in the city of Belford Roxo - RJ to train the algorithm and cross-reference it with local data. Sustainability: Development of a scalable methodology for national application, with a focus on vulnerable populations and environmental justice in urban planning.

challengeDetails.title: Data Pathways to Healthy Cities and Human Settlements
challengeDetails.excerpt: Climate change brings about new complexities to consider for maintaining the wellbeing of society and the environment in cities. Natural resources, ecosystems, and existing infrastructure all must be monitored to ensure human quality of life remains high. Your challenge is to demonstrate how an urban planner can use NASA Earth observation data to develop smart strategies for city growth that maintain both the wellbeing of people and the environment. (Earth Science Division)
